For Paula, Pavel, and Susanna

Preface
When I wrote the ï¬rst edition in the 1970s my goal was to present the state of
the art of a century old discipline that had recently undergone a revolutionary
transformation. After the book was reprinted in 1997 I started contemplating
a revised edition. It has soon become clear to me that in order to describe
the present day set theory I would have to write a more or less new book.
As a result this edition diï¬€ers substantially from the 1978 book. The major
diï¬€erence is that the three major areas (forcing, large cardinals and descrip-
tive set theory) are no longer treated as separate subjects. The progress in
past quarter century has blurred the distinction between these areas: forcing
has become an indispensable tool of every set theorist, while descriptive set
theory has practically evolved into the study of L(R) under large cardinal
assumptions. Moreover, the theory of inner models has emerged as a major
part of the large cardinal theory.
The book has three parts. The ï¬rst part contains material that every
student of set theory should learn and all results contain a detailed proof. In
the second part I present the topics and techniques that I believe every set
theorist should master; most proofs are included, even if some are sketchy.
For the third part I selected various results that in my opinion reï¬‚ect the
state of the art of set theory at the turn of the millennium.
I wish to express my gratitude to the following institutions that made
their facilities available to me while I was writing the book: Mathematical
Institute of the Czech Academy of Sciences, The Center for Theoretical Study
in Prague, CRM in Barcelona, and the Rockefeller Foundationâ€™s Bellagio Cen-
ter. I am also grateful to numerous set theorists who I consulted on various
subjects, and particularly to those who made invaluable comments on prelim-
inary versions of the manuscript. My special thanks are to Miroslav RepickÂ´y
who converted the handwritten manuscript to LATEX. He also compiled the
three indexes that the reader will ï¬nd extremely helpful.
Finally, and above all, I would like to thank my wife for her patience and
encouragement during the writing of this book.
Prague, May 2002
Thomas Jech

Part I
Basic Set Theory

1. Axioms of Set Theory
Axioms of Zermelo-Fraenkel
1.1. Axiom of Extensionality. If X and Y have the same elements, then
X = Y .
1.2. Axiom of Pairing. For any a and b there exists a set {a, b} that
contains exactly a and b.
1.3. Axiom Schema of Separation. If P is a property (with parameter p),
then for any X and p there exists a set Y = {u âˆˆX : P(u, p)} that contains
all those u âˆˆX that have property P.
1.4. Axiom of Union. For any X there exists a set Y =  X, the union
of all elements of X.
1.5. Axiom of Power Set. For any X there exists a set Y = P(X), the
set of all subsets of X.
1.6. Axiom of Inï¬nity. There exists an inï¬nite set.
1.7. Axiom Schema of Replacement. If a class F is a function, then for
any X there exists a set Y = F(X) = {F(x) : x âˆˆX}.
1.8. Axiom of Regularity. Every nonempty set has an âˆˆ-minimal element.
1.9. Axiom of Choice. Every family of nonempty sets has a choice func-
tion.
The theory with axioms 1.1â€“1.8 is the Zermelo-Fraenkel axiomatic set
theory ZF; ZFC denotes the theory ZF with the Axiom of Choice.
Why Axiomatic Set Theory?
Intuitively, a set is a collection of all elements that satisfy a certain given
property. In other words, we might be tempted to postulate the following
rule of formation for sets.

4
Part I. Basic Set Theory
1.10. Axiom Schema of Comprehension (false). If P is a property,
then there exists a set Y = {x : P(x)}.
This principle, however, is false:
1.11. Russellâ€™s Paradox. Consider the set S whose elements are all those
(and only those) sets that are not members of themselves: S = {X : X /âˆˆX}.
Question: Does S belong to S? If S belongs to S, then S is not a member of
itself, and so S /âˆˆS. On the other hand, if S /âˆˆS, then S belongs to S. In
either case, we have a contradiction.
Thus we must conclude that
{X : X /âˆˆX}
is not a set, and we must revise the intuitive notion of a set.
The safe way to eliminate paradoxes of this type is to abandon the Schema
of Comprehension and keep its weak version, the Schema of Separation:
If P is a property, then for any X there exists a set Y = {x âˆˆX : P(x)}.
Once we give up the full Comprehension Schema, Russellâ€™s Paradox is no
longer a threat; moreover, it provides this useful information: The set of all
sets does not exist. (Otherwise, apply the Separation Schema to the property
x /âˆˆx.)
In other words, it is the concept of the set of all sets that is paradoxical,
not the idea of comprehension itself.
Replacing full Comprehension by Separation presents us with a new prob-
lem. The Separation Axioms are too weak to develop set theory with its
usual operations and constructions. Notably, these axioms are not suï¬ƒcient
to prove that, e.g., the union X âˆªY of two sets exists, or to deï¬ne the notion
of a real number.
Thus we have to add further construction principles that postulate the
existence of sets obtained from other sets by means of certain operations.
The axioms of ZFC are generally accepted as a correct formalization of
those principles that mathematicians apply when dealing with sets.
Language of Set Theory, Formulas
The Axiom Schema of Separation as formulated above uses the vague notion
of a property. To give the axioms a precise form, we develop axiomatic set
theory in the framework of the ï¬rst order predicate calculus. Apart from
the equality predicate =, the language of set theory consists of the binary
predicate âˆˆ, the membership relation.

1. Axioms of Set Theory
5
The formulas of set theory are built up from the atomic formulas
x âˆˆy,
x = y
by means of connectives
Ï• âˆ§Ïˆ,
Ï• âˆ¨Ïˆ,
Â¬Ï•,
Ï• â†’Ïˆ,
Ï• â†”Ïˆ
(conjunction, disjunction, negation, implication, equivalence), and quantiï¬ers
âˆ€x Ï•,
âˆƒx Ï•.
In practice, we shall use in formulas other symbols, namely deï¬ned pred-
icates, operations, and constants, and even use formulas informally; but it
will be tacitly understood that each such formula can be written in a form
that only involves âˆˆand = as nonlogical symbols.
Concerning formulas with free variables, we adopt the notational conven-
tion that all free variables of a formula
Ï•(u1, . . . , un)
are among u1, . . . , un (possibly some ui are not free, or even do not occur,
in Ï•). A formula without free variables is called a sentence.
Classes
Although we work in ZFC which, unlike alternative axiomatic set theories,
has only one type of object, namely sets, we introduce the informal notion
of a class. We do this for practical reasons: It is easier to manipulate classes
than formulas.
If Ï•(x, p1, . . . , pn) is a formula, we call
C = {x : Ï•(x, p1, . . . , pn)}
a class. Members of the class C are all those sets x that satisfy Ï•(x, p1, . . . , pn):
x âˆˆC
if and only if
Ï•(x, p1, . . . , pn).
We say that C is deï¬nable from p1, . . . , pn; if Ï•(x) has no parameters pi
then the class C is deï¬nable.
Two classes are considered equal if they have the same elements: If
C = {x : Ï•(x, p1, . . . , pn)},
D = {x : Ïˆ(x, q1, . . . , qm)},
then C = D if and only if for all x
Ï•(x, p1, . . . , pn) â†”Ïˆ(x, q1, . . . , qm).

6
Part I. Basic Set Theory
The universal class, or universe, is the class of all sets:
V = {x : x = x}.
We deï¬ne inclusion of classes (C is a subclass of D)
C âŠ‚D if and only if for all x, x âˆˆC implies x âˆˆD,
and the following operations on classes:
C âˆ©D = {x : x âˆˆC and x âˆˆD},
C âˆªD = {x : x âˆˆC or x âˆˆD},
C âˆ’D = {x : x âˆˆC and x /âˆˆD},
 C = {x : x âˆˆS for some S âˆˆC} = {S : S âˆˆC}.
Every set can be considered a class. If S is a set, consider the formula x âˆˆS
and the class
{x : x âˆˆS}.
That the set S is uniquely determined by its elements follows from the Axiom
of Extensionality.
A class that is not a set is a proper class.
Extensionality
If X and Y have the same elements, then X = Y :
âˆ€u (u âˆˆX â†”u âˆˆY ) â†’X = Y.
The converse, namely, if X = Y then u âˆˆX â†”u âˆˆY , is an axiom of
predicate calculus. Thus we have
X = Y
if and only if
âˆ€u (u âˆˆX â†”u âˆˆY ).
The axiom expresses the basic idea of a set: A set is determined by its ele-
ments.
Pairing
For any a and b there exists a set {a, b} that contains exactly a and b:
âˆ€a âˆ€b âˆƒc âˆ€x (x âˆˆc â†”x = a âˆ¨x = b).

1. Axioms of Set Theory
7
By Extensionality, the set c is unique, and we can deï¬ne the pair
{a, b} = the unique c such that âˆ€x (x âˆˆc â†”x = a âˆ¨x = b).
The singleton {a} is the set
{a} = {a, a}.
Since {a, b} = {b, a}, we further deï¬ne an ordered pair
(a, b)
so as to satisfy the following condition:
(1.1)
(a, b) = (c, d) if and only if a = c and b = d.
For the formal deï¬nition of an ordered pair, we take
(a, b) = {{a}, {a, b}}.
We leave the veriï¬cation of (1.1) to the reader (Exercise 1.1).
We further deï¬ne ordered triples, quadruples, etc., as follows:
(a, b, c) = ((a, b), c),
(a, b, c, d) = ((a, b, c), d),
...
(a1, . . . , an+1) = ((a1, . . . , an), an+1).
It follows that two ordered n-tuples (a1, . . . , an) and (b1, . . . , bn) are equal if
and only if a1 = b1, . . . , an = bn.
Separation Schema
Let Ï•(u, p) be a formula. For any X and p, there exists a set Y = {u âˆˆX :
Ï•(u, p)}:
(1.2)
âˆ€X âˆ€p âˆƒY âˆ€u (u âˆˆY â†”u âˆˆX âˆ§Ï•(u, p)).
For each formula Ï•(u, p), the formula (1.2) is an Axiom (of Separation).
The set Y in (1.2) is unique by Extensionality.
Note that a more general version of Separation Axioms can be proved
using ordered n-tuples: Let Ïˆ(u, p1, . . . , pn) be a formula. Then
(1.3)
âˆ€X âˆ€p1 . . . âˆ€pn âˆƒY âˆ€u (u âˆˆY â†”u âˆˆX âˆ§Ïˆ(u, p1, . . . , pn)).

8
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Simply let Ï•(u, p) be the formula
âˆƒp1, . . . âˆƒpn (p = (p1, . . . , pn) and Ïˆ(u, p1, . . . , pn))
and then, given X and p1, . . . , pn, let
Y = {u âˆˆX : Ï•(u, (p1, . . . , pn))}.
We can give the Separation Axioms the following form: Consider the class
C = {u : Ï•(u, p1, . . . , pn)}; then by (1.3)
âˆ€X âˆƒY (C âˆ©X = Y ).
Thus the intersection of a class C with any set is a set; or, we can say even
more informally
a subclass of a set is a set.
One consequence of the Separation Axioms is that the intersection and the
diï¬€erence of two sets is a set, and so we can deï¬ne the operations
X âˆ©Y = {u âˆˆX : u âˆˆY }
and
X âˆ’Y = {u âˆˆX : u /âˆˆY }.
Similarly, it follows that the empty class
âˆ…= {u : u Ì¸= u}
is a setâ€”the empty set; this, of course, only under the assumption that at
least one set X exists (because âˆ…âŠ‚X):
(1.4)
âˆƒX (X = X).
We have not included (1.4) among the axioms, because it follows from the
Axiom of Inï¬nity.
Two sets X, Y are called disjoint if X âˆ©Y = âˆ….
If C is a nonempty class of sets, we let
 C = {X : X âˆˆC} = {u : u âˆˆX for every X âˆˆC}.
Note that  C is a set (it is a subset of any X âˆˆC). Also, X âˆ©Y = {X, Y }.
Another consequence of the Separation Axioms is that the universal
class V is a proper class; otherwise,
S = {x âˆˆV : x /âˆˆx}
would be a set.

1. Axioms of Set Theory
9
Union
For any X there exists a set Y =  X:
(1.5)
âˆ€X âˆƒY âˆ€u (u âˆˆY â†”âˆƒz (z âˆˆX âˆ§u âˆˆz)).
Let us introduce the abbreviations
(âˆƒz âˆˆX) Ï•
for
âˆƒz (z âˆˆX âˆ§Ï•),
and
(âˆ€z âˆˆX) Ï•
for
âˆ€z (z âˆˆX â†’Ï•).
By (1.5), for every X there is a unique set
Y = {u : (âˆƒz âˆˆX) u âˆˆz} = {z : z âˆˆX} =  X,
the union of X.
Now we can deï¬ne
X âˆªY = {X, Y },
X âˆªY âˆªZ = (X âˆªY ) âˆªZ,
etc.,
and also
{a, b, c} = {a, b} âˆª{c},
and in general
{a1, . . . , an} = {a1} âˆª. . . âˆª{an}.
We also let
X â–³Y = (X âˆ’Y ) âˆª(Y âˆ’X),
the symmetric diï¬€erence of X and Y .
Power Set
For any X there exists a set Y = P(X):
âˆ€X âˆƒY âˆ€u (u âˆˆY â†”u âŠ‚X).
A set U is a subset of X, U âŠ‚X, if
âˆ€z (z âˆˆU â†’z âˆˆX).
If U âŠ‚X and U Ì¸= X, then U is a proper subset of X.
The set of all subsets of X,
P(X) = {u : u âŠ‚X},
is called the power set of X.

10
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Using the Power Set Axiom we can deï¬ne other basic notions of set theory.
The product of X and Y is the set of all pairs (x, y) such that x âˆˆX and
y âˆˆY :
(1.6)
X Ã— Y = {(x, y) : x âˆˆX and y âˆˆY }.
The notation {(x, y) : . . . } in (1.6) is justiï¬ed because
{(x, y) : Ï•(x, y)} = {u : âˆƒx âˆƒy (u = (x, y) and Ï•(x, y))}.
The product X Ã— Y is a set because
X Ã— Y âŠ‚PP(X âˆªY ).
Further, we deï¬ne
X Ã— Y Ã— Z = (X Ã— Y ) Ã— Z,
and in general
X1 Ã— . . . Ã— Xn+1 = (X1 Ã— . . . Ã— Xn) Ã— Xn+1.
Thus
X1 Ã— . . . Ã— Xn = {(x1, . . . , xn) : x1 âˆˆX1 âˆ§. . . âˆ§xn âˆˆXn}.
We also let
Xn = X Ã— . . . Ã— X


n times
.
An n-ary relation R is a set of n-tuples. R is a relation on X if R âŠ‚Xn.
It is customary to write R(x1, . . . , xn) instead of
(x1, . . . , xn) âˆˆR,
and in case that R is binary, then we also use
x R y
for (x, y) âˆˆR.
If R is a binary relation, then the domain of R is the set
dom(R) = {u : âˆƒv (u, v) âˆˆR},
and the range of R is the set
ran(R) = {v : âˆƒu (u, v) âˆˆR}.
Note that dom(R) and ran(R) are sets because
dom(R) âŠ‚  R,
ran(R) âŠ‚  R.
The ï¬eld of a relation R is the set ï¬eld(R) = dom(R) âˆªran(R).

1. Axioms of Set Theory
11
In general, we call a class R an n-ary relation if all its elements are n-
tuples; in other words, if
R âŠ‚V n = the class of all n-tuples,
where Cn (and C Ã— D) is deï¬ned in the obvious way.
A binary relation f is a function if (x, y) âˆˆf and (x, z) âˆˆf implies y = z.
The unique y such that (x, y) âˆˆf is the value of f at x; we use the standard
notation
y = f(x)
or its variations f : x â†’y, y = fx, etc. for (x, y) âˆˆf.
f is a function on X if X = dom(f). If dom(f) = Xn, then f is an n-ary
function on X.
f is a function from X to Y ,
f : X â†’Y,
if dom(f) = X and ran(f) âŠ‚Y . The set of all functions from X to Y is
denoted by Y X. Note that Y X is a set:
Y X âŠ‚P(X Ã— Y ).
If Y = ran(f), then f is a function onto Y . A function f is one-to-one if
f(x) = f(y)
implies
x = y.
An n-ary operation on X is a function f : Xn â†’X.
The restriction of a function f to a set X (usually a subset of dom(f)) is
the function
fâ†¾X = {(x, y) âˆˆf : x âˆˆX}.
A function g is an extension of a function f if g âŠƒf, i.e., dom(f) âŠ‚dom(g)
and g(x) = f(x) for all x âˆˆdom(f).
If f and g are functions such that ran(g) âŠ‚dom(f), then the composition
of f and g is the function f â—¦g with domain dom(f â—¦g) = dom(g) such that
(f â—¦g)(x) = f(g(x)) for all x âˆˆdom(g).
We denote the image of X by f either fâ€œX or f(X):
fâ€œX = f(X) = {y : (âˆƒx âˆˆX) y = f(x)},
and the inverse image by
fâˆ’1(X) = {x : f(x) âˆˆX}.
If f is one-to-one, then f âˆ’1 denotes the inverse of f:
f âˆ’1(x) = y
if and only if
x = f(y).
The previous deï¬nitions can also be applied to classes instead of sets.
A class F is a function if it is a relation such that (x, y) âˆˆF and (x, z) âˆˆF

12
Part I. Basic Set Theory
implies y = z. For example, Fâ€œC or F(C) denotes the image of the class C
by the function F.
It should be noted that a function is often called a mapping or a corre-
spondence (and similarly, a set is called a family or a collection).
An equivalence relation on a set X is a binary relation â‰¡which is reï¬‚exive,
symmetric, and transitive: For all x, y, z âˆˆX,
x â‰¡x,
x â‰¡y implies y â‰¡x,
if x â‰¡y and y â‰¡z then x â‰¡z.
A family of sets is disjoint if any two of its members are disjoint. A par-
tition of a set X is a disjoint family P of nonempty sets such that
X = {Y : Y âˆˆP}.
Let â‰¡be an equivalence relation on X. For every x âˆˆX, let
[x] = {y âˆˆX : y â‰¡x}
(the equivalence class of x). The set
X/â‰¡= {[x] : x âˆˆX}
is a partition of X (the quotient of X by â‰¡). Conversely, each partition P
of X deï¬nes an equivalence relation on X:
x â‰¡y
if and only if
(âˆƒY âˆˆP)(x âˆˆY and y âˆˆY ).
If an equivalence relation is a class, then its equivalence classes may be
proper classes. In Chapter 6 we shall introduce a trick that enables us to
handle equivalence classes as if they were sets.
Inï¬nity
There exists an inï¬nite set.
To give a precise formulation of the Axiom of Inï¬nity, we have to deï¬ne
ï¬rst the notion of ï¬niteness. The most obvious deï¬nition of ï¬niteness uses the
notion of a natural number, which is as yet undeï¬ned. We shall deï¬ne natural
numbers (as ï¬nite ordinals) in Chapter 2 and give only a quick treatment of
natural numbers and ï¬niteness in the exercises below.
In principle, it is possible to give a deï¬nition of ï¬niteness that does not
mention numbers, but such deï¬nitions necessarily look artiï¬cial.
We therefore formulate the Axiom of Inï¬nity diï¬€erently:
âˆƒS (âˆ…âˆˆS âˆ§(âˆ€x âˆˆS)x âˆª{x} âˆˆS).
We call a set S with the above property inductive. Thus we have:

1. Axioms of Set Theory
13
Axiom of Inï¬nity. There exists an inductive set.
The axiom provides for the existence of inï¬nite sets. In Chapter 2 we
show that an inductive set is inï¬nite (and that an inductive set exists if there
exists an inï¬nite set).
We shall introduce natural numbers and ï¬nite sets in Chapter 2, as a part
of the introduction of ordinal numbers. In Exercises 1.3â€“1.9 we show an al-
ternative approach.
Replacement Schema
If a class F is a function, then for every set X, F(X) is a set.
For each formula Ï•(x, y, p), the formula (1.7) is an Axiom (of Replace-
ment):
(1.7)
âˆ€x âˆ€y âˆ€z (Ï•(x, y, p) âˆ§Ï•(x, z, p) â†’y = z)
â†’âˆ€X âˆƒY âˆ€y (y âˆˆY â†”(âˆƒx âˆˆX) Ï•(x, y, p)).
As in the case of Separation Axioms, we can prove the version of Replace-
ment Axioms with several parameters: Replace p by p1, . . . , pn.
If F = {(x, y) : Ï•(x, y, p)}, then the premise of (1.7) says that F is
a function, and we get the formulation above. We can also formulate the
axioms in the following ways:
If a class F is a function and dom(F) is a set, then ran(F) is a set.
If a class F is a function, then âˆ€X âˆƒf (Fâ†¾X = f).
The remaining two axioms, Choice and Regularity, will by introduced in
Chapters 5 and 6.
Exercises
1.1. Verify (1.1).
1.2. There is no set X such that P(X) âŠ‚X.
Let
N = T{X : X is inductive}.
N is the smallest inductive set. Let us use the following notation:
0 = âˆ…,

2 = {0, 1},
3 = {0, 1, 2},
. . . .
If n âˆˆN, let n + 1 = n âˆª{n}. Let us deï¬ne < (on N) by n < m if and only if
n âˆˆm.
A set T is transitive if x âˆˆT implies x âŠ‚T.

14
Part I. Basic Set Theory
1.3. If X is inductive, then the set {x âˆˆX : x âŠ‚X} is inductive. Hence N is
transitive, and for each n, n = {m âˆˆN : m < n}.
1.4. If X is inductive, then the set {x âˆˆX : x is transitive} is inductive. Hence
every n âˆˆN is transitive.
1.5. If X is inductive, then the set {x âˆˆX : x is transitive and x /âˆˆx} is inductive.
Hence n /âˆˆn and n Ì¸= n + 1 for each n âˆˆN.
1.6. If X is inductive, then {x âˆˆX : x is transitive and every nonempty z âŠ‚x has
an âˆˆ-minimal element} is inductive (t is âˆˆ-minimal in z if there is no s âˆˆz such
that s âˆˆt).
1.7. Every nonempty X âŠ‚N has an âˆˆ-minimal element.
[Pick n âˆˆX and look at X âˆ©n.]

each n Ì¸= 0 is m + 1 for some m.
1.9 (Induction). Let A be a subset of N such that 0 âˆˆA, and if n âˆˆA then
n + 1 âˆˆA. Then A = N.
A set X has n elements (where n âˆˆN) if there is a one-to-one mapping of n
onto X. A set is ï¬nite if it has n elements for some n âˆˆN, and inï¬nite if it is not
ï¬nite.
A set S is T-ï¬nite if every nonempty X âŠ‚P(S) has a âŠ‚-maximal element, i.e.,
u âˆˆX such that there is no v âˆˆX with u âŠ‚v and u Ì¸= v. S is T-inï¬nite if it is not
T-ï¬nite. (T is for Tarski.)
1.10. Each n âˆˆN is T-ï¬nite.
1.11. N is T-inï¬nite; the set N âŠ‚P(N) has no âŠ‚-maximal element.
1.12. Every ï¬nite set is T-ï¬nite.
1.13. Every inï¬nite set is T-inï¬nite.
[If S is inï¬nite, consider X = {u âŠ‚S : u is ï¬nite}.]

1. Axioms of Set Theory
15
Historical Notes
Set theory was invented by Georg Cantor. The ï¬rst attempt to consider inï¬nite sets
is attributed to Bolzano (who introduced the term Menge). It was however Cantor
who realized the signiï¬cance of one-to-one functions between sets and introduced
the notion of cardinality of a set. Cantor originated the theory of cardinal and
ordinal numbers as well as the investigations of the topology of the real line. Much of
the development in the ï¬rst four chapters follows Cantorâ€™s work. The main reference
to Cantorâ€™s work is his collected works, Cantor [1932]. Another source of references
to the early research in set theory is Hausdorï¬€â€™s book [1914].
Cantor started his investigations in [1874], where he proved that the set of
all real numbers is uncountable, while the set of all algebraic reals is countable.
In [1878] he gave the ï¬rst formulation of the celebrated Continuum Hypothesis.
The axioms for set theory (except Replacement and Regularity) are due to
Zermelo [1908]. The Replacement Schema is due to Fraenkel [1922a] and Skolem
(see [1970], pp. 137â€“152).
Exercises 1.12 and 1.13: Tarski [1925a].

2. Ordinal Numbers
In this chapter we introduce ordinal numbers and prove the Transï¬nite Re-
cursion Theorem.
Linear and Partial Ordering
Deï¬nition 2.1. A binary relation < on a set P is a partial ordering of P if:
(i) p Ì¸< p for any p âˆˆP;
(ii) if p < q and q < r, then p < r.
(P, <) is called a partially ordered set. A partial ordering < of P is a linear
ordering if moreover
(iii) p < q or p = q or q < p for all p, q âˆˆP.
If < is a partial (linear) ordering, then the relation â‰¤(where p â‰¤q if either
p < q or p = q) is also called a partial (linear) ordering (and < is sometimes
called a strict ordering).
Deï¬nition 2.2. If (P, <) is a partially ordered set, X is a nonempty subset
of P, and a âˆˆP, then:
a is a maximal element of X if a âˆˆX and (âˆ€x âˆˆX) a Ì¸< x;
a is a minimal element of X if a âˆˆX and (âˆ€x âˆˆX) x Ì¸< a;
a is the greatest element of X if a âˆˆX and (âˆ€x âˆˆX) x â‰¤a;
a is the least element of X if a âˆˆX and (âˆ€x âˆˆX) a â‰¤x;
a is an upper bound of X if (âˆ€x âˆˆX) x â‰¤a;
a is a lower bound of X if (âˆ€x âˆˆX) a â‰¤x;
a is the supremum of X if a is the least upper bound of X;
a is the inï¬mum of X if a is the greatest lower bound of X.
The supremum (inï¬mum) of X (if it exists) is denoted sup X (inf X).
Note that if X is linearly ordered by <, then a maximal element of X is its
greatest element (similarly for a minimal element).
If (P, <) and (Q, <) are partially ordered sets and f : P â†’Q, then f is
order-preserving if x < y implies f(x) < f(y). If P and Q are linearly ordered,
then an order-preserving function is also called increasing.

18
Part I. Basic Set Theory
A one-to-one function of P onto Q is an isomorphism of P and Q if
both f and f âˆ’1 are order-preserving; (P, <) is then isomorphic to (Q, <).
An isomorphism of P onto itself is an automorphism of (P, <).
Well-Ordering
Deï¬nition 2.3. A linear ordering < of a set P is a well-ordering if every
nonempty subset of P has a least element.
The concept of well-ordering is of fundamental importance. It is shown be-
low that well-ordered sets can be compared by their lengths; ordinal numbers
will be introduced as order-types of well-ordered sets.
Lemma 2.4. If (W, <) is a well-ordered set and f : W â†’W is an increasing
function, then f(x) â‰¥x for each x âˆˆW.
Proof. Assume that the set X = {x âˆˆW : f(x) < x} is nonempty and let z
be the least element of X. If w = f(z), then f(w) < w, a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 2.5. The only automorphism of a well-ordered set is the identity.
Proof. By Lemma 2.4, f(x) â‰¥x for all x, and f âˆ’1(x) â‰¥x for all x.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 2.6. If two well-ordered sets W1, W2 are isomorphic, then the
isomorphism of W1 onto W2 is unique.
âŠ“âŠ”
If W is a well-ordered set and u âˆˆW, then {x âˆˆW : x < u} is an initial
segment of W (given by u).
Lemma 2.7. No well-ordered set is isomorphic to an initial segment of itself.
Proof. If ran(f) = {x : x < u}, then f(u) < u, contrary to Lemma 2.4.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 2.8. If W1 and W2 are well-ordered sets, then exactly one of the
following three cases holds:
(i) W1 is isomorphic to W2;
(ii) W1 is isomorphic to an initial segment of W2;
(iii) W2 is isomorphic to an initial segment of W1.
Proof. For u âˆˆWi, (i = 1, 2), let Wi(u) denote the initial segment of Wi
given by u. Let
f = {(x, y) âˆˆW1 Ã— W2 : W1(x) is isomorphic to W2(y)}.
Using Lemma 2.7, it is easy to see that f is a one-to-one function. If h is
an isomorphism between W1(x) and W2(y), and xâ€² < x, then W1(xâ€²) and
W2(h(xâ€²)) are isomorphic. It follows that f is order-preserving.

2. Ordinal Numbers
19
If dom(f) = W1 and ran(f) = W2, then case (i) holds.
If y1 < y2 and y2 âˆˆran(f), then y1 âˆˆran(f). Thus if ran(f) Ì¸= W2 and
y0 is the least element of W2 âˆ’ran(f), we have ran(f) = W2(y0). Necessarily,
dom(f) = W1, for otherwise we would have (x0, y0) âˆˆf, where x0 = the least
element of W1 âˆ’dom(f). Thus case (ii) holds.
Similarly, if dom(f) Ì¸= W1, then case (iii) holds.
In view of Lemma 2.7, the three cases are mutually exclusive.
âŠ“âŠ”
If W1 and W2 are isomorphic, we say that they have the same order-type.
Informally, an ordinal number is the order-type of a well-ordered set.
We shall now give a formal deï¬nition of ordinal numbers.
Ordinal Numbers
The idea is to deï¬ne ordinal numbers so that
Î± < Î²
if and only if
Î± âˆˆÎ²,
and
Î± = {Î² : Î² < Î±}.
Deï¬nition 2.9. A set T is transitive if every element of T is a subset of T .
(Equivalently,  T âŠ‚T , or T âŠ‚P(T ).)
Deï¬nition 2.10. A set is an ordinal number (an ordinal) if it is transitive
and well-ordered by âˆˆ.
We shall denote ordinals by lowercase Greek letters Î±, Î², Î³, . . . . The class
of all ordinals is denoted by Ord.
We deï¬ne
Î± < Î²
if and only if
Î± âˆˆÎ².
Lemma 2.11.
(i) 0 = âˆ…is an ordinal.
(ii) If Î± is an ordinal and Î² âˆˆÎ±, then Î² is an ordinal.
(iii) If Î± Ì¸= Î² are ordinals and Î± âŠ‚Î², then Î± âˆˆÎ².
(iv) If Î±, Î² are ordinals, then either Î± âŠ‚Î² or Î² âŠ‚Î±.
Proof. (i), (ii) by deï¬nition.
(iii) If Î± âŠ‚Î², let Î³ be the least element of the set Î² âˆ’Î±. Since Î± is
transitive, it follows that Î± is the initial segment of Î² given by Î³. Thus
Î± = {Î¾ âˆˆÎ² : Î¾ < Î³} = Î³, and so Î± âˆˆÎ².
(iv) Clearly, Î± âˆ©Î² is an ordinal, Î± âˆ©Î² = Î³. We have Î³ = Î± or Î³ = Î²,
for otherwise Î³ âˆˆÎ±, and Î³ âˆˆÎ², by (iii). Then Î³ âˆˆÎ³, which contradicts the
deï¬nition of an ordinal (namely that âˆˆis a strict ordering of Î±).
âŠ“âŠ”

Part I. Basic Set Theory
Using Lemma 2.11 one gets the following facts about ordinal numbers
(the proofs are routine):
< is a linear ordering of the class Ord.
(2.1)
For each Î±, Î± = {Î² : Î² < Î±}.
(2.2)
If C is a nonempty class of ordinals, then  C is an ordinal,  C âˆˆC
and  C = inf C.
(2.3)
If X is a nonempty set of ordinals, then  X is an ordinal, and  X =
sup X.
(2.4)
For every Î±, Î± âˆª{Î±} is an ordinal and Î± âˆª{Î±} = inf{Î² : Î² > Î±}.
(2.5)
We thus deï¬ne Î± + 1 = Î± âˆª{Î±} (the successor of Î±). In view of (2.4), the
class Ord is a proper class; otherwise, consider sup Ord + 1.
We can now prove that the above deï¬nition of ordinals provides us with
order-types of well-ordered sets.
Theorem 2.12. Every well-ordered set is isomorphic to a unique ordinal
number.
Proof. The uniqueness follows from Lemma 2.7. Given a well-ordered set W,
we ï¬nd an isomorphic ordinal as follows: Deï¬ne F(x) = Î± if Î± is isomorphic
to the initial segment of W given by x. If such an Î± exists, then it is unique.
By the Replacement Axioms, F(W) is a set. For each x âˆˆW, such an Î±
exists (otherwise consider the least x for which such an Î± does not exist). If
Î³ is the least Î³ /âˆˆF(W), then F(W) = Î³ and we have an isomorphism of W
onto Î³.
âŠ“âŠ”
If Î± = Î² + 1, then Î± is a successor ordinal. If Î± is not a successor ordinal,
then Î± = sup{Î² : Î² < Î±} =  Î±; Î± is called a limit ordinal. We also consider 0
a limit ordinal and deï¬ne sup âˆ…= 0.
The existence of limit ordinals other than 0 follows from the Axiom of
Inï¬nity; see Exercise 2.3.
Deï¬nition 2.13 (Natural Numbers). We denote the least nonzero limit
ordinal Ï‰ (or N). The ordinals less than Ï‰ (elements of N) are called ï¬nite
ordinals, or natural numbers. Speciï¬cally,
0 = âˆ…,
1 = 0 + 1,
2 = 1 + 1,
3 = 2 + 1,
etc.
A set X is ï¬nite if there is a one-to-one mapping of X onto some n âˆˆN.
X is inï¬nite if it is not ï¬nite.
We use letters n, m, l, k, j, i (most of the time) to denote natural numbers.

Induction and Recursion
Theorem 2.14 (Transï¬nite Induction). Let C be a class of ordinals and
assume that:
(i) 0 âˆˆC;
(ii) if Î± âˆˆC, then Î± + 1 âˆˆC;
(iii) if Î± is a nonzero limit ordinal and Î² âˆˆC for all Î² < Î±, then Î± âˆˆC.
Then C is the class of all ordinals.
Proof. Otherwise, let Î± be the least ordinal Î± /âˆˆC and apply (i), (ii), or (iii).
âŠ“âŠ”
A function whose domain is the set N is called an (inï¬nite) sequence
(A sequence in X is a function f : N â†’X.) The standard notation for
a sequence is
âŸ¨an : n < Ï‰âŸ©
or variants thereof. A ï¬nite sequence is a function s such dom(s) = {i : i < n}
for some n âˆˆN; then s is a sequence of length n.
A transï¬nite sequence is a function whose domain is an ordinal:
âŸ¨aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±âŸ©.
It is also called an Î±-sequence or a sequence of length Î±. We also say that
a sequence âŸ¨aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±âŸ©is an enumeration of its range {aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±}. If
s is a sequence of length Î±, then sâŒ¢x or simply sx denotes the sequence of
length Î± + 1 that extends s and whose Î±th term is x:
sâŒ¢x = sx = s âˆª{(Î±, x)}.
Sometimes we shall call a â€œsequenceâ€
âŸ¨aÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrdâŸ©
a function (a proper class) on Ord.
â€œDeï¬nition by transï¬nite recursionâ€ usually takes the following form:
Given a function G (on the class of transï¬nite sequences), then for every Î¸
there exists a unique Î¸-sequence
âŸ¨aÎ± : Î± < Î¸âŸ©
such that
aÎ± = G(âŸ¨aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±âŸ©)
for every Î± < Î¸.
We shall give a general version of this theorem, so that we can also con-
struct sequences âŸ¨aÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrdâŸ©.

Ordinal Arithmetic
We shall now deï¬ne addition, multiplication and exponentiation of ordinal

Deï¬nition 2.18 (Addition). For all ordinal numbers Î±
(i) Î± + 0 = Î±,
(ii) Î± + (Î² + 1) = (Î± + Î²) + 1, for all Î²,
(iii) Î± + Î² = limÎ¾â†’Î²(Î± + Î¾) for all limit Î² > 0.
Deï¬nition 2.19 (Multiplication). For all ordinal numbers Î±

(ii) Î± Â· (Î² + 1) = Î± Â· Î² + Î± for all Î²,
(iii) Î± Â· Î² = limÎ¾â†’Î² Î± Â· Î¾ for all limit Î² > 0.
Deï¬nition 2.20 (Exponentiation). For all ordinal numbers Î±

(ii) Î±Î²+1 = Î±Î² Â· Î± for all Î²,
(iii) Î±Î² = limÎ¾â†’Î² Î±Î¾ for all limit Î² > 0.
As deï¬ned, the operations Î±+Î², Î±Â·Î² and Î±Î² are normal functions in the
second variable Î². Their properties can be proved by transï¬nite induction.
For instance, + and Â· are associative:
Lemma 2.21. For all ordinals Î±, Î² and Î³,
(i) Î± + (Î² + Î³) = (Î± + Î²) + Î³,
(ii) Î± Â· (Î² Â· Î³) = (Î± Â· Î²) Â· Î³.
Proof. By induction on Î³.

1 + Ï‰ = Ï‰ Ì¸= Ï‰ + 1,
2 Â· Ï‰ = Ï‰ Ì¸= Ï‰ Â· 2 = Ï‰ + Ï‰.
Ordinal sums and products can be also deï¬ned geometrically, as can sums
and products of arbitrary linear orders:
Deï¬nition 2.22. Let (A, <A) and (B, <B) be disjoint linearly ordered sets.
The sum of these linear orders is the set A âˆªB with the ordering deï¬ned as
follows: x < y if and only if
(i) x, y âˆˆA and x <A y, or
(ii) x, y âˆˆB and x <B y, or
(iii) x âˆˆA and y âˆˆB.

of these linear orders is the set A Ã— B with the ordering deï¬ned by
(a1, b1) < (a2, b2) if and only if either b1 < b2 or (b1 = b2 and a1 < a2).
Lemma 2.24. For all ordinals Î± and Î², Î± + Î² and Î± Â· Î² are, respectively,
isomorphic to the sum and to the product of Î± and Î².
Proof. By induction on Î².

Well-Founded Relations
Now we shall deï¬ne an important generalization of well-ordered sets.
A binary relation E on a set P is well-founded if every nonempty X âŠ‚P
has an E-minimal element, that is a âˆˆX such that there is no x âˆˆX with
x E a.
Clearly, a well-ordering of P is a well-founded relation.
Given a well-founded relation E on a set P, we can deï¬ne the height of E,
and assign to each x âˆˆP an ordinal number, the rank of x in E.
Theorem 2.27. If E is a well-founded relation on P, then there exists
a unique function Ï from P into the ordinals such that for all x âˆˆP,
(2.7)
Ï(x) = sup{Ï(y) + 1 : y E x}.
The range of Ï is an initial segment of the ordinals, thus an ordinal num-
ber. This ordinal is called the height of E.
Proof. We shall deï¬ne a function Ï satisfying (2.7) and then prove its unique-
ness. By induction, let
P0 = âˆ…,
PÎ±+1 = {x âˆˆP : âˆ€y (y E x â†’y âˆˆPÎ±)},
PÎ± = 

PÎ¾
if Î± is a limit ordinal.
Let Î¸ be the least ordinal such that PÎ¸+1 = PÎ¸ (such Î¸ exists by Replacement).
First, it should be easy to see that PÎ± âŠ‚PÎ±+1 for each Î± (by induction).
Thus P0 âŠ‚P1 âŠ‚. . . âŠ‚PÎ¸. We claim that PÎ¸ = P. Otherwise, let a be
an E-minimal element of P âˆ’PÎ¸. It follows that each x E a is in PÎ¸, and
so a âˆˆPÎ¸+1, a contradiction. Now we deï¬ne Ï(x) as the least Î± such that
x âˆˆPÎ±+1. It is obvious that if x E y, then Ï(x) < Ï(y), and (2.7) is easily
veriï¬ed. The ordinal Î¸ is the height of E.
The uniqueness of Ï is established as follows: Let Ïâ€² be another function
satisfying (2.7) and consider an E-minimal element of the set {x âˆˆP : Ï(x) Ì¸=
Ïâ€²(x)}.

Historical Notes
The theory of well-ordered sets was developed by Cantor, who also introduced
transï¬nite induction. The idea of identifying an ordinal number with the set of
smaller ordinals is due to Zermelo and von Neumann.

3. Cardinal Numbers
Cardinality
Two sets X, Y have the same cardinality (cardinal number, cardinal),
(3.1)
|X| = |Y |,
if there exists a one-to-one mapping of X onto Y .
The relation (3.1) is an equivalence relation. We assume that we can
assign to each set X its cardinal number |X| so that two sets are assigned
the same cardinal just in case they satisfy condition (3.1). Cardinal numbers
can be deï¬ned either using the Axiom of Regularity (via equivalence classes
of (3.1)), or using the Axiom of Choice. In this chapter we deï¬ne cardinal
numbers of well-orderable sets; as it follows from the Axiom of Choice that
every set can be well-ordered, this deï¬nes cardinals in ZFC.
We recall that a set X is ï¬nite if |X| = |n| for some n âˆˆN; then X is
said to have n elements. Clearly, |n| = |m| if and only if n = m, and so we
deï¬ne ï¬nite cardinals as natural numbers, i.e., |n| = n for all n âˆˆN.
The ordering of cardinal numbers is deï¬ned as follows:
(3.2)
|X| â‰¤|Y |
if there exists a one-to-one mapping of X into Y . We also deï¬ne the strict
ordering |X| < |Y | to mean that |X| â‰¤|Y | while |X| Ì¸= |Y |. The relation â‰¤
in (3.2) is clearly transitive. Theorem 3.2 below shows that it is indeed a par-
tial ordering, and it follows from the Axiom of Choice that the ordering is
linearâ€”any two sets are comparable in this ordering.
The concept of cardinality is central to the study of inï¬nite sets. The
following theorem tells us that this concept is not trivial:
Theorem 3.1 (Cantor). For every set X, |X| < |P(X)|.
Proof. Let f be a function from X into P(X). The set
Y = {x âˆˆX : x /âˆˆf(x)}
is not in the range of f: If z âˆˆX were such that f(z) = Y , then z âˆˆY if
and only if z /âˆˆY , a contradiction. Thus f is not a function of X onto P(X).
Hence |P(X)| Ì¸= |X|.

28
Part I. Basic Set Theory
The function f(x) = {x} is a one-to-one function of X into P(X) and so
|X| â‰¤|P(X)|. It follows that |X| < |P(X)|.
âŠ“âŠ”
In view of the following theorem, < is a partial ordering of cardinal num-
bers.
Theorem 3.2 (Cantor-Bernstein). If |A| â‰¤|B| and |B| â‰¤|A|, then
|A| = |B|.
Proof. If f1 : A â†’B and f2 : B â†’A are one-to-one, then if we let Bâ€² =
f2(B) and A1 = f2(f1(A)), we have A1 âŠ‚Bâ€² âŠ‚A and |A1| = |A|. Thus
we may assume that A1 âŠ‚B âŠ‚A and that f is a one-to-one function of A
onto A1; we will show that |A| = |B|.
We deï¬ne (by induction) for all n âˆˆN:
A0 = A,
An+1 = f(An),
B0 = B,
Bn+1 = f(Bn).
Let g be the function on A deï¬ned as follows:
g(x) =
f(x)
if x âˆˆAn âˆ’Bn for some n,
x
otherwise.
Then g is a one-to-one mapping of A onto B, as the reader will easily verify.
Thus |A| = |B|.
âŠ“âŠ”
The arithmetic operations on cardinals are deï¬ned as follows:
(3.3)
Îº + Î» = |A âˆªB|
where |A| = Îº, |B| = Î», and A, B are disjoint,
Îº Â· Î» = |A Ã— B|
where |A| = Îº, |B| = Î»,
ÎºÎ» = |AB|
where |A| = Îº, |B| = Î».
Naturally, the deï¬nitions in (3.3) are meaningful only if they are independent
of the choice of A and B. Thus one has to check that, e.g., if |A| = |Aâ€²| and
|B| = |Bâ€²|, then |A Ã— B| = |Aâ€² Ã— Bâ€²|.
Lemma 3.3. If |A| = Îº, then |P(A)| = 2Îº.
Proof. For every X âŠ‚A, let Ï‡X be the function
Ï‡X(x) =
1
if x âˆˆX,
0
if x âˆˆA âˆ’X.
The mapping f : X â†’Ï‡X is a one-to-one correspondence between P(A) and
{0, 1}A.
âŠ“âŠ”

3. Cardinal Numbers
29
Thus Cantorâ€™s Theorem 3.1 can be formulated as follows:
Îº < 2Îº
for every cardinal Îº.
A few simple facts about cardinal arithmetic:
+ and Â· are associative, commutative and distributive.
(3.4)
(Îº Â· Î»)Âµ = ÎºÂµ Â· Î»Âµ.
(3.5)
ÎºÎ»+Âµ = ÎºÎ» Â· ÎºÂµ.
(3.6)
(ÎºÎ»)Âµ = ÎºÎ»Â·Âµ.
(3.7)
If Îº â‰¤Î», then ÎºÂµ â‰¤Î»Âµ.
(3.8)
If 0 < Î» â‰¤Âµ, then ÎºÎ» â‰¤ÎºÂµ.
(3.9)
Îº0 = 1; 1Îº = 1; 0Îº = 0 if Îº > 0.
(3.10)
To prove (3.4)â€“(3.10), one has only to ï¬nd the appropriate one-to-one func-
tions.
Alephs
An ordinal Î± is called a cardinal number (a cardinal) if |Î±| Ì¸= |Î²| for all Î² < Î±.
We shall use Îº, Î», Âµ, . . . to denote cardinal numbers.
If W is a well-ordered set, then there exists an ordinal Î± such that |W| =
|Î±|. Thus we let
|W| = the least ordinal such that |W| = |Î±|.
Clearly, |W| is a cardinal number.
Every natural number is a cardinal (a ï¬nite cardinal); and if S is a ï¬nite
set, then |S| = n for some n.
The ordinal Ï‰ is the least inï¬nite cardinal. Note that all inï¬nite cardinals
are limit ordinals. The inï¬nite ordinal numbers that are cardinals are called
alephs.
Lemma 3.4.
(i) For every Î± there is a cardinal number greater than Î±.
(ii) If X is a set of cardinals, then sup X is a cardinal.
For every Î±, let Î±+ be the least cardinal number greater than Î±, the
cardinal successor of Î±.
Proof. (i) For any set X, let
(3.11)
h(X) = the least Î± such that there is no one-to-one
function of Î± into X.
There is only a set of possible well-orderings of subsets of X. Hence there
is only a set of ordinals for which a one-to-one function of Î± into X exists.
Thus h(X) exists.

30
Part I. Basic Set Theory
If Î± is an ordinal, then |Î±| < |h(Î±)| by (3.11). That proves (i).
(ii) Let Î± = sup X. If f is a one-to-one mapping of Î± onto some Î² < Î±,
let Îº âˆˆX be such that Î² < Îº â‰¤Î±. Then |Îº| = |{f(Î¾) : Î¾ < Îº}| â‰¤Î²,
a contradiction. Thus Î± is a cardinal.
âŠ“âŠ”
Using Lemma 3.4, we deï¬ne the increasing enumeration of all alephs. We

Sets whose cardinality is â„µ0 are called countable; a set is at most countable

A cardinal â„µÎ±+1 is a successor cardinal. A cardinal â„µÎ± whose index is
a limit ordinal is a limit cardinal.
Addition and multiplication of alephs is a trivial matter, due to the fol-

We say that a set B is a projection of a set A if there is a mapping of A onto B.

A set S is Dedekind-ï¬nite (D-ï¬nite) if there is no one-to-one mapping of S
onto a proper subset of S. Every ï¬nite set is D-ï¬nite. Using the Axiom of Choice,
one proves that every inï¬nite set is D-inï¬nite, and so D-ï¬niteness is the same as
ï¬niteness. Without the Axiom of Choice, however, one cannot prove that every
D-ï¬nite set is ï¬nite.
The set N of all natural numbers is D-inï¬nite and hence every S such that
|S| â‰¥â„µ0, is D-inï¬nite.

Historical Notes
Cardinal numbers and alephs were introduced by Cantor. The proof of the Cantor-
Bernstein Theorem is Bernsteinâ€™s; see Borel [1898], p. 103. (There is an earlier proof
by Dedekind.) The ï¬rst proof of â„µÎ±Â·â„µÎ± = â„µÎ± appeared in Hessenberg [1906], p. 593.
Regularity of cardinals was investigated by Hausdorï¬€, who also raised the question
of existence of regular limit cardinals. D-ï¬niteness was formulated by Dedekind.

4. Real Numbers
The set of all real numbers R (the real line or the continuum) is the unique
ordered ï¬eld in which every nonempty bounded set has a least upper bound.
The proof of the following theorem marks the beginning of Cantorâ€™s theory
of sets.
Theorem 4.1 (Cantor). The set of all real numbers is uncountable.
Proof. Let us assume that the set R of all reals is countable, and let c0,
c1, . . . , cn, . . . , n âˆˆN, be an enumeration of R. We shall ï¬nd a real number
diï¬€erent from each cn.
Let a0 = c0 and b0 = ck0 where k0 is the least k such that a0 < ck.
For each n, let an+1 = cin where in is the least i such that an < ci < bn,
and bn+1 = ckn where kn is the least k such that an+1 < ck < bn. If we let
a = sup{an : n âˆˆN}, then a Ì¸= ck for all k.
âŠ“âŠ”
The Cardinality of the Continuum
Let c denote the cardinality of R. As the set Q of all rational numbers is
dense in R, every real number r is equal to sup{q âˆˆQ : q < r} and because
Q is countable, it follows that c â‰¤|P(Q)| = 2â„µ0.
Let C (the Cantor set) be the set of all reals of the form âˆ
n=1 an/3n,
where each an = 0 or 2. C is obtained by removing from the closed interval
[0, 1], the open intervals ( 1
3, 2
3), ( 1
9, 2
9), ( 7
9, 8
9), etc. (the middle-third intervals).
C is in a one-to-one correspondence with the set of all Ï‰-sequences of 0â€™s
and 2â€™s and so |C| = 2â„µ0.
Therefore c â‰¥2â„µ0, and so by the Cantor-Bernstein Theorem we have
(4.1)
c = 2â„µ0.
By Cantorâ€™s Theorem 4.1 (or by Theorem 3.1), c > â„µ0. Cantor conjectured
that every set of reals is either at most countable or has cardinality of the
continuum. In ZFC, every inï¬nite cardinal is an aleph, and so 2â„µ0 â‰¥â„µ1.
Cantorâ€™s conjecture then becomes the statement
2â„µ0 = â„µ1
known as the Continuum Hypothesis (CH).

38
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Among sets of cardinality c are the set of all sequences of natural numbers,
the set of all sequences of real numbers, the set of all complex numbers. This
is because â„µâ„µ0
0
= (2â„µ0)â„µ0 = 2â„µ0, 2â„µ0 Â· 2â„µ0 = 2â„µ0.
Cantorâ€™s proof of Theorem 4.1 yielded more than uncountability of R; it
showed that the set of all transcendental numbers has cardinality c (cf. Ex-
ercise 4.5).
The Ordering of R
A linear ordering (P, <) is complete if every nonempty bounded subset of P
has a least upper bound. We stated above that R is the unique complete
ordered ï¬eld. We shall generally disregard the ï¬eld properties of R and will
concern ourselves more with the order properties.
One consequence of being a complete ordered ï¬eld is that R contains the
set Q of all rational numbers as a dense subset. The set Q is countable and
its ordering is dense.
Deï¬nition 4.2. A linear ordering (P, <) is dense if for all a < b there exists
a c such that a < c < b.
A set D âŠ‚P is a dense subset if for all a < b in P there exists a d âˆˆD
such that a < d < b.
The following theorem proves the uniqueness of the ordered set (R, <).
We say that an ordered set is unbounded if it has neither a least nor a greatest
element.
Theorem 4.3 (Cantor).
(i) Any two countable unbounded dense linearly ordered sets are isomor-
phic.
(ii) (R, <) is the unique complete linear ordering that has a countable
dense subset isomorphic to (Q, <).
Proof. (i) Let P1 = {an : n âˆˆN} and let P2 = {bn : n âˆˆN} be two
such linearly ordered sets. We construct an isomorphism f : P1 â†’P2 in the
following way: We ï¬rst deï¬ne f(a0), then f âˆ’1(b0), then f(a1), then f âˆ’1(b1),
etc., so as to keep f order-preserving. For example, to deï¬ne f(an), if it is not
yet deï¬ned, we let f(an) = bk where k is the least index such that f remains
order-preserving (such a k always exists because f has been deï¬ned for only
ï¬nitely many a âˆˆP1, and because P2 is dense and unbounded).
(ii) To prove the uniqueness of R, let C and Câ€² be two complete dense
unbounded linearly ordered sets, let P and P â€² be dense in C and Câ€², re-
spectively, and let f be an isomorphism of P onto P â€². Then f can be
extended (uniquely) to an isomorphism f âˆ—of C and Câ€²: For x âˆˆC, let
f âˆ—(x) = sup{f(p) : p âˆˆP and p â‰¤x}.
âŠ“âŠ”

4. Real Numbers
39
The existence of (R, <) is proved by means of Dedekind cuts in (Q, <).
The following theorem is a general version of this construction:
Theorem 4.4. Let (P, <) be a dense unbounded linearly ordered set. Then
there is a complete unbounded linearly ordered set (C, â‰º) such that:
(i) P âŠ‚C, and < and â‰ºagree on P;
(ii) P is dense in C.
Proof. A Dedekind cut in P is a pair (A, B) of disjoint nonempty subsets
of P such that
(i) A âˆªB = P;
(ii) a < b for any a âˆˆA and b âˆˆB;
(iii) A does not have a greatest element.
Let C be the set of all Dedekind cuts in P and let (A1, B1) â‰¼(A2, B2) if
A1 âŠ‚A2 (and B1 âŠƒB2). The set C is complete: If {(Ai, Bi) : i âˆˆI} is
a nonempty bounded subset of C, then (
iâˆˆI Ai, 
iâˆˆI Bi) is its supremum.
For p âˆˆP, let
Ap = {x âˆˆP : x < p},
Bp = {x âˆˆP : x â‰¥p}.
Then P â€² = {(Ap, Bp) : p âˆˆP} is isomorphic to P and is dense in C.
âŠ“âŠ”
Suslinâ€™s Problem
The real line is, up to isomorphism, the unique linearly ordered set that is
dense, unbounded, complete and contains a countable dense subset.
Since Q is dense in R, every nonempty open interval of R contains a ra-
tional number. Hence if S is a disjoint collection of open intervals, S is at
most countable. (Let âŸ¨rn : n âˆˆNâŸ©be an enumeration of the rationals. To
each J âˆˆS assign rn âˆˆJ with the least possible index n.)
Let P be a dense linearly ordered set. If every disjoint collection of open
intervals in P is at most countable, then we say that P satisï¬es the countable
chain condition.
Suslinâ€™s Problem. Let P be a complete dense unbounded linearly ordered
set that satisï¬es the countable chain condition. Is P isomorphic to the real
line?
This question cannot be decided in ZFC; we shall return to the problem
in Chapter 9.

40
Part I. Basic Set Theory
The Topology of the Real Line
The real line is a metric space with the metric d(a, b) = |a âˆ’b|. Its metric
topology coincides with the order topology of (R, <). Since Q is a dense
set in R and since every Cauchy sequence of real numbers converges, R is
a separable complete metric space. (A metric space is separable if it has
a countable dense set; it is complete if every Cauchy sequence converges.)
Open sets are unions of open intervals, and in fact, every open set is the
union of open intervals with rational endpoints. This implies that the number
of all open sets in R is the continuum and so is the number of all closed sets
in R (Exercise 4.6).
Every open interval has cardinality c, therefore every nonempty open
set has cardinality c. We show below that every uncountable closed set has
cardinality c. Proving this was Cantorâ€™s ï¬rst step in the search for the proof of
the Continuum Hypothesis. In Chapter 11 we show that CH holds for Borel
and analytic sets as well.
A nonempty closed set is perfect if it has no isolated points. Theorems 4.5
and 4.6 below show that every uncountable closed set contains a perfect set.
Theorem 4.5. Every perfect set has cardinality c.
Proof. Given a perfect set P, we want to ï¬nd a one-to-one function F from
{0, 1}Ï‰ into P. Let S be the set of all ï¬nite sequences of 0â€™s and 1â€™s. By
induction on the length of s âˆˆS one can ï¬nd closed intervals Is such that
for each n and all s âˆˆS of length n,

A set of reals is called nowhere dense if its closure has empty interior. The
following theorem shows that R is not the union of countably many nowhere
dense sets (R is not of the ï¬rst category).
Theorem 4.8 (The Baire Category Theorem). If D0, D1, . . ., Dn, . . .,
n âˆˆN, are dense open sets of reals, then the intersection D = âˆ

Borel Sets
Deï¬nition 4.9. An algebra of sets is a collection S of subsets of a given
set S such that
(i) S âˆˆS,
(ii) if X âˆˆS and Y âˆˆS then X âˆªY âˆˆS,
(iii) if X âˆˆS then S âˆ’X âˆˆS.
(4.2)
(Note that S is also closed under intersections.)
A Ïƒ-algebra is additionally closed under countable unions (and intersec-
tions):
(iv) If Xn âˆˆS for all n, then âˆ
n=0 Xn âˆˆS.
For any collection X of subsets of S there is a smallest algebra (Ïƒ-alge-
bra) S such that S âŠƒX; namely the intersection of all algebras (Ïƒ-algebras) S
of subsets of S for which X âŠ‚S.
Deï¬nition 4.10. A set of reals B is Borel if it belongs to the smallest Ïƒ-
algebra B of sets of reals that contains all open sets.

42
Part I. Basic Set Theory
In Chapter 11 we investigate Borel sets in more detail. In particular, we
shall classify Borel sets by deï¬ning a hierarchy of Ï‰1 levels. For that we need
however a weak version of the Axiom of Choice that is not provable in ZF
alone. At this point we mention the lowest level of the hierarchy (beyond
open sets and closed sets): The intersections of countably many open sets
are called GÎ´ sets, and the unions of countably many closed sets are called
FÏƒ sets.
Lebesgue Measure
We assume that the reader is familiar with the basic theory of Lebesgue
measure. As we shall return to the subject in Chapter 11 we do not deï¬ne
the concept of measure at this point. We also caution the reader that some
of the basic theorems on Lebesgue measure require the Countable Axiom of
Choice (to be discussed in Chapter 5).
Lebesgue measurable sets form a Ïƒ-algebra and contain all open intervals
(the measure of an interval is its length). Thus all Borel sets are Lebesgue
measurable.
The Baire Space
The Baire space is the space N = Ï‰Ï‰ of all inï¬nite sequences of natural
numbers, âŸ¨an : n âˆˆNâŸ©, with the following topology: For every ï¬nite sequence
s = âŸ¨ak : k < nâŸ©, let
(4.3)
O(s) = {f âˆˆN : s âŠ‚f} = {âŸ¨ck : k âˆˆNâŸ©: (âˆ€k < n) ck = ak}.
The sets (4.3) form a basis for the topology of N. Note that each O(s) is also
closed.
The Baire space is separable and is metrizable: consider the metric
d(f, g) = 1/2n+1 where n is the least number such that f(n) Ì¸= g(n). The
countable set of all eventually constant sequences is dense in N. This sepa-
rable metric space is complete, as every Cauchy sequence converges.
Every inï¬nite sequence âŸ¨an : n âˆˆNâŸ©of positive integers deï¬nes a con-
tinued fraction 1/(a0 + 1/(a1 + 1/(a2 + . . .))), an irrational number between
0 and 1. Conversely, every irrational number in the interval (0, 1) can be
so represented, and the one-to-one correspondence is a homeomorphism. It
follows that the Baire space is homeomorphic to the space of all irrational
numbers.
For various reasons, modern descriptive set theory uses the Baire space
rather than the real line. Often the functions in Ï‰Ï‰ are called reals.
Clearly, the space N satisï¬es the Baire Category Theorem; the proof is
similar to the proof of Theorem 4.8 above. The Cantor-Bendixson Theorem
holds as well. For completeness we give a description of perfect sets in N.

Polish Spaces
Deï¬nition 4.12. A Polish space is a topological space that is homeomorphic
to a separable complete metric space.
Examples of Polish spaces include R, N, the Cantor space, the unit in-
terval [0, 1], the unit circle T , the Hilbert cube [0, 1]Ï‰, etc.
Every Polish space is a continuous image of the Baire space. In Chapter 11
we prove a somewhat more general statement.

5. The Axiom of Choice and Cardinal
Arithmetic
The Axiom of Choice
Axiom of Choice (AC). Every family of nonempty sets has a choice func-
tion.
If S is a family of sets and âˆ…/âˆˆS, then a choice function for S is a func-
tion f on S such that
(5.1)
f(X) âˆˆX
for every X âˆˆS.
The Axiom of Choice postulates that for every S such that âˆ…/âˆˆS there
exists a function f on S that satisï¬es (5.1).
The Axiom of Choice diï¬€ers from other axioms of ZF by postulating
the existence of a set (i.e., a choice function) without deï¬ning it (unlike,
for instance, the Axiom of Pairing or the Axiom of Power Set). Thus it is
often interesting to know whether a mathematical statement can be proved
without using the Axiom of Choice. It turns out that the Axiom of Choice is
independent of the other axioms of set theory and that many mathematical
theorems are unprovable in ZF without AC.
In some trivial cases, the existence of a choice function can be proved
outright in ZF:
(i) when every X âˆˆS is a singleton X = {x};
(ii) when S is ï¬nite; the existence of a choice function for S is proved by
induction on the size of S;
(iii) when every X âˆˆS is a ï¬nite set of real numbers; let f(X) = the least
element of X.
On the other hand, one cannot prove existence of a choice function (in ZF)
just from the assumption that the sets in S are ï¬nite; even when every X âˆˆS
has just two elements (e.g., sets of reals), we cannot necessarily prove that
S has a choice function.
Using the Axiom of Choice, one proves that every set can be well-ordered,
and therefore every inï¬nite set has cardinality equal to some â„µÎ±. In particular,

48
Part I. Basic Set Theory
any two sets have comparable cardinals, and the ordering
|X| â‰¤|Y |
is a well-ordering of the class of all cardinals.
Theorem 5.1 (Zermeloâ€™s Well-Ordering Theorem). Every set can be
well-ordered.
Proof. Let A be a set. To well-order A, it suï¬ƒces to construct a transï¬nite
one-to-one sequence âŸ¨aÎ± : Î± < Î¸âŸ©that enumerates A. That we can do by
induction, using a choice function f for the family S of all nonempty subsets
of A. We let for every Î±
aÎ± = f(A âˆ’{aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±})
if A âˆ’{aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±} is nonempty. Let Î¸ be the least ordinal such that A =
{aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î¸}. Clearly, âŸ¨aÎ± : Î± < Î¸âŸ©enumerates A.
âŠ“âŠ”
In fact, Zermeloâ€™s Theorem 5.1 is equivalent to the Axiom of Choice:
If every set can be well-ordered, then every family S of nonempty sets has
a choice function. To see this, well-order  S and let f(X) be the least element
of X for every X âˆˆS.
Of particular importance is the fact that the set of all real numbers can
be well-ordered. It follows that 2â„µ0 is an aleph and so 2â„µ0 â‰¥â„µ1.
The existence of a well-ordering of R yields some interesting counterex-
amples. Well known is Vitaliâ€™s construction of a nonmeasurable set (Exer-
cise 10.1); another example is an uncountable set of reals without a perfect
subset (Exercise 5.1).
If every set can be well-ordered, then every inï¬nite set has a countable
subset: Well-order the set and take the ï¬rst Ï‰ elements. Thus every inï¬nite
set is Dedekind-inï¬nite, and so ï¬niteness and Dedekind ï¬niteness coincide.
Dealing with cardinalities of sets is much easier when we have the Axiom
of Choice. In the ï¬rst place, any two sets have comparable cardinals. Another
consequence is:
(5.2)
if f maps A onto B then |B| â‰¤|A|.
To show (5.2), we have to ï¬nd a one-to-one function from B to A. This is
done by choosing one element from fâˆ’1({b}) for each b âˆˆB.
Another consequence of the Axiom of Choice is:
(5.3)
The union of a countable family of countable sets is countable.
(By the way, this often used fact cannot be proved in ZF alone.) To prove (5.3)
let An be a countable set for each n âˆˆN. For each n, let us choose an

enumeration âŸ¨an,k : k âˆˆNâŸ©of An. That gives us a projection of N Ã—N onto
âˆ
n=0 An:
(n, k) â†’an,k.
Thus âˆ
n=0 An is countable.
In a similar fashion, one can prove a more general statement.
Lemma 5.2. |  S| â‰¤|S| Â· sup{|X| : X âˆˆS}.
Proof. Let Îº = |S| and Î» = sup{|X| : X âˆˆS}. We have S = {XÎ± : Î± < Îº}
and for each Î± < Îº, we choose an enumeration XÎ± = {aÎ±,Î² : Î² < Î»Î±}, where

In particular, the union of â„µÎ± sets, each of cardinality â„µÎ±, has cardinal-

Corollary 5.3. Every â„µÎ±+1 is a regular cardinal.
Proof. This is because otherwise Ï‰Î±+1 would be the union of at most â„µÎ± sets
of cardinality at most â„µÎ±.

Using the Axiom of Choice in Mathematics
In algebra and point set topology, one often uses the following version of
the Axiom of Choice. We recall that if (P, <) is a partially ordered set, then
a âˆˆP is called maximal in P if there is no x âˆˆP such that a < x. If X is
a nonempty subset of P, then c âˆˆP is an upper bound of X if x â‰¤c for every
x âˆˆX.
We say that a nonempty C âŠ‚P is a chain in P if C is linearly ordered
by <.
Theorem 5.4 (Zornâ€™s Lemma). If (P, <) is a nonempty partially ordered
set such that every chain in P has an upper bound, then P has a maximal
element.
Proof. We construct (using a choice function for nonempty subsets of P),
a chain in P that leads to a maximal element of P. We let, by induction,
aÎ± = an element of P such that aÎ± > aÎ¾ for every Î¾ < Î± if there is one.
Clearly, if Î± > 0 is a limit ordinal, then CÎ± = {aÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±} is a chain in P
and aÎ± exists by the assumption. Eventually, there is Î¸ such that there is no
aÎ¸+1 âˆˆP, aÎ¸+1 > aÎ¸. Thus aÎ¸ is a maximal element of P.
âŠ“âŠ”

50
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Like Zermeloâ€™s Theorem 5.1, Zornâ€™s Lemma 5.4 is equivalent to the Axiom
of Choice (in ZF); see Exercise 5.5.
There are numerous examples of proofs using Zornâ€™s Lemma. To mention
only of few:
Every vector space has a basis.
Every ï¬eld has a unique algebraic closure.
The Hahn-Banach Extension Theorem.
Tikhonovâ€™s Product Theorem for compact spaces.
The Countable Axiom of Choice
Many important consequences of the Axiom of Choice, particularly many
concerning the real numbers, can be proved from a weaker version of the
Axiom of Choice.
The Countable Axiom of Choice. Every countable family of nonempty
sets has a choice function.
For instance, the countable AC implies that the union of countably many
countable sets is countable. In particular, the real line is not a countable
union of countable sets. Similarly, it follows that â„µ1 is a regular cardinal. On
the other hand, the countable AC does not imply that the set of all reals can
be well-ordered.
Several basic theorems about Borel sets and Lebesgue measure use the
countable AC; for instance, one needs it to show that the union of count-
ably many FÏƒ sets is FÏƒ. In modern descriptive set theory one often works
without the Axiom of Choice and uses the countable AC instead. In some
instances, descriptive set theorists use a somewhat stronger principle (that
follows from AC):
The Principle of Dependent Choices (DC). If E is a binary relation
on a nonempty set A, and if for every a âˆˆA there exists b âˆˆA such that
b E a, then there is a sequence a0, a1, . . ., an, . . . in A such that
(5.4)
an+1 E an
for all n âˆˆN.
The Principle of Dependent Choices is stronger than the Countable Axiom
of Choice; see Exercise 5.7.
As an application of DC we have the following characterization of well-
founded relations and well-orderings:
Lemma 5.5.
(i) A linear ordering < of a set P is a well-ordering of P if and only if
there is no inï¬nite descending sequence
a0 > a1 > . . . > an > . . .
in A.

5. The Axiom of Choice and Cardinal Arithmetic
51
(ii) A relation E on P is well-founded if and only if there is no inï¬nite
sequence âŸ¨an : n âˆˆNâŸ©in P such that
(5.5)
an+1 E an
for all n âˆˆN.
Proof. Note that (i) is a special case of (ii) since a well-ordering is a well-
founded linear ordering.
If a0, a1, . . . , an, . . . is a sequence that satisï¬es (5.5), then the set {an :
n âˆˆN} has no E-minimal element and hence E is not well-founded.
Conversely, if E is not well-founded, then there is a nonempty set A âŠ‚P
with no E-minimal element. Using the Principle of Dependent Choices we
construct a sequence a0, a1, . . . , an, . . . that satisï¬es (5.5).
âŠ“âŠ”
Cardinal Arithmetic
In the presence of the Axiom of Choice, every set can be well-ordered and so
every inï¬nite set has the cardinality of some â„µÎ±. Thus addition and multipli-
cation of inï¬nite cardinal numbers is simple: If Îº and Î» are inï¬nite cardinals
then
Îº + Î» = Îº Â· Î» = max{Îº, Î»}.
The exponentiation of cardinals is more interesting. The rest of Chapter 5 is
devoted to the operations 2Îº and ÎºÎ», for inï¬nite cardinals Îº and Î».
Lemma 5.6. If 2 â‰¤Îº â‰¤Î» and Î» is inï¬nite, then ÎºÎ» = 2Î».
Proof.
2Î» â‰¤ÎºÎ» â‰¤(2Îº)Î» = 2ÎºÂ·Î» = 2Î».
âŠ“âŠ”
(5.6)

The Continuum Function
Cantorâ€™s Theorem 3.1 states that 2â„µÎ± > â„µÎ±, and therefore 2â„µÎ± â‰¥â„µÎ±+1, for
all Î±. The Generalized Continuum Hypothesis (GCH) is the statement
2â„µÎ± = â„µÎ±+1
for all Î±. GCH is independent of the axioms of ZFC. Under the assumption
of GCH, cardinal exponentiation is evaluated as follows:
Theorem 5.15. If GCH holds and Îº and Î» are inï¬nite cardinals then:
(i) If Îº â‰¤Î», then ÎºÎ» = Î»+.
(ii) If cf Îº â‰¤Î» < Îº, then ÎºÎ» = Îº+.
(iii) If Î» < cf Îº, then ÎºÎ» = Îº.
Proof. (i) Lemma 5.6.
(ii) This follows from (5.7) and (5.8).
(iii) By Lemma 3.9(ii), the set ÎºÎ» is the union of the sets Î±Î», Î± < Îº, and
|Î±Î»| â‰¤2|Î±|Â·Î» = (|Î±| Â· Î»)+ â‰¤Îº.
âŠ“âŠ”
The beth function is deï¬ned by induction:
â„¶0 = â„µ0,
â„¶Î±+1 = 2â„¶Î±,
â„¶Î± = sup{â„¶Î² : Î² < Î±}
if Î± is a limit ordinal.
Thus GCH is equivalent to the statement â„¶Î± = â„µÎ± for all Î±.
We shall now investigate the general behavior of the continuum func-
tion 2Îº, without assuming GCH.

and Î».
We start with the following observation: If Îº is a regular cardinal and

Thus

and so
ÎºÎ» = 

In particular, if Îº is a successor cardinal, we obtain the Hausdorï¬€formula
(5.22)
â„µâ„µÎ²
Î±+1 = â„µâ„µÎ²
Î± Â· â„µÎ±+1.
(Note that (5.22) holds for all Î± and Î².)
In general, we can compute ÎºÎ» using the following lemma. If Îº is a limit
cardinal, we use the notation limÎ±â†’Îº Î±Î» to abbreviate sup{ÂµÎ» : Âµ is a cardinal
and Âµ < Îº}.
Lemma 5.19. If Îº is a limit cardinal, and Î» â‰¥cf Îº, then
ÎºÎ» = (limÎ±â†’Îº Î±Î»)cf Îº.
Proof. Let Îº = 

âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 5.20. Let Î» be an inï¬nite cardinal. Then for all inï¬nite cardi-
nals Îº, the value of ÎºÎ» is computed as follows, by induction on Îº:
(i) If Îº â‰¤Î» then ÎºÎ» = 2Î».

(iii) If Îº > Î» and if ÂµÎ» < Îº for all Âµ < Îº, then:
(a) if cf Îº > Î» then ÎºÎ» = Îº,

a limit cardinal, we have limÎ±â†’Îº Î±Î» = Îº. If cf Îº > Î» then every f : Î» â†’Îº is
bounded and we have ÎºÎ» = limÎ±â†’Îº Î±Î» = Îº. If cf Îº â‰¤Î» then by Lemma 5.19,

In the Exercises, we list some properties of the gimel function.
A cardinal Îº is a strong limit cardinal if
2Î» < Îº
for every Î» < Îº.
Obviously, every strong limit cardinal is a limit cardinal. If the GCH holds,
then every limit cardinal is a strong limit.
It is easy to see that if Îº is a strong limit cardinal, then
Î»Î½ < Îº
for all Î», Î½ < Îº.
An example of a strong limit cardinal is â„µ0. Actually, the strong limit cardi-
nals form a proper class: If Î± is an arbitrary cardinal, then the cardinal
Îº = sup{Î±, 2Î±, 22Î±, . . . }
(of coï¬nality Ï‰) is a strong limit cardinal.
Another fact worth mentioning is:
(5.23)
If Îº is a strong limit cardinal, then 2Îº = Îºcf Îº.
We recall that Îº is weakly inaccessible if it is uncountable, regular, and
limit. We say that a cardinal Îº is inaccessible (strongly) if Îº > â„µ0, Îº is
regular, and Îº is strong limit.
Every inaccessible cardinal is weakly inaccessible. If the GCH holds, then
every weakly inaccessible cardinal Îº is inaccessible.
The inaccessible cardinals owe their name to the fact that they cannot be
obtained from smaller cardinals by the usual set-theoretical operations.
If Îº is inaccessible and |X| < Îº, then |P(X)| < Îº. If |S| < Îº and if |X| < Îº
for every X âˆˆS, then |  S| < Îº.
In fact, â„µ0 has this property too. Thus we can say that in a sense an
inaccessible cardinal is to smaller cardinals what â„µ0 is to ï¬nite cardinals.
This is one of the main themes of the theory of large cardinals.
The Singular Cardinal Hypothesis
The Singular Cardinal Hypothesis (SCH) is the statement: For every singular
cardinal Îº, if 2cf Îº < Îº, then Îºcf Îº = Îº+.
Obviously, the Singular Cardinals Hypothesis follows from GCH. If 2cf Îº â‰¥
Îº then Îºcf Îº = 2cf Îº. If 2cf Îº < Îº, then Îº+ is the least possible value of Îºcf Îº.

5. The Axiom of Choice and Cardinal Arithmetic
59
We shall prove later in the book that if SCH fails then a large cardinal
axiom holds. In fact, the failure of SCH is equiconsistent with the existence
of a certain large cardinal.
Under the assumption of SCH, cardinal exponentiation is determined by
the continuum function on regular cardinals:
Theorem 5.22. Assume that SCH holds.
(i) If Îº is a singular cardinal then
(a) 2Îº = 2<Îº if the continuum function is eventually constant below Îº,
(b) 2Îº = (2<Îº)+ otherwise.
(ii) If Îº and Î» are inï¬nite cardinals, then:
(a) If Îº â‰¤2Î» then ÎºÎ» = 2Î».
(b) If 2Î» < Îº and Î» < cf Îº then ÎºÎ» = Îº.
(c) If 2Î» < Îº and cf Îº â‰¤Î» then ÎºÎ» = Îº+.
Proof. (i) If Îº is a singular cardinal, then by Theorem 5.16, 2Îº is either Î»
or Î»cf Îº where Î» = 2<Îº. The latter occurs if 2Î± is not eventually constant
below Îº. Then cf Î» = cf Îº, and since 2cf Îº < 2<Îº = Î», we have Î»cf Î» = Î»+ by
the Singular Cardinals Hypothesis.
(ii) We proceed by induction on Îº, for a ï¬xed Î». Let Îº > 2Î». If Îº is
a successor cardinal, Îº = Î½+, then Î½Î» â‰¤Îº (by the induction hypothesis), and
ÎºÎ» = (Î½+)Î» = Î½+ Â· Î½Î» = Îº, by the Hausdorï¬€formula.
If Îº is a limit cardinal, then Î½Î» < Îº for all Î½ < Îº. By Theorem 5.20, ÎºÎ» = Îº
if Î» < cf Îº, and ÎºÎ» = Îºcf Îº if Î» â‰¥cf Îº, In the latter case, 2cf Îº â‰¤2Î» < Îº, and
by the Singular Cardinals Hypothesis, Îºcf Îº = Îº+.
âŠ“âŠ”

Historical Notes
The Axiom of Choice was formulated by Zermelo, who used it to prove the Well-
Ordering Theorem in [1904]. Zornâ€™s Lemma is as in Zorn [1935]; for a related prin-
ciple, see Kuratowski [1922]. (Hausdorï¬€in [1914], pp. 140â€“141, proved that every
partially ordered set has a maximal linearly ordered subset.) The Principle of De-
pendent Choices was formulated by Bernays in [1942].
KÂ¨onigâ€™s Theorem 5.10 appeared in J. KÂ¨onig [1905]. Corollary 5.17 was found
independently by BukovskÂ´y [1965] and Hechler. The discovery that cardinal expo-
nentiation is determined by the gimel function was made by BukovskÂ´y; cf. [1965].
The inductive computation of ÎºÎ» in Theorem 5.20 is as in Jech [1973a].
The Hausdorï¬€formula (5.22): Hausdorï¬€[1904].
Inaccessible cardinals were introduced in the paper by SierpiÂ´nski and Tar-
ski [1930]; see Tarski [1938] for more details.

6. The Axiom of Regularity
The Axiom of Regularity states that the relation âˆˆon any family of sets is
well-founded:
Axiom of Regularity. Every nonempty set has an âˆˆ-minimal element:
âˆ€S (S Ì¸= âˆ…â†’(âˆƒx âˆˆS) S âˆ©x = âˆ…).
As a consequence, there is no inï¬nite sequence
x0 âˆ‹x1 âˆ‹x2 âˆ‹. . . .
(Consider the set S = {x0, x1, x2, . . .} and apply the axiom.) In particular,
there is no set x such that
x âˆˆx
and there are no â€œcyclesâ€
x0 âˆˆx1 âˆˆ. . . âˆˆxn âˆˆx0.
Thus the Axiom of Regularity postulates that sets of certain type do no
exist. This restriction on the universe of sets is not contradictory (i.e., the
axiom is consistent with the other axioms) and is irrelevant for the devel-
opment of ordinal and cardinal numbers, natural and real numbers, and in
fact of all ordinary mathematics. However, it is extremely useful in the meta-
mathematics of set theory, in construction of models. In particular, all sets
can be assigned ranks and can be arranged in a cumulative hierarchy.
We recall that a set T is transitive if x âˆˆT implies x âŠ‚T .
Lemma 6.1. For every set S there exists a transitive set T âŠƒS.
Proof. We deï¬ne by induction
S0 = S,
Sn+1 =  Sn
and
(6.1)
T =
âˆ

n=0
Sn.
Clearly, T is transitive and T âŠƒS.

Part I. Basic Set Theory
Since every transitive set must satisfy  T âŠ‚T , it follows that the set
in (6.1) is the smallest transitive T âŠƒS; it is called transitive closure of S:
TC(S) = {T : T âŠƒS and T is transitive}.
Lemma 6.2. Every nonempty class C has an âˆˆ-minimal element.
Proof. Let S âˆˆC be arbitrary. If S âˆ©C = âˆ…, then S is a minimal element
of C; if S âˆ©C Ì¸= âˆ…, we let X = T âˆ©C where T = TC(S). X is a nonempty

It follows that x âˆ©C = âˆ…; otherwise, if y âˆˆx and y âˆˆC, then y âˆˆT since
T is transitive, and so y âˆˆx âˆ©T âˆ©C = x âˆ©X. Hence x is a minimal element
of C.

6. The Axiom of Regularity
65
(ii) rank(Î±) = Î±.
One of the uses of the rank function is a deï¬nition of equivalence classes
for equivalence relations on a proper class. The basic trick is the following:
Given a class C, let
(6.4)
Ë†C = {x âˆˆC : (âˆ€z âˆˆC) rank x â‰¤rank z}.
Ë†C is always a set, and if C is nonempty, then Ë†C is nonempty. Moreover,
(6.4) can be applied uniformly.
Thus, for example, if â‰¡is an equivalence on a proper class C, we ap-

[x] = {y âˆˆC : y â‰¡x and âˆ€z âˆˆC (z â‰¡x â†’rank y â‰¤rank z)}
and
C/â‰¡= {[x] : x âˆˆC}.
In particular, this trick enables us to deï¬ne isomorphism types for a given
isomorphism. For instance, one can deï¬ne order-types of linearly ordered sets,
or cardinal numbers (even without AC).
We use the same argument to prove the following.
Collection Principle.
(6.5)
âˆ€X âˆƒY (âˆ€u âˆˆX)[âˆƒv Ï•(u, v, p) â†’(âˆƒv âˆˆY ) Ï•(u, v, p)]
(p is a parameter).
The Collection Principle is a schema of formulas. We can formulate it as
follows:
Given a â€œcollection of classesâ€ Cu, u âˆˆX (X is a set), then there is a set Y
such that for every u âˆˆX,
if Cu Ì¸= âˆ…,
then Cu âˆ©Y Ì¸= âˆ….
To prove (6.5), we let
Y = 
uâˆˆX
Ë†Cu
where Cu = {v : Ï•(u, v, p)}, i.e.,
v âˆˆY â†”(âˆƒu âˆˆX)(Ï•(u, v, p) and âˆ€z (Ï•(u, z, p) â†’rankv â‰¤rank z)).
That Y is a set follows from the Replacement Schema.
Note that the Collection Principle implies the Replacement Schema:
Given a function F, then for every set X we let Y be a set such that
(âˆ€u âˆˆX)(âˆƒv âˆˆY ) F(u) = v.
Then
Fâ†¾X = F âˆ©(X Ã— Y )
is a set by the Separation Schema.

âˆˆ-Induction

(i) Î¦(âˆ…);

Then every x âˆˆT has property Î¦.
Proof. Let C be the class of all x âˆˆT that do not have the property Î¦. If

One consequence of the Axiom of Regularity is that the universe does not
admit nontrivial âˆˆ-automorphisms. More generally:

Well-Founded Relations
The notion of well-founded relations that was introduced in Chapter 2 can
be generalized to relations on proper classes, and one can extend the method
of induction to well-founded relations.
Let E be a binary relation on a class P. For each x âˆˆP, we let
extE(x) = {z âˆˆP : z E x}
the extension of x.
Deï¬nition 6.8. A relation E on P is well-founded, if:
(i) every nonempty set x âŠ‚P has an E-minimal element;
(ii) extE(x) is a set, for every x âˆˆP.
(6.9)
(Condition (ii) is vacuous if P is a set.) Note that the relation âˆˆis well-
founded on any class, by the Axiom of Regularity.
Lemma 6.9. If E is a well-founded relation on P, then every nonempty class
C âŠ‚P has an E-minimal element.
Proof. We follow the proof of Lemma 6.2; we are looking for x âˆˆC such that
extE(x) âˆ©C = âˆ…. Let S âˆˆC be arbitrary and assume that extE(S) âˆ©C Ì¸= âˆ….
We let X = T âˆ©C where
T =

and

As in Lemma 6.2, it follows that an E-minimal element x of X is E-minimal
in C.

Example 6.12 (The Rank Function). We deï¬ne, by induction, for all
