Ï(x) = sup{Ï(z) + 1 : z E x}
(compare with (2.7)). The range of Ï is either an ordinal or the class Ord.
For all x, y âˆˆP,
x E y â†’Ï(x) < Ï(y).
âŠ“âŠ”
Example 6.13 (The Transitive Collapse). By induction, let
Ï€(x) = {Ï€(z) : z E x}
for every x âˆˆP. The range of Ï€ is a transitive class, and for all x, y âˆˆP,
x E y â†’Ï€(x) âˆˆÏ€(y).
âŠ“âŠ”
The transitive collapse of a well-founded relation is not necessarily a one-
to-one function. It is one-to-one if E satisï¬es an additional condition, exten-
sionality.
Deï¬nition 6.14. A well-founded relation E on a class P is extensional if
(6.11)
extE(X) Ì¸= extE(Y )
whenever X and Y are distinct elements of P.
A class M is extensional if the relation âˆˆon M is extensional, i.e., if for
any distinct X and Y âˆˆM, X âˆ©M Ì¸= Y âˆ©M.

6. The Axiom of Regularity
69
The following theorem shows that the transitive collapse of an extensional
well-founded relation is one-to-one, and that every extensional class is âˆˆ-
isomorphic to a transitive class.
Theorem 6.15 (Mostowskiâ€™s Collapsing Theorem).
(i) If E is a well-founded and extensional relation on a class P, then there
is a transitive class M and an isomorphism Ï€ between (P, E) and
(M, âˆˆ). The transitive class M and the isomorphism Ï€ are unique.
(ii) In particular, every extensional class P is isomorphic to a transitive
class M. The transitive class M and the isomorphism Ï€ are unique.
(iii) In case (ii), if T âŠ‚P is transitive, then Ï€x = x for every x âˆˆT .
Proof. Since (ii) is a special case of (i) (E = âˆˆin case (ii)), we shall prove
the existence of an isomorphism in the general case.
Since E is a well-founded relation, we can deï¬ne Ï€ by well-founded induc-
tion (Theorem 6.11), i.e., Ï€(x) can be deï¬ned in terms of the Ï€(z)â€™s, where
z E x. We let, for each x âˆˆP
(6.12)
Ï€(x) = {Ï€(z) : z E x}.
In particular, in the case E = âˆˆ, (6.12) becomes
(6.13)
Ï€(x) = {Ï€(z) : z âˆˆx âˆ©P}.
The function Ï€ maps P onto a class M = Ï€(P), and it is immediate from the
deï¬nition (6.12) that M is transitive.
We use the extensionality of E to show that Ï€ is one-to-one. Let z âˆˆM
be of least rank such that z = Ï€(x) = Ï€(y) for some x Ì¸= y. Then extE(x) Ì¸=
extE(y) and there is, e.g., some u âˆˆextE(x) such that u /âˆˆextE(y). Let
t = Ï€(u). Since t âˆˆz = Ï€(y), there is v âˆˆextE(y) such that t = Ï€(v). Thus
we have t = Ï€(u) = Ï€(v), u Ì¸= v, and t is of lesser rank than z (since t âˆˆz).
A contradiction.
Now it follows easily that
(6.14)
x E y â†”Ï€(x) âˆˆÏ€(y).
If x E y, then Ï€(x) âˆˆÏ€(y) by deï¬nition (6.12). On the other hand, if Ï€(x) âˆˆ
Ï€(y), then by (6.12), Ï€(x) = Ï€(z) for some z E y. Since Ï€ is one-to-one, we
have x = z and so x E y.
The uniqueness of the isomorphism Ï€, and the transitive class M = Ï€(P),
follows from Theorem 6.7. If Ï€1 and Ï€2 are two isomorphisms of P and M1,
M2, respectively, then Ï€2Ï€âˆ’1
1
is an isomorphism between M1 and M2, and
therefore the identity mapping. Hence Ï€1 = Ï€2.
It remains to prove (iii). If T âŠ‚P is transitive, then we ï¬rst observe that
x âŠ‚P for every x âˆˆT and so x âˆ©P = x, and we have
Ï€(x) = {Ï€(z) : z âˆˆx}
for all x âˆˆT . It follows easily by âˆˆ-induction that Ï€(x) = x for all x âˆˆT .
âŠ“âŠ”

70
Part I. Basic Set Theory
The Bernays-GÂ¨odel Axiomatic Set Theory
There is an alternative axiomatization of set theory. We consider two types
of objects: sets (for which we use lower case letters) and classes (denoted by
capital letters).
A.
1. Extensionality: âˆ€u (u âˆˆX â†”y âˆˆY ) â†’X = Y .
2. Every set is a class.
3. If X âˆˆY , then X is a set.
4. Pairing: For any sets x and y there is a set {x, y}.
B. Comprehension:
âˆ€X1 . . . âˆ€Xn âˆƒY Y = {x : Ï•(x, X1, . . . , Xn)}
where Ï• is a formula in which only set variables are quantiï¬ed.
C.
1. Inï¬nity: There is an inï¬nite set.
2. Union: For every set x the set  x exists.
3. Power Set: For every set x the power set P(x) of x exists.
4. Replacement: If a class F is a function and x is a set, then {F(z) :
z âˆˆx} is a set.
D. Regularity.
E. Choice: There is a function F such that F(x) âˆˆx for every nonempty
set x.
Let BG denote the axiomatic theory Aâ€“D and let BGC denote BG +
Choice.
If a set-theoretical statement is provable in ZF (ZFC), then it is provable
in BG (BGC).
On the other hand, a theorem of Shoenï¬eld (using proof-theoretic meth-
ods) states that if a sentence involving only set variables is provable in BG,
then it is provable in ZF. This result can be extended to BGC/ZFC using
the method of forcing.
Exercises
6.1. rank(x) = sup{rank(z) + 1 : z âˆˆx}.
6.2. |VÏ‰| = â„µ0, |VÏ‰+Î±| = â„¶Î±.
6.3. If Îº is inaccessible, then |VÎº| = Îº.
6.4. If x and y have rank â‰¤Î± then {x, y}, âŸ¨x, yâŸ©, x âˆªy, S x, P(x), and xy have
rank < Î± + Ï‰
6.5. The sets Z, Q, R are in VÏ‰+Ï‰.
6.6. Let B be the class of all x that are hereditarily in the class A. Show that
(i) x âˆˆB if and only if TC(x) âŠ‚A,
(ii) B is the largest transitive class B âŠ‚A.

6. The Axiom of Regularity
71
Historical Notes
The Axiom of Regularity was introduced by von Neumann in [1925], although a sim-
ilar principle had been considered previously by Skolem (see [1970], pp. 137â€“152).
The concept of rank appears ï¬rst in Mirimanov [1917]. The transitive collapse is
deï¬ned in Mostowski [1949]. Induction on well-founded relations (Theorems 6.10,
6.11) was formulated by Montague in [1955].
The axiomatic system BG was introduced by Bernays in [1937]. Shoenï¬eldâ€™s
result was published in [1954].
For more references on the history of axioms of set theory consult Fraenkel et
al. [1973].

7. Filters, Ultraï¬lters and Boolean Algebras
Filters and Ultraï¬lters
Filters and ideals play an important role in several mathematical disciplines
(algebra, topology, logic, measure theory). In this chapter we introduce the
notion of ï¬lter (and ideal) on a given set. The notion of ideal extrapolates
the notion of small sets: Given an ideal I on S, a set X âŠ‚S is considered
small if it belongs to I.
Deï¬nition 7.1. A ï¬lter on a nonempty set S is a collection F of subsets
of S such that
(i) S âˆˆF and âˆ…/âˆˆF,
(ii) if X âˆˆF and Y âˆˆF, then X âˆ©Y âˆˆF,
(iii) If X, Y âŠ‚S, X âˆˆF, and X âŠ‚Y , then Y âˆˆF.
(7.1)
An ideal on a nonempty set S is a collection I of subsets of S such that:
(i) âˆ…âˆˆI and S /âˆˆI,
(ii) if X âˆˆI and Y âˆˆI, then X âˆªY âˆˆI,
(iii) if X, Y âŠ‚S, X âˆˆI, and Y âŠ‚X, then Y âˆˆI.
(7.2)
If F is a ï¬lter on S, then the set I = {S âˆ’X : X âˆˆF} is an ideal on S; and
conversely, if I is an ideal, then F = {S âˆ’X : X âˆˆI} is a ï¬lter. If this is the
case we say that F and I are dual to each other.
Examples. 1. A trivial ï¬lter: F = {S}.
2. A principal ï¬lter. Let X0 be a nonempty subset of S. The ï¬lter F =
{X âŠ‚S : X âŠƒX0} is a principal ï¬lter. Note that every ï¬lter on a ï¬nite set
is principal.
The dual notions are a trivial ideal and a principal ideal.
3. The FrÂ´echet ï¬lter. Let S be an inï¬nite set, and let I be the ideal of all
ï¬nite subsets of S. The dual ï¬lter F = {X âŠ‚S : S âˆ’X is ï¬nite} is called
the FrÂ´echet ï¬lter on S. Note that the FrÂ´echet ï¬lter is not principal.
4. Let A be an inï¬nite set and let S = [A]<Ï‰ be the set of all ï¬nite subsets
of A. For each P âˆˆS, let Ë†P = {Q âˆˆS : P âŠ‚Q}. Let F be the set of all
X âŠ‚S such that X âŠƒË†P for some P âˆˆS. Then F is a nonprincipal ï¬lter
on S.

74
Part I. Basic Set Theory
5. A set A âŠ‚N has density 0 if limnâ†’âˆ|A âˆ©n|/n = 0. The set of all A
of density 0 is an ideal on N.
A family G of sets has the ï¬nite intersection property if every ï¬nite H =
{X1, . . . , Xn} âŠ‚G has a nonempty intersection X1 âˆ©. . . âˆ©Xn Ì¸= âˆ…. Every
ï¬lter has the ï¬nite intersection property.
Lemma 7.2.
(i) If F is a nonempty family of ï¬lters on S, then  F is a ï¬lter on S.
(ii) If C is a âŠ‚-chain of ï¬lters on S, then  C is a ï¬lter on S.
(iii) If G âŠ‚P(S) has the ï¬nite intersection property, then there is a ï¬lter F
on S such that G âŠ‚F.
Proof. (i) and (ii) are easy to verify.
(iii) Let F be the set of all X âŠ‚S such that there is a ï¬nite H = {X1, . . . ,
Xn} âŠ‚G with X1 âˆ©. . . âˆ©Xn âŠ‚X. Then F is a ï¬lter and F âŠƒG.
âŠ“âŠ”
Since every ï¬lter F âŠƒG must contain all ï¬nite intersections of sets in G,
it follows that the ï¬lter F constructed in the proof of Lemma 7.2(iii) is the
smallest ï¬lter on S that extends G:
F = {D : D is a ï¬lter on S and G âŠ‚D}.
We say that the ï¬lter F is generated by G.
Deï¬nition 7.3. A ï¬lter U on a set S is an ultraï¬lter if
(7.3)
for every X âŠ‚S, either X âˆˆU or S âˆ’X âˆˆU.
The dual notion is a prime ideal: For every X âŠ‚S, either X âˆˆI or Sâˆ’X âˆˆI.
Note that I = P(S) âˆ’U.
A ï¬lter F on S is maximal if there is no ï¬lter F â€² on S such that F âŠ‚F â€²
and F Ì¸= F â€².
Lemma 7.4. A ï¬lter F on S is an ultraï¬lter if and only if it is maximal.
Proof. (a) An ultraï¬lter U is clearly a maximal ï¬lter: Assume that U âŠ‚F
and X âˆˆF âˆ’U. Then S âˆ’X âˆˆU, and so both S âˆ’X âˆˆF and X âˆˆF,
a contradiction.
(b) Let F be a ï¬lter that is not an ultraï¬lter. We will show that F is not
maximal. Let Y âŠ‚S be such that neither Y nor S âˆ’Y is in F. Consider the
family G = F âˆª{Y }; we claim that G has the ï¬nite intersection property.
If X âˆˆF, then X âˆ©Y Ì¸= âˆ…, for otherwise we would have S âˆ’Y âŠƒX and
S âˆ’Y âˆˆF. Thus, if X1, . . . , Xn âˆˆF, we have X1 âˆ©. . . âˆ©Xn âˆˆF and so
Y âˆ©X1 âˆ©. . . âˆ©Xn Ì¸= âˆ…. Hence G has the ï¬nite intersection property, and by
Lemma 7.2(iii) there is a ï¬lter F â€² âŠƒG. Since Y âˆˆF â€² âˆ’F, F is not maximal.

Theorem 7.5 (Tarski). Every ï¬lter can be extended to an ultraï¬lter.
Proof. Let F0 be a ï¬lter on S. Let P be the set of all ï¬lters F on S such
that F âŠƒF0 and consider the partially ordered set (P, âŠ‚). If C is a chain
in P, then by Lemma 7.2(ii),  C is a ï¬lter and hence an upper bound of C
in P. By Zornâ€™s Lemma there exists a maximal element U in P. This U is an
ultraï¬lter by Lemma 7.4.
âŠ“âŠ”
For every a âˆˆS, the principal ï¬lter {X âŠ‚S : a âˆˆX} is an ultraï¬lter. If
S is ï¬nite, then every ultraï¬lter on S is principal.
If S is inï¬nite, then there is a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on S: If U extends
the FrÂ´echet ï¬lter, then U is nonprincipal.
The proof of Theorem 7.5 uses the Axiom of Choice. We shall see later
that the existence of nonprincipal ultraï¬lters cannot be proved without AC.
If S is an inï¬nite set of cardinality Îº, then because every ultraï¬lter on S
is a subset of P(S), there are at most 22Îº ultraï¬lters on S. The next theorem
shows that the number of ultraï¬lters on Îº is exactly 22Îº. To get a slightly
stronger result, let us call an ultraï¬lter D on Îº uniform if |X| = Îº for all
X âˆˆD.

form ultraï¬lters on Îº.

intersection

has cardinality Îº.
Lemma 7.7. There exists an independent family of subsets of Îº of cardinal-

Ultraï¬lters on Ï‰
We present two properties of ultraï¬lters on Ï‰ that are frequently used in
set-theoretic topology.
Let D be a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Ï‰. D is called a p-point if for every
partition {An : n âˆˆÏ‰} of Ï‰ into â„µ0 pieces such that An /âˆˆD for all n, there
exists X âˆˆD such that X âˆ©An is ï¬nite, for all n âˆˆÏ‰.
First we notice that it is easy to ï¬nd a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter that is not
a p-point: Let {An : n âˆˆÏ‰} be any partition of Ï‰ into â„µ0 inï¬nite pieces, and
let F be the following ï¬lter on Ï‰:
X âˆˆF if and only if except for ï¬nitely many n, X âˆ©An contains all
but ï¬nitely many elements of An.
(7.6)
If D is any ultraï¬lter extending F, then D is not a p-point.
Theorem 7.8 below shows that existence of p-points follows from the Con-
tinuum Hypothesis. By a result of Shelah there exists a model of ZFC in which
there are no p-points.
A nonprincipal ultraï¬lter D on Ï‰ is a Ramsey ultraï¬lter if for every
partition {An : n âˆˆÏ‰} of Ï‰ into â„µ0 pieces such that An /âˆˆD for all n, there
exists X âˆˆD such that X âˆ©An has one element for all n âˆˆÏ‰.
Every Ramsey ultraï¬lter is a p-point.
Theorem 7.8. If 2â„µ0 = â„µ1, then a Ramsey ultraï¬lter exists.

More generally, if Îº is a regular uncountable cardinal, and F is a ï¬lter on S,

A Ïƒ-complete ï¬lter is the same as an â„µ1-complete ï¬lter.

is the smallest Îº-complete ideal on S containing all singletons {a}.
The question whether a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on a set can be Ïƒ-complete
gives rise to deep investigations of the foundations of set theory. In particular,
if such ultraï¬lters exist, then there exist large cardinals (inaccessible, etc.).

Part I. Basic Set Theory
Boolean Algebras
An algebra of sets (see Deï¬nition 4.9) is a collection of subsets of a given
nonempty set that is closed under unions, intersections and complements.
These properties of algebras of sets are abstracted in the notion of Boolean
algebra:
Deï¬nition 7.9. A Boolean algebra is a set B with at least two elements, 0
and 1, endowed with binary operations + and Â· and a unary operation âˆ’.
The Boolean operations satisfy the following axioms:
(7.9)
u + v = v + u,
u Â· v = v Â· u,
(commutativity)
u + (v + w) = (u + v) + w,
u Â· (v Â· w) = (u Â· v) Â· w,
(associativity)
u Â· (v + w) = u Â· v + u Â· w,
u + (v Â· w) = (u + v) Â· (u + w),
(distributivity)
u Â· (u + v) = u,
u + (u Â· v) = u,
(absorption)
u + (âˆ’u) = 1,
u Â· (âˆ’u) = 0.
(complementation)
An algebra of sets S, with  S = S, is a Boolean algebra, with Boolean
operations XâˆªY , Xâˆ©Y and Sâˆ’X, and with âˆ…and S being 0 and 1. If follows
from Stoneâ€™s Representation Theorem below that every Boolean algebra is
isomorphic to an algebra of sets.
From the axioms (7.9) one can derive additional Boolean algebraic rules
that correspond to rules for the set operations âˆª, âˆ©and âˆ’. Among others,
we have
u + u = u,
u Â· u = u,
u + 0 = u,
u Â· 0 = 0,
u + 1 = 1,
u Â· 1 = u
and the De Morgan laws
âˆ’(u + v) = âˆ’u Â· âˆ’v,
âˆ’(u Â· v) = âˆ’u + âˆ’v.
Two elements u, v âˆˆB are disjoint if u Â· v = 0. Let us deï¬ne
u âˆ’v = u Â· (âˆ’v),
and
(7.10)
u â‰¤v
if and only if
u âˆ’v = 0.
It is easy to see that â‰¤is a partial ordering of B and that
u â‰¤v
if and only if
u + v = v
if and only if
u Â· v = u.
Moreover, 1 is the greatest element of B and 0 is the least element. Also, for
any u, v âˆˆB, u + v is the least upper bound of {u, v} and u Â· v is the greatest

7. Filters, Ultraï¬lters and Boolean Algebras
79
lower bound of {u, v}. Since âˆ’u is the unique v such that u + v = 1 and
u Â· v = 0, it follows that all Boolean-algebraic operations can be deï¬ned in
terms of the partial ordering of B.
We shall now give an example showing the relation between Boolean al-
gebras and logic:
Let L be a ï¬rst order language and let S be the set of all sentences of L. We
consider the equivalence relation âŠ¢Ï• â†”Ïˆ on S. The set B of all equivalence
classes [Ï•] is a Boolean algebra under the following operations:
[Ï•] + [Ïˆ] = [Ï• âˆ¨Ïˆ],
0 = [Ï• âˆ§Â¬Ï•],
[Ï•] Â· [Ïˆ] = [Ï• âˆ§Ïˆ],
1 = [Ï• âˆ¨Â¬Ï•].
âˆ’[Ï•] = [Â¬Ï•],
This algebra is called the Lindenbaum algebra.
A subset A of a Boolean algebra B is a subalgebra if it contains 0 and 1
and is closed under the Boolean operations:
(i) 0 âˆˆA, 1 âˆˆA;
(ii) if u, v âˆˆA, then u + v âˆˆA, u Â· v âˆˆA, âˆ’u âˆˆA.
(7.11)
If X âŠ‚B, then there is a smallest subalgebra A of B that contains X; A can
be described either as {A : X âŠ‚A âŠ‚B and A is a subalgebra}, or as the
set of all Boolean combinations in B of elements of X. The subalgebra A is
generated by X. If X is inï¬nite, then |A| = |X|. See Exercises 7.18â€“7.20.
If B is a Boolean algebra, let B+ = B âˆ’{0} denote the set of all nonzero
elements of B. If a âˆˆB+, the set Bâ†¾a = {u âˆˆB : u â‰¤a} with the partial
order inherited from B, is a Boolean algebra; its + and Â· are the same as in B,
and the complement of u is a âˆ’u. An element a âˆˆB is called an atom if it is
a minimal element of B+; equivalently, if there is no x such that 0 < x < a.
A Boolean algebra is atomic if for every u âˆˆB+ there is an atom a â‰¤u; B is
atomless if it has no atoms.
Let B and C be two Boolean algebras. A mapping h : B â†’C is a homo-
morphism if it preserves the operations:
(i) h(0) = 0, h(1) = 1,
(ii) h(u + v) = h(u) + h(v), h(u Â· v) = h(u) Â· h(v), h(âˆ’u) = âˆ’h(u).
(7.12)
Note that the range of a homomorphism is a subalgebra of C and that
h(u) â‰¤h(v) whenever u â‰¤v. A one-to-one homomorphism of B onto C
is called an isomorphism. An embedding of B in C is an isomorphism of B
onto a subalgebra of C. Note that if h : B â†’C is a one-to-one mapping
such that u â‰¤v if and only if h(u) â‰¤h(v), then h is an isomorphism. An
isomorphism of a Boolean algebra onto itself is called an automorphism.

Ideals and Filters on Boolean Algebras
The deï¬nition of ï¬lter (and ideal) given earlier in this chapter generalizes to
arbitrary Boolean algebras. Let B be a Boolean algebra. An ideal on B is
a subset I of B such that:
(i) 0 âˆˆI, 1 /âˆˆI;
(ii) if u âˆˆI and v âˆˆI, then u + v âˆˆI;
(iii) if u, v âˆˆB, u âˆˆI and v â‰¤u, then v âˆˆI.
(7.13)
A ï¬lter on B is a subset F of B such that:
(i) 1 âˆˆF, 0 /âˆˆF;
(ii) if u âˆˆF and v âˆˆF, then u Â· v âˆˆF;
(iii) if u, v âˆˆB, u âˆˆF and u â‰¤v, then v âˆˆF.
(7.14)
The trivial ideal is the ideal {0}; an ideal is principal if I = {u âˆˆB :
u â‰¤u0} for some u0 Ì¸= 1. Similarly for ï¬lters.
A subset G of B âˆ’{0} has the ï¬nite intersection property if for every
ï¬nite {u1, . . . , un} âŠ‚G, u1 Â· . . . Â· un Ì¸= 0. Every G âŠ‚B that has the ï¬nite
intersection property generates a ï¬lter on B; this and the other two clauses
of Lemma 7.2 hold also for Boolean algebras.
There is a relation between ideals and homomorphisms. If h : B â†’C is
a homomorphism, then
(7.15)
I = {u âˆˆB : h(u) = 0}
is an ideal on B (the kernel of the homomorphism). On the other hand, let
I be an ideal on B. Let us consider the following equivalence relation on B:
(7.16)
u âˆ¼v
if and only if
u â–³v âˆˆI
where
u â–³v = (u âˆ’v) + (v âˆ’u).
Let C be the set of all equivalence classes, C = B/âˆ¼, and endow C with the
following operations:
(7.17)
[u] + [v] = [u + v],
0 = [0],
[u] Â· [v] = [u Â· v],
1 = [1].
âˆ’[u] = [âˆ’u],
Then C is a Boolean algebra, the quotient of B mod I, and is a homomorphic
image of B under the homomorphism
(7.18)
h(u) = [u].
The quotient algebra is denoted B/I.

7. Filters, Ultraï¬lters and Boolean Algebras
81
An ideal I on B is a prime ideal if
(7.19)
for every u âˆˆB, either u âˆˆI or âˆ’u âˆˆI.
The dual of a prime ideal is an ultraï¬lter.
Lemma 7.4 holds in general: An ideal is a prime ideal (and a ï¬lter is an
ultraï¬lter) if and only if it is maximal. Also, an ideal I on B is prime if and
only if the quotient of B mod I is the trivial algebra {0, 1}.
Tarskiâ€™s Theorem 7.5 easily generalizes to Boolean algebras:
Theorem 7.10 (The Prime Ideal Theorem). Every ideal on B can be
extended to a prime ideal.
âŠ“âŠ”
The proof of the Prime Ideal Theorem uses the Axiom of Choice. It is
known that the theorem cannot be proved without using the Axiom of Choice.
However, it is also known that the Prime Ideal Theorem is weaker than the
Axiom of Choice.
Theorem 7.11 (Stoneâ€™s Representation Theorem). Every Boolean al-
gebra is isomorphic to an algebra of sets.
Proof. Let B be a Boolean algebra. We let
(7.20)
S = {p : p is an ultraï¬lter on B}.
For every u âˆˆB, let Xu be the set of all p âˆˆS such that u âˆˆp. Let
(7.21)
S = {Xu : u âˆˆB}.
Let us consider the mapping Ï€(u) = Xu from B onto S. Clearly, Ï€(1) = S
and Ï€(0) = âˆ…. It follows from the deï¬nition of ultraï¬lter that
Ï€(u Â· v) = Ï€(u) âˆ©Ï€(v),
Ï€(u + v) = Ï€(u) âˆªÏ€(v),
Ï€(âˆ’u) = S âˆ’Ï€(u).
Thus Ï€ is a homomorphism of B onto the algebra of sets S. It remains to
show that Ï€ is one-to-one.
If u Ì¸= v, then using the Prime Ideal Theorem, one can ï¬nd an ultraï¬lter p
on B containing one of these two elements but not the other. Thus Ï€ is an
isomorphism.
âŠ“âŠ”
Complete Boolean Algebras
The partial ordering â‰¤of a Boolean algebra can be used to deï¬ne inï¬nitary
operations on B, generalizing + and Â· . Let us recall that u + v = sup{u, v}

82
Part I. Basic Set Theory
and u Â· v = inf{u, v} in the partial ordering of B. Thus for any nonempty
X âŠ‚B, we deï¬ne
(7.22)
{u : u âˆˆX} = sup X
and
{u : u âˆˆX} = inf X,
provided that the least upper bound (the greatest lower bound) exists. We
also deï¬ne  âˆ…= 0 and  âˆ…= 1.
If the inï¬nitary sum and product is deï¬ned for all X âŠ‚B, the Boolean al-
gebra is called complete. Similarly, we call B Îº-complete (where Îº is a regular
uncountable cardinal) if sums and products exist for all X of cardinality < Îº.
An â„µ1-complete Boolean algebra is called Ïƒ-complete or countably complete.
An algebra of sets S is Îº-complete if it is closed under unions and inter-
sections of < Îº sets. A Îº-complete algebra of sets is a Îº-complete Boolean
algebra and for every X âŠ‚S such that |X| < Îº,  X =  X.
An ideal I on a Îº-complete Boolean algebra is Îº-complete if
{u : u âˆˆX} âˆˆI
whenever X âŠ‚I and |X| < Îº. A Îº-complete ï¬lter is the dual notion.
If I is a Îº-complete ideal on a Îº-complete Boolean algebra B, then B/I is
Îº-complete, and
{[u] : u âˆˆX} = [ {u : u âˆˆX}]
for every X âŠ‚B, |X| < Îº. Similarly for products.
An â„µ1-complete ideal is called a Ïƒ-ideal.
There are two important examples of Ïƒ-ideals on the Boolean algebra of
all Borel sets of reals: the Ïƒ-ideal of Borel sets of Lebesgue measure 0, and
the Ïƒ-ideal of meager Borel sets. (Exercises 7.14 and 7.15.)
Let A be a subalgebra of a Boolean algebra B. A is a dense subalgebra
of B if for every u âˆˆB+ there is a v âˆˆA+ such that v â‰¤u.
A completion of a Boolean algebra B is a complete Boolean algebra C
such that B is a dense subalgebra of C.
Lemma 7.12. The completion of a Boolean algebra B is unique up to iso-
morphism.
Proof. Let C and D be completions of B. We deï¬ne an isomorphism Ï€ : C â†’
D by
(7.23)
Ï€(c) = D{u âˆˆB : u â‰¤c}.
To verify that Ï€ is an isomorphism, one uses the fact that B is a dense
subalgebra of both C and D. For example, to show that Ï€(c) Ì¸= 0 whenever
c Ì¸= 0: There is u âˆˆB such that 0 < u â‰¤c, and we have 0 < u â‰¤Ï€(c).
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 7.13. Every Boolean algebra has a completion.

7. Filters, Ultraï¬lters and Boolean Algebras
83
Proof. We use a construction similar to the method of Dedekind cuts. Let A
be a Boolean algebra. Let us call a set U âŠ‚A+ a cut if
(7.24)
p â‰¤q and q âˆˆU implies p âˆˆU.
For every p âˆˆA+, let Up denote the cut {x : x â‰¤p}.
A cut U is regular if
(7.25)
whenever p /âˆˆU, then there exists q â‰¤p such that Uq âˆ©U = âˆ….
Note that every Up is regular, and that every cut includes some Up.
We let B be the set of all regular cuts in A+. We claim that B, under the
partial ordering by inclusion, is a complete Boolean algebra. Note that the
intersection of any collection of regular cuts is a regular cut, and hence each
cut U is included in a least regular cut U. In fact,
U = {p : (âˆ€q â‰¤p) U âˆ©Uq Ì¸= âˆ…}.
Thus for u, v âˆˆB we have
u Â· v = u âˆ©v,
u + v = u âˆªv.
The complement of u âˆˆB is the regular cut
âˆ’u = {p : Up âˆ©u = âˆ…}.
And, of course, âˆ…and A+ are the zero and the unit of B. It is not diï¬ƒcult to
verify that B is a complete Boolean algebra, and we leave the veriï¬cation to
the reader.
Furthermore, for all p, q âˆˆA+ we have Up + Uq = Up+q, Up Â· Uq = UpÂ·q
and âˆ’Up = Uâˆ’p. Thus A embeds in B as a dense subalgebra.
âŠ“âŠ”
Complete and Regular Subalgebras
Let B be a complete Boolean algebra. A subalgebra A of B is a complete
subalgebra if  X âˆˆA and  X âˆˆA for all X âŠ‚A. (Caution: A subalgebra A
of B that is itself complete is not necessarily a complete subalgebra of B.)
Similarly, a complete homomorphism is a homomorphism h of B into C such
that for all X âŠ‚B,
(7.26)
h( X) =  h(X),
h( X) =  h(X).
A complete embedding is an embedding that satisï¬es (7.26). Note that every
isomorphism is complete.
Since the intersection of any collection of complete subalgebras of B is
a complete subalgebra, every X âŠ‚B is included in a smallest complete sub-
algebra of B. This algebra is called the complete subalgebra of B completely
generated by X.

84
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Deï¬nition 7.14. A set W âŠ‚B+ is an antichain in a Boolean algebra B if
u Â· v = 0 for all distinct u, v âˆˆW.
If W is an antichain and if  W = u then we say that W is a partition
of u. A partition of 1 is just a partition, or a maximal antichain.
If B is a Boolean algebra and A is a subalgebra of B then an antichain
in A that is maximal in A need not be maximal in B. If every maximal
antichain in A is also maximal in B, then A is called a regular subalgebra
of B.
If A is a complete subalgebra of a complete Boolean algebra B then A is
a regular subalgebra of B. Also, if A is a dense subalgebra of B then A is
a regular subalgebra. See also Exercise 7.31.
Saturation
Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal. A Boolean algebra B is Îº-saturated if there is
no partition W of B such that |W| = Îº, and
(7.27)
sat(B) = the least Îº such that B is Îº-saturated.
B is also said to satisfy the Îº-chain condition; this is because if B is complete,
B is Îº-saturated if and only if there exists no descending Îº-sequence u0 >
u1 > . . . > uÎ± > . . ., Î± < Îº, of elements of B. The â„µ1-chain condition is
called the countable chain condition (c.c.c.).
Theorem 7.15. If B is an inï¬nite complete Boolean algebra, then sat(B) is
a regular uncountable cardinal.
Proof. Let Îº = sat(B). It is clear that Îº is uncountable. Let us assume that
Îº is singular; we shall obtain a contradiction by constructing a partition of
size Îº.
For u âˆˆB, u Ì¸= 0, let sat(u) denote sat(Bu). Let us call u âˆˆB stable if
sat(v) = sat(u) for every nonzero v â‰¤u. The set S of stable elements is dense
in B; otherwise, there would be a descending sequence u0 > u1 > u2 > . . .
with decreasing cardinals sat(u0) > sat(u1) > . . .. Let T be a maximal set of
pairwise disjoint elements of S. Thus T is a partition of B, and |T | < Îº.
First we show that sup{sat(u) : u âˆˆT } = Îº. For every regular Î» < Îº such
that Î» > |T |, consider a partition W of B of size Î». Then at least one u âˆˆT
is partitioned by W into Î» pieces.
Thus we consider two cases:
Case I. There is u âˆˆT such that sat(u) = Îº. Since cf Îº < Îº, there is a par-
tition W of u of size cf Îº: W = {uÎ± : Î± < cf Îº}. Let ÎºÎ±, Î± < cf Îº, be an
increasing sequence with limit Îº. For each Î±, sat(uÎ±) = sat(u) = Îº and so let
WÎ± be a partition of uÎ± of size ÎºÎ±. Then 
Î±<cf Îº WÎ± is a partition of u of
size Îº.

Historical Notes
The notion of ï¬lter is, according to Kuratowskiâ€™s book [1966], due to H. Cartan.
Theorem 7.5 was ï¬rst proved by Tarski in [1930].
Theorem 7.6 is due to PospÂ´Ä±Ë‡sil [1937]; the present proof uses independent sets
(Lemma 7.7); cf. Fichtenholz and Kantorovich [1935] (Îº = Ï‰) and Hausdorï¬€[1936b].
W. Rudin [1956] proved that p-points exist if 2â„µ0 = â„µ1, a recent result of Shelah
shows that existence of p-points is unprovable in ZFC. Galvin showed that 2â„µ0 = â„µ1
implies the existence of Ramsey ultraï¬lters.
Facts about Boolean algebras can be found in Handbook of Boolean alge-
bras [1989] which also contains an extensive bibliography. The Representation The-
orem for Boolean algebras as well as the existence of the completion (Theorems 7.11
and 7.13) are due to Stone [1936]. Theorem 7.15 on saturation was proved by ErdËos
and Tarski [1943].
Exercise 7.8: Booth [1970/71].
Exercise 7.10: FrolÂ´Ä±k [1968], M. E. Rudin [1971].
The Rudin-Keisler equivalence was ï¬rst studied by W. Rudin in [1956]; the
study of the Rudin-Keisler ordering was initiated by M. E. Rudin [1966].
Exercise 7.25: Makinson [1969].
Exercises 7.29 and 7.30: Sikorski [1964].
Exercise 7.32: Pierce [1958]. The assumption can be weakened to â€œÏƒ-complete,â€
see Comfort and Hager [1972].

8. Stationary Sets
In this chapter we develop the theory of closed unbounded and stationary
subsets of a regular uncountable cardinal, and its generalizations.
Closed Unbounded Sets
If X is a set of ordinals and Î± > 0 is a limit ordinal then Î± is a limit point
of X if sup(X âˆ©Î±) = Î±.
Deï¬nition 8.1. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal. A set C âŠ‚Îº is
a closed unbounded subset of Îº if C is unbounded in Îº and if it contains all
its limit points less than Îº.
A set S âŠ‚Îº is stationary if Sâˆ©C Ì¸= âˆ…for every closed unbounded subset C
of Îº.
An unbounded set C âŠ‚Îº is closed if and only if for every sequence
Î±0 < Î±1 < . . . < Î±Î¾ < . . . (Î¾ < Î³) of elements of C, of length Î³ < Îº, we have
limÎ¾â†’Î³ Î±Î¾ âˆˆC.
Lemma 8.2. If C and D are closed unbounded, then C âˆ©D is closed un-
bounded.
Proof. It is immediate that Câˆ©D is closed. To show that Câˆ©D is unbounded,
let Î± < Îº. Since C is unbounded, there exists an Î±1 > Î± with Î±1 âˆˆC.
Similarly there exists an Î±2 > Î±1 with Î±2 âˆˆD. In this fashion, we construct
an increasing sequence
(8.1)
Î± < Î±1 < Î±2 < . . . < Î±n < . . .
such that Î±1, Î±3, Î±5, . . . âˆˆC, Î±2, Î±4, Î±6, . . . âˆˆD. If we let Î² be the limit of
the sequence (8.1), then Î² < Îº, and Î² âˆˆC and Î² âˆˆD.
âŠ“âŠ”
The collection of all closed unbounded subsets of Îº has the ï¬nite inter-
section property. The ï¬lter generated by the closed unbounded sets consists
of all X âŠ‚Îº that contain a closed unbounded subset. We call this ï¬lter the
closed unbounded ï¬lter on Îº.

Part I. Basic Set Theory
The set of all limit ordinals Î± < Îº is closed unbounded in Îº. If A is an
unbounded subset of Îº, then the set of all limit points Î± < Îº of A is closed
unbounded.
A function f : Îº â†’Îº is normal if it is increasing and continuous (f(Î±) =
limÎ¾â†’Î± f(Î¾) for every nonzero limit Î± < Îº). The range of a normal function
is a closed unbounded set. Conversely, if C is closed unbounded, there is
a unique normal function that enumerates C.
The closed unbounded ï¬lter on Îº is Îº-complete:

Mahlo Cardinals
Let Îº be an inaccessible cardinal. The set of all cardinals below Îº is a closed
unbounded subset of Îº, and so is the set of its limit points, the set of all
limit cardinals. In fact, the set of all strong limit cardinals below Îº is closed
unbounded.
If Îº is the least inaccessible cardinal, then all strong limit cardinals below Îº
are singular, and so the set of all singular strong limit cardinals below Îº is
closed unbounded. If Îº is the Î±th inaccessible, where Î± < Îº, then still the set
of all regular cardinals below Îº is nonstationary.
An inaccessible cardinal Îº is called a Mahlo cardinal if the set of all regular
cardinals below Îº is stationary.

96
Part I. Basic Set Theory
(Then the set of all inaccessibles below Îº is stationary, and Îº is the Îºth
inaccessible cardinal.)
Similarly, we deï¬ne a weakly Mahlo cardinal as a cardinal Îº that is weakly
inaccessible and the set of all regular cardinals bellow Îº is stationary (then
the set of all weakly inaccessibles is stationary in Îº).
Normal Filters
Let F be a ï¬lter on a cardinal Îº; F is normal if it is closed under diagonal
intersections:
(8.7)
if XÎ± âˆˆF for all Î± < Îº,
then â–³Î±<Îº XÎ± âˆˆF.
An ideal I on Îº is normal if the dual ï¬lter is normal.
The closed unbounded ï¬lter is Îº-complete and normal, and contains all
complements of bounded sets. It is the smallest such ï¬lter on Îº:
Lemma 8.11. If Îº is regular and uncountable and if F is a normal ï¬lter
on Îº that contains all ï¬nal segments {Î± : Î±0 < Î± < Îº}, then F contains all
closed unbounded sets.
Proof. First we note that the set C0 of all limit ordinals is in F: C0 is the
diagonal intersection of the sets XÎ± = {Î¾ : Î± + 1 < Î¾ < Îº}. Now let C
be a closed unbounded set, and let C = {aÎ± : Î± < Îº} be its increasing
enumeration. We let XÎ± = {Î¾ : aÎ± < Î¾ < Îº}. Then C âŠƒC0 âˆ©â–³Î±<Îº XÎ±.

A Hierarchy of Stationary Sets
If Î± is a limit ordinal of uncountable coï¬nality, it still makes sense to
talk about closed unbounded and stationary subsets of Î±. Since cf Î± > Ï‰,
Lemma 8.2 holds, and the closed unbounded sets generate a ï¬lter on Î±. The
closed unbounded ï¬lter is cf Î±-complete. A set S âŠ‚Î± is stationary if and only
if for some (or for any) normal function f : cf Î± â†’Î±, fâˆ’1(S) is a stationary
subset of cf Î±.
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal, and let us consider the following
operation (the Mahlo operation) on stationary sets:
Deï¬nition 8.17. If S âŠ‚Îº is stationary, the trace of S is the set
Tr(S) = {Î± < Îº : cf Î± > Ï‰ and S âˆ©Î± is stationary}.
The Mahlo operation is invariant under equivalence mod INS and can
thus be considered as an operation on the Boolean algebra P(Îº)/INS (see
Exercise 8.11).
In the context of closed unbounded and stationary sets we use the phrase
for almost all Î± âˆˆS to mean that the set of all contrary Î± âˆˆS is nonsta-
tionary.
Deï¬nition 8.18. Let S and T be stationary subsets of Îº.
S < T
if and only if
S âˆ©Î± is stationary for almost all Î± âˆˆT .
(It is implicit in the deï¬nition that almost all Î± âˆˆT have uncountable coï¬-
nality.)
As an example, if Î» < Âµ are regular, then EÎº
Î» < EÎº
Âµ. The following prop-
erties are easily veriï¬ed:
Lemma 8.19.
(i) A < Tr(A),

100
Part I. Basic Set Theory
(ii) if A < B and B < C then A < C,
(iii) if A < B, A â‰ƒAâ€² mod INS and B â‰ƒBâ€² mod INS then Aâ€² < Bâ€².
âŠ“âŠ”
Thus < is a transitive relation on P(Îº)/INS. The next theorem shows that
it is a well-founded partial ordering:
Theorem 8.20 (Jech). The relation < is well-founded.
Proof. Assume to the contrary that there exist stationary sets such that
A1 > A2 > A3 . . .. Therefore there exist closed unbounded sets Cn such that
An âˆ©Cn âŠ‚Tr(An+1) for n = 1, 2, 3, . . . . For each n, let
Bn = An âˆ©Cn âˆ©Lim(Cn+1) âˆ©Lim(Lim(Cn+2)) âˆ©. . .
where Lim(C) is the set of all limit points of C.
Each Bn is stationary, and for every n, Bn âŠ‚Tr(Bn+1). Let Î±n = min Bn.
Since Bn+1 âˆ©Î±n is stationary, we have Î±n+1 < Î±n and therefore, a decreasing
sequence Î±1 > Î±2 > . . .. A contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
The rank of a stationary set A âŠ‚Îº in the well-founded relation < is called
the order of the set A, and the height of < is the order of the cardinal Îº:
o(A) = sup{o(X) + 1 : X < A},
o(Îº) = sup{o(A) + 1 : A âŠ‚Îº is stationary}.
We also deï¬ne o(â„µ0) = 0, and o(Î±) = o(cf Î±) for every limit ordinal Î±. Note
that o(EÎº
Ï‰) = 0, o(EÎº
Ï‰1) = 1, o(â„µ1) = 1, o(â„µ2) = 2, etc. See Exercises 8.13
and 8.14.
The Closed Unbounded Filter on PÎº(Î»)
We shall now consider a generalization of closed unbounded and stationary
sets, to the space PÎº(Î»). This generalization replaces (Îº, <) with the structure
(PÎº(Î»), âŠ‚).
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let A be a set of cardinality
at least Îº.
Deï¬nition 8.21. A set X âŠ‚PÎº(A) is unbounded if for every x âˆˆPÎº(A)
there exists a y âŠƒx such that y âˆˆX.
A set X âŠ‚PÎº(A) is closed if for any chain x0 âŠ‚x1 âŠ‚. . . âŠ‚xÎ¾ âŠ‚. . .,
Î¾ < Î±, of sets in X, with Î± < Îº, the union 
Î¾<Î± xÎ¾ is in X.
A set C âŠ‚PÎº(A) is closed unbounded if it is closed and unbounded.
A set S âŠ‚PÎº(A) is stationary if S âˆ©C Ì¸= âˆ…for every closed unbounded
C âŠ‚PÎº(A).
The closed unbounded ï¬lter on PÎº(A) is the ï¬lter generated by the closed
unbounded sets.

8. Stationary Sets
101
When |A| = |B| then PÎº(A) and PÎº(B) are isomorphic, with closed un-
bounded and stationary sets corresponding to closed unbounded and sta-
tionary sets, and so it often suï¬ƒces to consider such sets in PÎº(Î») where Î» is
a cardinal â‰¥Îº.
When |A| = Îº, then the set Îº âŠ‚PÎº(Îº) is closed unbounded, and the
closed unbounded ï¬lter on Îº is the restriction to Îº of the closed unbounded
ï¬lter on PÎº(Îº).
Theorem 8.22 (Jech). The closed unbounded ï¬lter on PÎº(A) is Îº-complete.

8. Stationary Sets

Historical Notes
The deï¬nition of stationary set is due to Bloch [1953], and the fundamental theo-
rem (Theorem 8.7) was proved by Fodor [1956]. (A precursor of Fodorâ€™s Theorem
appeared in Aleksandrov-Urysohn [1929].) The concept of stationary sets is implicit
in Mahlo [1911].
Theorem 8.10 was proved by Solovay [1971] using the technique of saturated
ideals.
Mahlo cardinals are named after P. Mahlo, who in 1911â€“1913 investigated what
is now called weakly Mahlo cardinals. Theorems 8.12 and 8.13 are due to Sil-
ver [1975]. Silverâ€™s proof uses generic ultrapowers; the elementary proof given here
is as in Baumgartner-Prikry [1976, 1977]. Lemma 8.16: ErdÂ¨os, Hajnal, and Mil-
ner [1968].
Deï¬nition 8.18 and Theorem 8.20 are due to Jech [1984]. The generalization of
closed unbounded and stationary sets (Deï¬nition 8.21 and Theorems 8.22 and 8.24)
was given by Jech [1971b] and [1972/73]; Kueker [1972, 1977] also formulated
these concepts for Îº = Ï‰1 and proved Theorem 8.28. Theorem 8.27 is due to
Menas [1974/75].
Exercise 8.5: Friedman [1974].
Exercise 8.17: Carr [1982].

9. Combinatorial Set Theory
In this chapter we discuss topics in inï¬nitary combinatorics such as trees and
partition properties.
Partition Properties
Let us consider the following argument (the pigeonhole principle): If seven
pigeons occupy three pigeonholes, then at least one pigenhole is occupied by
three pigeons. More generally: If an inï¬nite set is partitioned into ï¬nitely
many pieces, then at least one piece is inï¬nite.
Recall that a partition of a set S is a pairwise disjoint family P = {Xi :
i âˆˆI} such that 
iâˆˆI Xi = S. With the partition P we can associate a func-
tion F : S â†’I such that F(x) = F(y) if and only if x and y are in the same
X âˆˆP. Conversely, any function F : S â†’I determines a partition of S. (We
shall sometimes say that F is a partition of S.)
For any set A and any natural number n > 0,
(9.1)
[A]n = {X âŠ‚A : |X| = n}
is the set of all subsets of A that have exactly n elements. It is sometimes
convenient, when A is a set of ordinals, to identify [A]n with the set of all
sequences âŸ¨Î±1, . . . , Î±nâŸ©in A such that Î±1 < . . . < Î±n. We shall consider
partitions of sets [A]n for various inï¬nite sets A and natural numbers n. Our
starting point is the theorem of Ramsey dealing with ï¬nite partitions of [Ï‰]n.
If {Xi : i âˆˆI} is a partition of [A]n, then a set H âŠ‚A is homogeneous for
the partition if for some i, [H]n is included in Xi; that is, if all the n-element
subsets of H are in the same piece of the partition.
Theorem 9.1 (Ramsey). Let n and k be natural numbers. Every partition
{X1, . . . , Xk} of [Ï‰]n into k pieces has an inï¬nite homogeneous set.
Equivalently, for every F : [Ï‰]n â†’{1, . . . , k} there exists an inï¬nite H âŠ‚
Ï‰ such that F is constant on [H]n.
Proof. By induction on n. If n = 1, the theorem is trivial, so we assume
that it holds for n and prove for n + 1. Let F be a function from [Ï‰]n+1 into

108
Part I. Basic Set Theory
{1, . . . , k}. For each a âˆˆÏ‰, let Fa be the function on [Ï‰ âˆ’{a}]n deï¬ned as
follows:
Fa(X) = F({a} âˆªX).
By the induction hypothesis, there exists for each a âˆˆÏ‰ and each inï¬nite
S âŠ‚Ï‰ an inï¬nite set HS
a âŠ‚S âˆ’{a} such that Fa is constant on [HS
a ]n. We
construct an inï¬nite sequence âŸ¨ai : i = 0, 1, 2, . . .âŸ©: We let S0 = Ï‰ and a0 = 0,
and

ai ,

It is clear that for each i âˆˆÏ‰, the function Fai is constant on [{am : m > i}]n;
let G(ai) be its value. Now there is an inï¬nite subset H âŠ‚{ai : i âˆˆÏ‰}

this is because for x1 < . . . < xn+1 in H we have F({x1, . . . , xn+1}) =
Fx1({x2, . . . , xn+1}).
âŠ“âŠ”
The following lemma explains the terminology introduced in Chapter 7
where Ramsey ultraï¬lters were deï¬ned:
Lemma 9.2. Let D be a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Ï‰. D is Ramsey if and
only if for all natural numbers n and k, every partition F : [Ï‰]n â†’{1, . . . , k}
has a homogeneous set H âˆˆD.
Proof. First assume that D has the partition property stated in the lemma.

homogeneous for F, then clearly H has at most one element common with
each A âˆˆA.

Now we use the property (9.2) to prove the partition property; we proceed

for all a âˆˆX; say Fa(x) = r for all a âˆˆX and all x âˆˆ[Ha]n.
For each n, let Xn = Xâˆ©H0âˆ©H1âˆ©. . .âˆ©Hn. By (9.2) there exists a sequence

{an}âˆ
n=0 âˆˆD. Let H = {an}âˆ

{am : m > i} âŠ‚Hai. Hence Fai(x) = r for all x âˆˆ[{am : m > i}]n, and it

To facilitate our investigation of generalizations of Ramseyâ€™s Theorem,
we shall now introduce the arrow notation. Let Îº and Î» be inï¬nite cardinal
numbers, let n be a natural number and let m be a (ï¬nite or inï¬nite) cardinal.
The symbol
(9.3)

Weakly Compact Cardinals
In the positive results given by the ErdËos-Rado Theorem, the size of the ho-
mogeneous set is smaller than the size of the set being partitioned. A natural
question arises, whether the relation Îº â†’(Îº)2 can hold for cardinals other
than Îº = Ï‰.
Deï¬nition 9.8. A cardinal Îº is weakly compact if it is uncountable and
satisï¬es the partition property Îº â†’(Îº)2.
The reason for the name â€œweakly compactâ€ is that these cardinals satisfy
a certain compactness theorem for inï¬nitary languages; we shall investigate
weakly compact cardinals further in Part II.
Lemma 9.9. Every weakly compact cardinal is inaccessible.
Proof. Let Îº be a weakly compact cardinal. To show that Îº is regular, let
us assume that Îº is the disjoint union {AÎ³ : Î³ < Î»} such that Î» < Îº
and |AÎ³| < Îº for each Î³ < Î». We deï¬ne a partition F : [Îº]2 â†’{0, 1} as
follows: F({Î±, Î²}) = 0 just in case Î± and Î² are in the same AÎ³. Obviously,
this partition does not have a homogeneous set H âŠ‚Îº of size Îº.
That Îº is a strong limit cardinal follows from Lemma 9.4: If Îº â‰¤2Î»
for some Î» < Îº, then because 2Î» Ì¸â†’(Î»+)2, we have Îº Ì¸â†’(Î»+)2 and hence
Îº Ì¸â†’(Îº)2.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall prove in Chapter 17 that every weakly compact cardinal Îº is the
Îºth inaccessible cardinal.
Trees
Many problems in combinatorial set theory can be formulated as problems
about trees.
In this chapter we discuss Suslinâ€™s Problem as well as the use of trees in
partition calculus and large cardinals.

114
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Deï¬nition 9.10. A tree is a partially ordered set (T, <) with the property
that for each x âˆˆT , the set {y : y < x} of all predecessors of x is well-ordered
by <.
The Î±th level of T consists of all x âˆˆT such that {y : y < x} has order-
type Î±. The height of T is the least Î± such that the Î±th level of T is empty;
in other words, it is the height of the well-founded relation <:
(9.8)
o(x) = the order-type of {y : y < x},
Î±th level = {x : o(x) = Î±},
height(T ) = sup{o(x) + 1 : x âˆˆT }.
A branch in T is a maximal linearly ordered subset of T . The length of
a branch b is the order-type of b. An Î±-branch is a branch of length Î±.
We shall now turn our attention to Suslinâ€™s Problem introduced in Chap-
ter 4. In Lemma 9.14 below we show that the problem can be restated as
a question about the existence of certain trees of height Ï‰1.
Suslinâ€™s Problem asks whether the real line is the only complete dense
unbounded linearly ordered set that satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
An equivalent question is whether every dense linear ordering that satisï¬es
the countable chain condition is separable, i.e., has a countable dense subset.
Deï¬nition 9.11. A Suslin line is a dense linearly ordered set that satisï¬es
the countable chain condition and is not separable.
Thus Suslinâ€™s Problem asks whether a Suslin line exists. We shall show
that the existence of a Suslin line is equivalent to the existence of a Suslin
tree.
Let T be a tree. An antichain in T is a set A âŠ‚T such that any two
distinct elements x, y of A are incomparable, i.e., neither x < y nor y < x.
Deï¬nition 9.12. A tree T is a Suslin tree if
(i) the height of T is Ï‰1;
(ii) every branch in T is at most countable;
(iii) every antichain in T is at most countable.
For the formulation of Suslinâ€™s Problem in terms of trees it is useful to
consider Suslin trees that are called normal.
Let Î± be an ordinal number, Î± â‰¤Ï‰1. A normal Î±-tree is a tree T with
the following properties:
(i) height(T ) = Î±;
(ii) T has a unique least point (the root);
(iii) each level of T is at most countable;
(iv) if x is not maximal in T , then there are inï¬nitely many y > x at
the next level (immediate successors of x);
(9.9)

9. Combinatorial Set Theory
115
(v) for each x âˆˆT there is some y > x at each higher level less
than Î±;
(vi) if Î² < Î± is a limit ordinal and x, y are both at level Î² and if
{z : z < x} = {z : z < y}, then x = y.
See Exercise 9.6 for a representation of normal trees.
Lemma 9.13. If there exists a Suslin tree then there exists a normal Suslin
tree.
Proof. Let T be a Suslin tree. T has height Ï‰1, and each level of T is count-
able. We ï¬rst discard all points x âˆˆT such that Tx = {y âˆˆT : y â‰¥x} is at
most countable, and let T1 = {x âˆˆT : Tx is uncountable}. Note that if x âˆˆT1
and Î± > o(x), then |Ty| = â„µ1 for some y > x at level Î±. Hence T1 satisï¬es
condition (v). Next, we satisfy property (vi): For every chain C = {z : z < y}
in T1 of limit length we add an extra node aC and stipulate that z < aC for
all z âˆˆC, and aC < x for every x such that x > z for all z âˆˆC. The resulting
tree T2 satisï¬es (iii), (v) and (vi). For each x âˆˆT2 there are uncountably
many branching points z > x, i.e., points that have at least two immediate
successors (because there is no uncountable chain and T2 satisï¬es (v)). The
tree T3 = {the branching points of T2} satisï¬es (iii), (v) and (vi) and each
x âˆˆT3 is a branching point. To get property (iv), let T4 consists of all z âˆˆT3
at limit levels of T3. The tree T4 satisï¬es (i), (iii), (iv), and (v); and then
T5 âŠ‚T4 satisfying (ii) as well is easily obtained.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 9.14. There exists a Suslin line if and only if there exists a Suslin
tree.
Proof. (a) Let S be a Suslin line. We shall construct a Suslin tree. The tree
will consist of closed (nondegenerate) intervals on the Suslin line S. The
partial ordering of T is by inverse inclusion: If I, J âˆˆT , then I â‰¤J if and
only if I âŠƒJ.
The collection T of intervals is constructed by induction on Î± < Ï‰1. We
let I0 = [a0, b0] be arbitrary (such that a0 < b0). Having constructed IÎ²,
Î² < Î±, we consider the countable set C = {aÎ² : Î² < Î±} âˆª{bÎ² : Î² < Î±} of
endpoints of the intervals IÎ², Î² < Î±. Since S is a Suslin line, C is not dense
in S and so there exists an interval [a, b] disjoint from C; we pick some such
[aÎ±, bÎ±] = IÎ±. The set T = {IÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} is uncountable and partially ordered
by âŠƒ. If Î± < Î², then either IÎ± âŠƒIÎ² or IÎ± is disjoint from IÎ². It follows that
for each Î±, {I âˆˆT : I âŠƒIÎ±} is well-ordered by âŠƒand thus T is a tree.
We shall show that T has no uncountable branches and no uncountable
antichains. Then it is immediate that the height of T is at most Ï‰1; and since
every level is an antichain and T is uncountable, we have height(T ) = Ï‰1.
If I, J âˆˆT are incomparable, then they are disjoint intervals of S; and
since S satisï¬es the countable chain condition, every antichain in T is at most
countable. To show that T has no uncountable branch, we note ï¬rst that if

116
Part I. Basic Set Theory
b is a branch of length Ï‰1, then the left endpoints of the intervals I âˆˆB
form an increasing sequence {xÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} of points of S. It is clear that the
intervals (xÎ±, xÎ±+1), Î± < Ï‰1, form a disjoint uncountable collection of open
intervals in S, contrary to the assumption that S satisï¬es the countable chain
condition.
(b) Let T be a normal Suslin tree. The line S will consist of all branches
of T (which are all countable). Each x âˆˆT has countably many immediate
successors, and we order these successors as rational numbers. Then we order
the elements of S lexicographically: If Î± is the least level where two branches
a, b âˆˆS diï¬€er, then Î± is a successor ordinal and the points aÎ± âˆˆa and bÎ± âˆˆb
are both successors of the same point at level Î± âˆ’1; we let a < b or b < a
according to whether aÎ± < bÎ± or bÎ± < aÎ±.
It is easy to see that S is linearly ordered and dense. If (a, b) is an open
interval in S, then one can ï¬nd x âˆˆT such that Ix âŠ‚(a, b), where Ix is the
interval Ix = {c âˆˆS : x âˆˆc}. And if Ix and Iy are disjoint, then x and y are
incomparable points of T . Thus every disjoint collection of open intervals of S
must be at most countable, and so S satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
The line S is not separable: If C is a countable set of branches of T , let Î±
be a countable ordinal bigger than the length of any branches b âˆˆC. Then if
x is any point at level Î±, the interval Ix does not contain any b âˆˆC, and so
C is not dense in S.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 9.14 reduces Suslinâ€™s Problem to a purely combinatorial problem.
In Part II we shall return to it and show that the problem is independent of
the axioms of set theory.
We now turn our attention to the following problem, related to Suslin
trees.
Deï¬nition 9.15. An Aronszajn tree is a tree of height Ï‰1 all of whose levels
are at most countable and which has no uncountable branches.
Theorem 9.16 (Aronszajn). There exists an Aronszajn tree.
Proof. We construct a tree T whose elements are some bounded increasing
transï¬nite sequences of rational numbers. If x, y âˆˆT are two such sequences,
then we let x â‰¤y just in case y extends x, i.e., x âŠ‚y. Also, if y âˆˆT and x is
an initial segment of y, then we let x âˆˆT ; thus the Î±th level of T will consist
of all those x âˆˆT whose length is Î±.
It is clear that an uncountable branch in T would yield an increasing
Ï‰1-sequence of rational numbers, which is impossible. Thus T will be an
Aronszajn tree, provided we arrange that T has â„µ1 levels, all of them at
most countable. We construct T by induction on levels. For each Î± < Ï‰1
we construct a set UÎ± of increasing Î±-sequences of rationals; UÎ± will be the
Î±th level of T . We construct the UÎ± so that for each Î±, |UÎ±| â‰¤â„µ0, and that:
For each Î² < Î±, each x âˆˆUÎ² and each q > sup x there is y âˆˆUÎ± such
that x âŠ‚y and q â‰¥sup y.
(9.10)

9. Combinatorial Set Theory
117
Condition (9.10) enables us to continue the construction at limit steps.
To start, we let U0 = {âˆ…}. The successor steps of the construction are also
fairly easy. Given UÎ±, we let UÎ±+1 be the set of all extensions xâŒ¢r of sequences
in UÎ± such that r > sup x. It is clear that since UÎ± satisï¬es condition (9.10),
UÎ±+1 satisï¬es it also (for Î± + 1), and it is equally clear that UÎ±+1 is at most
countable.
Thus let Î± be a limit ordinal (Î± < Ï‰1) and assume that we have con-
structed all levels UÎ³, Î³ < Î±, of T below Î±, and that all the UÎ³ satisfy (9.10);
we shall construct UÎ±. The points x âˆˆT below level Î± form a (normal) tree TÎ±
of length Î±. We claim that TÎ± has the following property:
For each x âˆˆTÎ± and each q > sup x there is an increasing Î±-sequence
of rationals y such that x âŠ‚y and q â‰¥sup y and that yâ†¾Î² âˆˆTÎ± for
all Î² < Î±.
(9.11)
The last condition means that {yâ†¾Î² : Î² < Î±} is a branch in TÎ±. To prove the
claim, we let Î±n, n = 0, 1, . . . , be an increasing sequence of ordinals such
that x âˆˆUÎ±0 and limn Î±n = Î±, and let {qn}âˆ
n=0 be an increasing sequence
of rational numbers such that q0 > sup x and limn qn â‰¤q. Using repeatedly
condition (9.10), for all Î±n (n = 0, 1, . . . ), we can construct a sequence
y0 âŠ‚y1 âŠ‚. . . âŠ‚yn . . . such that y0 = x, yn âˆˆUÎ±n, and sup yn â‰¤qn for
each n. Then we let y = âˆ
n=0 yn; clearly, y satisï¬es (9.11).
Now we construct UÎ± as follows: For each x âˆˆTÎ± and each rational
number q such that q > sup x, we choose a branch y in TÎ± that satisï¬es (9.11),
and let UÎ± consists of all these y : Î± â†’Q. The set UÎ± so constructed is
countable and satisï¬es condition (9.10).
Then T = 
Î±<Ï‰1 UÎ± is an Aronszajn tree.
âŠ“âŠ”
The Aronszajn tree constructed in Theorem 9.16 has the property that
there exists a function f : T â†’R such that f(x) < f(y) whenever x < y
(Exercise 9.8). With a little more care, one can construct T so that there is
a function f : T â†’Q such that f(x) < f(y) if x < y. Such trees are called
special Aronszajn trees. In Part II weâ€™ll show that it is consistent that all
Aronszajn trees are special.
Almost Disjoint Sets and Functions
In combinatorial set theory one often consider families of sets that are as
much diï¬€erent as possible; a typical example is an almost disjoint family of
inï¬nite setsâ€”any two intersect in a ï¬nite set. Here we present a sample of
results and problems of this kind.
Deï¬nition 9.17. A collection of ï¬nite sets Z is called a âˆ†-system if there
exists a ï¬nite set S such that X âˆ©Y = S for any two distinct sets X, Y âˆˆZ.

118
Part I. Basic Set Theory
The following theorem is often referred to as the âˆ†-Lemma:
Theorem 9.18 (Shanin). Let W be an uncountable collection of ï¬nite sets.
Then there exists an uncountable Z âŠ‚W that is a âˆ†-system.
Proof. Since W is uncountable, it is clear that uncountably many X âˆˆW
have the same size; thus we may assume that for some n, |X| = n for all
X âˆˆW. We prove the theorem by induction on n. If n = 1, the theorem is
trivial. Thus assume that the theorem holds for n, and let W be such that
|X| = n + 1 for all X âˆˆW.
If there is some element a that belongs to uncountably many X âˆˆW,
we apply the induction hypothesis to the collection {X âˆ’{a} : X âˆˆW and
a âˆˆX}, and obtain Z âŠ‚W with the required properties.
Otherwise, each a belongs to at most countably many X âˆˆW, and we
construct a disjoint collection Z = {XÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} as follows, by induction
on Î±. Given XÎ¾, Î¾ < Î±, we ï¬nd X = XÎ± âˆˆW that is disjoint from all XÎ¾,
Î¾ < Î±.
âŠ“âŠ”
For an alternative proof, using Fodorâ€™s Theorem, see Exercise 9.10. The-
orem 9.18 generalizes to greater cardinals, under the assumption of GCH:
Theorem 9.19. Assume Îº<Îº = Îº. Let W be a collection of sets of cardi-
nality less than Îº such that |W| = Îº+. Then there exist a collection Z âŠ‚W
such that |Z| = Îº+ and a set A such that X âˆ©Y = A for any two distinct
elements X, Y âˆˆZ.
âŠ“âŠ”
Deï¬nition 9.20. If X and Y are inï¬nite subsets of Ï‰ then X and Y are
almost disjoint if X âˆ©Y is ï¬nite.
Let Îº be a regular cardinal. If X âˆ©Y are subsets of Îº of cardinality Îº then
X and Y are almost disjoint if |X âˆ©Y | < Îº.
An almost disjoint family of sets is a family of pairwise almost disjoint
sets.
Lemma 9.21. There exists an almost disjoint family of 2â„µ0 subsets of Ï‰.
Proof. Let S be the set of all ï¬nite 0â€“1 sequences: S = âˆ

2â„µ0 almost disjoint subsets of the countable set S, and the lemma follows.

A generalization from Ï‰ to arbitrary regular Îº is not provable in ZFC (al-
though under GCH the generalization is straightforward; see Exercise 9.11).
Without assuming the GCH, the best one can do is to ï¬nd an almost disjoint
family of Îº+ subsets of Îº; this follows from Lemma 9.23 below.
Deï¬nition 9.22. Let Îº be a regular cardinal. Two functions f and g on Îº

Lemma 9.23. For every regular cardinal Îº, there exists an almost disjoint
family of Îº+ functions from Îº to Îº.
Proof. It suï¬ƒces to show that given Îº almost disjoint functions {fÎ½ : Î½ < Îº},

Let us consider the special case when Îº = Ï‰1.
Deï¬nition 9.24. A tree (T, <) is a Kurepa tree if:
(i) height(T ) = Ï‰1;
(ii) each level of T is at most countable;
(iii) T has at least â„µ2 uncountable branches.
If T is a Kurepa tree, then the family of all Ï‰1-branches is an almost
disjoint family of uncountable subsets of T . In fact, since the levels of T are
countable, we can identify the Ï‰1-branches with the functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰
and get the following result:
There exists an almost disjoint family of â„µ2
functions f : Ï‰1 â†’Ï‰.
Lemma 9.25. A Kurepa tree exists if and only if there exists a family F of
subsets of Ï‰1 such that:
(i) |F| â‰¥â„µ2;
(ii) for each Î± < Ï‰1, |{X âˆ©Î± : X âˆˆF}| â‰¤â„µ0.
(9.12)
Proof. (a) Let (T, <T) be a Kurepa tree. Since T has size â„µ1, we may assume
that T = Ï‰1, and moreover that Î± < Î² whenever Î± <T Î². If we let F be the
family of all Ï‰1-branches of T , then F satisï¬es (9.12).

âŠ“âŠ”
The existence of a Kurepa tree is independent of the axioms of set theory.
In fact, the nonexistence of Kurepa trees is equiconsistent with an inaccessible
cardinal.

The Tree Property and Weakly Compact Cardinals
Generalizing the concept of Aronszajn tree to cardinals > Ï‰1 we say that
a regular uncountable cardinal Îº has the tree property if every tree of height Îº
whose levels have cardinality < Îº has a branch of cardinality Îº.
Lemma 9.26.
(i) If Îº is weakly compact, then Îº has the tree property.
(ii) If Îº is inaccessible and has the tree property, then Îº is weakly compact,
and in fact Îº â†’(Îº)2
m for every m < Îº.
Proof. (i) Let Îº be weakly compact and let (T, <T) be a tree of height Îº such
that each level of T has size < Îº. Since Îº is inaccessible, |T | = Îº and we
may assume that T = Îº. We extend the partial ordering <T of Îº to a linear
ordering â‰º: If Î± <T Î², then we let Î± â‰ºÎ²; if Î± and Î² are incomparable and if
Î¾ is the ï¬rst level where the predecessors Î±Î¾, Î²Î¾ of Î± and Î² are distinct, we
let Î± â‰ºÎ² if and only if Î±Î¾ < Î²Î¾.
Let F : [Îº]2 â†’{0, 1} be the partition deï¬ned by F({Î±, Î²}) = 1 if and
only if â‰ºagrees with < on {Î±, Î²}. By weak compactness, let H âŠ‚Îº be
homogeneous for F, |H| = Îº.
We now consider the set B âŠ‚Îº of all x âˆˆÎº such that {Î± âˆˆH : x <T Î±}
has size Îº. Since every level has size < Îº, it is clear that at each level there
is at least one x in B. Thus if we show that any two elements of B are
<T -comparable, we shall have proved that B is a branch in T of size Îº.
Thus assume that x, y are incomparable elements of B; let x â‰ºy. Since
both x and y have Îº successors in H, there exist Î± < Î² < Î³ in H such that
x <T Î±, y <T Î², and x <T Î³. By the deï¬nition of â‰º, we have Î± â‰ºÎ² and
Î³ â‰ºÎ². Thus F({Î±, Î²}) = 1 and F({Î³, Î²}) = 0, contrary to the homogeneity
of H.

Historical Notes
Theorem 9.1 is due to Ramsey [1929/30]. Ramsey ultraï¬lters are investigated in
Booth [1970/71]. The theory of partition relations has been developed by ErdËos,
who has written a number of papers on the subject, some coauthored by Rado,
Hajnal, and others. The arrow notation is introduced in ErdËos and Rado [1956].
Other major comprehensive articles on partition relations are ErdËos, Hajnal, and
Rado [1965] and ErdËos and Hajnal [1971].

9. Combinatorial Set Theory
123
Theorem 9.6 appears in ErdËos and Rado [1956]. Lemma 9.4 is due to SierpiÂ´n-
ski [1933]. Theorem 9.7 is in Dushnik-Miller [1941].
Weakly compact cardinals (as in Deï¬nition 9.8 as well as the tree property)
were introduced by ErdËos and Tarski in [1961].
The equivalence of Suslinâ€™s Problem with the tree formulation (Lemma 9.14) is
due to Kurepa [1935]; this paper also presents Aronszajnâ€™s construction and Kurepa
trees, with Lemma 9.25.
Theorems 9.18 and 9.19: Shanin [1946] and ErdËos-Rado [1960].
Ramsey cardinals were ï¬rst studied by ErdËos and Hajnal in [1962].
Exercise 9.2: ErdËos-Rado [1956], Exercises 9.4 and 9.13: ErdËos-Rado [1952].
Exercise 9.5: D. KÂ¨onig [1927].
Exercise 9.9: Galvin.

10. Measurable Cardinals
The theory of large cardinals owes its origin to the basic problem of measure
theory, the Measure Problem of H. Lebesgue.
The Measure Problem
Let S be an inï¬nite set. A (nontrivial Ïƒ-additive probabilistic) measure on S
is a real-valued function Âµ on P(S) such that:
(i) Âµ(âˆ…) = 0 and Âµ(S) = 1;
(ii) if X âŠ‚Y , then Âµ(X) â‰¤Âµ(Y );
(iii) Âµ({a}) = 0 for all a âˆˆS (nontriviality);
(iv) if Xn, n = 0, 1, 2, . . . , are pairwise disjoint, then
Âµ
 âˆ

n=0
Xn

=
âˆ

n=0
Âµ(Xn)
(Ïƒ-additivity).
(10.1)
It follows from (ii) that Âµ(X), the measure of X, is nonnegative for every
X âŠ‚S; in a special case of (iv) we get Âµ(X âˆªY ) = Âµ(X) + Âµ(Y ) whenever
X âˆ©Y = âˆ…(ï¬nite additivity).
More generally, let A be a Ïƒ-complete algebra of sets. A measure on A
is a real-valued function Âµ on A satisfying (i)â€“(iv). Thus a measure on S is
a measure on P(S).
An example of a measure on a Ïƒ-complete algebra of sets is the Lebesgue
measure on the algebra of all Lebesgue measurable subsets of the unit in-
terval [0, 1]. The Lebesgue measure has, in addition to (i)â€“(iv), the following
property:
If X is congruent by translation to a measurable set Y , then X is
measurable and Âµ(X) = Âµ(Y ).
(10.2)
It is well known that there exist sets of reals that are not Lebesgue mea-
surable, and in fact that there is no measure on [0, 1] with the property (10.2)
(translation invariant measure); see Exercise 10.1.
The natural question to ask is whether the Lebesgue measure can be
extended to some measure (not translation invariant) such that all subsets

126
Part I. Basic Set Theory
of [0, 1] are measurable, or whether there exists any measure on [0, 1]. Or,
whether there exists a measure on some set S.
The investigation of this problem has lead to important discoveries in set
theory, opening up a new ï¬eld, the theory of large cardinal numbers, which
has far-reaching consequences both in pure set theory and in descriptive set
theory.
A measure Âµ on S is two-valued if Âµ(X) is either 0 or 1 for all X âŠ‚S. If
Âµ is a two-valued measure on S, let
(10.3)
U = {X âŠ‚S : Âµ(X) = 1}.
It is easy to verify that U is an ultraï¬lter on S. (For instance, if X âˆˆU and
Y âˆˆU, then Xâˆ©Y âˆˆU. If Âµ(X) = Âµ(Y ) = 1, then X = (Xâˆ’Y )âˆª(Xâˆ©Y ) and
Y = (Y âˆ’X)âˆª(Xâˆ©Y ). If Âµ(Xâˆ©Y ) were not 1, then Âµ(Xâˆ’Y ) = Âµ(Y âˆ’X) = 1,
and we would have Âµ(X âˆªY ) = 2.)
Next we note that the ultraï¬lter U is Ïƒ-complete. This is so because Âµ is
Ïƒ-additive, and an ultraï¬lter U on S is Ïƒ-complete if and only if there is no
partition of S into countably many disjoint parts S = âˆ
n=0 Xn such that
Xn /âˆˆU, for all n.
Thus if Âµ is a two-valued measure on S, U is a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on S.
Conversely, if U is a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on S, then the following function
is a two-valued measure on S:
(10.4)
Âµ(X) =
1
if X âˆˆU,
0
if X /âˆˆU.
Let Âµ be a measure on S. A set A âŠ‚S is an atom of Âµ if Âµ(A) > 0 and if
for every X âŠ‚A, we have either Âµ(X) = 0 or Âµ(X) = Âµ(A).
If Âµ has an atom A, then
(10.5)
U = {X âŠ‚S : Âµ(X âˆ©A) = Âµ(A)}
is again a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on S.
A measure Âµ on S is atomless if it has no atoms. Then every set X âŠ‚S
of positive measure can be split into two disjoint sets of positive measure:
X = Y âˆªZ, and Âµ(Y ) > 0, Âµ(Z) > 0.
We shall eventually prove various strong consequences of the existence of
a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure and establish the relationship between the
Measure Problem and large cardinals. Our starting point is the following
theorem which shows that if a measure exists, then there exists at least
a weakly inaccessible cardinal.
Theorem 10.1 (Ulam). If there is a Ïƒ-additive nontrivial measure on S,
then either there exists a two-valued measure on S and |S| is greater than
or equal to the least inaccessible cardinal, or there exists an atomless mea-
sure on 2â„µ0 and 2â„µ0 is greater than or equal to the least weakly inaccessible
cardinal.

10. Measurable Cardinals
127
Theorem 10.1 will be proved in a sequence of lemmas, which will also
provide additional information on the Measure Problem and introduce ba-
sic notions and methods of the theory of large cardinals. First we make the
following observation. Let Îº be the least cardinal that carries a nontrivial
Ïƒ-additive two-valued measure. Clearly, Îº is uncountable and is also the least
cardinal that has a nonprincipal countably complete ultraï¬lter. And we ob-
serve that such an ultraï¬lter is in fact Îº-complete:
Lemma 10.2. Let Îº be the least cardinal with the property that there is
a nonprincipal Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº, and let U be such an ultraï¬lter.
Then U is Îº-complete.
Proof. Let U be a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº, and let us assume that U is
not Îº-complete. Then there exists a partition {XÎ± : Î± < Î³} of Îº such that
Î³ < Îº, and XÎ± /âˆˆU for all Î± < Î³. We shall now use this partition to construct
a nonprincipal Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on Î³, thus contradicting the choice of Îº
as the least cardinal that carries such an ultraï¬lter.
Let f be the mapping of Îº onto Î³ deï¬ned as follows:
f(x) = Î±
if and only if
x âˆˆXÎ±
(x âˆˆÎº).
The mapping f induces a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on Î³: we deï¬ne D âŠ‚P(Î³) by
(10.6)

if and only if
fâˆ’1(Z) âˆˆU.
The ultraï¬lter D is nonprincipal: Assume that {Î±} âˆˆD for some Î± < Î³. Then
XÎ± âˆˆU, contrary to our assumption on XÎ±. Thus Î³ carries a Ïƒ-complete
nonprincipal ultraï¬lter.
âŠ“âŠ”
Measurable and Real-Valued Measurable Cardinals
We are now ready to deï¬ne the central notion of this chapter.
Deï¬nition 10.3. An uncountable cardinal Îº is measurable if there exists
a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter U on Îº.
By Lemma 10.2, the least cardinal that carries a nontrivial two-valued Ïƒ-
additive measure is measurable. Note that if U is a Îº-complete nonprincipal
ultraï¬lter on Îº, then every set X âˆˆU has cardinality Îº because every set of
smaller size is the union of fewer than Îº singletons. For similar reasons, Îº is
a regular cardinal because if Îº is singular, then it is the union of fewer than
Îº small sets. The next lemma gives a ï¬rst link of the Measure Problem with
large cardinals.
Lemma 10.4. Every measurable cardinal is inaccessible.

128
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Proof. We have just given an argument why a measurable cardinal is regular.
Let us show that measurable cardinals are strong limit cardinals. Let Îº be
measurable, and let us assume that there exists Î» < Îº such that 2Î» â‰¥Îº; we
shall reach a contradiction.
Let S be a set of functions f : Î» â†’{0, 1} such that |S| = Îº, and let U be
a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on S. For each Î± < Î», let XÎ± be that
one of the two sets {f âˆˆS : f(Î±) = 0}, {f âˆˆS : f(Î±) = 1} which is in U, and
let ÎµÎ± be 0 or 1 accordingly. Since U is Îº-complete, the set X = 
Î±<Î» XÎ± is
in U. However, X has at most one element, namely the function f that has
the values f(Î±) = ÎµÎ±. A contradiction.

Let us now turn our attention to measures that are not necessarily two-
valued. Let Âµ be a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure on a set S. In analogy
with (10.3) we consider the ideal of all null sets:
(10.7)
IÂµ = {X âŠ‚S : Âµ(X) = 0}.
IÂµ is a nonprincipal Ïƒ-complete ideal on S. Moreover, it has these properties:
(i) {x} âˆˆI for every x âˆˆS;
(ii) every family of pairwise disjoint sets X âŠ‚S that are not in I is
at most countable.
(10.8)
To see that (ii) holds, note that if W is a disjoint family of set of positive
measure, then for each integer n > 0, there are only ï¬nitely many sets X âˆˆW
of measure â‰¥1/n.
A Ïƒ-complete nonprincipal ideal I on S is called Ïƒ-saturated if it satis-
ï¬es (10.8).
The following lemma is an analog of Lemma 10.2:
Lemma 10.5.
(i) Let Îº be the least cardinal that carries a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure
and let Âµ be such a measure on Îº. Then the ideal IÂµ of null sets is
Îº-complete.
(ii) Let Îº be the least cardinal with the property that there is a Ïƒ-complete
Ïƒ-saturated ideal on Îº, and let I be such an ideal. Then I is Îº-complete.

Corollary 10.7. Let Îº be the least cardinal that carries a nontrivial Ïƒ-addi-
tive measure and let Âµ be such a measure. Then Âµ is Îº-additive.

Deï¬nition 10.8. An uncountable cardinal Îº is real-valued measurable if
there exists a nontrivial Îº-additive measure Âµ on Îº.
By Corollary 10.7, the least cardinal that carries a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive
measure is real-valued measurable. We shall show that if a real-valued mea-
surable cardinal Îº is not measurable, then Îº â‰¤2â„µ0. Note that if Âµ is a non-
trivial Îº additive measure on Îº, then every set of size < Îº has measure 0,
and moreover Îº cannot be the union of fewer than Îº sets of size < Îº. Thus
a real-valued measurable cardinal is regular. We shall show that it is weakly
inaccessible.
We shall ï¬rst prove the ï¬rst claim made in the preceding paragraph.
Lemma 10.9.
(i) If there exists an atomless nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure, then there
exists a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure on some Îº â‰¤2â„µ0.
(ii) If I is a Ïƒ-complete Ïƒ-saturated ideal on S, then either there exists
Z âŠ‚S, such that Iâ†¾Z = {X âŠ‚Z : X âˆˆI} is a prime ideal, or there
exists a Ïƒ-complete Ïƒ-saturated ideal on some Îº â‰¤2â„µ0.
Proof. (i) Let Âµ be such a measure on S. We construct a tree T of subsets
of S, partially ordered by reverse inclusion. The 0th level of T is {S}. Each

X âˆˆT has two immediate successors: We choose two sets Y , Z of positive
measure such that Y âˆªZ = X and Y âˆ©Z = âˆ…. If Î± is a limit ordinal, then
the Î±th level consists of all intersections X = 
Î¾<Î± XÎ¾ such that each XÎ¾ is
on the Î¾th level of T and such that X has positive measure.
We observe that every branch of T has countable length: If {XÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±} is
a branch in T , then the set {YÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±}, where YÎ¾ = XÎ¾ âˆ’XÎ¾+1, is a disjoint
collection of sets of positive measure. Consequently, T has height at most Ï‰1.
Similarly, each level of T is at most countable, and it follows that T has at
most 2â„µ0 branches.

Î¾ < Î³} such that 

(ii) The proof is similar. We deï¬ne a tree T as above and then induce an

The proof of Lemma 10.9 shows that if Âµ is atomless, then there is a par-

Corollary 10.10. If Îº is a real-valued measurable cardinal, then either Îº is
measurable or Îº â‰¤2â„µ0.
More generally, if Îº carries a Îº-complete Ïƒ-saturated ideal, then either
Îº is measurable or Îº â‰¤2â„µ0.

The measure Î½ obtained in Lemma 10.9(i) is atomless; this follows from
the fact that Îº â‰¤2â„µ0 and Lemma 10.4. If there exists an atomless Ïƒ-additive
measure, then there is one on some Îº â‰¤2â„µ0. Clearly, such a measure can
be extended to a measure on 2â„µ0: For X âŠ‚2â„µ0, we let Âµ(X) = Âµ(X âˆ©Îº).
Thus we conclude that there exists an atomless Ïƒ-additive measure on the
set R of all reals. It turns out that using the same assumption, we can obtain
a Ïƒ-additive measure on R that extends Lebesgue measure. This can be done
by a slight modiï¬cation of the proof of Lemma 10.9:

Xs âŠ‚S such that Xâˆ…= S, and for every s âˆˆSeq, XsâŒ¢0 âˆªXsâŒ¢1 = Xs,

we obtain a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure Î½ on [0, 1]. This measure agrees
with the Lebesgue measure on all intervals [k/2n, (k + 1)/2n], and hence on
all Borel sets. Every set of Lebesgue measure 0 is included in a Borel (in fact,
GÎ´) set of Lebesgue measure 0 and hence has Î½-measure 0. Every Lebesgue
measurable set X can be written as X = (Bâˆ’N1)âˆªN2, where N1 and N2 have
Lebesgue measure 0, and hence the Lebesgue measure of X is equal to Î½(X).
Thus Î½ agrees with the Lebesgue measure on all Lebesgue measurable subsets
of [0, 1].
We shall now show that a real-valued measurable cardinal is weakly in-
accessible. The proof is by a combinatorial argument, using matrices of sets.
Deï¬nition 10.11. An Ulam matrix (more precisely, an Ulam (â„µ1, â„µ0)-
matrix) is a collection {AÎ±,n : Î± < Ï‰1, n < Ï‰} of subsets of Ï‰1 such that:
(i) if Î± Ì¸= Î², then AÎ±,n âˆ©AÎ²,n = âˆ…for every n < Ï‰;
(ii) for each Î±, the set Ï‰1 âˆ’âˆ
n=0 AÎ±,n is at most countable.
(10.12)
An Ulam matrix has â„µ1 rows and â„µ0 columns. Each column consists of
pairwise disjoint sets, and the union of each row contains all but countably
many elements of Ï‰1.

Proof. For each Î¾ < Ï‰1, let fÎ¾ be a function on Ï‰ such that Î¾ âŠ‚ran(fÎ¾). Let
us deï¬ne AÎ±,n for Î± < Ï‰1 and n < Ï‰ by

Using an Ulam matrix, we can show that there is no measure on Ï‰1:
Lemma 10.13. There is no nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure on Ï‰1. More gen-
erally, there is no Ïƒ-complete Ïƒ-saturated ideal on Ï‰1.
Proof. Let {AÎ±,n : Î± < Ï‰1, n < Ï‰} be an Ulam matrix. Assuming that we
have a measure on Ï‰1, there is for each Î± some n = nÎ± such that AÎ±,n has
positive measure (because of (10.12)(ii)). Hence there exist an uncountable
set W âŠ‚Ï‰1 and some n < Ï‰ such that nÎ± = n for all Î± âˆˆW. Then
{AÎ±,n : Î± âˆˆW} is an uncountable, pairwise disjoint (by (10.12)(i)) family of
sets of positive measure; a contradiction.

Corollary 10.15. Every real-valued measurable cardinal is weakly inacces-
sible.

Lemma 10.14 completes the proof of Theorem 10.1: If there is a Ïƒ-additive
nontrivial measure on S, then either the measure has an atom A and we can
construct a two-valued measure on S via a Ïƒ-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter
on A, and then |S| â‰¥the least measurable cardinal, which is inaccessible; or
the measure on S is atomless and we construct, as in Lemma 10.9, an atomless
measure on 2â„µ0, and then 2â„µ0 â‰¥the least real-valued measurable cardinal,
which is weakly inaccessible.
âŠ“âŠ”
Prior to Ulamâ€™s work, Banach and Kuratowski proved that if the Con-
tinuum Hypothesis holds then there exists no Ïƒ-additive measure on R. We
present their proof below; in fact, Lemma 10.16 gives a slightly more general
result.
If f and g are functions from Ï‰ to Ï‰, let f < g mean that f(n) < g(n) for
all but ï¬nitely many n âˆˆÏ‰. A Îº-sequence of functions âŸ¨fÎ± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©is called
a Îº-scale if fÎ± < fÎ² whenever Î± < Î², and if for every g : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰ there exists
an Î± such that g < fÎ±.
Lemma 10.16. If there exists a Îº-scale, then Îº is not a real-valued measur-
able cardinal.
Proof. Let fÎ±, Î± < Îº, be a Îº-scale. We deï¬ne an (â„µ0, â„µ0)-matrix of subsets
of Îº as follows: For n, k < Ï‰, let
(10.15)

if and only if

(Î± âˆˆÎº).

Measurable Cardinals
By Lemma 10.4, every measurable cardinal is inaccessible. While we shall
investigate measurable cardinals extensively in Part II, we now present a few
basic results that establish the relationship of measurable cardinals and the
large cardinals introduced in Chapter 9.
We recall that by Lemma 9.26, a cardinal Îº is weakly compact if and only
if it is inaccessible and has the tree property.
Lemma 10.18. Every measurable cardinal is weakly compact.
Proof. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal. To show that Îº is weakly compact,
it suï¬ƒces to prove the tree property. Let (T, <) be a tree of height Îº with
levels of size < Îº. We consider a nonprincipal Îº-complete ultraï¬lter U on T .
Let B be the set of all x âˆˆT such that the set of all successors of x is in U.
It is clear that B is a branch in T and it is easy to verify that each level of T
has one element in B; thus B is a branch of size Îº.
âŠ“âŠ”
Normal Measures
In Chapter 8 we deï¬ned the notion of a normal Îº-complete ï¬lter, namely
a ï¬lter closed under diagonal intersections (8.7).
Thus we call a normal Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter a normal mea-
sure on Îº. Note that by Exercise 8.8, a measure is normal if and only if every
regressive function on a set of measure one is constant on a set of measure
one.
Lemma 10.19. If D is a normal measure on Îº, then every set in D is sta-
tionary.
Proof. By Lemma 8.11, every closed unbounded set is in D, and the lemma
follows.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 10.20 below shows that if Îº is measurable cardinal then a normal
measure exists.
Theorem 10.20. Every measurable cardinal carries a normal measure. If
U is a nonprincipal Îº-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº then there exists a function
f : Îº â†’Îº such that fâˆ—(U) = {X âŠ‚Îº : fâˆ’1(X) âˆˆU} is a normal measure.

Proof. Let U be a nonprincipal Îº-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº. For f and g in ÎºÎº,
let
f â‰¡g
if and only if
{Î± < Îº : f(Î±) = g(Î±)} âˆˆU.

if and only if

There exists no inï¬nite descending sequence f0 > f1 > . . . > fn > . . .:

Let D = fâˆ—(U) = {X âŠ‚Îº : fâˆ’1(X) âˆˆU}. We claim that D is a normal

It is easy to verify that D is a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter. For every Î³ < Îº, we
have fâˆ’1({Î³}) /âˆˆU, and so {Î³} /âˆˆD, and so D is nonprincipal.
In order to show that D is normal, let h be a regressive function on a set
X âˆˆD. We shall show that h is constant on a set in D. Let g be the function
deï¬ned by g(Î±) = h(f(Î±)). As g(Î±) < f(Î±) for all Î± âˆˆfâˆ’1(X), we have
g < f, and it follows by the minimality of f that g is constant on some
Y âˆˆU. Hence h is constant on f(Y ) and f(Y ) âˆˆD.
âŠ“âŠ”
As an application of normal measures we show that every measurable
cardinal is a Mahlo cardinal, and improve Lemma 10.18 by showing that
every measurable cardinal is a Ramsey cardinal.
Lemma 10.21. Every measurable cardinal is a Mahlo cardinal.
Proof. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal. We shall show that the set of all
inaccessible cardinals Î± < Îº is stationary. As Îº is strong limit, the set of all
strong limit cardinals Î± < Îº is closed unbounded, and it suï¬ƒces to show that
the set of all regular cardinals Î± < Îº is stationary.
Let D be a normal measure on Îº. We claim that {Î± < Îº : Î± is regu-
lar} âˆˆD; this will complete the proof, since every set in D is stationary, by
Lemma 10.19.
Toward a contradiction, assume that {Î± : cf Î± < Î±} âˆˆD. By normality,
there is some Î» < Îº such that EÎ» = {Î± : cf Î± = Î»} âˆˆD. For each Î± âˆˆEÎ»,
let âŸ¨xÎ±,Î¾ : Î¾ < Î»âŸ©be an increasing sequence with limit Î±. For each Î¾ < Î»
there exist yÎ¾ and AÎ¾ âˆˆD such that xÎ±,Î¾ = yÎ¾ for all Î± âˆˆAÎ¾. Let A =

Î¾<Î» AÎ¾. Then A âˆˆD, but A contains only one element, namely limÎ¾â†’Î» yÎ¾;
a contradiction.

Theorem 10.22. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal, let D be a normal measure
on Îº, and let F be a partition of [Îº]<Ï‰ into less than Îº pieces. Then there
exists a set H âˆˆD homogeneous for F. Hence every measurable cardinal is
a Ramsey cardinal.
Proof. Let D be a normal measure on Îº, and let F be a partition of [Îº]<Ï‰
into fewer than Îº pieces. It suï¬ƒces to show that for each n = 1, 2, . . . ,
there is Hn âˆˆD such that F is constant on [Hn]n; then H = âˆ
n=1 Hn is
homogeneous for F.
We prove, by induction on n, that every partition of [Îº]n into fewer than Îº
pieces is constant on [H]n for some H âˆˆD. The assertion is trivial for n = 1,
so we assume that it is true for n and prove that it holds also for n + 1. Let
F : [Îº]n+1 â†’I, where |I| < Îº. For each Î± < Îº, we deï¬ne FÎ± on [Îº âˆ’{Î±}]n
by FÎ±(x) = F({Î±} âˆªx).
By the induction hypothesis, there exists for each Î± < Îº a set XÎ± âˆˆD
such that FÎ± is constant on [XÎ±]n; let ia be its constant value. Let X be the
diagonal intersection X = {Î± < Îº : Î± âˆˆ
Î³<Î± XÎ³}. We have X âˆˆD since
D is normal; also, if Î³ < Î±1 < . . . < Î±n are in X, then {Î±1, . . . , Î±n} âˆˆ[XÎ³]n
and so F({Î³, Î±1, . . . , Î±n}) = FÎ³({Î±1, . . . , Î±n}) = iÎ³. Now, there exist i âˆˆI
and H âŠ‚X in D such that iÎ³ = i for all Î³ âˆˆH. It follows that F(x) = i for
all x âˆˆ[H]n+1.
âŠ“âŠ”
Strongly Compact and Supercompact Cardinals
Among the various large cardinals that we shall investigate in more detail
in Part II there are two that are immediate generalizations of measurable
cardinals.
Deï¬nition 10.23. An uncountable cardinal Îº is strongly compact if for any
set S, every Îº-complete ï¬lter on S can be extended to a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter
on S.
Clearly, every strongly compact cardinal is measurable.
Let A be a set of size at least Îº, and let us consider the ï¬lter F on PÎº(A)
generated by the sets Ë†P = {Q âˆˆPÎº(A) : P âŠ‚Q}. F is a Îº-complete ï¬lter and
if Îº is strongly compact, F can be extended to a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter U.
A Îº-complete ultraï¬lter U on PÎº(A) that extends F is called a ï¬ne measure.
In Part II we prove that if a ï¬ne measure on PÎº(A) exists for every A, then
Îº is strongly compact.
A ï¬ne measure U on P<Îº(A) is normal if whenever f : PÎº(A) â†’A is
such that f(P) âˆˆP for all P in a set in U, then f is constant on a set
in U. Equivalently, U is normal if it is closed under diagonal intersections
â–³aâˆˆA Xa = {x âˆˆPÎº(A) : x âˆˆ
aâˆˆx Xa}.
Deï¬nition 10.24. An uncountable cardinal Îº is supercompact if for every A
such that |A| â‰¥Îº there exists a normal measure on PÎº(A).

10. Measurable Cardinals

We return to the subject of strongly compact and supercompact cardinals
in Part II.
