Historical Notes
The study of measurable cardinals originated around 1930 with the work of Banach,
Kuratowski, Tarski, and Ulam. Ulam showed in [1930] that measurable cardinals are
large, that the least measurable cardinal is at least as large as the least inaccessible
cardinal.
The main result on measurable and real-valued measurable cardinals (Theo-
rem 10.1) is due to Ulam [1930]. The fact that a measurable cardinal is inaccessible
(Lemma 10.4) was discovered by Ulam and Tarski (cf. Ulam [1930]). Prior to Ulam,

138
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Banach and Kuratowski proved in [1929] that if 2â„µ0 = â„µ1, then there is no mea-
sure on the continuum; their proof is as in Lemma 10.16. Real-valued measurable
cardinals were introduced by Banach in [1930].
Lemma 10.18: ErdËos and Tarski [1943]. Hanf [1963/64a] proved that the least
inaccessible cardinal is not measurable. That every measurable cardinal is a Ram-
sey cardinal was proved by ErdËos and Hajnal [1962]; the stronger version (Theo-
rem 10.22) is due to Rowbottom [1971].
Strongly compact cardinals were introduced by Keisler and Tarski in [1963/64];
supercompact cardinals were deï¬ned by Reinhardt and Solovay, cf. Solovay et
al. [1978].
Exercise 10.1: Vitali [1905].

11. Borel and Analytic Sets
Descriptive set theory deals with sets of reals that are described in some
simple way: sets that have a simple topological structure (e.g., continuous
images of closed sets) or are deï¬nable in a simple way. The main theme is
that questions that are diï¬ƒcult to answer if asked for arbitrary sets of reals,
become much easier when asked for sets that have a simple description. An
example of that is the Cantor-Bendixson Theorem (Theorem 4.6): Every
closed set of reals is either at most countable or has size 2â„µ0.
Since properties of deï¬nable sets can usually be established eï¬€ectively,
without use of the Axiom of Choice, we shall work in set theory ZF without
the Axiom of Choice. When some statement depends on the Axiom of Choice,
we shall explicitly say so. However, we shall assume a weak form of the Axiom
of Choice. The reason is that in descriptive set theory one frequently considers
unions and intersections of countably many sets of reals, and we shall often
use facts like â€œthe union of countably many countable sets is countable.â€ Thus
we shall work, throughout this chapter, in set theory ZF + the Countable
Axiom of Choice.
In this chapter we develop the basic theory of Borel and analytic sets in
Polish spaces. A Polish space is a topological space that is homeomorphic to
a complete separable metric space (Deï¬nition 4.12).
A canonical example of a Polish space is the Baire space N. The following
lemma shows that every Polish space is a continuous image of N:
Lemma 11.1. Let X be a Polish space. Then there exists a continuous map-
ping from N onto X.
Proof. Let X be a complete separable metric space; we construct a mapping f
of N onto X as follows: It is easy to construct, by induction on the length of
s âˆˆSeq, a collection {Cs : s âˆˆSeq} of closed balls such that Câˆ…= X and
(i) diameter(Cs) â‰¤1/n where n = length(s),
(ii) Cs âŠ‚âˆ
k=0 CsâŒ¢k (all s âˆˆSeq),
(iii) if s âŠ‚t then center(Ct) âˆˆCs.
(11.1)
For each a âˆˆN, let f(a) be the unique point in {Cs : s âŠ‚a}; it is easily
checked that f is continuous and that X = f(N).
âŠ“âŠ”

142
Part I. Basic Set Theory
Analytic Sets
While the collection of Borel sets of reals is closed under Boolean operations,
and countable unions and intersections, it is not closed under continuous
images: As we shall learn presently, the image of a Borel set by a continuous
function need not be a Borel set. We shall now investigate the continuous
images of Borel sets.
Deï¬nition 11.4. A subset of A of a Polish space X is analytic if there exists
a continuous function f : N â†’X such that A = f(N).
Deï¬nition 11.5. The projection of a set S âŠ‚X Ã— Y (into X) is the set
P = {x âˆˆX : âˆƒy (x, y) âˆˆS}.
The following lemma gives equivalent deï¬nitions of analytic sets.
Lemma 11.6. The following are equivalent, for any set A in a Polish
space X:
(i) A is the continuous image of N.
(ii) A is the continuous image of a Borel set B (in some Polish space Y ).
(iii) A is the projection of a Borel set in X Ã— Y , for some Polish space Y .
(iv) A is the projection of a closed set in X Ã— N.
Proof. We shall prove that every closed set (in any Polish space) is analytic
and that every Borel set is the projection of a closed set in X Ã— N. Then
the lemma follows: Since the projection map Ï€ : X Ã— Y â†’X deï¬ned by
Ï€(x, y) = x is continuous, it follows that every Borel set is analytic and that
the continuous image of a Borel set is analytic. Conversely, if A âŠ‚X is an
analytic set, A = f(N), then A is the projection of the set {(f(x), x) : x âˆˆN}
which is a closed set in X Ã— N.
In order to prove that every closed set is analytic, note that every closed
set in a Polish space is itself a Polish space, and thus a continuous image
of N by Lemma 11.1.
In order to prove that every Borel set in X is the projection of a closed
set in X Ã— N, it suï¬ƒces to show that the family P of all subsets of X that
are such projections contains all closed sets, all open sets, and is closed under
countable unions and intersections.
Clearly, the family P contains all closed sets. Moreover, every open set
is a countable union of closed sets; thus it suï¬ƒces to show that P is closed
under âˆ
n=0 and âˆ
n=0.
Recall the continuous mapping a â†’âŸ¨a(n) : n âˆˆNâŸ©of N onto N Ï‰ from
Lemma 11.2, and also recall that the inverse image of a closed set under
a continuous function is closed. Let An, n < Ï‰, be projections of closed sets
in X Ã—N; we shall show that âˆ
n=0 An and âˆ
n=0 An are projections of closed
sets.

Lemma 11.7. A set A in a Polish space is analytic if and only if A is the
result of the operation A applied to a family of closed sets.

It follows from the preceding lemmas that the collection of all analytic
sets in a Polish space is closed under countable unions and intersections,
continuous images, and inverse images, and the Suslin operation (the last
statement is proved like the ï¬rst part of Lemma 11.7). It is however not the
case that the complement of an analytic set is analytic (if X is an uncountable
Polish space). In the next section we establish exactly that; we show that
there exists an analytic set (in N) whose complement is not analytic.

The collection of all âˆ†1

Theorem 11.10 (Suslin). Every analytic set whose complement is also an-
alytic is a Borel set. Thus âˆ†1

Let X be a Polish space and let A and B be two disjoint analytic sets
in X. We say that A and B are separated by a Borel set if there exists a Borel

since in the preceding paragraph we proved exactly the opposite: There is k

Lebesgue Measure
We shall now review basic properties of Lebesgue measure on the n-dimen-
sional Euclidean space.
The standard way of deï¬ning Lebesgue measure is to deï¬ne ï¬rst the
outer measure Âµâˆ—(X) of a set X âŠ‚Rn as the inï¬mum of all possible sums
{v(Ik) : k âˆˆN} where {Ik : k âˆˆN} is a collection of n-dimensional
intervals such that X âŠ‚âˆ
k=0 Ik, and v(I) denotes the volume of I. For
each X, Âµâˆ—(X) â‰¥0 and possibly = âˆ. A set X is null if Âµâˆ—(X) = 0.

11. Borel and Analytic Sets
147
A set A âŠ‚Rn is Lebesgue measurable if for each X âŠ‚Rn,
Âµâˆ—(X) = Âµâˆ—(X âˆ©A) + Âµâˆ—(X âˆ’A).
For a measurable set A, we write Âµ(A) instead of Âµâˆ—(A) and call Âµ(A) the
Lebesgue measure of A.
The standard development of the theory of Lebesgue measure gives the
following facts:
(i) Every interval is Lebesgue measurable, and its measure is equal
to its volume.
(ii) The Lebesgue measurable sets form a Ïƒ-algebra; hence every
Borel set is measurable.
(iii) Âµ is Ïƒ-additive: If An, n < Ï‰, are pairwise disjoint and mea-
surable, then
Âµ
 âˆ

n=0
An

=
âˆ

n=0
Âµ(An).
(iv) Âµ is Ïƒ-ï¬nite: If A is measurable, then there exist measurable
sets An, n < Ï‰, such that A = âˆ
n=0 An, and Âµ(An) < âˆfor
each n.
(v) Every null set is measurable. The null sets form a Ïƒ-ideal and
contain all singletons.
(vi) If A is measurable, then
Âµ(A) = sup{Âµ(K) : K âŠ‚A is compact}.
(vii) If A is measurable, then there is an FÏƒ set F and a GÎ´ set G
such that F âŠ‚A âŠ‚G and G âˆ’F is null.
(11.15)
This last property gives this characterization of Lebesgue measurable sets:
A set A âŠ‚Rn is measurable if and only if there is a Borel set B such that
the symmetric diï¬€erence A â–³B = (A âˆ’B) âˆª(B âˆ’A) is null.
One consequence of this is that if we denote by B the Ïƒ-algebra of Borel
sets and by M the Ïƒ-algebra of measurable sets, and if IÂµ is the ideal of all
null sets, then B/IÂµ = M/IÂµ. The Boolean algebra B/IÂµ is Ïƒ-complete; and
since a familiar argument shows that IÂµ is (as an ideal in M) Ïƒ-saturated,
we conclude that B/IÂµ is a complete Boolean algebra. We shall return to this
in Part II.
Assuming the Axiom of Choice one can show that there exists a set of reals
that is not Lebesgue measurable. One such example is the Vitali set in Exer-
cise 10.1. As another example there exists a set X âŠ‚Rn such that neither X
nor its complement has a perfect subset (see Exercise 5.1 for a construc-
tion of such a set). The set X is not measurable: Otherwise, e.g., Âµ(X) > 0
and by (11.15)(vi) there is a closed K âŠ‚X such that Âµ(K) > 0; thus K is
uncountable and hence contains a perfect subset, a contradiction.
However, we shall show in Part II that it is consistent (with ZF + DC)
that all sets or reals are Lebesgue measurable.

We conclude this review of Lebesgue measurability with two lemmas.
One is the well-known Fubini Theorem, and we state it here, without proof,
for the sake of completeness. The other lemma will be used in the proof of
Theorem 11.18 below.
If A is a subset of the plane R2 and x âˆˆR, let Ax denote the set {y :
(x, y) âˆˆA}.
Lemma 11.12. Let A âŠ‚R2 be a measurable set. Then A is null if and only
if for almost all x, Ax is null (i.e., the set {x : Ax is not null} is null).
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 11.13. For any set X âŠ‚Rn there exists a measurable set A âŠƒX
with the property that whenever Z âŠ‚A âˆ’X is measurable, then Z is null.

and A âŠƒX}, there is a measurable A âŠƒX such that Âµ(A) = Âµâˆ—(X); clearly

It should be mentioned that the main results of descriptive set theory on
Lebesgue measure can be proved in a more general context, namely for rea-
sonable Ïƒ-additive measures on Polish spaces. An example of such a measure
is the product measure in the Cantor space {0, 1}Ï‰.
The Property of Baire
In Chapter 4 we proved the Baire Category Theorem (Theorem 4.8): The
intersection of countably many dense open sets of reals is nonempty. It is
fairly easy to see that the proof works not only for the real line R but for
any Polish space.
Let us consider a Polish space X. Let us call a set A âŠ‚X nowhere dense
if the complement of A contains a dense open set. Note that A is nowhere
dense just in case for every nonempty open set G, there is a nonempty open
set H âŠ‚G such that A âˆ©H = âˆ…. A set A is nowhere dense if and only if its
closure A is nowhere dense.
A set A âŠ‚X is meager (or of ï¬rst category) if A is the union of countably
many nowhere dense sets. A nonmeager set is called a set of second category.
The Baire Category Theorem states in eï¬€ect that in a Polish space every
nonempty open set is of second category.
The meager sets form a Ïƒ-ideal. Moreover, in case of Rn, N, or the Cantor
space, every singleton {x} is nowhere dense and so the ideal of meager sets
contains all countable sets.
Deï¬nition 11.14. A set A has the Baire property if there exists an open
set G such that A â–³G is meager.

11. Borel and Analytic Sets
149
Clearly, every meager set has the Baire property. Note that if G is open,
then G âˆ’G is nowhere dense. Hence if A â–³G is meager then (X âˆ’A) â–³
(X âˆ’G) = Aâ–³G is meager, and it follows that the complement of a set with
the Baire property also has the Baire property. It is also easy to see that the
union of countably many sets with the Baire property has the Baire property
and we have:
Lemma 11.15. The sets having the Baire property form a Ïƒ-algebra; hence
every Borel set has the Baire property.
âŠ“âŠ”
If B denotes the Ïƒ-algebra of Borel sets, and if we denote by C the Ïƒ-
algebra of sets with the Baire property, and if I is the Ïƒ-ideal of meager
sets, we have B/I = C/I. Note that the algebra B/I is Ïƒ-saturated: Let O
be a countable topology base for X. For each nonmeager set X with the
Baire property there exists G âˆˆO such that G âˆ’X is meager. Thus the set
D = {[G] : G âˆˆO} of equivalence classes is a dense set in B/I. Hence B/I is
Ïƒ-saturated and is a complete Boolean algebra.
The Axiom of Choice implies that sets without the Baire property exist.
For instance, the Vitali set (Exercise 10.1) is such, see Exercise 11.7.
If X âŠ‚Rn is such that neither X nor its complement has a perfect
subset, then X does not have the Baire property: Otherwise, e.g., X is of
second category and hence X contains a GÎ´ subset G of second category.
Now G is uncountable, and this is a contradiction since as we shall prove
in Theorem 11.18, every uncountable Borel set (even analytic) has a perfect
subset.
The following two lemmas are analogs of Lemmas 11.12 and 11.13. The
ï¬rst one, although not very diï¬ƒcult to prove, is again stated without proof.
Lemma 11.16. Let A âŠ‚R2 have the property of Baire. Then A is meager
if and only if Ax is meager for all x except a meager set.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 11.17. For any set S in a Polish space X, there exists a set A âŠƒS
that has the Baire property and such that whenever Z âŠ‚A âˆ’S has the Baire
property, then Z is meager.
Proof. Let us consider a ï¬xed countable topology basis O for X. Let S âŠ‚X.
Let
D(S) = {x âˆˆX : for every U âˆˆO such that x âˆˆU, U âˆ©S is not meager}.
Note that the complement of D(S) is the union of open sets and hence open;
thus D(S) is closed.
The set S âˆ’D(S) is the union of all S âˆ©U where U âˆˆO and S âˆ©U is
meager; since O is countable, X âˆ’D(S) is meager. Let
A = S âˆªD(S).
Since A = (S âˆ’D(S))âˆªD(S) is the union of a meager and a closed set, A has
the Baire property.

Part I. Basic Set Theory
Let Z âŠ‚A âˆ’S have the Baire property; we shall show that Z is meager.
Otherwise there is U âˆˆO such that U âˆ’Z is meager; hence U âˆ©S is meager.
Since U âˆ©Z Ì¸= âˆ…and Z âŠ‚D(S), there is x âˆˆU such that x âˆˆD(S), and
hence U âˆ©S is not meager, a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
Although both â€œnullâ€ and â€œmeagerâ€ mean in a sense â€œnegligible,â€ see
Exercise 11.8 that shows that the real line can be decomposed into a null set
and a meager set.
Analytic Sets: Measure, Category, and the Perfect Set
Property
Theorem 11.18.
(i) Every analytic set of reals is Lebesgue measurable.
(ii) Every analytic set has the Baire property.
(iii) Every uncountable analytic set contains a perfect subset.
Corollary 11.19. Every Î 1
1 set of reals is Lebesgue measurable and has the
Baire property.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 11.20. Every analytic (and in particular every Borel) set is ei-

âŠ“âŠ”
We prove (ii) and (iii) for an arbitrary Polish space. The proof of (i) is
general enough to work for other measures (in Polish spaces) as well.
Proof. The proof of (i) and (ii) is exactly the same and uses either Lem-

Baire property). We give the proof of (i) and leave (ii) to the reader.

In this fashion we construct st âˆˆT (Î±) for each ï¬nite 0â€“1 sequence t. These
elements st generate a subtree U = {s : s âŠ‚st for some t} of T (Î±) such
that (1) U is perfect, (2) every s has at most two immediate successors in U
(hence [U] is a compact set in N), and (3) f is one-to-one on [U].
Let P be the image of [U] under the function f. Since [U] is compact and
f is continuous, P is also compact, and hence closed. Moreover, P has no
isolated points because [U] is perfect and f is continuous. Thus P is a perfect
subset of A.

Historical Notes
Borel sets were introduced by Borel in [1905]. Lebesgue in [1905] proved in eï¬€ect
Lemma 11.2. Suslinâ€™s discovery of an error in a proof in Lebesgueâ€™s article led to
a construction of an analytic non-Borel set and introduction of the operation A.
The basic results on analytic sets as well as Theorem 11.10 appeared in Suslinâ€™s
article [1917].
Projective sets were introduced by Luzin [1925] and [1927a], and SierpiÂ´nski
[1925] and [1927]. The present notation (Î£ and Î ) appeared ï¬rst in the paper
[1959] of Addison who noticed the analogy between Luzinâ€™s hierarchy of projective
sets and Kleeneâ€™s hierarchy of analytic predicates [1955].
Lemma 11.8: Luzin [1930].
Lemma 11.11: Luzin [1927b].
For detailed treatment of Lebesgue measure, we refer the reader to Halmosâ€™
book [1950]; Lebesgue introduced his measure and integral in his thesis [1902]. Sets
of ï¬rst and second category were introduced by Baire [1899].
Lemmas 11.13 and 11.17: Marczewski [1930a].
Lemma 11.16: Kuratowski and Ulam [1932].
Theorem 11.18(i) (measurability of analytic sets) is due to Luzin [1917]. The-
orem 11.18(ii) (Baire property) is due to Luzin and SierpiÂ´nski [1923] and Theo-
rem 11.18(iii) (perfect subsets) is due to Suslin; cf. Luzin [1930]. The present proof
of (i) and (ii) follows Marczewski [1930a]. Prior to Suslin (and following the Cantor-
Bendixson Theorem for closed sets) Young proved in [1906] the perfect subset result
for GÎ´ and FÏƒ sets; and Hausdorï¬€[1916] and Aleksandrov [1916] proved the same
for Borel sets.

12. Models of Set Theory
Modern set theory uses extensively construction of models to establish rela-
tive consistency of various axioms and conjectures. As the techniques often
involve standard model-theoretic concepts, we assume familiarity with basic
notions of models and satisfaction, submodels and embeddings, as well as
Skolem functions, direct limit and ultraproducts. We shall review the basic
notions, notation and terminology of model theory.
Review of Model Theory
A language is a set of symbols: relation symbols, function symbols, and con-
stant symbols:
L = {P, . . . , F, . . . , c, . . .}.
Each P is assumed to be an n-placed relation for some integer n â‰¥1; each F
is an m-placed function symbol for some m â‰¥1.
Terms and formulas of a language L are certain ï¬nite sequences of sym-
bols of L, and of logical symbols (identity symbol, parentheses, variables,
connectives, and quantiï¬ers). The set of all terms and the set of all formulas
are deï¬ned by recursion. If the language is countable (i.e., if |L| â‰¤â„µ0), then
we may identify the symbols of L, as well as the logical symbols, with some
hereditarily ï¬nite sets (elements of VÏ‰); then formulas are also hereditarily
ï¬nite.
A model for a given language L is a pair A = (A, I), where A is the
universe of A and I is the interpretation function which maps the symbols
of L to appropriate relations, functions, and constants in A. A model for L
is usually written in displayed form as
A = (A, P A, . . . , F A, . . . , cA, . . .)
By recursion on length of terms and formulas one deï¬nes the value of a term
tA[a1, . . . , an]
and satisfaction
A âŠ¨Ï•[a1, . . . , an]
where t is a term, Ï• is a formula, and âŸ¨a1, . . . , anâŸ©is a ï¬nite sequence in A.

156
Part I. Basic Set Theory

for all relations, functions, and constants of A. If f is an isomorphism, then

A submodel of A is a subset B âŠ‚A endowed with the relations P A âˆ©Bn,

An embedding of B into A is an isomorphism between B and a submodel
Bâ€² âŠ‚A.

Two models A, B are elementarily equivalent if they satisfy the same
sentences.

A âŠ¨Ï•[a, a1, . . . , an].

for every a1, . . . , an. Using the Axiom of Choice, one can construct a Skolem

Given a set of Skolem functions, one for each formula of L, the closure of
a set X âŠ‚A is a Skolem hull of X. It is clear that the Skolem hull of X is
an elementary submodel of A, and has cardinality at most |X| Â· |L| Â· â„µ0. In
particular, we have the following:

Theorem 12.1 (LÂ¨owenheim-Skolem). Every inï¬nite model for a count-

An elementary embedding is an embedding whose range is an elementary
submodel.
A set X âŠ‚A is deï¬nable over A if there exist a formula Ï• and some
a1, . . . , an âˆˆA such that
X = {x âˆˆA : A âŠ¨Ï•[x, a1, . . . , an]}.
We say that X is deï¬nable in A from a1, . . . , an. If Ï• is a formula of x only,
without parameters a1, . . . , an, then X is deï¬nable in A. An element a âˆˆA
is deï¬nable (from a1, . . . , an) if the set {a} is deï¬nable (from a1, . . . , an).
GÂ¨odelâ€™s Theorems
The cornerstone of modern logic are GÂ¨odelâ€™s theorems: the Completeness
Theorem and two incompleteness theorems.
A set Î£ of sentences of a language L is consistent if there is no formal
proof of contradiction from Î£. The Completeness Theorem states that every
consistent set of sentences has a model.
The First Incompleteness Theorem shows that no consistent (recursive)
extension of Peano Arithmetic is complete: there exists a statement that is
undecidable in the theory. In particular, if ZFC is consistent (as we believe),
no additional axioms can prove or refute every sentence in the language of
set theory.
The Second Incompleteness Theorem proves that suï¬ƒciently strong math-
ematical theories such as Peano Arithmetic or ZF (if consistent) cannot prove
its own consistency. GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second Incompleteness Theorem implies that it
is unprovable in ZF that there exists a model of ZF. This fact is signiï¬cant for
the theory of large cardinals, and we shall return to it later in this chapter.
Direct Limits of Models
An often used construction in model theory is the direct limit of a directed
system of models. A directed set is a partially ordered set (D, <) such that
for every i, j âˆˆD there is a k âˆˆD such that i â‰¤k and j â‰¤k.
First consider a system of models {Ai : i âˆˆD}, indexed by a directed
set D, such that for all i, j âˆˆD, if i < j then Ai â‰ºAj. Let A = 
iâˆˆD Ai; i.e.,
the universe of A is the union of the universes of the Ai, P A = 
iâˆˆD P Ai, etc.
It is easily proved by induction on the complexity of formulas that Ai â‰ºA
for all i.
In general, we consider a directed system of models which consists of
models {Ai : i âˆˆD} together with elementary embeddings ei,j : Ai â†’Aj
such that ei,k = ej,k â—¦ei,j for all i < j < k.

Proof. Consider the set S of all pairs (i, a) such that i âˆˆD and a âˆˆAi, and

In set theory, a frequent application of direct limits involves the case when
D is an ordinal number (and < is its well-ordering).

Models of Set Theory and Relativization
The language of set theory consists of one binary predicate symbol âˆˆ, and
so models of set theory are given by its universe M and a binary relation E
on M that interprets âˆˆ.
We shall also consider models of set theory that are proper classes. How-
ever, due to GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second Incompleteness Theorem, we have to be careful
how the generalization is formulated.
Deï¬nition 12.6. Let M be a class, E a binary relation on M and let
Ï•(x1, . . . , xn) be a formula of the language of set theory. The relativization
of Ï• to M, E is the formula
(12.14)
Ï•M,E(x1, . . . , xn)
deï¬ned inductively as follows:
(12.15)
(x âˆˆy)M,E â†”x E y
(x = y)M,E â†”x = y
(Â¬Ï•)M,E â†”Â¬Ï•M,E
(Ï• âˆ§Ïˆ)M,E â†”Ï•M,E âˆ§ÏˆM,E
(âˆƒx Ï•)M,E â†”(âˆƒx âˆˆM) Ï•M,E
and similarly for the other connectives and âˆ€.

When E is âˆˆ, we write Ï•M instead of Ï•M,âˆˆ.
When using relativization Ï•M,E(x1, . . . , xn) it is implicitly assumed that
the variables x1, . . . , xn range over M. We shall often write
(M, E) âŠ¨Ï•(x1, . . . , xn)
instead of (12.14) and say that the model (M, E) satisï¬es Ï•. We point out

the general satisfaction relation is formally undeï¬nable in ZF.
Let Form denote the set of all formulas of the language {âˆˆ}. As with any
actual (metamathematical) natural number we can associate the correspond-

theory the corresponding element of the set Form. To make the distinction,
if Ï• is a formula, let âŒœÏ•âŒdenote the corresponding element of Form.

of (12.16) (relativization) is not deï¬ned for Ï• âˆˆForm, and the right-hand
side (satisfaction) is not deï¬ned if M is a proper class.
Below we sketch a proof of a theorem of Tarski, closely related to GÂ¨odelâ€™s
Second Incompleteness Theorem. The theorem states that there is no set-
theoretical property T (x) such that if Ïƒ is a sentence that T (âŒœÏƒâŒ) holds if and
only if Ïƒ holds.

if Ïƒ is a sentence, then #Ïƒ is the GÂ¨odel number of Ïƒ, a natural number. We
say that T (x) is a truth deï¬nition if:
(i) âˆ€x (T (x) â†’x âˆˆÏ‰);
(ii) if Ïƒ is a sentence, then Ïƒ â†”T (#Ïƒ).
(12.17)
Theorem 12.7 (Tarski). A truth deï¬nition does not exist.

Relative Consistency
By GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second Incompleteness Theorem it is impossible to show the
consistency of ZF (or related theories) by means limited to ZF alone.
Once we assume that ZF (or ZFC) is consistent, we may ask whether the
theory remains consistent if we add an additional axiom A.
Let T be a mathematical theory (in our case, T is either ZF or ZFC), and
let A be an additional axiom. We say that T + A is consistent relative to T
(or that A is consistent with T) if the following implication holds:
if T is consistent, then so is T + A.
If both A and Â¬A are consistent with T, we say that A is independent of T.
The question whether A is consistent with T is equivalent to the question
whether the negation of A is provable in T (provided T is consistent); this is
because T + A is consistent if and only if Â¬A is not provable in T.
The way to show that an axiom A is consistent with ZF (ZFC) is to
use models. For assume that we have a model M (possibly a proper class)
of ZF such that M âŠ¨A. (More precisely, the relativizations ÏƒM hold for all
axioms Ïƒ of ZF, as well as AM.) Then A is consistent with ZF: If it were not,
then Â¬A would be provable in ZF, and since M is a model of ZF, M would
satisfy Â¬A. However, (Â¬A)M contradicts AM.
Transitive Models and âˆ†0 Formulas
If M is a transitive class then the model (M, âˆˆ) is called a transitive model.
We note that transitive models satisfy the Axiom of Extensionality (see Ex-
ercise 12.4) and that every well-founded extensional model is isomorphic to
a transitive model (Theorem 6.15).
Deï¬nition 12.8. A formula of set theory is a âˆ†0-formula if
(i) it has no quantiï¬ers, or
(ii) it is Ï•âˆ§Ïˆ, Ï•âˆ¨Ïˆ, Â¬Ï•, Ï• â†’Ïˆ or Ï• â†”Ïˆ where Ï• and Ïˆ are âˆ†0-formulas,
or
(iii) it is (âˆƒx âˆˆy) Ï• or (âˆ€x âˆˆy) Ï• where Ï• is a âˆ†0-formula.

It should be emphasized that cardinal concepts are generally not absolute.

Consistency of the Axiom of Regularity
As an application of the theory of transitive models we show that the Axiom
of Regularity is consistent with the other axioms of ZF. In this section only
we work in the theory ZF minus Regularity, i.e., axioms 1.1â€“1.7.
The cumulative hierarchy VÎ± is deï¬ned as in Chapter 6, and we denote (in
the present section only) V not the universal class but the class 
Î±âˆˆOrd VÎ±.
We shall show that V is a transitive model of ZF. Thus the Axiom of Regu-
larity is consistent relative to the theory 1.1â€“1.7.
Theorem 12.11. In ZF minus Regularity, ÏƒV holds for every axiom Ïƒ
of ZF.
Proof. We use absoluteness of âˆ†0-formulas and the fact that for every set x,
if x âŠ‚V , then x âˆˆV .
Extensionality. The formula
((âˆ€u âˆˆX) u âˆˆY âˆ§(âˆ€u âˆˆY ) u âˆˆX) â†’X = Y
is âˆ†0.

is âˆ†0 (see Lemma 12.10), the Pairing Axiom holds in V .

V âŠ¨âˆ€X âˆ€p âˆƒY âˆ€u (u âˆˆY â†”u âˆˆX âˆ§Ï•(u, p)).

Inaccessibility of Inaccessible Cardinals
Theorem 12.12. The existence of inaccessible cardinals is not provable
in ZFC. Moreover, it cannot be shown that the existence of inaccessible car-
dinals is consistent with ZFC.
We shall prove the ï¬rst assertion and invoke GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second Incomplete-
ness Theorem to obtain the second part.
First we prove (in ZFC):
Lemma 12.13. If Îº is an inaccessible cardinal, then VÎº is a model of ZFC.
Proof. The proof of all axioms of ZFC except Replacement is as in the proof
of consistency of the Axiom of Regularity (see Exercises 12.7 and 12.8). To
show that VÎº âŠ¨Replacement, it is enough to show:
(12.21)
If F is a function from some X âˆˆVÎº into VÎº, then F âˆˆVÎº.
Since Îº is inaccessible, we have |VÎº| = Îº and |X| < Îº for every X âˆˆVÎº. If
F is a function from X âˆˆVÎº into VÎº, then |F(X)| â‰¤|X| < Îº and (since Îº is
regular) F(X) âŠ‚VÎ± for some Î± < Îº. It follows that F âˆˆVÎº.
âŠ“âŠ”
Proof of Theorem 12.12. If Îº is an inaccessible cardinal, then not only is VÎº
a model of ZFC, but in addition
(Î± is an ordinal)VÎº â†”Î± is an ordinal.
(Î± is a cardinal)VÎº â†”Î± is a cardinal.
(Î± is a regular cardinal)VÎº â†”Î± is a regular cardinal.
(Î± is an inaccessible cardinal)VÎº â†”Î± is an inaccessible cardinal.
We leave the details to the reader.
In particular, if Îº is inaccessible cardinal, then
VÎº âŠ¨there is no inaccessible cardinal.
Thus we have a model of ZFC+â€œthere is no inaccessible cardinalâ€ (if there is
no inaccessible cardinal, we take the universe as the model). Hence it cannot
be proved in ZFC that inaccessible cardinals exist.
To prove the second part, assume that it can be shown that the existence
of inaccessible cardinals is consistent with ZFC; in other words, we assume
if ZFC is consistent, then so is ZFC + I
where I is the statement â€œthere is an inaccessible cardinal.â€
We naturally assume that ZFC is consistent. Since I is consistent with
ZFC, we conclude that ZFC + I is consistent. It is provable in ZFC + I that
there is a model of ZFC (Lemma 12.13). Thus the sentence â€œZFC is consis-
tentâ€ is provable in ZFC + I. However, we have assumed that â€œI is consistent
with ZFCâ€ is provable, and so â€œZFC+ I is consistentâ€ is provable in ZFC+ I.
This contradicts GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second Incompleteness Theorem.
âŠ“âŠ”

168
Part I. Basic Set Theory
The wording of the second part of Theorem 12.12 (and its proof) is some-
what vague; â€œit cannot be shownâ€ means: It cannot be shown by methods
formalizable in ZFC.
Reï¬‚ection Principle
The theorem that we prove below is the analog of the LÂ¨owenheim-Skolem
Theorem. While that theorem states that every model has a small elemen-
tary submodel, the Reï¬‚ection Principle provides, for any ï¬nite number of
formulas, a set M that is like an â€œelementary submodelâ€ of the universe,
with respect to the given formulas. The theorem is proved without the use
of the Axiom of Choice, but using the Axiom of Choice, one can obtain
countable model.
Theorem 12.14 (Reï¬‚ection Principle).
(i) Let Ï•(x1, . . . , xn) be a formula. For each M0 there exists a set M âŠƒM0
such that
(12.22)
Ï•M(x1, . . . , xn) â†”Ï•(x1, . . . , xn)
for every x1, . . . , xn âˆˆM. (We say that M reï¬‚ects Ï•.)
(ii) Moreover, there is a transitive M âŠƒM0 that reï¬‚ects Ï•; moreover,
there is a limit ordinal Î± such that M0 âŠ‚VÎ± and VÎ± reï¬‚ects Ï•.
(iii) Assuming the Axiom of Choice, there is an M âŠƒM0 such that M re-
ï¬‚ects Ï• and |M| â‰¤|M0| Â· â„µ0. In particular, there is a countable M
that reï¬‚ects Ï•.
Remarks. 1. We may require either that M be transitive or that |M| â‰¤
|M0| Â· â„µ0 but not both.
2. The proof works for any ï¬nite number of formulas, not just one. Thus
if Ï•1, . . . , Ï•n are formulas, then there exists a set M that reï¬‚ects each of Ï•1,
. . . , Ï•n.
3. If Ïƒ is a true sentence, then the Reï¬‚ection Principle yields a set M that
is a model of Ïƒ; using the Axiom of Choice, one can get a countable transitive
model of Ïƒ.
4. As a consequence of the Reï¬‚ection Principle, and of GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second
Incompleteness Theorem, it follows that the theory ZF is not ï¬nitely axiom-
atizable: Any ï¬nite number of theorems of ZF have a model (a set) by the
Reï¬‚ection Principle, while the existence of a model of ZF is not provable. (By
the same argument, no consistent extension of ZF is ï¬nitely axiomatizable.)
The key step in the proof of Theorem 12.14 is the following lemma, which
we prove ï¬rst.

12. Models of Set Theory
169

size â‰¤|M0| Â· â„µ0. To prove (ii), one has to modify the proof of Lemma 12.15

follows: In (12.28), we replace Mi+1 by its transitive closure (or by the least
VÎ³ âŠƒMi+1). Then M is transitive (or M = VÎ±).

Part I. Basic Set Theory
Historical Notes
For concepts of model theory, the history of the subject and for model-theoretical
terminology, I refer the reader to Chang and Keislerâ€™s book [1973].
Reduced products were ï¬rst investigated by LoÂ´s in [1955], who also proved
Theorem 12.3 on ultraproducts.
For Tarskiâ€™s Theorem 12.7, see Tarski [1939].
The impossibility of a consistency proof of the existence of inaccessible cardinals
follows from GÂ¨odelâ€™s Theorem [1931]. An argument that more or less establishes
the consistency of the Axiom of Regularity appeared in Skolemâ€™s work in 1923 (see
Skolem [1970], pp. 137â€“152).
The study of transitive models of set theory originated with GÂ¨odelâ€™s work on
constructible sets. The Reï¬‚ection Principle was introduced by Montague; see [1961]
and LÂ´evy [1960b].
Exercise 12.12: Montague and Vaught [1959].
Exercise 12.14: Galvin.

Part II
Advanced Set Theory

13. Constructible Sets
Constructible sets were introduced by GÂ¨odel in his proof of consistency of
the Axiom of Choice and of the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis. The
class L of all constructible sets (the constructible universe) is a transitive
model of ZFC, and is the smallest transitive model of ZF that contains all
ordinal numbers. In this chapter we study constructible sets and some related
concepts.
The Hierarchy of Constructible Sets
Recall that a set X is deï¬nable over a model (M, âˆˆ) (where M is a set) if
there exist a formula Ï• âˆˆForm (the set of all formulas of the language {âˆˆ})
and some a1, . . . , an âˆˆM such that X = {x âˆˆM : (M, âˆˆ) âŠ¨Ï•[x, a1, . . . , an]}.
Let
def(M) = {X âŠ‚M : X is deï¬nable over (M, âˆˆ)}.
Clearly, M âˆˆdef(M) and M âŠ‚def(M) âŠ‚P(M).
Deï¬nition 13.1. We deï¬ne by transï¬nite induction
(i) L0 = âˆ…, LÎ±+1 = def(LÎ±),
(ii) LÎ± = 
Î²<Î± LÎ² if Î± is a limit ordinal, and
(iii) L = 
Î±âˆˆOrd LÎ±.
The (deï¬nable) class L is the class of constructible sets. The statement V = L,
i.e., â€œevery set is constructible,â€ is the Axiom of Constructibility.
It follows from Deï¬nition 13.1 that âŸ¨LÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrdâŸ©is a cumulative hier-
archy (see (12.30)); in particular, each LÎ± is transitive, LÎ± âŠ‚LÎ² if Î± < Î²,
and L is a transitive class.
Lemma 13.2. For every Î±, Î± âŠ‚LÎ± (and LÎ± âˆ©Ord = Î±).
Proof. By induction on Î±. At stage Î± + 1, we need to show that Î± âˆˆLÎ±+1,
or that Î± is a deï¬nable subset of LÎ±. Since Î± = {x âˆˆLÎ± : x is an ordinal},
and â€œx is an ordinalâ€ is a âˆ†0 formula, we have Î± = {x âˆˆLÎ± : LÎ± âŠ¨x is an
ordinal}.

Theorem 13.3. L is a model of ZF.
Proof. We show that ÏƒL holds for every axiom Ïƒ of ZF. Since L is a transitive
class, every âˆ†0 formula is absolute for L.
Extensionality. L is transitive and therefore extensional.
Pairing. Given a, b âˆˆL, let c = {a, b}. Let Î± be such that a âˆˆLÎ± and b âˆˆLÎ±.
Since {a, b} is deï¬nable over LÎ±, we have c âˆˆLÎ±+1, and since â€œc = {a, b}â€
is âˆ†0, the Pairing Axiom holds in L.
Separation. Let Ï• be a formula. Given X, p âˆˆL, we wish to show that the set
Y = {u âˆˆX : Ï•L(u, p)} is in L. By the Reï¬‚ection Principle (applied to the
cumulative hierarchy LÎ±, cf. Exercise 12.6), there exists an Î± such that X, p âˆˆ
LÎ± and Y = {u âˆˆX : Ï•LÎ±(u, p)}. Thus Y = {u âˆˆLÎ± : LÎ± âŠ¨u âˆˆX âˆ§Ï•(u, p)}
and so Y âˆˆL.
Union. Given X âˆˆL, let Y =  X. As L is transitive, we have Y âŠ‚L; let Î±
be such that X âˆˆLÎ± and Y âŠ‚LÎ±. Y is deï¬nable over LÎ± by the âˆ†0 formula
â€œx âˆˆ Xâ€ and so Y âˆˆL. Since â€œY =  Xâ€ is âˆ†0, the Axiom of Union holds
in L.
Power Set. Given X âˆˆL, let Y = P(X) âˆ©L. Let Î± be such that Y âŠ‚LÎ±.
Y is deï¬nable over LÎ± by the âˆ†0 formula â€œx âŠ‚Xâ€ and so Y âˆˆL. We
claim that Y = P L(X), i.e., that â€œY is the power set of Xâ€ holds in L. But
â€œx âˆˆY â†”x âŠ‚Xâ€ is a âˆ†0 formula true for every x âˆˆL.
Inï¬nity. We can repeat the proof from Theorem 12.11 as Ï‰ âˆˆL.
Replacement. The easiest way to verify these axioms is to refer to Exer-
cise 1.15, speciï¬cally to (1.10). If a class F is a function in L then for every
X âˆˆL there exists an Î± such that {F(x) : x âˆˆX} âŠ‚LÎ±. Since LÎ± âˆˆL, this
suï¬ƒces.
Regularity. If S âˆˆL is nonempty, let x âˆˆS be such that x âˆ©S = âˆ…. Then
x âˆˆL and the âˆ†0 formula â€œx âˆ©S = âˆ…â€ holds in L.
âŠ“âŠ”
We will show that the model L satisï¬es both the Axiom of Choice and the
Generalized Continuum Hypothesis, thus establishing the consistency of AC
and GCH (relative to ZF). This will be done by showing that L is a model
of the Axiom of Constructibility (V = L), and that V = L implies both AC
and GCH.
It is rather clear that V = L implies AC: it is relatively straightforward to
deï¬ne a well-ordering of L (by transï¬nite induction, using some enumeration
of the set Form of all formulas).
It may appear that L is trivially a model of â€œevery set is constructible.â€
However, to verify V = L in L, we have to prove ï¬rst that the property
â€œx is constructibleâ€ is absolute for L, i.e., that for every x âˆˆL we have
(x is constructible)L. We shall do this by analyzing the complexity of the
property â€œconstructible.â€ While this can be done working directly with the
model-theoretic concepts involved, we prefer to use an alternative approach
(also due to GÂ¨odel).

GÂ¨odel Operations
The Axiom Schema of Separation states that given a formula Ï•(x), for ev-
ery X there exists a set Y = {u âˆˆX : Ï•(u)}. It turns out that for âˆ†0 for-
mulas, the construction of Y from X can be described by means of a ï¬nite
number of elementary operations.
Theorem 13.4 (GÂ¨odelâ€™s Normal Form Theorem). There exist opera-
tions G1, . . ., G10 such that if Ï•(u1, . . . , un) is a âˆ†0 formula, then there is
a composition G of G1, . . ., G10 such that for all X1, . . ., Xn,
(13.1)
G(X1, . . . , Xn) = {(u1, . . . , un) : u1 âˆˆX1, . . . , un âˆˆXn and Ï•(u1, . . . , un)}.
The operations G1, . . . , G10 will be deï¬ned below. Compositions of
G1, . . . , G10 are called GÂ¨odel operations.
We call the following sentence an instance of âˆ†0-Separation:
(13.2)
âˆ€p1 . . . âˆ€pn âˆ€X âˆƒY âˆ€u (u âˆˆY â†”u âˆˆX âˆ§Ï•(u, p1, . . . , pn))
where Ï• is a âˆ†0 formula. We say that a transitive class M satisï¬es âˆ†0-
Separation if for every âˆ†0 formula Ï•, M satisï¬es (13.2).
A class C is closed under an operation F if F(x1, . . . , xn) âˆˆC whenever
x1, . . . , xn âˆˆC. If a class M is closed under the operations G1, . . . , G10 then
M is closed under all GÂ¨odel operations.
Corollary 13.5. If M is a transitive class closed under GÂ¨odel operations
then M satisï¬es âˆ†0-Separation.
Proof. Let Ï•(u, p1, . . . , pn) be a âˆ†0 formula, and let X, p1, . . . , pn âˆˆM. Let
Y = {u âˆˆX : Ï•(u, p1, . . . , pn)}.
By Lemma 12.9 it suï¬ƒces to show that Y âˆˆM, in order that M satisfy (13.2).
By GÂ¨odelâ€™s Normal Form Theorem, there is a GÂ¨odel operation G such that
G(X, {p1}, . . . , {pn}) = {(u, p1, . . . , pn) : u âˆˆX âˆ§Ï•(u, p1, . . . , pn)}.
It follows that
Y = {u : âˆƒu1 . . . âˆƒun (u, u1, . . . , un) âˆˆG(X, {p1}, . . . , {pn})}
= dom . . . dom

Since both {x, y} and dom(x) are GÂ¨odel operations (see below) and since
M is closed under GÂ¨odel operations, we have Y âˆˆM.

Deï¬nition 13.6 (GÂ¨odel Operations).
G1(X, Y ) = {X, Y },
G2(X, Y ) = X Ã— Y,
G3(X, Y ) = Îµ(X, Y ) = {(u, v) : u âˆˆX âˆ§v âˆˆY âˆ§u âˆˆv},

G9(X) = {(u, v, w) : (u, w, v) âˆˆX},
G10(X) = {(u, v, w) : (v, w, u) âˆˆX}.
Proof of Theorem 13.4. The theorem is proved by induction on the complex-
ity of âˆ†0 formulas. To simplify matters, we consider only formulas of this
form:
(i) the only logical symbols in Ï• are Â¬, âˆ§, and restricted âˆƒ;

(âˆƒum+1 âˆˆui) Ïˆ(u1, . . . , um+1)
where i â‰¤m.
(13.3)
Every âˆ†0 formula can be rewritten in this form: The use of logical symbols
can be restricted to Â¬, âˆ§, and âˆƒ; x = y can be replaced by (âˆ€u âˆˆx) u âˆˆy âˆ§
(âˆ€v âˆˆy) v âˆˆx, x âˆˆx can be replaced by (âˆƒu âˆˆx) u = x and the bound vari-
ables in Ï•(u1, . . . , un) can be renamed so that the variable with the highest
index is quantiï¬ed.
Note that we allow dummy variables, so that for instance Ï•(u1, . . . , u5) =
u3 âˆˆu2 and Ï•(u1, . . . , u6) = u3 âˆˆu2 are considered separately.
Thus let Ï•(u1, . . . , un) be a formula in the form (13.3) and let us assume
that the theorem holds for all subformulas of Ï•.

The following lemma shows that GÂ¨odel operations are absolute for tran-
sitive models.
Lemma 13.7. If G is a GÂ¨odel operation then the property Z = G(X1, . . . ,
Xn) can be written as a âˆ†0 formula.
Proof. We show, by induction on the complexity of G (a composition of G1,
. . . , G10):
(i) u âˆˆG(X, . . .) is âˆ†0.
(ii) If Ï• is âˆ†0, then so are âˆ€u âˆˆG(X, . . .) Ï• and âˆƒu âˆˆG(X, . . .) Ï•.
(iii) Z = G(X, . . .) is âˆ†0.
(iv) If Ï• is âˆ†0, then so is Ï•(G(X, . . .)).
(13.5)
We proved (iii) for most of the G1, . . . , G10 in Lemma 12.10; the rest of
the Gi are handled similarly, e.g.,

an obvious modiï¬cation of Ï•, e.g., replacing âˆƒu âˆˆM by âˆƒu). Thus we have
the following description of def(M):
Corollary 13.8. For every transitive set M,
def(M) = cl(M âˆª{M}) âˆ©P(M),
where cl denotes the closure under G1, . . ., G10.

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Inner Models of ZF
An inner model of ZF is a transitive class that contains all ordinals and
satisï¬es the axioms of ZF. The constructible universe L is an inner model
of ZF, and as we show later in this chapter, L is the smallest inner model
of ZF.
In Chapter 12 we proved that âˆ†0 formulas are absolute for all transitive
models, i.e., Ï•M is equivalent to Ï•, for every transitive class M. One can ex-
tend the use of superscripts to concepts other than formulas, namely classes,
operations and constants:
If C is a class {x : Ï•(x)} then CM denotes the class {x : Ï•M(x)}. As
an example, OrdM is either Ord (if M contains all ordinals), or is the least
ordinal not in M.
If F is an operation then F M is the corresponding operation in M (if
x âˆˆM then F M(x) is deï¬ned if M satisï¬es the statement that F(x) ex-
ists). If F M(x) = F(x) for all x for which F M(x) is deï¬ned, we say that
F is absolute for M. By Lemma 13.7, all GÂ¨odel operations are absolute for
transitive models. As an example, P M(X) = P(X) âˆ©M, and V M
Î±
= VÎ± âˆ©M
(Exercise 13.6).
Similarly, if c is a constant symbol then cM, if it exists, is the correspond-
ing constant in M. Thus âˆ…M = âˆ…(if âˆ…âˆˆM), Ï‰M = Ï‰ (if Ï‰ âˆˆM), etc.
The following theorem gives a necessary and suï¬ƒcient condition for a tran-
sitive class to be an inner model of ZF:
Theorem 13.9. A transitive class M is an inner model of ZF if and only if
it is closed under GÂ¨odel operations and is almost universal, i.e., every subset
X âŠ‚M is included in some Y âˆˆM.
Proof. As GÂ¨odel operations are absolute for transitive models, an inner model
is necessarily closed under G1, . . . , G10. If X is a subset of an inner model M,
then X âŠ‚VÎ± âˆ©M for some Î±, and VÎ± âˆ©M is in M because Î± âˆˆM and
VÎ± âˆ©M = V M
Î± . Thus the condition is necessary.
Now let M be a transitive almost universal class that is closed under GÂ¨odel
operations. Except for the Separation Schema, the veriï¬cation of the axioms
of ZF in M follows closely the proof of Theorem 13.3 (or of Theorem 12.11),
but using almost universality. For example, if X âˆˆM then P(X) âˆ©M is
included in some Y âˆˆM, verifying the weak version (1.9) of the Power Set
Axiom. We leave the details to the reader.

The LÂ´evy Hierarchy
Deï¬nable concepts can be classiï¬ed by means of the following hierarchy of
formulas, introduced by Azriel LÂ´evy:
A formula is Î£0 and Î 0 if its only quantiï¬ers are bounded, i.e., a âˆ†0 for-
mula. Inductively, a formula is Î£n+1 if it is of the form âˆƒx Ï• where Ï• is Î n,
and Î n+1 if its is of the form âˆ€x Ï• where Ï• is Î£n.
We say that a property (class, relation) is Î£n (or Î n) if it can be expressed
by a Î£n (or Î n) formula. A function F is Î£n (Î n) if the relation y = F(x)
is Î£n (Î n).

184
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
This classiï¬cation of deï¬nable concepts is not syntactical: To verify that
a concept can be expressed in a certain way may need a proof (in ZF). To
illustrate this, consider the proof of Lemma 13.10 bellow: To contract two
like quantiï¬ers into one uses an application of the Pairing Axiom.
Whenever we say that a property P is Î£n we always mean P can be
expressed by a Î£n formula in ZF, unless we speciï¬cally state which axioms
of ZF are assumed. Since every proof uses only ï¬nitely many axioms, every
speciï¬c property requires a ï¬nite set Î£ of axioms of ZF for its classiï¬cation
in the hierarchy. This ï¬nite set is implicit in the use of the deï¬ning formula.
When M is a transitive model of Î£ then the relativization P M is unambigu-
ous, namely the formula Ï•M. We call such transitive models adequate for P.
A property is âˆ†n if it is both Î£n and Î n.

(i) If P, Q are Î£n properties, then so are âˆƒx P, P âˆ§Q, P âˆ¨Q, (âˆƒu âˆˆx) P,

Consistency of the Axiom of Choice
Theorem 13.18 (GÂ¨odel). There exists a well-ordering of the class L. Thus
V = L implies the Axiom of Choice.
Combining Theorems 13.16 and 13.18, we conclude that the Axiom of
Choice holds in the model L, and so it is consistent with ZF.
Proof. We will show that L has a deï¬nable well-ordering.

Consistency of the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis
Theorem 13.20 (GÂ¨odel). If V = L then 2â„µÎ± = â„µÎ±+1 for every Î±.
Proof. We shall prove that if X is a constructible subset of Ï‰Î± then there
exists a Î³ < Ï‰Î±+1 such that X âˆˆLÎ³. Therefore P L(Ï‰Î±) âŠ‚LÏ‰Î±+1, and

Relative Constructibility
Constructibility can be generalized by considering sets constructible relative
to a given set A, resulting in an inner model L[A]. The idea is to relativize
the hierarchy LÎ± by using the generalization
(13.20)
defA(M) = {X âŠ‚M : X is deï¬nable over (M, âˆˆ, A âˆ©M)}
where A âˆ©M is considered a unary predicate. A generalization of Corol-

set M,
(13.21)
defA(M) = cl(M âˆª{M} âˆª{A âˆ©M}) âˆ©P(M).
The class of all sets constructible from A is deï¬ned as follows:
(13.22)

LÎ±[A] = 

LÎ²[A]
if Î± is a limit ordinal,
L[A] =


LÎ±[A].
The following theorem is the generalization of the relevant theorem on con-
structible sets:
Theorem 13.22. Let A be an arbitrary set.
(i) L[A] is a model of ZFC.
(ii) L[A] satisï¬es the axiom âˆƒX (V = L[X]).

Ordinal-Deï¬nable Sets
A set X is ordinal-deï¬nable if there is a formula Ï• such that
(13.25)
X = {u : Ï•(u, Î±1, . . . , Î±n)}
for some ordinal numbers Î±1, . . . , Î±n.
It is not immediate clear that the property â€œordinal-deï¬nableâ€ is express-
ible in the language of set theory. Thus we give a diï¬€erent deï¬nition of ordinal
deï¬nable sets and show that it is equivalent to (13.25).
We recall that cl(M) denotes the closure of a set M under GÂ¨odel opera-
tions. The class OD of all ordinal-deï¬nable sets is deï¬ne as follows:
(13.26)
OD =

Î±âˆˆOrd
cl{VÎ² : Î² < Î±}.
In other words, OD is the GÂ¨odel closure of {VÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrd}, that is, ordinal
deï¬nable sets are obtained from the VÎ± by applications of GÂ¨odel operations.
We shall show that the elements of the class OD are exactly the sets satisfy-
ing (13.25).
Lemma 13.25. There exists a deï¬nable well-ordering of the class OD (and
a one-to-one deï¬nable mapping F of Ord onto OD).
Proof. Earlier we described how to construct from a given well-ordering of
a set M, a well-ordering of the set cl(M). For every Î±, the set {VÎ² : Î² < Î±}
has an obvious well-ordering, which induces a well-ordering of cl{VÎ² : Î² < Î±}.
Thus we get a well-ordering of the class OD, and denote F the corresponding
(deï¬nable) one-to-one mapping of Ord onto OD.
âŠ“âŠ”
Now it follows that every X âˆˆOD has the form (13.25). There exists Î±
such that X = {u : Ï•(u, Î±)} where Ï•(u, Î±) is the formula u âˆˆF(Î±).
We shall show that on the other hand, if Ï• is a formula and X is the set
in (13.25), then X âˆˆOD. By the Reï¬‚ection Principle, let Î² be such that
X âŠ‚VÎ², Î±1, . . . , Î±n < Î² and that VÎ² reï¬‚ects Ï•. Then we have
X = {u âˆˆVÎ² : Ï•VÎ²(u, Î±1, . . . , Î±n)}.
Since Ï•VÎ² is a âˆ†0 formula, we apply the normal form theorem and ï¬nd a GÂ¨odel
operation G such that X = G(VÎ², Î±1, . . . , Î±n). Since every Î± is obtained (uni-
formly) from VÎ± by a GÂ¨odel operation (because Î± = {x âˆˆVÎ± : x is an ordi-
nal}), there exists a GÂ¨odel operation H such that X = H(VÎ±1, . . . , VÎ±n, VÎ²)
and therefore X âˆˆOD.
Thus let HOD denote the class of hereditarily ordinal-deï¬nable sets
HOD = {x : TC({x}) âŠ‚OD}.
The class HOD is transitive and contains all ordinals.

13. Constructible Sets
195
Theorem 13.26. The class HOD is a transitive model of ZFC.
Proof. The class HOD is transitive, and it is easy to see that it is closed
under GÂ¨odel operations. Thus to show that HOD is a model of ZF, it suï¬ƒces
to show that HOD is almost universal. For that, it is enough to verify that
VÎ±âˆ©HOD âˆˆHOD, for all Î±. For any Î±, the set VÎ±âˆ©HOD is a subset of HOD,
and so it is suï¬ƒcient to prove that VÎ± âˆ©HOD is ordinal-deï¬nable. This is
indeed true because VÎ± âˆ©HOD is the set of all u satisfying the formula
u âˆˆVÎ± âˆ§(âˆ€z âˆˆTC({u})) âˆƒÎ² [z âˆˆcl{VÎ³ : Î³ < Î²}]
and thus VÎ± âˆ©HOD âˆˆOD.
It remains to prove that HOD satisï¬es the Axiom of Choice. We shall show
that for each Î± there exists a one-to-one function g âˆˆHOD of VÎ± âˆ©HOD into
the ordinals. Since every such function is a subset of HOD, it suï¬ƒces to ï¬nd
g âˆˆOD.
By Lemma 13.25, there is a deï¬nable one-to-one mapping G of the
class OD onto the ordinals. If we let g be the restriction of G to the or-
dinal-deï¬nable set VÎ± âˆ©HOD, then g is ordinal-deï¬nable.
âŠ“âŠ”
A set X is ordinal-deï¬nable from A, X âˆˆOD[A], if there is a formula Ï•
such that
(13.27)
X = {u : Ï•(u, Î±1, . . . , Î±n, A)}
for some ordinal numbers Î±1, . . . , Î±n.
As above, this notion is expressible in the language of set theory:
(13.28)
OD[A] = cl({VÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrd} âˆª{A}).
The class OD[A] has a well-ordering deï¬nable from A and thus every set
in OD[A] is of the form (13.27). Conversely (using the Reï¬‚ection Principle),
every set X in (13.27) belongs to OD[A].
The proof of Theorem 13.26 generalizes easily to the case of HOD[A].
Thus HOD[A], the class of all sets hereditarily ordinal-deï¬nable from A, is
a transitive model of ZFC.
As a further generalization, we call X ordinal-deï¬nable over A, X âˆˆ
OD(A), if it belongs to the GÂ¨odel closure of {VÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrd} âˆª{A} âˆªA. If
X âˆˆOD(A), then X âˆˆcl({VÎ± : Î± âˆˆOrd}âˆª{A}âˆªE), where E = {x0, . . . , xk}
is a ï¬nite subset of A. Hence there is a ï¬nite sequence s = âŸ¨x0, . . . , xkâŸ©in A
such that X is ordinal-deï¬nable from A and s. On the other hand, if s is
a ï¬nite sequence in A, then obviously s âˆˆOD(A) and thus we have
OD(A) = {X : X âˆˆOD[A, s] for some ï¬nite sequence s in A}.
In other words, X âˆˆOD(A) if and only if there is a formula Ï• such that
X = {u : Ï•(u, Î±1, . . . , Î±n, A, âŸ¨x0, . . . , xkâŸ©)}
for some ordinal numbers Î±1, . . . , Î±n and a ï¬nite sequence âŸ¨x0, . . . , xkâŸ©in A.

The class HOD(A) of all sets hereditarily ordinal-deï¬nable over A is
a transitive model of ZF. To show that HOD(A) is almost universal, it
suï¬ƒces to verify that VÎ± âˆ©HOD(A) âˆˆOD(A). In fact, VÎ± âˆ©HOD(A) is
ordinal-deï¬nable from A: It is the set
{u âˆˆVÎ± : (âˆ€z âˆˆTC({u})) z âˆˆcl({VÎ² : Î² âˆˆOrd} âˆª{A} âˆªA)}.
More on Inner Models
We conclude this chapter with some comments on inner models of ZF.
As we remarked earlier, cardinal concepts are generally not absolute. The
following theorem summarizes the relations between some of the concepts
and their relativizations (see also Lemma 13.13):
Theorem 13.27. Let M be an inner model of ZF. Then
(i) P M(X) = P(X) âˆ©M, V M
Î±
= VÎ± âˆ©M.
(ii) If |X|M = |Y |M then |X| = |Y |.
(iii) If Î± is a cardinal then Î± is a cardinal in M; if Î± is a limit cardinal,
then Î± is a limit cardinal in M.
(iv) |Î±| â‰¤|Î±|M, cf(Î±) â‰¤cfM(Î±).
(v) If Î± is a regular cardinal, then Î± is a regular cardinal in M; if Î± is
weakly inaccessible, then Î± is weakly inaccessible in M.
(vi) If M is a model of ZFC and Îº is inaccessible, then Îº is inaccessible
in M.
âŠ“âŠ”
Concerning (vi), if Î± < Îº, then since M âŠ¨AC, we must have either
(2Î±)M < Îº or (2Î±)M â‰¥Îº and the latter is impossible since 2Î± < Îº.
If M is a transitive model of ZFC, then the Axiom of Choice in M enables
us to code all sets in M by sets of ordinals and the model is determined by
its sets or ordinals. The precise statement of this fact is: If M and N are
two transitive models of ZFC with the same sets of ordinals, then M = N.
In fact, a slightly stronger assertion is true. (On the other hand, one cannot
prove that M = N if neither model satisï¬es AC.)
Theorem 13.28. Let M and N be transitive models of ZF and assume that
the Axiom of Choice holds in M. If M and N have the same sets of ordinals,
i.e., P M(OrdM) = P N(OrdN), then M = N.
Proof. We start with a rather trivial remark: M and N have the same sets of
pairs of ordinals. To see this, use the absolute canonical one-to-one function
Î“ : Ord Ã— Ord â†’Ord. If X âŠ‚Ord2 and X âˆˆM, then Î“(X) is both in M
and in N, and we have X = Î“âˆ’1(Î“(X)) âˆˆN.

13. Constructible Sets
197
First we prove that M âŠ‚N. Let X âˆˆM. Since M satisï¬es AC, there is
a one-to-one mapping f âˆˆM of some ordinal Î¸ onto TC({X}). Let E âˆˆM
be the following relation on Î¸:
Î± E Î²
if and only if
f(Î±) âˆˆf(Î²).
E is a set of pairs of ordinals and thus we have E âˆˆN. In M, E is well-founded
and extensional. However, these properties are absolute and so E is well-
founded and extensional in N. Applying the Collapsing Theorem (in N), we
get a transitive set T âˆˆN such that (T, âˆˆ) is isomorphic to (Î¸, E). Hence T is
isomorphic to TC({X}) and since both are transitive, we have T = TC({X}).
It follows that TC({X}) âˆˆN and so X âˆˆN.
Now we prove M = N by âˆˆ-induction. Let X âˆˆN and assume that
X âŠ‚M; we prove that X âˆˆM. Let Y âˆˆM be such that X âŠ‚Y (for instance
let Y = V M
Î±
where Î± = rank(X); the rank function is absolute). Let f âˆˆM
be a one-to-one function of Y into the ordinals. Since M âŠ‚N, f is in N and
so f(X) âˆˆN. Since M âŠ‚N, f is in N and so f(X) âˆˆN. However, f(X) is
a set of ordinals and so f(X) âˆˆM, and we have X = fâˆ’1(f(X)) âˆˆM.
âŠ“âŠ”

Historical Notes
The main results, namely consistency of the Axiom of Choice and the General-
ized Continuum Hypothesis, are due to Kurt GÂ¨odel, as is the concept of con-
structible sets. The results were announced in [1938], and an outline of proof ap-
peared in [1939]. GÂ¨odelâ€™s monograph [1940] contains a detailed construction of L,
and the proof that L satisï¬es AC and GCH.

200
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
In [1939] GÂ¨odel deï¬ned constructible sets using LÎ±+1 = the set of all subsets
of LÎ± deï¬nable over LÎ±; in [1940] he used ï¬nitely many operations (and worked in
the system BG).
The investigation of transitive models of set theory was of course motivated by
GÂ¨odelâ€™s construction of the model L. The ï¬rst systematic study of transitive models
was done by Shepherdson in [1951, 1952, 1953]. Bernays in [1937], employed a ï¬nite
number of operations on classes to give a ï¬nite axiomatization of BG. Theorem 13.9
is explicitly stated by Hajnal in [1956].
The Î£n hierarchy was introduced by LÂ´evy in [1965a]. Another result of LÂ´evy
[1965b] is that the truth predicate âŠ¨n+1 is Î£n+1
Karpâ€™s paper [1967] investigates Î£1 relations and gives a detailed computation
verifying that constructibility is Î£1. The characterization of the sets LÎ± as transitive
models of a single sentence Ïƒ is a result of Boolos [1970].
The Diamond Principle was introduced by Jensen in [1972].
Relative constructibility was investigated by Hajnal [1956], Shoenï¬eld [1959]
and most generally by LÂ´evy [1957] and [1960a].
The concept of ordinal deï¬nability was suggested by GÂ¨odel in his talk in 1946,
cf. [1965]; the theory was developed independently by Myhill and Scott in [1971]
and by VopË‡enka, Balcar, and HÂ´ajek in [1968].
Theorem 13.28 is due to VopË‡enka and Balcar [1967].

14. Forcing
The method of forcing was introduced by Paul Cohen in his proof of inde-
pendence of the Continuum Hypothesis and of the Axiom of Choice. Forcing
proved to be a remarkably general technique for producing a large number
of models and consistency results.
The main idea of forcing is to extend a transitive model M of set theory
(the ground model) by adjoining a new set G (a generic set) in order to obtain
a larger transitive model of set theory M[G] called a generic extension. The
generic set is approximated by forcing conditions in the ground model, and
a judicious choice of forcing conditions determines what is true in the generic
extension.
Cohenâ€™s original approach was to start with a countable transitive model M
of ZFC (and a particular set of forcing conditions in M). A generic set can eas-
ily be proved to exist, and the main result was to show that M[G] is a model
of ZFC, and moreover, that the Continuum Hypothesis fails in M[G].
A minor diï¬ƒculty with this approach is that a countable transitive model
need not exist. Its existence is unprovable, by GÂ¨odelâ€™s Second Incompleteness
Theorem. The modern approach to forcing is to let the ground model be the
universe V , and pretend that V has a generic extension, i.e., to postulate
the existence of a generic set G, for the given set of forcing conditions. As
the properties of the generic extension can be described entirely withing the
ground model, statements about V [G] can be understood as statements in
the ground model using the language of forcing. We shall elaborate on this
in due course.
Forcing Conditions and Generic Sets
Let M be a transitive model of ZFC, the ground model. In M, let us consider
a nonempty partially ordered set (P, <). We call (P, <) a notion of forcing
and the elements of P forcing conditions. We say that p is stronger than q if
p < q. If p and q are conditions and there exists r such that both r â‰¤p and
r â‰¤q, then p and q are compatible; otherwise they are incompatible. A set
W âŠ‚P is an antichain if its elements are pairwise incompatible. A set D âŠ‚P
is dense in P if for every p âˆˆP there is q âˆˆD such that q â‰¤p.

202
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Deï¬nition 14.1. A set F âŠ‚P is a ï¬lter on P if
(i) F is nonempty;
(ii) if p â‰¤q and p âˆˆF, then q âˆˆF;
(iii) if p, q âˆˆF, then there exists r âˆˆF such that r â‰¤p and r â‰¤q.
(14.1)
A set of conditions G âŠ‚P is generic over M if
(i) G is a ï¬lter on P;
(ii) if D is dense in P and D âˆˆM, then G âˆ©D Ì¸= âˆ….
(14.2)
We also say that G is M-generic, or P-generic (over M), or just generic.
Note how genericity depends on the ground model M: What matters is
which dense subsets of P are in M. Thus if D is any collection of sets, let us
say that a set G âŠ‚P is a D-generic ï¬lter on P if it is a ï¬lter and if Gâˆ©D Ì¸= âˆ…
for every dense subset of P that is in D. Then G is generic over M just in
case it is D-generic where D is the collection of all D âˆˆM dense in P.
Genericity can be described in several equivalent ways. A set D âŠ‚P is
open dense if it is dense and in addition, p âˆˆD and q â‰¤p imply q âˆˆD; D is
predense if every p âˆˆP is compatible with some q âˆˆD. If p âˆˆP, then D is
dense (open dense, predense, an antichain) below p if it is dense (open dense,
predense, an antichain) in the set {q âˆˆP : q â‰¤p}.
If D is either dense or a maximal antichain then D is predense. In Deï¬ni-
tion 14.1, â€œdenseâ€ in (14.2)(ii) can be replaced by â€œopen dense,â€ â€œpredense,â€
or â€œa maximal antichainâ€â€”see Exercises 14.3, 14.4, and 14.5.
Example 14.2. Let P be the following notion of forcing: The elements of P
are ï¬nite 0â€“1 sequences âŸ¨p(0), . . . , p(n âˆ’1)âŸ©and a condition p is stronger
than q (p < q) if p extends q. Clearly, p and q are compatible if either p âŠ‚q
or q âŠ‚p. Let M be the ground model (note that (P, <) âˆˆM), and let G âŠ‚P
be generic over M. Let f =  G. Since G is a ï¬lter, f is a function. For every
n âˆˆÏ‰, the sets Dn = {p âˆˆP : n âˆˆdom(p)} is dense in P, hence it meets G,
and so dom(f) = Ï‰.
The 0â€“1 function f is the characteristic function of a set A âŠ‚Ï‰. We claim
that the function f (or the set A) is not in the ground model. For every
0â€“1 function g in M, let Dg = {p âˆˆP : p Ì¸âŠ‚g}. The set Dg is dense, hence it
meets G, and it follows that f Ì¸= g.
âŠ“âŠ”
This example describes the simplest way of adjoining a new set of natural
numbers to the ground model. A set A âŠ‚Ï‰ obtained this way is called
a Cohen generic real.
Except in trivial cases, a generic set does not belong to the ground model;
see Exercise 14.6.

This example describes the simplest way of collapsing a cardinal.
As these examples suggest, a generic set over a transitive model need not
exist in general. However, if the ground model is countable, then generic sets
do exist. If M is countable and (P, <) âˆˆM, then the collection D of all
D âˆˆM that are dense in P is countable and the following lemma applies:
Lemma 14.4. If (P, <) is a partially ordered set and D is a countable col-
lection of dense subsets of P, then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P. In
fact, for every p âˆˆP there exists a D-generic ï¬lter G on P such that p âˆˆG.
Proof. Let D1, D2, . . . be the sets in D. Let p0 = p, and for each n, let pn
be such that pn â‰¤pnâˆ’1 and pn âˆˆDn. The set
G = {q âˆˆP : q â‰¥pn for some n âˆˆN}
is a D-generic ï¬lter on P and p âˆˆG.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall now state the ï¬rst of the three main theorems on generic models.
We shall prove these theorems (14.5, 14.6, 14.7) later in this chapter.
Theorem 14.5 (The Generic Model Theorem). Let M be a transitive
model of ZFC and let (P, <) be a notion of forcing in M. If G âŠ‚P is generic
over P, then there exists a transitive model M[G] such that:
(i) M[G] is a model of ZFC;
(ii) M âŠ‚M[G] and G âˆˆM[G];
(iii) OrdM[G] = OrdM;
(iv) if N is a transitive model of ZF such that M âŠ‚N and G âˆˆN, then
M[G] âŠ‚N.
The model M[G] is called a generic extension of M. The sets in M[G]
will be deï¬nable from G and ï¬nitely many elements of M. Each element
of M[G] will have a name in M describing how it has been constructed. An
important feature of forcing is that the generic model M[G] can be described
within the ground model. Associated with the notion of forcing (P, <) is
a forcing language. This forcing language as well as the forcing relation âŠ©
are deï¬ned in the ground model M. The forcing language contains a name
for every element of M[G], including a constant Ë™G, the name for a generic
set (it is customary to denote names by dotted letters Ë™a). Once we select
a generic set G, then every constant of the forcing language is interpreted as
an element of the model M[G].

204
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
The forcing relation is a relation between the forcing conditions and sen-
tences of the forcing language:
p âŠ©Ïƒ
(p forces Ïƒ). The forcing relation, which is deï¬ned in M, is a generalization
of the notion of satisfaction. For instance, if p âŠ©Ïƒ and if Ïƒâ€² is a logical
consequence of Ïƒ, then p âŠ©Ïƒâ€².
The second main theorem on generic models establishes the relation be-
tween forcing and truth in M[G]:
Theorem 14.6 (The Forcing Theorem). Let (P, <) be a notion of forcing
in the ground model M. If Ïƒ is a sentence of the forcing language, then for
every G âŠ‚P generic over M,
(14.3)

if and only if
(âˆƒp âˆˆG) p âŠ©Ïƒ.
[In the left-hand-side Ïƒ one interprets the constants of the forcing language
according to G.]
The third main theorem lists the most important properties of the forcing
relation.
Theorem 14.7 (Properties of Forcing). Let (P, <) be a notion of forcing
in the ground model M, and let M P be the class (in M) of all names.
(i) (a) If p forces Ï• and q â‰¤p, then q âŠ©Ï•.
(b) No p forces both Ï• and Â¬Ï•.

q âŠ©Ï• or q âŠ©Â¬Ï•.

Separative Quotients and Complete Boolean Algebras
While the forcing relation can be deï¬ned directly from the partial order-
ing (P, <), it turns out that its properties, and the properties of the generic
extension are determined by a certain complete Boolean algebra that can
be associated with (P, <). We shall therefore introduce the Boolean alge-
bra B(P) and then use it to deï¬ne the class M P (the P-names) and the
forcing relation âŠ©.
Deï¬nition 14.8. A partially ordered set (P, <) is separative if for all
p, q âˆˆP,
(14.4)
if p â‰°q then there exists an r â‰¤p that is incompatible with q.

14. Forcing
205
The forcing notions in Examples 14.2 and 14.3 are separative. On the other
hand, a linear ordering is not separative (if it has more than one element).
Another example of a nonseparative partial order is the set of all inï¬nite
subsets of Ï‰, ordered by inclusion.
If B is a Boolean algebra, then (B+, <) is a separative partial order.
A more general statement is true. A set D âŠ‚P is dense in a partially ordered
set (P, <) if for every p âˆˆP there is a d âˆˆD such that d â‰¤p. A set D âŠ‚B+
is dense in a Boolean algebra B if it is dense in (B+, <). The following lemma
is easy to verify:
Lemma 14.9. If D is a dense subset of a Boolean algebra B, then (D, <) is
a separative partial order.
âŠ“âŠ”
Conversely, every separative partial order can be embedded densely in
a complete Boolean algebra:
Theorem 14.10. Let (P, <) be a separative partially ordered set. Then there
is a complete algebra B such that:
(i) P âŠ‚B+ and < agrees with the partial ordering of B.
(ii) P is dense in B.
The algebra B is unique up to isomorphism.
Proof. The proof is exactly the same as the proof of Theorem 7.13. B is the
set of all regular cuts in P and separativity implies that every Up (where
p âˆˆP) is regular.
âŠ“âŠ”
When (P, <) is not separative, we can replace it by a separative partial
order that will produce the same generic extension. This is the consequence
of the following lemma:
Lemma 14.11. Let (P, <) be a partially ordered set. There exists a separa-
tive partially ordered set (Q, â‰º) and a mapping h of P onto Q such that
(i) x â‰¤y implies h(x) â‰¼h(y);
(ii) x and y are compatible in P if and only if h(x) and h(y) are
compatible in Q.
(14.5)
Proof. Let us deï¬ne the following equivalence relation on P:
x âˆ¼y
if and only if
âˆ€z (z is compatible with x â†”z is compatible with y).
Let Q = P/âˆ¼and let us deï¬ne
[x] â‰¼[y] â†”(âˆ€z â‰¤x)[z and y are compatible].
The relation â‰¼on Q is a partial ordering, and it is easy to verify that (Q, â‰º) is
separative. The mapping h(x) = [x] satisï¬es (14.5).
âŠ“âŠ”

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
The partial order (Q, â‰º) is called the separative quotient of (P, <) and is
unique (up to isomorphism); see Exercise 14.9.
Corollary 14.12. For every partially ordered set (P, <) there is a complete
Boolean algebra B = B(P) and a mapping e : P â†’B+ such that:
(i) if p â‰¤q then e(p) â‰¤e(q);
(ii) p and q are compatible if and only if e(p) Â· e(q) Ì¸= 0;
(iii) {e(p) : p âˆˆP} is dense in B.
(14.6)
B is unique up to isomorphism.
âŠ“âŠ”
Our earlier statements about the generic extension being determined
by B(P) are based on the following facts:
Lemma 14.13. (i) In the ground model M, let Q be the separative quotient
of P and let h map P onto Q such that (14.5) holds. If G âŠ‚P is generic
over M then h(G) âŠ‚Q is generic over M. Conversely, if H âŠ‚Q is generic
over M then hâˆ’1(H) âŠ‚P is generic over M.
(ii) In the ground model M, let P be a dense subset of a partially ordered
set Q. If G âŠ‚Q is generic over M then G âˆ©P âŠ‚P is generic over M.
Conversely, if H âŠ‚P is generic over M then G = {q âˆˆQ : (âˆƒp âˆˆG) p â‰¤q}
is generic over M.
Proof. The proof is an exercise in verifying deï¬nitions (Exercise 14.1 is useful
here).
âŠ“âŠ”
As a consequence, if e : P â†’B(P) is as in Corollary 14.12 then G âŠ‚P
and H = {u âˆˆB : âˆƒp âˆˆG e(p) â‰¤u} are deï¬nable from each other, and G is
generic if and only if H is, and M[G] = M[H]. Thus P and B(P) produce
the same generic extension.
In the ground model M, let B be a complete Boolean algebra. Outside M,
B is still a Boolean algebra, though not necessarily complete. An ultraï¬lter G
on B is called generic (over M) if
(14.7)

A routine veriï¬cation (see Exercise 14.10) shows that G is a generic ultraï¬lter
if and only if G is a generic ï¬lter on B+.
Boolean-Valued Models
Let B be a complete Boolean algebra. A Boolean-valued model (of the lan-
guage of set theory) A consists of a Boolean universe A and functions of two
variables with values in B,
(14.8)
âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥,
âˆ¥x âˆˆyâˆ¥

(the Boolean values of = and âˆˆ), that satisfy the following:
(i) âˆ¥x = xâˆ¥= 1,
(ii) âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥= âˆ¥y = xâˆ¥,
(iii) âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥Â· âˆ¥y = zâˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥x = zâˆ¥,

Note how the notion of a Boolean-valued model generalizes the notion of
a model; the Boolean value of Ï• is a generalization of the satisfaction pred-
icate âŠ¨. If B is the trivial algebra {0, 1}, then a Boolean-valued model is
just a (two-valued) model; i.e., consider A/â‰¡where x â‰¡y if and only if
âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥= 1.
We say that Ï•(a1, . . . , an) is valid in A, if âˆ¥Ï•(a1, . . . , an)âˆ¥= 1. An im-
plication Ï• â†’Ïˆ is valid if âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥Ïˆâˆ¥. Hence it is postulated in (14.9)
that the axioms for the equality predicate = are valid in a Boolean-valued
model. It can be easily veriï¬ed that all the other axioms of predicate calculus
are valid, and that the rules of inference applied to valid sentences result
in valid sentences. Thus every sentence provable in predicate calculus has
Boolean value 1, and if two formulas Ï•, Ïˆ are provably equivalent, we have
âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥= âˆ¥Ïˆâˆ¥. For example, we have
âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥Â· âˆ¥Ï•(x)âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥Ï•(y)âˆ¥.
Boolean-valued models can therefore be used in consistency proofs in much
the same way as two-valued models. Let A be a Boolean-valued model such

208
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
that all the axioms of ZFC are valid in A. (We say that A is a Boolean-
valued model of ZFC.) Let Ïƒ be a set-theoretical statement and assume that
âˆ¥Ïƒâˆ¥Ì¸= 0. Then we can conclude that Ïƒ is consistent relative to ZFC; otherwise,
Â¬Ïƒ would be provable in ZFC and therefore valid in A: âˆ¥Â¬Ïƒâˆ¥= âˆ’âˆ¥Ïƒâˆ¥= 1.
There is an important special case of Boolean-valued models, and in this
special case, the Boolean-valued model can be transformed into a two-valued
model.
We say that a Boolean-valued model A is full if for any formula Ï•(x, x1,
. . . , xn) the following holds: For all a1, . . . , an âˆˆA, there exists an a âˆˆA such
that
(14.10)
âˆ¥Ï•(a, a1, . . . , an)âˆ¥= âˆ¥âˆƒx Ï•(x, a1, . . . , an)âˆ¥.
Let F be an ultraï¬lter on B. We deï¬ne an equivalence relation on A by
(14.11)

if and only if
âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥âˆˆF,
and a binary relation E on A/â‰¡by
(14.12)

if and only if
âˆ¥x âˆˆyâˆ¥âˆˆF.
That â‰¡is an equivalence relation, and that (14.12) does not depend on the

a ï¬lter. Thus A/F = (A/â‰¡, E) is a model. Moreover, we have the following
relationship between the Boolean-valued model A and the model A/F:
Lemma 14.14. Let A be full. For any formula Ï•(x1, . . . , xn),
(14.13)
A/F âŠ¨Ï•([a1], . . . , [an])
if and only if
âˆ¥Ï•(a1, . . . , an)âˆ¥âˆˆF,
for all a1, . . . , an âˆˆA.
Proof. (a) If Ï• is atomic, then (14.13) is true by deï¬nition.

ultraï¬lter, and the deï¬nition of âˆ¥âˆ¥; e.g., we use

âˆ¥Ïˆâˆ¥âˆˆF and âˆ¥Ï‡âˆ¥âˆˆF.

The Boolean-Valued Model V B
We now deï¬ne the Boolean-valued model V B. Let B be a complete Boolean
algebra.
Our intention is to deï¬ne a Boolean-valued model in which all the axioms
of ZFC are valid. In particular, we want V B to be extensional, i.e., the Axiom
of Extensionality to be valid in V B:
(14.14)

The Forcing Relation
Let M be a transitive model of ZFC (the ground model) and let (P, <) âˆˆM be
a notion of forcing. We shall now introduce the forcing language by specifying
names, deï¬ne the forcing relation âŠ©and prove the fundamental properties
of âŠ©(Theorem 14.7). Throughout this section we work inside the ground
model.
Let (P, <) be a notion of forcing. By Corollary 14.12 there exists a com-
plete Boolean algebra B = B(P) such that P embeds in B by a mapping
e : P â†’B that satisï¬es (14.6) (and is not one-to-one if P is not separative).
We use M B to denote the B-valued model deï¬ned in (14.15) (inside M).

14. Forcing
215
Deï¬nition 14.26. M P = M B(P ). The elements of M P are called P-names
(or just names). P-names are usually denoted by dotted letters. The forcing
language is the language of set theory with names added as constants. The
forcing relation âŠ©P (or just âŠ©) is deï¬ned by
p âŠ©Ï•(Ë™a1, . . . , Ë™an)
if and only if
e(p) â‰¤âˆ¥Ï•(Ë™a1, . . . , Ë™an)âˆ¥
where Ï• is a formula of set theory and Ë™a1, . . . , Ë™an are names.
We remark that both names and the forcing relation can be deï¬ned di-
rectly from P without using the complete Boolean algebra. However, we ï¬nd
the direct deï¬nition somewhat less intuitive.
Proof of Theorem 14.7.
(i) (a) If q â‰¤p then e(q) â‰¤e(p).
(b) âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥Â· âˆ¥Â¬Ï•âˆ¥= 0.
(c) If e(p) Â· âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥Ì¸= 0 then there is a q â‰¤p such that e(q) â‰¤âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥;
similarly if e(p) Â· âˆ¥Â¬Ï•âˆ¥Ì¸= 0.
(ii) (a) Left-to-right: Use (i)(a) and (b). Right-to-left: If p does not
force Â¬Ï• then e(p) Â· âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥Ì¸= 0 and proceed as in (i)(c).
(b) By (14.9)(b) and (c).

One ï¬nal remark: By Theorem 14.24, every axiom of ZFC is forced by every
condition. So is every axiom of predicate calculus, and the forcing relation
is preserved by the rules of inference. Hence every condition forces every
sentence provable in ZFC.

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
The Forcing Theorem and the Generic Model Theorem
We shall now deï¬ne the generic extension M[G] and prove Theorems 14.5
and 14.6. We do it ï¬rst for Boolean-valued models and handle the general
case afterward.
Let M be a generic transitive model of ZFC, and let B be a complete
Boolean algebra in M. Let G be an M-generic ultraï¬lter on B, i.e., generic
over M.
Deï¬nition 14.27 (Interpretation by G). For every x âˆˆM B we deï¬ne xG
by induction on Ï(x):
(i) âˆ…G = âˆ…,
(ii) xG = {yG : x(y) âˆˆG}.
Using the interpretation by G, we let
(14.30)
M[G] = {xG : x âˆˆM B}.
Lemma 14.28. Let G be an M-generic ultraï¬lter on B. Then for all names
x, y âˆˆM B
(i) xG âˆˆyG if and only if âˆ¥x âˆˆyâˆ¥âˆˆG,
(ii) xG = yG if and only if âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥âˆˆG.
Proof. We prove (i) and (ii) simultaneously, by induction on pairs (Ï(x), Ï(y)).
(i) âˆ¥x âˆˆyâˆ¥âˆˆG â†”âˆƒt âˆˆdom(y) (y(t) âˆˆG and âˆ¥x = tâˆ¥âˆˆG)
â†”âˆƒt (y(t) âˆˆG and xG = tG)
â†”xG âˆˆ{tG : y(t) âˆˆG}
â†”xG âˆˆyG.
(ii) âˆ¥x âŠ‚yâˆ¥âˆˆG â†”
tâˆˆdom x(x(t) â‡’âˆ¥t âˆˆyâˆ¥) âˆˆG
â†”âˆ€t âˆˆdom(x) (x(t) âˆˆG implies âˆ¥t âˆˆyâˆ¥âˆˆG)
â†”âˆ€t (x(t) âˆˆG implies tG âˆˆyG)
â†”{tG : x(t) âˆˆG} âŠ‚yG
â†”xG âŠ‚yG.
âŠ“âŠ”
M[G] is a transitive class. The following is the Forcing Theorem for
Boolean-valued models.

Corollary 14.30. M[G] is a model of ZFC.

The following completes the proof of both Theorems 14.5 and 14.6 when

Lemma 14.31.
(i) M âŠ‚M[G], and both models have the same ordinals.
(ii) G âˆˆM[G] and if N âŠƒM is a transitive model of ZFC such that
G âˆˆN, then N âŠƒM[G].
Proof. (i) For every x âˆˆM, the G-interpretation of the canonical name Ë‡x

Lemma 14.23.

containing G, then the construction of M[G] can be carried out inside N, and

We shall now prove Theorems 14.5 and 14.6:
Let (P, <) be a notion of forcing in the ground model M, and let G âŠ‚P
be generic over M. Let B = B(P), and let M P = M B be the class of the

(i) âˆ…G = âˆ…,
(ii) xG = {yG : (âˆƒp âˆˆG) e(p) â‰¤x(y)}.
(14.32)
Then we let

Now let H be the ultraï¬lter on B generated by e(G): H = {u âˆˆB :
âˆƒp âˆˆG e(p) â‰¤u}. H is M-generic, and it is easily seen that xG = xH for all
x âˆˆM B. Thus M[G] = M[H].
The Forcing Theorem now follows from the deï¬nition of âŠ©and The-

the ï¬rst part of (b) are immediate consequences of Lemma 14.31; it only

G = {p âˆˆP : e(p) âˆˆH} is in M[H], or invoke (14.29) and verify that
Ë™GG = G.
Consistency Proofs
Forcing is used mainly (but not exclusively) in consistency proofs. In practice,
a consistency result is usually presented as follows: Suppose that A is some
sentence (in the language of set theory) and we wish to prove that A is consis-
tent with ZFC, or more generally, that A is consistent with some extension T
of ZFC. This is accomplished by assuming that T holds (in V , the universe)
and by exhibiting a forcing notion P such that the generic extension V [G]
satisï¬es A.
One way to make this argument legitimate is to assume that there exists
a countable transitive model M of T. Using a forcing notion P âˆˆM, there
exists a P-generic ï¬lter G over M, and M[G] is a transitive model that
satisï¬es A. Hence A is consistent relative to T.
The assumption of a countable transitive model is unnecessary, as state-
ments about generic extensions can be considered merely as an informal refor-
mulation of statements about the forcing relation. In particular, â€œV [G] satis-
ï¬es Aâ€ is to be understood to mean â€œevery p âˆˆP forces A.â€ Then (assuming
that T is consistent), the negation Â¬A is not provable: If it were then every
condition would force Â¬A (or, the Boolean value âˆ¥Â¬Aâˆ¥would be 1). Note

14. Forcing
219
that for consistency of A, it is enough to show that some p âˆˆP forces A; in
the language of generic extensions, one ï¬nds a p âˆˆP such that when G is
generic and p âˆˆG, then V [G] âŠ¨A.
In some cases, forcing results are stated as independence results: A sen-
tence A is independent of the axioms T. This usually means that both A
and Â¬A are consistent with T.
Independence of the Continuum Hypothesis
We now present Cohenâ€™s proof of independence of CH.
Theorem 14.32. There is a generic extension V [G] that satisï¬es 2â„µ0 > â„µ1.
Proof. We describe the notion of forcing that produces a generic extension
with the desired property. Let P be the set of all functions p such that
(i) dom(p) is a ï¬nite subset of Ï‰2 Ã— Ï‰,
(ii) ran(p) âŠ‚{0, 1},
(14.33)
and let p be stronger than q if and only if p âŠƒq.
If G is a generic set of conditions, we let f =  G. We claim that
(i) f is a function;
(ii) dom(f) = Ï‰2 Ã— Ï‰.
(14.34)
(Of course, Ï‰2 means Ï‰2 in the ground model.)
Part (i) of (14.34) holds because G is a ï¬lter. For part (ii), the sets DÎ±,n =
{p âˆˆP : (Î±, n) âˆˆdom(p)} are dense in P, hence G meets each of them, and
so (Î±, n) âˆˆdom(f) for all (Î±, n) âˆˆÏ‰2 Ã— Ï‰.
Now, for each Î± < Ï‰2, let fÎ± : Ï‰ â†’{0, 1} be the function deï¬ned as
follows:
fÎ±(n) = f(Î±, n).
If Î± Ì¸= Î², then fÎ± Ì¸= fÎ²; this is because the set

Each fÎ± is the characteristic function of a set aÎ± âŠ‚Ï‰. As in Example 14.2,
we call these sets Cohen generic reals. Thus P adjoins â„µ2 Cohen generic reals
to the ground model.
The proof of Theorem 14.32 is almost complete, except for one detail: We
donâ€™t know that the ordinal Ï‰V

the proof by showing that V [G] has the same cardinals as the ground model
(P preserves cardinals).

Deï¬nition 14.33. A forcing notion P satisï¬es the countable chain condition
(c.c.c.) if every antichain in P is at most countable.
The following theorem is one of the basic tools of forcing:
Theorem 14.34. If P satisï¬es the countable chain condition then V and
V [G] have the same cardinals and coï¬nalities.
In other words cfV Î± = cfV [G] Î± for all limit ordinals Î±; the statement on
cardinals follows.
Proof. It suï¬ƒces to show that if Îº is a regular cardinal then Îº remains regular
in V [G]. Thus let Î» < Îº; we show that every function f âˆˆV [G] from Î» into Îº
is bounded.
Let Ë™f be a name, let p âˆˆP and assume
(14.35)
p âŠ©Ë™f is a function from Ë‡Î» to Ë‡Îº.
For every Î± < Î» consider the set

We claim that every AÎ± is at most countable: If W = {qÎ² : Î² âˆˆAÎ±} is a set
of witnesses to Î² âˆˆAÎ± then W is an antichain, and therefore countable by
c.c.c. Hence |AÎ±| â‰¤â„µ0.
Now, because Îº is regular, the set 
