below Îº. It follows that in V [G], every function f : Î» â†’Îº is bounded.

Now we complete the proof of Theorem 14.32 by showing that the forc-
ing notion that we employed satisï¬es c.c.c. That follows from the following
consequence of Theorem 9.18 on âˆ†-systems.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 14.35. Let P be a set of ï¬nite functions, with values in a given
countable set C. Let p < q be deï¬ned as p âŠƒq, and assume that for all p, q âˆˆ
P, if pâˆªq is a function then pâˆªq âˆˆP (or more generally, âˆƒr âˆˆP (r âŠƒpâˆªq)).
Then P satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
Proof. Let F be an uncountable subset of P, and let W be the set {dom(p) :
p âˆˆF}. As C is countable, the set W must be uncountable. By Theorem 9.18
there exists an uncountable âˆ†-system Z âŠ‚W; let S = X âˆ©Y for any X Ì¸= Y
in Z. Let G be the set of all p âˆˆF such that dom(p) âˆˆZ; again because C is
countable there are uncountably many p âˆˆG with the same pâ†¾S. Now if p
and q are two such functions, i.e., dom(p)âˆ©dom(q) = S and pâ†¾S = qâ†¾S, then
p and q are compatible functions and therefore compatible conditions. Hence
F is not an antichain.

Independence of the Axiom of Choice
If the ground model M satisï¬es the Axiom of Choice, then so does the
generic extension. However, we can still use the method of forcing to con-
struct a model in which AC fails; namely, we ï¬nd a suitable submodel of the
generic model, a model N such that M âŠ‚N âŠ‚M[G].
Theorem 14.36 (Cohen). There is a model of ZF in which the real num-
bers cannot be well-ordered. Thus the Axiom of Choice is independent of the
axioms of ZF.
Before we construct a model without Choice, we shall prove an easy but
useful lemma on automorphisms of Boolean-valued models. Let B be a com-
plete Boolean algebra and let Ï€ be an automorphism of B. We deï¬ne, by
induction on Ï(x) an automorphism of the Boolean-valued universe V B, and
denote it also Ï€:
(i) Ï€(âˆ…) = âˆ…;
(ii) dom(Ï€x) = Ï€(dom(x)), and (Ï€x)(Ï€y) = Ï€(x(y)) for all Ï€(y) âˆˆ
dom(Ï€x).
(14.36)
Clearly, Ï€ is a one-to-one function of V B onto itself, and Ï€(Ë‡x) = Ë‡x for every x.
Lemma 14.37. Let Ï•(x1, . . . , xn) be a formula. If Ï€ is an automorphism
of B, then for all x1, . . . , xn âˆˆV B,
(14.37)
âˆ¥Ï•(Ï€x1, . . . , Ï€xn)âˆ¥= Ï€(âˆ¥Ï•(x1, . . . , xn)âˆ¥).
Proof. (a) If Ï• is an atomic formula, (14.37) is proved by induction (as in the
deï¬nition of âˆ¥x âˆˆyâˆ¥, âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥). For instance,
âˆ¥Ï€x âˆˆÏ€yâˆ¥=

Exercises
14.1. Show that in the deï¬nition of generic set one can replace (14.1)(iii) by the
following weaker property: If p, q âˆˆG, then p and q are compatible.
[To prove (14.1)(iii), show that D = {r âˆˆP : either r is incompatible with p,
or r is incompatible with q, or r â‰¤p and r â‰¤q} is dense.]

Historical Notes
The method of forcing was invented by Paul Cohen who used it to prove the inde-
pendence of the Continuum Hypothesis and the Axiom of Choice (see [1963, 1964]
and the book [1966]). The Boolean-valued version of Cohenâ€™s method has been for-
mulated by Scott, Solovay, and VopË‡enka. Following an observation of Solovay that
the forcing relation can be viewed as assigning Boolean-values to formulas, Scott
formulated his version of Boolean-valued models in [1967]. VopË‡enka developed a the-
ory of Cohenâ€™s method of forcing, using open sets in a topological space as forcing
conditions (in [1964, 1965a, 1965b, 1965c, 1966, 1967a] and VopË‡enka-HÂ´ajek [1967]),
eventually arriving at the Boolean-valued version of forcing more or less identical
to Scott-Solovayâ€™s version (VopË‡enka [1967b]).

15. Applications of Forcing
In this chapter we present some important applications of the method of
forcing. These applications establish several major consistency results and
illustrate the techniques involved in use of forcing. Throughout we use V to
denote the ground model, and V [G] for the generic extension.
Cohen Reals
In (14.23) we described a notion of forcing that adjoins â„µ2 real numbers to
the ground model. In general, let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal. The following
notion of forcing adjoins Îº real numbers, called Cohen reals.
Let P be the set of all functions p such that
(i) dom(p) is a ï¬nite subset of Îº Ã— Ï‰,
(ii) ran(p) âŠ‚{0, 1},
(15.1)
and let p be stronger than q if and only if p âŠƒq.
Let G be a generic set of conditions and let f =  G. By a genericity
argument, f is a function from Îº Ã— Ï‰ into {0, 1}. For each Î± < Îº, we let
fÎ± be the function on Ï‰ deï¬ned by fÎ±(n) = f(Î±, n) and let aÎ± = {n âˆˆÏ‰ :
fÎ±(n) = 1}. Each aÎ± is a real (a subset of Ï‰), aÎ± /âˆˆV and if Î± Ì¸= Î², then
aÎ± Ì¸= aÎ². This is proved as in Theorem 14.32.
Also as in Theorem 14.32 one shows that P satisï¬es the countable chain
condition. It follows that cardinals and coï¬nalities are preserved in the generic
extension.
Since P adds Îº distinct Cohen reals, the size of the continuum in V [G] is
at least Îº. In fact, it is at least (Îºâ„µ0)V :
(2â„µ0)V [G] = ((2â„µ0)â„µ0)V [G] â‰¥(Îºâ„µ0)V [G] â‰¥(Îºâ„µ0)V .
It turns out that there are precisely (Îºâ„µ0)V reals in V [G]. The following is
a general estimate of the number of new sets in a generic extension:
Lemma 15.1. Let Î» be a cardinal in V . If G is a V -generic ultraï¬lter on B,
then
(2Î»)V [G] â‰¤(|B|Î»)V .

226
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Proof. Every subset A âŠ‚Î» in V [G] has a name Ë™A âˆˆV B; every such Ë™A deter-
mines a function Î± â†’âˆ¥Ë‡Î± âˆˆË™Aâˆ¥from Î» into B. Diï¬€erent subsets correspond
to diï¬€erent functions, and thus the number of all subsets of Î» in V [G] is not
greater than the number of all functions from Î» into B in V .
âŠ“âŠ”
When P is the forcing (15.1) that adds Îº Cohen reals, P satisï¬es c.c.c. and
so every element of B = B(P) is the Boolean sum of a countable antichain
in P; hence |B| â‰¤|P|â„µ0 = Îºâ„µ0. By Exercise 7.32, |B| = |B|â„µ0 and it follows
that |B| = Îºâ„µ0, and consequently, (2â„µ0)V [G] = (Îºâ„µ0)V .
If we start with a ground model that satisï¬es GCH, and if Îº is (in V ) a car-
dinal of uncountable coï¬nality, then Îºâ„µ0 = Îº in V , and we get a model V [G]
in which 2â„µ0 = Îº.
Adding Subsets of Regular Cardinals
The forcing that adds a Cohen real generalizes easily from Ï‰ to any regular
cardinal Îº. Let Îº be, in V , a regular cardinal and assume that 2<Îº = Îº.
Let P be the set of all functions p such that
(i) dom(p) âŠ‚Îº and | dom(p)| < Îº;
(ii) ran(p) âŠ‚{0, 1}.
(15.2)
A condition p be stronger than q if and only if p âŠƒq.
Let G be a set of conditions generic over V and let f =  G. As before,
f is a function from Îº into {0, 1}, and X = {Î± < Îº : f(Î±) = 1} is a subset
of Îº and X /âˆˆV .
In order to add more new subsets of Îº, we use a generalization of (15.1):
Let Îº be as above, and let Î» be a cardinal greater than Îº such that Î»Îº = Î».
Let P be the set of all functions p such that:
(i) dom(p) âŠ‚Î» Ã— Îº and | dom(p)| < Îº,
(ii) ran(p) âŠ‚{0, 1},
(15.3)
and let p be stronger than q if and only if p âŠƒq.
Let G be a generic set of conditions and let f =  G. For each Î± < Î», we
let
aÎ± = {Î¾ < Îº : f(Î±, Î¾) = 1}.
Each aÎ± is a subset of Îº, each aÎ± /âˆˆV and aÎ± Ì¸= aÎ² whenever Î± Ì¸= Î².
We claim that in the generic extension, all cardinals are preserved, and
2Îº = Î». But to show this, we need additional results in the theory of forcing,
proved in the next two sections.

The Îº-Chain Condition
Deï¬nition 15.2. A forcing notion P satisï¬es the Îº-chain condition (Îº-c.c.)
if every antichain in P has cardinality less than Îº.
The â„µ1-chain condition is the c.c.c. Note that P satisï¬es the Îº-c.c. if and
only if B(P) satisï¬es the Îº-c.c.
Theorem 14.34 generalizes as follows:
Theorem 15.3. If Îº is a regular cardinal and if P satisï¬es the Îº-chain con-
dition then Îº remains a regular cardinal in the generic extension by P.
Proof. The proof is exactly as the proof of Theorem 14.34. The only diï¬€erence
is that the set AÎ± is not necessarily countable but has cardinality less than Îº.
âŠ“âŠ”
Consequently, all regular cardinals Îº â‰¥sat(B(P)), and in particular all
regular Îº â‰¥|P|+ are preserved in V [G].
The following lemma generalizes Lemma 14.35, and implies that the forc-
ing notion (15.3) satisï¬es the Îº+-chain condition. We remark that Lemma 15.4
is related to (a generalization of) Theorem 9.18 on âˆ†-systems.
Lemma 15.4. Let Îº be a regular cardinal such that 2<Îº = Îº. Let S be an
arbitrary set and let |C| â‰¤Îº. Let P be the set of all functions p whose
domains are subsets of S of size < Îº, with values in C. Let p < q if and only
if q âŠƒq. Then P satisï¬es the Îº+-chain condition.
Proof. Let W âŠ‚P be an antichain. We construct sequences A0 âŠ‚A1 âŠ‚

(Î± < Îº) of subsets of W. If Î± is a limit ordinal, we let WÎ± = 

Distributivity
In (7.28) we deï¬ned Îº-distributivity of complete Boolean algebras. We now
show that this concept plays a crucial role in the theory of forcing.
Deï¬nition 15.5. A forcing notion P is Îº-distributive if the intersection of
Îº open dense sets is open dense. P is <Îº-distributive if it is Î»-distributive for
all Î» < Îº.
Note that if P is dense in B then P is Îº-distributive if and only if B is.
Theorem 15.6. Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal and assume that (P, <) is Îº-
distributive. Then if f âˆˆV [G] is a function from Îº into V , then f âˆˆV . In
particular, Îº has no new subsets in V [G].
Proof. Let f : Îº â†’V and f âˆˆV [G], let Ë™f be a name for f. There exist some
A âˆˆV and a condition p0 âˆˆG such that p0 forces
Ë™f is a function from Ë‡Îº into Ë‡A.
For each Î± < Îº, the set
DÎ± = {p â‰¤p0 : (âˆƒx âˆˆA) p âŠ©Ë™f(Ë‡Î±) = Ë‡x}
is open dense below p0. Thus D = 
Î±<Îº DÎ± is dense below p0 and therefore
there is some p âˆˆDâˆ©G. Now we argue in V : For each Î± < Îº there is some xÎ±
such that p âŠ©Ë™f(Ë‡Î±) = Ë‡xÎ±; let g : Îº â†’A be the function deï¬ned by g(Î±) = xÎ±.
However, it is easy to see that f(Î±) = xÎ± = g(Î±), for every Î± < Îº, and thus
f âˆˆV .
âŠ“âŠ”
See Exercise 15.5 for the converse.
The following property, stronger than distributivity, is often easy to verify:
Deï¬nition 15.7. P is Îº-closed if for every Î» â‰¤Îº, every descending sequence
p0 â‰¥p1 â‰¥. . . â‰¥pÎ± â‰¥. . . (Î± < Î») has a lower bound. P is <Îº-closed if it is
Î»-closed for all Î» < Îº.
Lemma 15.8. If P is Îº-closed then it is Îº-distributive.
Proof. Let {DÎ± : Î± < Îº} be a collection of open dense sets. The intersection
D = 
Î±<Îº DÎ± is clearly open; to show that D is dense, let p âˆˆP be arbitrary.
By induction on Î± < Îº, we construct a descending Îº-sequence of conditions
p â‰¥p0 â‰¥p1 â‰¥. . .. We let pÎ± be a condition stronger than all pÎ¾, Î¾ < Î±,
and such that pÎ± âˆˆDÎ±. Finally, we let q be a condition stronger than all pÎ±,
Î± < Îº. Clearly, q âˆˆD.
âŠ“âŠ”
Now we can prove the claim about the generic extension by the forcing
in (15.3). The forcing P is <Îº-closed, and therefore Îº has no new bounded
subsets; hence Îº is preserved. The cardinals above Îº are preserved because
P satisï¬es the Îº+-chain condition, by Lemma 15.4. We have |P| = Î» and
therefore |B| = |P|Îº = Î», and so, by Lemma 15.1, (2Îº)V [G] = Î»Îº = Î».

Product Forcing
Let P and Q be two notions of forcing. The product P Ã— Q is the coordinate-
wise partially ordered set product of P and Q:
(15.4)
(p1, q1) â‰¤(p2, q2)
if and only if
p1 â‰¤p2 and q1 â‰¤q2.
If G is a generic ï¬lter on P Ã— Q, let
(15.5)
G1 = {p âˆˆP : âˆƒq (p, q) âˆˆG},
G2 = {q âˆˆQ : âˆƒp (p, q) âˆˆG}.
The sets G1 and G2 are generic on P and Q respectively, and G = G1 Ã— G2.
The following lemma describes genericity on products:
Lemma 15.9 (The Product Lemma). Let P and Q be two notions of
forcing in M. In order that G âŠ‚P Ã— Q be generic over M, it is necessary
and suï¬ƒcient that G = G1Ã—G2 where G1 âŠ‚P is generic over M and G2 âŠ‚Q
is generic over M[G1]. Moreover, M[G] = M[G1][G2].
As a corollary, if G1 is generic over M and G2 is generic over M[G1], then
G1 is generic over M[G2], and M[G1][G2] = M[G2][G1].
Proof. First let G be an M-generic ï¬lter on P Ã— Q. We deï¬ne G1 and G2
by (15.5). Clearly, G1 and G2 are ï¬lters, and G âŠ‚G1 Ã— G2. If (p1, p2) âˆˆ
G1 Ã— G2, then there are pâ€²

(q1, q2) âˆˆG. Hence (p1, p2) âˆˆG and we have G = G1 Ã— G2.

We shall now deï¬ne products of inï¬nitely many notions of forcing. In

A natural generalization of a product is Îº-product:
Deï¬nition 15.11. Let Îº be a regular cardinal. The Îº-product (the product
with <Îº-support) of Pi is the set of all functions p on I with p(i) âˆˆPi such
that |s(p)| < Îº; the ordering is coordinatewise (15.6).
As usual, Î»-support means <Î»+-support, countable support means <â„µ1-
support, etc.
The following lemma is immediate:
Lemma 15.12. If P and Q are Î»-closed then P Ã— Q is Î»-closed. More gen-
erally, if each Pi is Î»-closed and P is the Îº-product of the Pi, with Î» < Îº,
then P is Î»-closed.
Proof. Let Î± â‰¤Î» and let pÎ¾ = âŸ¨pÎ¾
i : i âˆˆIâŸ©, Î¾ < Î±, be a descending Î±-sequence
of conditions in P. If we let s = 

Î»-closed, it is easy to ï¬nd p = âŸ¨pi : i âˆˆIâŸ©such that s(p) = s and that pi â‰¤pÎ¾

for each i âˆˆI and each Î¾ < Î±.
âŠ“âŠ”
Chain conditions are generally not preserved by products. While it is con-
sistent that c.c.c. is preserved by products (we return to this in Chapter 16),
it is also consistent to have a forcing P that satisï¬es c.c.c. but P Ã— P does
not (see Exercise 15.28).
The following property (K for Knaster) is stronger than the countable
chain condition:

15. Applications of Forcing
231
Deï¬nition 15.13. A notion of forcing has property (K) if every uncountable
set of conditions has an uncountable subset of pairwise compatible elements.
Lemma 15.14. If P and Q both have property (K) then so does P Ã— Q.
Proof. Let W âŠ‚P Ã— Q be uncountable. If there exists a p âˆˆP such that the
set X = {q : (p, q) âˆˆW} is uncountable, then since Q has property (K) there
exists an uncountable Y âŠ‚X of pairwise compatible elements, and {p} Ã— Y
is such a subset of W in P Ã— Q.
The proof is similar if for some q âˆˆQ, the set {p : (p, q) âˆˆW} is uncount-
able. In the remaining case, there is an uncountable set of pairs F âŠ‚W that
is a one-to-one function. Applying successively property (K) to P and Q, we
get an uncountable G âŠ‚F such that for any two elements (p1, q1) and (p2, q2)
of G, p1 is compatible with p2 in P and q1 is compatible with q2 in Q, hence
(p1, q1) and (p2, q2) are compatible.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 15.15. If for every i âˆˆI, Pi has property (K) then 
iâˆˆI Pi has
property (K).
Proof. Let X be an uncountable subset of P, and let W = {s(p) : p âˆˆX}.
If W is countable, then there is a ï¬nite set J âŠ‚I such that s(p) = J
for uncountably many p. By Lemma 15.14, 
iâˆˆJ Pi has property (K) and
the theorem follows. If W is uncountable, there exist, by Theorem 9.18, an
uncountable Z âŠ‚X and a ï¬nite set J âŠ‚I such that s(p)âˆ©s(q) = J whenever
p, q âˆˆZ, p Ì¸= q. Since 
iâˆˆI Pi has property (K), Z has an uncountable

âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 15.16. The product of any collection of countable forcing notions
has property (K) and so it satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
âŠ“âŠ”
The best one can say about the chain condition in products is this:
Theorem 15.17. (i) If each Pi has size Î» (inï¬nite) then the product of the Pi
satisï¬es the Î»+-chain condition.
(ii) If Îº is regular, Î» â‰¥Îº, Î»<Îº = Î» and |Pi| â‰¤Î» for all i âˆˆI, then the
Îº-product of the Pi satisï¬es the Î»+-chain condition.
(iii) If Î» is inaccessible, Îº < Î» is regular, and |Pi| < Î» for each i, then
the Îº-product satisï¬es the Î»-chain condition.
Proof. (i) is a special case of (ii); thus consider Îº-products. Let P be the
Îº-product, and let W be an antichain in P. If p = âŸ¨pi : i âˆˆIâŸ©and q = âŸ¨qi :
i âˆˆIâŸ©are incompatible in P, then for some i âˆˆs(p) âˆ©s(p), pi and qi are
incompatible in Pi, and in particular pi Ì¸= qi. Thus we can regard elements
of W as functions whose domain is a subset s(p) of I of size < Îº, with values
in the Pi, and show that if W consists of pairwise incompatible functions
then |W| has the required bound.

Eastonâ€™s Theorem
The theorem that we are about to prove shows that in ZFC alone the contin-
uum function 2Îº can behave in any prescribed way consistent with KÂ¨onigâ€™s
Theorem, for regular cardinals Îº. As we have seen in Chapter 8 (Silverâ€™s The-
orem) and shall see again in Chapter 24, this is not the case with singular
cardinals.
Theorem 15.18 (Easton). Let M be a transitive model of ZFC and as-
sume that the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis holds in M. Let F be a func-
tion (in M) whose arguments are regular cardinals and whose values are
cardinals, such that for all regular Îº and Î»:
(i) F(Îº) > Îº;
(ii) F(Îº) â‰¤F(Î») whenever Îº â‰¤Î»;
(iii) cf F(Îº) > Îº.
(15.7)
Then there is a generic extension M[G] of M such that M and M[G] have
the same cardinals and coï¬nalities, and for every regular Îº,
M[G] âŠ¨2Îº = F(Îº).
We have to point out that the generic extension is obtained by forcing with
a class of conditions. By Lemma 15.1, a notion of forcing can only increase
the size of 2Îº for Îº < |B(P)|; thus we have to use a class of conditions. We
shall describe the appropriate generalization of the forcing method.
Since the proof of Eastonâ€™s Theorem involves forcing with a class of con-
ditions, we shall ï¬rst give a proof of the special case, when the â€œcontinuum
functionâ€ F is prescribed for only a set of regular cardinals. Thus let us work
in a ground model M that satisï¬es the GCH and let F be a function deï¬ned
on a set A of regular cardinals and having the properties (15.7)(i)â€“(iii).

Forcing with a Class of Conditions
We shall now show how to generalize the preceding construction to prove
Eastonâ€™s Theorem in full generality, when the function F is deï¬ned for all
regular cardinals. This generalization involves forcing with a proper class of
conditions. Although it is possible to give a general method of forcing with
a class, we shall concentrate only on the particular example.
Thus let M be a transitive model of ZFC + GCH. Moreover, we assume
that M has a well-ordering of the universe (e.g., if M satisï¬es V = L).
Let F be a function (in M) deï¬ned on all regular cardinals and having the
properties (15.7)(i)â€“(iii). We deï¬ne a class P of forcing conditions as follows:
P is the class of all functions p with values 0 and 1, whose domain consists
of triples (Îº, Î±, Î²) where Îº is a regular cardinal, Î± < Îº and Î² < F(Îº), and
such that for every regular cardinal Î³, (15.10) holds, i.e.,
|{(Îº, Î±, Î²) âˆˆdom(p) : Îº â‰¤Î³}| < Î³
(and p is stronger than q if and only if p âŠƒq).
As before, we deï¬ne P â‰¤Î» and P >Î» for every regular cardinal Î». Note that
P â‰¤Î» is a set. To deï¬ne the Boolean-valued model M B and the forcing relation,
we use the fact that P is the Easton product of PÎº, Îº a regular cardinal. For
each regular Î», we let BÎ» = B(P â‰¤Î»). If Î» < Âµ then the inclusion P â‰¤Î» âŠ‚P â‰¤Âµ
deï¬nes an obvious embedding of BÎ» into BÂµ; thus we arrange the deï¬nition
of the BÎ» so that BÎ» is a complete subalgebra of BÂµ whenever Î» < Âµ. Then
we let B = 
Î» BÎ». B is a proper class; otherwise it has all the features of
a complete Boolean algebra. In particular,  X exists for every set X âŠ‚B.
Also, P
is dense in B.

since B is not a set. However, we simply let M B = 

We shall now show that M[G] is a model of ZFC. The proofs of all axioms
of ZFC except Power Set and Replacement go through as when we forced with
a set. (Separation also needs some extra work which we leave to the reader.) It
is no surprise that the Power Set and Replacement Axioms present problems.
It is easy to construct either a class of forcing conditions adding a proper
class of Cohen reals, or a class of conditions collapsing Ord onto Ï‰ (as in
the following section). The present proof of the Power Set and Replacement
Axioms uses the fact that for every regular Î» (or at least for arbitrarily large
regular Î»), P = P >Î» Ã— P â‰¤Î» where P >Î» is Î»-closed and P â‰¤Î» is a set and
satisï¬es the Î»+-chain condition.

Î±<Î» DÎ± is

that every subset of Î» in M[G] is in M[G]. Since P â‰¤Î» is a set, it follows that
the Power Set Axiom holds in M[G].

We conclude the section with a remark on the Bernays-GÂ¨odel axiomatic
set theory. If a sentence involving only set variables is provable in BGC =
BG + Axiom E, then it is provable in BG + AC. This is a consequence of
the following: If M is a transitive model of BG + AC, then there is a generic
extension M[G] that has the same sets and has a choice function F deï¬ned
for all nonempty sets. The forcing conditions p âˆˆP used in the proof are
choice functions whose domain is a set of nonempty sets (and p < q means
p âŠƒq). The proof that M[G] is a model of BG is rather easy since no new sets
are added (P is Îº-closed for all Îº). The generic ï¬lter on P deï¬nes a choice
function F =  G, and F is deï¬ned for all nonempty sets X âˆˆM[G].
The LÂ´evy Collapse
One of the most useful techniques provided by forcing is collapsing cardinals.
We start with the simplest example:
Example 15.20. Let Î» be an uncountable cardinal. Let P be the set of
all ï¬nite sequences âŸ¨p(0), . . . , p(n âˆ’1)âŸ©of ordinals less than Î»; p is stronger
than q if p âŠƒq.
Let G be a generic ï¬lter on P and let f =  G; f is a function with
domain Ï‰ and range Î». Thus P collapses Î»: Its cardinality in V [G] is â„µ0.
As |P| = Î», P satisï¬es the Î»+-chain condition and so all cardinals greater
than Î» are preserved (as are all coï¬nalities greater than Î»).
âŠ“âŠ”
This construction generalizes to collapsing Î» to Îº:
Lemma 15.21. Let Îº be a regular cardinal and let Î» > Îº be a cardinal. There
is a notion of forcing (P, <) that collapses Î» onto Îº, i.e., Î» has cardinality Îº
in the generic extension. Moreover,
(i) every cardinal Î± â‰¤Îº in V remains a cardinal in V [G]; and
(ii) if Î»<Îº = Î», then every cardinal Î± > Î» remains a cardinal in the
extension.

238
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
[The condition in (ii) is satisï¬ed if GCH holds and cf Î» â‰¥Îº.]
Proof. Let P be the set of all functions p such that:
(i) dom(p) âŠ‚Îº and | dom(p)| < Îº,
(ii) ran(p) âŠ‚Î»,
(15.18)
and let p < q if and only if p âŠƒq.
Let G be a generic set of conditions and let f =  G. Clearly, f is a func-
tion, and it maps Îº onto Î».
(P, <) is <Îº-closed and therefore all cardinals â‰¤Îº are preserved. If Î»<Îº =
Î», then |P| = Î» and it follows that all cardinals â‰¥Î»+ are preserved.
âŠ“âŠ”
The following technique collapses all cardinals below an inaccessible car-
dinal Î» while preserving Î», thus making Î» a successor cardinal in the generic
extension. The forcing notion P deï¬ned in (15.19) is called the LÂ´evy collapse;
we denote B(P) = Col(Îº, <Î»).
Theorem 15.22 (LÂ´evy). Let Îº be a regular cardinal and let Î» > Îº be an
inaccessible cardinal. There is a notion of forcing (P, <) such that:
(i) every Î± such that Îº â‰¤Î± < Î» has cardinality Îº in V [G]; and
(ii) every cardinal â‰¤Îº and every cardinal â‰¥Î» remains a cardinal in V [G].
Hence V [G] âŠ¨Î» = Îº+.
Proof. For each Î± < Î», let PÎ± be the set of all functions pÎ± such that
dom(pÎ±) âŠ‚Îº, | dom(pÎ±)| < Îº, and ran(pÎ±) âŠ‚Î±; let pÎ± < qÎ± if and only
if pÎ± âŠƒqÎ±.
Let (P, <) be the Îº-product of the PÎ±, Î± < Î». Equivalently, the conditions
p âˆˆP are functions on subsets of Î» Ã— Îº such that
(i) | dom(p)| < Îº;
(ii) p(Î±, Î¾) < Î± for each (Î±, Î¾) âˆˆdom(p).
(15.19)
Let G be a generic set of conditions; for each Î± < Î», let GÎ± be the projec-

for every Î± < Î».
The notion of forcing (P, <) is <Îº-closed and hence it preserves all car-
dinals and coï¬nalities â‰¤Îº. In particular, Îº is a cardinal in V [G].
By Theorem 15.17(iii), (P, <) satisï¬es the Î»-chain condition. Hence Î» re-
mains a cardinal in V [G], and so do all cardinals greater than Î». It follows
that in V [G], Î» is the cardinal successor of Îº.

15. Applications of Forcing

Suslin Trees
One of the earliest applications of forcing was the solution of Suslinâ€™s Problem:
The existence of a Suslin line is independent of ZFC. In this section we show
how to construct a Suslin tree by forcing and in L; in Chapter 16 we will
construct a generic model in which there are no Suslin trees.
Theorem 15.23. There is a generic extension in which there exists a Suslin
tree.
Proof. Let P be the collection of all countable normal trees, i.e., all T such
that for some Î± < Ï‰1,
(i) each t âˆˆT is a function t : Î² â†’Ï‰ for some Î² < Î±;
(ii) if t âˆˆT and s is an initial segment of t then s âˆˆT ;
(iii) if Î² + 1 < Î± and t : Î² â†’Ï‰ is in T , then tâŒ¢n âˆˆT for all n âˆˆÏ‰;
(iv) if Î² < Î± and t : Î² â†’Ï‰ is in T , then for every Î³ such that
Î² â‰¤Î³ < Î± there exists an s : Î³ â†’Ï‰ in T such that t âŠ‚s;
(v) T âˆ©Ï‰Î² is at most countable for all Î² < Î±.
(15.20)
(See (9.9) and Exercise 9.6.) T1 is stronger than T2 if T1 is an extension of T2,
i.e.,
(15.21)
T1 < T2
if and only if
âˆƒÎ± < height(T1) T2 = {tâ†¾Î± : t âˆˆT1}.
Let G be a generic set of conditions and let T = {T : T âˆˆG}. We shall
show that in V [G], T is a normal Suslin tree.
First we note that if T1 and T2 are two conditions, then either one is an
extension of the other, or T1 and T2 are incompatible. Thus G consists of
pairwise comparable trees and one can easily verify that T is a normal tree
(of height â‰¤Ï‰1).
If T0, T1, . . . , Tn, . . . is a sequence of conditions such that for each n,
Tn+1 is an extension of Tn, then âˆ
n=0 Tn is a normal countable tree (and
extends each Tn). Hence P is â„µ0-closed, and consequently, the cardinal â„µ1 is
preserved (and V [G] has the same countable sequences in V as V ).
To show that the height of T is Ï‰1, we verify that for every Î± < Ï‰1,
G contains a condition T of height at least Î±. We show that the set {T âˆˆP :
height(T ) â‰¥Î±} is dense in P, for any Î± < Ï‰1. In other words, we show that
for each T0 âˆˆP and each Î± < Ï‰1, there is an extension T âˆˆP of T0, of height
at least Î±. It suï¬ƒces to show that each T0 âˆˆP has an extension T âˆˆP that
has one more level; for then we can proceed by induction and take unions at
limit steps.
If height(T0) is a successor ordinal, then an extension of T0 is easily ob-
tained. If height(T0) is a limit ordinal, then we ï¬rst observe that for each
t âˆˆT0 there exists a branch b of length Î± in T0 such that t âˆˆb: Using an in-
creasing sequence Î±0 < Î±1 < . . . < Î±n . . . with limit Î±, we use the normality

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
condition (15.20)(iv) to obtain such a branch. Now we construct an exten-
sion T of T0, of height Î± + 1, as follows: For each t âˆˆT0, we pick a branch bt
of length Î± in T0 such that t âˆˆbt, and let T = T0 âˆª{s : s =  bt for some
t âˆˆT } (we extend all the branches bt, t âˆˆT0, of T0). Since T0 is countable
the added level is countable, and one can verify that T âˆˆP.
It remains to show that T has no uncountable antichain. If T is a tree
and A is an antichain in T , then A is called a maximal antichain if there is
no antichain Aâ€² in T such that Aâ€² âŠƒA: Each t âˆˆT is comparable with some
a âˆˆA. If A is a maximal antichain in T and if T â€² is an extension of T , then
A is not necessarily maximal in T . Let us call a set S âŠ‚T bounded in T if
there is some Î± < height(T ) such that all elements of S are at levels â‰¤Î±. (If
the height of T is a successor ordinal, then every S âŠ‚T is bounded.)
Lemma 15.24. If A is a maximal antichain in a normal tree T and if A is
bounded in T (in particular, if the height of T is a successor ordinal), then
A is maximal in every extension of T .
Proof. Let T â€² be an extension of T . Let Î± < height(T ) be such that each
a âˆˆA is at level â‰¤Î±. If tâ€² âˆˆT â€² âˆ’T , then there exists t âˆˆT at level Î± such
that t âŠ‚tâ€²; in turn, there exists a âˆˆA such that a âŠ‚t. Hence tâ€² is comparable
with some a âˆˆA.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 15.25. Let Î± be a countable limit ordinal, let T âˆˆP be a normal
Î±-tree and let A be a maximal antichain in T . Then there exists an extension
T â€² âˆˆP of T of height Î± + 1 such that A is a maximal antichain in T â€² (and
hence A is a bounded maximal antichain in T â€²).
Proof. For each t âˆˆT there exists a âˆˆA such that either t âŠ‚a or a âŠ‚t. In

a âˆˆb. Let T â€² be the extension of T obtained by extending the branches bt,
for all t âˆˆT : T â€² = T âˆª{ bt : t âˆˆT }. The tree T â€² is a normal (Î± + 1)-tree
and extends T ; moreover, since every s âˆˆT â€² is comparable with some a âˆˆA,
A is maximal in T â€².

In the Exercises (15.21 and 15.22) we present another forcing notion (with
ï¬nite conditions) that produces a Suslin tree. Later in the book we show that
the forcing that adds a Cohen real also adds a Suslin tree.
The following theorem shows that a Suslin tree exists in L.
Theorem 15.26 (Jensen). If V = L then there exists a Suslin tree.
Proof. We shall prove that the Diamond Principle â™¦implies that a Suslin
tree exists. First we make the following observation. If T is a normal Ï‰1-tree,
let TÎ± = {x âˆˆT : o(x) < Î±}.
Lemma 15.27. If A is a maximal antichain in T , then the set
C = {Î± : A âˆ©TÎ± is a maximal antichain in TÎ±}
is closed unbounded.
Proof. It is easy to see that C is closed. To show that C is unbounded, let
Î±0 < Ï‰1 be arbitrary. Since TÎ±0 is countable, there exists a countable ordinal
Î±1 > Î±0 such that every t âˆˆTÎ±0 is compatible with some a âˆˆA âˆ©TÎ±1. Then
there is Î±2 > Î±1 such that each t âˆˆTÎ±1 is comparable with some a âˆˆAâˆ©TÎ±2,
etc. If Î±0 < Î±1 < Î±2 < . . . < Î±n < . . . is constructed in this way and if
Î± = limn Î±n, then A âˆ©TÎ± is a maximal antichain in TÎ±.
âŠ“âŠ”
We now use â™¦to construct a normal Suslin tree (T, <T). We proceed by
induction on levels. To facilitate the use of â™¦, we let points of T be countable

ordinals, T = Ï‰1, and in fact each TÎ± (the ï¬rst Î± levels of T ) is an initial
segment of Ï‰1.
We construct TÎ±, Î± < Ï‰1, such that each TÎ± is a normal Î±-tree and such
that TÎ² extends TÎ± whenever Î² > Î±. T1 consists of one point. If Î± is a limit
ordinal, then (TÎ±, <T ) is the union of the trees (TÎ², <T), Î² < Î±. If Î± is
a successor ordinal, then (TÎ±+1, <T ) is an extension of (TÎ±, <T ) obtained by
adjoining inï¬nitely immediate successors to each x at the top level of TÎ±.
It remains to describe the construction of TÎ±+1 if Î± is a limit ordinal. Let
âŸ¨SÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©be a â™¦-sequence. If SÎ± is a maximal antichain in (TÎ±, <T ),

We shall now show that the tree T = 
Î±<Ï‰1 TÎ± is a normal Suslin tree.
It suï¬ƒces to verify that T has no uncountable antichain. If A âŠ‚T (= Ï‰1)
is a maximal antichain in T , then by Lemma 15.27, A âˆ©TÎ± is a maximal

the construction that for a closed unbounded set of Î±â€™s, TÎ± = Î±. Thus using
the Diamond Principle, we ï¬nd a limit ordinal Î± such that A âˆ©Î± = SÎ± and
A âˆ©Î± is a maximal antichain in TÎ±. However, we constructed TÎ±+1 in such
a way that A âˆ©Î± is maximal in TÎ±+1, and therefore in T . It follows that
A = A âˆ©Î± and so A is countable.
âŠ“âŠ”
Suslin trees are a fruitful source of counterexamples in set-theoretic topol-
ogy as well as in the theory of Boolean algebras. As an example, let (T, <)
be a Suslin tree, and consider the partial ordering (PT , <) = (T, >). Any
two elements of T are incomparable in T if and only if they are incompatible
in PT . Thus PT satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
Lemma 15.28. If T is a normal Suslin tree, then PT is â„µ0-distributive.
Proof. Let Dn, n = 0, 1, 2 . . . , be open dense subsets of PT . We shall prove
that âˆ
n=0 Dn is dense in PT . First we claim that if D âŠ‚PT is open dense,
then there is an Î± < Ï‰1 such that D contains all levels of T above Î±. To prove
this, let A be a maximal antichain in D. A is an antichain in T and hence
countable. Thus let Î± < Ï‰1 be such that all a âˆˆA are below level Î±. Now
if x âˆˆT is at level â‰¥Î±, x is comparable with some a âˆˆA (by maximality
of A), and hence a â‰¤T x. Since D is open, we have x âˆˆD.
Now if Dn, n = 0, 1, . . . , are open dense, we pick countable ordinals Î±n
such that Dn contains all levels of T above Î±n; and since T is normal, this
implies that âˆ
n=0 Dn is dense in PT .
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 15.29. If T is a normal Suslin tree, then B = B(PT ) is an â„µ0-
distributive, c.c.c., atomless, complete Boolean algebra.

15. Applications of Forcing

Random Reals
Consider the notion of forcing where forcing conditions are Borel sets of reals
of positive Lebesgue measure; a condition p is stronger than q if p âŠ‚q. The
corresponding complete Boolean algebra is B/IÂµ where B is the Ïƒ-algebra of
all Borel sets of reals and IÂµ is the Ïƒ-ideal of all null sets. As IÂµ is Ïƒ-saturated,
B/IÂµ satisï¬es the countable chain condition, and hence the forcing preserves
cardinals.
The generic extension V [G] is determined by a single real, called a random
real. Let a âˆˆRV [G] be the unique member of each rational interval [r1, r2]V [G]
such that [r1, r2]V âˆˆG. Conversely, G can be deï¬ned from a, and so V [G] =
V [a]. (see Exercise 13.34 for the meaning of V [a].)
The following lemma illustrates one of the diï¬€erences between random and
generic reals. If f and g are functions from Ï‰ to Ï‰ we say that g dominates f
if f(n) < g(n) for all n.
Lemma 15.30. (i) In the random real extension V [G], every f : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰ is
dominated by some g âˆˆV .
(ii) In the Cohen real extension V [G], there exists a function f : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰
that is not dominated by any g âˆˆV .
Proof. (i) Forcing conditions are Borel sets of positive measure, and we freely
confuse them with their equivalence classes in B/IÂµ.
Let p âŠ©Ë™f : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰; we shall ï¬nd a q < p and some g : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰ such that
q forces that g dominates Ë™f. For each n, let g(n) be suï¬ƒciently large, so that
Âµ(p âˆ’âˆ¥Ë™f(n) < g(n)âˆ¥) < 1
2n Â· 1
4 Â· Âµ(p).
The Borel set q = p âˆ©âˆ
n=0 âˆ¥Ë™f(n) < g(n)âˆ¥has measure at least Âµ(p)/2, and
forces âˆ€n Ë™f(n) < g(n).
(ii) We use the following variant of Cohen forcing: Forcing conditions are
ï¬nite sequences âŸ¨p(0), . . . , p(n âˆ’1)âŸ©of natural numbers, and p < q if and
only if p âŠƒq. (This forcing produces the same generic extensionâ€”and has
the same B(P)â€”as the forcing from Example 14.2).
Let Ë™f be the name for the function f =  G. If p is any condition and
g : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰ is in V , then there exist a stronger q âŠƒp and some n âˆˆdom(q)
such that q(n) > g(n). It follows that q forces g(n) > Ë™f(n) (because q âŠ©
Ë™f(n) = q(n)).
âŠ“âŠ”
To add a large number of random reals, we use product measure:
Example 15.31. Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal and let I = Îº Ã— Ï‰. Let â„¦=
{0, 1}I. Let T be the set of all ï¬nite 0â€“1 functions with dom(t) âŠ‚I. Let S be
the Ïƒ-algebra generated by the sets St, t âˆˆT , where St = {f âˆˆâ„¦: t âŠ‚f}.
The product measure on S is the unique Ïƒ-additive measure such that each St
has measure 1/2|t|. Let B = S/I where I is the ideal of measure 0 sets.

If G is a generic ultraï¬lter on B then f = {t : St âˆˆG} is a 0â€“1 function
on I, and for each Î± < Îº, we deï¬ne fÎ±(n) = f(Î±, n), for all n < Ï‰. The fÎ±,
Î± < Îº, are Îº-distinct random reals, and the continuum in V [G] has size at

Forcing with Perfect Trees
This section describes forcing with perfect trees (due to Gerald Sacks) that
produces a real of minimal degree of constructibility. If forced over L, the
generic ï¬lter yields a real a such that a /âˆˆL and such that for every real
x âˆˆL[a], either x âˆˆL or a âˆˆL[x].
Let Seq({0, 1}) denote the set of all ï¬nite 0â€“1 sequences. A tree is a set
T âŠ‚Seq({0, 1}) that satisï¬es
(15.24)
if t âˆˆT and s = tâ†¾n for some n, then s âˆˆT .
A nonempty tree T is perfect if for every t âˆˆT there exists an s âŠƒt such that
both sâŒ¢0 and sâŒ¢1 are in T . (Compare with (4.4) and Lemma 4.11.) The set
of all paths in a perfect tree is a perfect set in the Cantor space {0, 1}Ï‰.
Deï¬nition 15.32 (Forcing with Perfect Trees). Let P be the set of all
perfect trees p âŠ‚Seq({0, 1}); p is stronger than q if and only if p âŠ‚q.
If G is a generic set of perfect trees, let
(15.25)
f = {s : (âˆ€p âˆˆG) s âˆˆp}.
The function f : Ï‰ â†’{0, 1} is called a Sacks real. Note that V [G] = V [f].
Since |P| = 2â„µ0, if we assume CH in the ground model, P satisï¬es the â„µ2-
chain condition and all cardinals â‰¥â„µ2 are preserved. We prove below that
â„µ1 is preserved as well.
Deï¬nition 15.33. A generic ï¬lter G is minimal over the ground model M
if for every set of ordinals X in M[G], either X âˆˆM or G âˆˆM[X].
Theorem 15.34 (Sacks). When forcing with perfect trees, the generic ï¬lter
is minimal over the ground model.

s âˆˆp is a splitting node if both sâŒ¢0 âˆˆp and sâŒ¢1 âˆˆp; a splitting node s is
an nth splitting node if there are exactly n splitting nodes t such that t âŠ‚s.

(15.26)
p â‰¤n q if and only if p â‰¤q and every nth splitting node of q is an
nth splitting node of p.

More on Generic Extensions
Properties of a generic extensions are determined by properties of the forcing
notion that constructs it. For instance, if P satisï¬es the countable chain con-
dition then V [G] preserves cardinals. Or, if P is Ï‰-distributive then V [G] has

246
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
no new countable sets of ordinals. But since the model V [G] is determined
by the complete Boolean algebra B(P), its properties depend on properties
of the algebra. Below we illustrate the correspondence between properties of
a complete Boolean algebra B and truth in the model V B.
The ï¬rst example shows the importance of distributivity.
Let Îº and Î» be cardinals. A complete Boolean algebra B is (Îº, Î»)-dis-
tributive if
(15.28)

Î±<Îº

Î²<Î»
uÎ±,Î² =

Let B be a complete Boolean algebra and let D be a complete subalgebra
of B. If G is generic on B, then it is easy to see that G âˆ©D is generic on D,
and so V [G âˆ©D] is a model of ZFC, and V âŠ‚V [G âˆ©D] âŠ‚V [G]. We shall
prove that every model of ZFC between V and V [G] is obtained this way,
and that for every subset A of V in V [G] there is a complete subalgebra D
of B such that V [G âˆ©D] = V [A].

We recall (cf. Chapter 7) that a complete subalgebra B of a complete
Boolean algebra D is (completely) generated by a set X âŠ‚D if B is the
smallest complete subalgebra of D such that X âŠ‚B. Let Îº be a cardinal. We
say that a complete Boolean algebra B is Îº-generated if there exists some
X âŠ‚B of size at most Îº such that the complete subalgebra of B generated
by X is equal to B.
Lemma 15.40. Let X be a subset of a complete Boolean algebra B such that
B is completely generated by X. Then for every generic G on B, V [G] =
V [X âˆ©G].

and . Thus let XÎ± be subsets of B deï¬ned recursively as follows:

Lemma 15.43. Let G be generic on B. If M is a model of ZFC such that
V âŠ‚M âŠ‚V [G], then there exists a complete subalgebra D âŠ‚B such that

Proof. We show that M = V [A], where A is a set of ordinals. Then the

and hence X âˆˆV [A]. Thus M = V [A].

Let us now address the question under what conditions one generic ex-
tension embeds (as a submodel) into another generic extension. Of course, if
B(P) = B(Q), then V P = V Q and if B(P) is a complete subalgebra of B(Q)
then V P âŠ‚V Q. But if B1 is a complete subalgebra of B2, we can have
V [Gâˆ©B1] = V [G] even if B1 Ì¸= B2. For every a âˆˆB+
2 (not necessarily in B1),
let B1â†¾a = {xÂ·a : x âˆˆB1}. Now assume that the set {a âˆˆB+
2 : B1â†¾a = B2â†¾a}
is dense in B2. Then it is easy to see that V [G âˆ©B1] = V [G], for every
generic G on B2. (One can show that this condition is also necessarily for B1
to give the same generic extension as B2.)
By V P âŠ‚V Q we mean the following: Whenever G is a generic ï¬lter on Q
then there is some H âˆˆV [G] that is a generic ï¬lter on P. In practice there
are several ways how to verify V P âŠ‚V Q. The following two lemmas are
sometimes useful:
Lemma 15.44. Let i : P â†’Q be such that
(i) if p1 â‰¤p2 then i(p1) â‰¤i(p2),
(ii) if p1 and p2 are incompatible then i(p1) and i(p2) are incompatible,
(iii) for every q âˆˆQ there is a p âˆˆP such that for all pâ€² â‰¤p, i(pâ€²) is
comparable with q.
Then V P âŠ‚V Q.
Proof. If G is generic on Q then iâˆ’1(G) is generic on P.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 15.45. Let h : Q â†’P be such that
(i) if q1 â‰¤q2 then h(q1) â‰¤h(q2).
(ii) for every q âˆˆQ and every p â‰¤h(q) there exists a qâ€² compatible with q
such that h(qâ€²) â‰¤p.
Then V P âŠ‚V Q.
Proof. If D âŠ‚P is open dense then hâˆ’1(D) is predense in Q. It follows that
if G is generic on Q then {p âˆˆP : p â‰¥h(q) for some q âˆˆG} is generic
on P.

We conclude this section with the following result that shows that for
every set A of ordinals, the model L[A] is a generic extension of HOD:

Theorem 15.46 (VopË‡enka). Let V = L[A] where A is a set of ordinals.
Then V is a generic extension of the model HOD. There is a Boolean algebra
B âˆˆHOD complete in HOD, and there is an ultraï¬lter G âŠ‚B, generic
over HOD, such that V = HOD[G].
Proof. Let Îº be such that A âŠ‚Îº. We let C = OD âˆ©P(P(Îº)) be the family of
all ordinal deï¬nable sets of subsets of Îº. Let us consider the partial ordering
(C, âŠ‚).
First we claim that there is a hereditarily ordinal deï¬nable partially or-

(B, â‰¤): There is a deï¬nable one-to-one mapping F of OD into the ordinals.
The set C is an ordinal deï¬nable set of ordinal deï¬nable sets and so Fâ†¾C is
an OD one-to-one mapping of C onto F(C). We let B = F(C), and deï¬ne
the partial ordering of B so that (B, â‰¤) is isomorphic to (C, âŠ‚). Since âŠ‚âˆ©C2
is an OD relation, we have (B, â‰¤) âˆˆHOD.
Now (C, âŠ‚) is clearly a Boolean algebra. Moreover, if X âŠ‚C is ordinal
deï¬nable, then  X is ordinal deï¬nable and so  X = C X. Hence the
algebra C is OD-complete; and using the OD isomorphism Ï€, we can conclude
that (B, â‰¤) is a complete Boolean algebra in HOD.
Now we let H = {u âˆˆC : A âˆˆu}. Clearly, H is an ultraï¬lter on C,
and if X âŠ‚H is OD, then  X âˆˆH. Hence G = Ï€(H) is an HOD-generic
ultraï¬lter on B.
It remains to show that V = HOD[G]. Let f : Îº â†’B be the function
deï¬ned by f(Î±) = Ï€({Z âŠ‚Îº : Î± âˆˆZ}). Clearly, f is OD, and so f âˆˆHOD.
Now we note that for every Î± < Îº, Î± âˆˆA if and only if f(Î±) âˆˆG and
therefore A âˆˆHOD[G]. It follows that V = L[A] = HOD[G].
âŠ“âŠ”
Symmetric Submodels of Generic Models
In Chapter 14 we constructed a model of set theory in which the reals cannot
be well-ordered, thus showing that the Axiom of Choice is independent of the
axioms of ZF. What follows is a more systematic study of models in which the
Axiom of Choice fails. We shall present a general method of construction of
submodels of generic extensions. The construction uses symmetry arguments
similar to those used in Theorem 14.36, and the models obtained are generally
models of ZF and do not satisfy the Axiom of Choice. This method has been
used to obtain a number of results about the relative strength of various
weaker versions and consequences of the Axiom of Choice.
The main idea of the construction of symmetric models is the use of auto-
morphisms of the Boolean-valued model V B and the Symmetry Lemma 14.37.
In fact, the idea of using automorphisms of the universe to show that the Ax-
iom of Choice is unprovable dates back into the preforcing era of set theory.
We shall describe this older construction ï¬rst.

250
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
In order to describe this method, we introduce the theory ZFA, set theory
with atoms. In addition to sets, ZFA has additional objects called atoms.
These atoms do not have any elements themselves but can be collected into
sets. Obviously, we have to modify the Axiom of Extensionality, for any two
atoms have the same elementsâ€”none.
The language of ZFA has, in addition to the predicate âˆˆ, a constant A.
The elements of A are called atoms; all other objects are sets. The axioms
of ZFA are the axioms 1.1â€“1.8 of ZF plus (15.31) and (15.32):
(15.31)
If a âˆˆA, then there is no x such that x âˆˆa.
The Axiom of Extensionality takes this form:
(15.32)
If two sets X and Y have the same elements, then X = Y .
Other axioms of ZF remain unchanged. In particular, the Axiom of Regularity
states that every nonempty set has an âˆˆ-minimal element. This minimal
element may be an atom.
The eï¬€ect of atoms is that the universe is no longer obtained by iterated
power set operation from the empty set. In ZFA, the universe is built up from
atoms.
Ordinal numbers are deï¬ned as usual except that one has to add that an
ordinal does not contain any atom. For any set S, let us deï¬ne the following
cumulative hierarchy:
(15.33)
P 0(S) = S,
P Î±(S) = 
Î²<Î±
P Î²(S)
if Î± is limit,
P Î±+1(S) = P Î±(S) âˆªP(P Î±(S)),
P âˆ(S) =

Î±âˆˆOrd
P Î±(S).
It follows that V
= P âˆ(A), and that the kernel, the class P âˆ(âˆ…) of
â€œhereditaryâ€ sets, is a model of ZF. If A is empty, then we have just ZF.
Lemma 15.47. The theory ZFA+AC+â€œA is inï¬niteâ€ is consistent relative
to ZFC.
Proof. Construct a model of ZFA. Let C be an inï¬nite set of sets of the same
rank (so that X /âˆˆTC(Y ) for any X, Y âˆˆC). Consider one X0 âˆˆC as the
empty set, and all other X âˆˆC as atoms. Build up the model from C by
iterating the operation P âˆ—(Z) = P(Z) âˆ’{âˆ…}.
âŠ“âŠ”
While in ZF, the universe does not admit nontrivial automorphisms, the
important feature of ZFA is that every permutation of atoms induces an

15. Applications of Forcing
251
automorphism of V : If Ï€ is a one-to-one mapping of A onto A (a permutation
of A), then we deï¬ne for every x (by âˆˆ-induction)
Ï€(x) = {Ï€(t) : t âˆˆx}.
Clearly, Ï€ is an âˆˆ-automorphism, and we have Ï€(x) = x for every x in the
kernel P âˆ(âˆ…).
We use these automorphisms to construct transitive models of ZFA. First
we point out that the analog of Theorem 13.9 is true in ZFA: If M is a tran-
sitive, almost universal class closed under GÂ¨odel operations, and if A âˆˆM,
then M is a model of ZFA.
Let G be a group of permutations of a set S. A set F of subgroups of G
is a ï¬lter on G, if for all subgroups H, K of G:
(i) G âˆˆF;
(ii) if H âˆˆF and H âŠ‚K, then K âˆˆF;
(iii) if H âˆˆF and K âˆˆF, then H âˆ©K âˆˆF;
(iv) if Ï€ âˆˆG and H âˆˆF, then Ï€HÏ€âˆ’1 âˆˆF.
(15.34)
For a given group of permutations G of the set A of atoms and a given ï¬lter F
on G, we say that x is symmetric if the group
sym(x) = {Ï€ âˆˆG : Ï€(x) = x}
belongs to F.
Let us further assume that sym(a) âˆˆF for all a âˆˆA, that is, that all
atoms are symmetric and let U be the class of all hereditarily symmetric
objects:
(15.35)
U = {x : every z âˆˆTC({x}) is symmetric}.
The class U is called a permutation model. It is a transitive class and includes
the kernel (because sym(x) = G for all x âˆˆP âˆ(âˆ…)), moreover, all atoms are
in U, and A âˆˆU.
Lemma 15.48. U is a transitive model of ZFA.
Proof. We show that U is closed under GÂ¨odel operations and almost univer-
sal. It is easy to see that Gi(Ï€x, Ï€y) = Ï€(Gi(x, y)) for all i = 1, . . ., 10, and
therefore
sym(Gi(x, y)) âŠƒsym(x) âˆ©sym(y)
(i = 1, . . . , 10).
It follows that if x and y are hereditarily symmetric, then so is Gi(x, y).
To show that U is almost universal, it suï¬ƒces to verify that for each Î±,
U âˆ©P Î±(A) is symmetric. For all x and all Ï€ âˆˆG we have rank(Ï€x) = rank x.
Also, sym(Ï€x) = Ï€ Â· sym(x) Â· Ï€âˆ’1, and hence, by property (iv) in (15.34), if
x is symmetric and Ï€ âˆˆG, then Ï€(x) is symmetric. Thus for all Ï€ âˆˆG we
have Ï€(U âˆ©P Î±(A)) = U âˆ©P Î±(A) and therefore, sym(U âˆ©P Î±(A)) = G.
âŠ“âŠ”

In the following examples we construct permutation models as follows:
For every ï¬nite E âŠ‚A, we let
(15.36)
ï¬x(E) = {Ï€ âˆˆG : Ï€a = a for all a âˆˆE}
and let F be the ï¬lter on G generated by {ï¬x(E) : E âŠ‚A is ï¬nite}. F is
a ï¬lter since Ï€ Â· ï¬x(E) Â· Ï€âˆ’1 = ï¬x(Ï€(E)). Thus x is symmetric if and only
if there exists a ï¬nite set of atoms E, a support for x, such that Ï€(x) = x
whenever Ï€ âˆˆG and Ï€(a) = a for all a âˆˆE.
We shall now give two examples of permutation models.
Example 15.49. Let A be inï¬nite, and let G be the group of all permuta-
tions of A. Let F be generated by {ï¬x(E) : E âŠ‚A is ï¬nite}, and let U be
the permutation model. In the model U the set A, although inï¬nite, has no
countable subset. Hence the Axiom of Choice fails in U.
Proof. Assume that there exists an f âˆˆU that is a one-to-one mapping of Ï‰
into A. Let E be a ï¬nite subset of A such that Ï€f = f for every Ï€ âˆˆï¬x(E).
Since E is ï¬nite, there exists an a âˆˆA âˆ’E such that a = f(n) for some n;
also, let b âˆˆAâˆ’E be arbitrary such that b Ì¸= a. Now, let Ï€ be a permutation
of A such that Ï€a = b but Ï€x = x for all x âˆˆE. Then Ï€f = f, and since n is
in the kernel, we have Ï€n = n. It follows that Ï€(f(n)) = (Ï€f)(Ï€n) = f(n);
however, f(n) = a while Ï€(f(n)) = Ï€(a) Ì¸= a. A contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
Example 15.50. Let A be a disjoint countable union of pairs: A = âˆ
n=0 Pn,
Pn = {an, bn}, and let G be the group of all permutations of A such that
Ï€({an, bn}) = {an, bn}, for all n. Let F be generated by {ï¬x(E) : E âŠ‚A is
ï¬nite}, and let U be the permutation model. In the model U, {Pn : n âˆˆÏ‰}
is a countable set of pairs and has no choice function.
Proof. Each Pn is a symmetric set since Ï€(Pn) = Pn for all Ï€ âˆˆG. For the
same reason, Ï€âŸ¨Pn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©= Ï€({(n, Pn) : n âˆˆÏ‰}) = âŸ¨Pn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©, for all
Ï€ âˆˆG, and so âŸ¨Pn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©âˆˆU. Hence S = {Pn : n âˆˆÏ‰} is a countable set
in U.
We show that there is no function f âˆˆU such that dom(f) = S and
f(Pn) âˆˆPn for all n. Assume that f is such a function and let E be a support
of f. There exists n such that neither an nor bn is in E, and we let Ï€ âˆˆG be
such that Ï€(an) = bn but Ï€x = x for all x âˆˆE. Then Ï€f = f, Ï€Pn = Pn,
and so Ï€(f(Pn)) = (Ï€f)(Ï€Pn) = f(Pn) but Ï€(f(Pn)) = bn while f(Pn) = an;
a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
The method of permutation models gives numerous examples of violation
of the Axiom of Choice. One usually uses the set of atoms to produce a coun-
terexample (in the permutation model) to some consequence of the Axiom of
Choice, thus showing the limitations of proofs not using the Axiom of Choice.
(A typical example is a vector space that has no basis, a set that cannot be
linearly ordered, etc.) However, these examples do not give any information

15. Applications of Forcing
253
about the â€œtrueâ€ sets, like real numbers, sets of real numbers, etc., since those
sets are in the kernel. It is clear that a diï¬€erent method has to be used to
investigate the role of the Axiom of Choice in ZF. We shall now describe such
a method and exploit the similarities between it and permutation models.
We shall use automorphisms (symmetries) to construct submodels of
generic extensions. As shown in (14.36), every automorphism Ï€ of a com-
plete Boolean algebra B induces an automorphism of the Boolean-valued
model V B. The important property of such an automorphism is (14.36) in
the Symmetry Lemma 14.37:
âˆ¥Ï•(Ï€ Ë™x1, . . . , Ï€ Ë™xn)âˆ¥= Ï€(âˆ¥Ï•( Ë™x1, . . . , Ë™xn)âˆ¥).
for all names Ë™x1, . . . , Ë™xn.
Let G be a group of automorphisms of B, and let F be a ï¬lter on G,
i.e., a set of subgroups that satisï¬es (15.34). For each Ë™x âˆˆV B we deï¬ne its
symmetry group
sym( Ë™x) = {Ï€ âˆˆG : Ï€( Ë™x) = Ë™x}.
If Ï€ is an automorphism of B, then
(15.37)
sym(Ï€ Ë™x) = Ï€ Â· sym( Ë™x) Â· Ï€âˆ’1.
This is because Ïƒ(Ï€ Ë™x) = Ï€ Ë™x if and only if (Ï€âˆ’1ÏƒÏ€)( Ë™x) = Ë™x. Given a ï¬l-
ter F on G, we call Ë™x symmetric if sym( Ë™x) âˆˆF. The class HS of hereditarily
symmetric names is deï¬ned by induction on Ï( Ë™x):
if dom( Ë™x) âŠ‚HS and if Ë™x is symmetric, then Ë™x âˆˆHS.
Note that Ï€(Ë‡x) = Ë‡x for all x and all Ï€, and so all Ë‡x are in HS. If a name Ë™x
is symmetric, and if Ï€ âˆˆG, then by (15.37) and (15.34)(iv), Ï€( Ë™x) is also
symmetric. It follows that Ï€ Ë™x âˆˆHS whenever Ë™x âˆˆHS and Ï€ âˆˆG.
The class HS is a submodel of the Boolean-valued model V B, and can be
shown to satisfy all axioms of ZF. Instead, we prove that its interpretation
is a transitive model of ZF.
Thus let M be the ground model, let B be a complete Boolean algebra
in M, and let G and F be respectively (in M), a group of automorphisms
of B and a ï¬lter on G. Let G be an M-generic ultraï¬lter on B. We let
(15.38)
N = { Ë™xG : Ë™x âˆˆHS}
be the class of all elements of M[G] that have a hereditarily symmetric name.
N is called a symmetric submodel of M[G]. We will prove that N is a tran-
sitive model of ZF. Before we do so, we notice that HS is a Boolean-valued
model (with the same âˆ¥x âˆˆyâˆ¥and âˆ¥x = yâˆ¥as M B). Thus we can deï¬ne
âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥HS for every formula Ï•. Note that
(15.39)
âˆ¥âˆƒx Ï•(x)âˆ¥HS =

Ë™xâˆˆHS
âˆ¥Ï•( Ë™x)âˆ¥

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
and that âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥HS = âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥whenever Ï• is a âˆ†0 formula. We also have a forcing
theorem for the model N:
(15.40)
N âŠ¨Ï•(x1, . . . , xn)
if and only if
âˆ¥Ï•( Ë™x1, . . . , Ë™xn)âˆ¥HS âˆˆG
where Ë™x1, . . . , Ë™xn âˆˆHS are names for x1, . . . , xn. Finally, since Ï€(HS) = HS
for all Ï€ âˆˆG, we have the Symmetry Lemma for âˆ¥âˆ¥HS: If Ï€ âˆˆG and
Ë™x1, . . . , Ë™xn âˆˆHS, then
(15.41)
âˆ¥Ï•(Ï€ Ë™x1, . . . , Ï€ Ë™xn)âˆ¥HS = Ï€(âˆ¥Ï•( Ë™x1, . . . , Ë™xn)âˆ¥HS).
Lemma 15.51. A symmetric submodel N of M[G] is a transitive model
of ZF, and M âŠ‚N âŠ‚M[G].
Proof. Since Ë‡x âˆˆHS for every x âˆˆM, we have M âŠ‚N. The heredity of HS
implies that N is transitive. To verify that the axioms of ZF hold in N, we
follow closely the proof of the Generic Model Theorem. As there, we have to
show that certain sets exist in the model by exhibiting names for the sets;
here we have to ï¬nd such names in HS.
A. Extensionality, Regularity, Inï¬nity. These axioms hold in N since N is
transitive and N âŠƒM.
B. Separation. Let Ï• be a formula and let
Y = {x âˆˆX : N âŠ¨Ï•(x, p)}
where X, p âˆˆN. Let

In general, the set G is not a member of N, and N does not satisfy the

The model in Example 15.52 is due to Cohen. It is an analog of the
permutation model in Example 15.49, and in fact, it is the same model that
was used in Theorem 14.36.
Example 15.52. Let V [G] be the generic extension adjoining countably
many Cohen reals: P is the set of all ï¬nite 0â€“1 functions p with domain

an inï¬nite set of reals in N.

âŠ“âŠ”
The set A in Example 15.52 is a set of reals and is therefore linearly
ordered. LÂ´evy proved that in the model N in Example 15.52, every set can

256
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
be linearly ordered. In fact, Halpern and LÂ´evy proved that the model even
satisï¬es the Prime Ideal Theorem, thus establishing the independence of the
Axiom of Choice from the Prime Ideal Theorem. We note that numerous
consequences of the Axiom of Choice in mathematics can be proved using
the Prime Ideal Theorem insteadâ€”among others the Hahn-Banach Theo-
rem, Compactiï¬cation Theorems, the Completeness Theorem, the Tikhonov
Theorem for Hausdorï¬€spaces, etc.
Another construction of Cohen yields a model that has similar properties
as the permutation model in Example 15.50. The atoms are replaced not by
reals, but by sets of reals.
The similarity between permutation models and symmetric submodels is
made precise by the following result that shows that every permutation model
can be embedded in a symmetric model of ZF, â€œwith a prescribed degree of
accuracy.â€
Theorem 15.53 (Jech-Sochor). Let U be a permutation model, let A be
its set of atoms, and let Î± be an ordinal. There exist a symmetric model N
of ZF and an embedding x â†’Ëœx of U into N such that
(PÎ±(A))U is âˆˆ-isomorphic to

PÎ±( ËœA)
N.
Proof. We work in the theory ZFA, plus the Axiom of Choice. We denote A
the set of all atoms, and let M be the kernel, M = P âˆ(âˆ…). We consider
a group G of permutations of A, and a ï¬lter F on G, and let U be the
permutation model given by G and F. Let Î± be an ordinal number.
We shall construct a generic extension M[G] of the kernel, and then the
model N as a symmetric submodel of M[G]. We construct M[G] by adjoining
to M a number of subsets of a regular cardinal Îº, Îº of them for each a âˆˆA.
We use these to embed U in M[G].
Let Îº be a regular cardinal such that Îº > |P Î±(A)|. The set P of forcing
conditions consists of 0â€“1 functions p such that | dom(p)| < Îº and dom(p) âŠ‚
(A Ã— Îº) Ã— Îº; as usual, p < q if and only if p âŠƒq.

and let ËœA = {Ëœa : a âˆˆA}. The sets Ëœa and ËœA have obvious canonical names.

Lemma 15.54. For all x and y, x âˆˆy if and only if Ëœx âˆˆËœy, and x = y if and
only if Ëœx = Ëœy.
Proof. First we note that âˆ¥Ë™xa,Î¾ = Ë™xaâ€²,Î¾â€²âˆ¥= 0 whenever (a, Î¾) Ì¸= (aâ€², Î¾â€²), and

xa,Î¾: xa,Î¾ is a subset of Îº, while the transitive closure of Ëœx contains some of
the xa,Î¾.
Now we can prove the lemma, simultaneously for âˆˆand =, by induction
on rank:

y cannot be an atom because then we would have Ëœx = xa,Î¾ for some a, Î¾,
which is impossible. Hence Ëœx = Ëœz for some z âˆˆy and we have x = z by the
induction hypothesis; thus x âˆˆy.
(b) If x = y, then Ëœx = Ëœy. Conversely, if x Ì¸= y, then either both x and y
are atoms and then Ëœx Ì¸= Ëœy; or, e.g., x contains some z that is not in y, and
then, by the induction hypothesis, Ëœz âˆˆËœx and Ëœz /âˆˆËœy; thus Ëœx Ì¸= Ëœy.

As for applications of Theorem 15.53, consider a formula Ï•(X, Î³) such

Therefore, if we wish to prove consistency (with ZF) of an existential state-

(of ZFA).
Note that â€œX cannot be well ordered,â€ â€œX cannot be linearly orderedâ€
are formulas of the above type and so is â€œX is a countable set of pairs without
a choice function.â€
Theorem 15.53, in conjunction with the construction of permutation mod-
els, has interesting applications in algebra. One can construct various abstract
counterexamples to theorems whose proofs use the Axiom of Choice. For ex-
ample, one can construct a vector space that has no basis, etc.
We conclude this section by sketching two examples of models of ZF in
which the Axiom of Choice fails. The ï¬rst model was constructed by Feferman
and LÂ´evy, the other by Feferman.
Example 15.57. Let M be a transitive model of ZFC. There is a model
N âŠƒM such that (â„µ1)N = (â„µÏ‰)M; hence â„µ1 is singular in N.

If the ground model M in the above example satisï¬es GCH, then one can

If T1 and T2 are trees, then an isomorphism Ï€ : T1 â†’T2 between T1 and T2 is
a one-to-one mapping of T1 onto T2 such that x < y if and only if Ï€(x) < Ï€(y). An
isomorphism maps level Î± of T1 onto level Î± of T2 (for all Î±); and if b is a branch
in T1, then Ï€(b) is a branch in T2. An automorphism of T is an isomorphism
of T1 onto T2. A tree T is rigid if it has no nontrivial automorphism, i.e., the only
automorphism of T is the identity mapping. T is homogeneous if for any x, y at
the same level of T, there exists an automorphism Ï€ of T such that Ï€(x) = y.

[Construct T â€² so that for some branch b in T, b is extended while Ï€(b) is not.]

Historical Notes
The forcing that adds Cohen reals is due to Cohen. Shortly after Cohenâ€™s discoveries,
Solovay (in [1963]) noticed that Cohenâ€™s construction of a model for 2â„µ0 = â„µ2 can
be generalized so that for a regular cardinal Îº one obtains a model of with 2Îº = Î»
(assuming 2<Îº = Îº and Î»Îº = Î» in the ground model).
The relation between the chain condition and preservation of cardinals is ba-
sically due to Cohen; the observation that a Î»-closed notion of forcing does not
produce new subsets of Î» is due to Solovay. The Product Lemma 15.9 is due to
Solovay [1970]. Theorem 15.15 comes from general topology and is due to Engelk-
ing and Karlowicz [1965].
Eastonâ€™s Theorem (Theorem 15.18) was published in [1970]. The generalization
of Cohenâ€™s method allowing a class of forcing conditions is due to Easton. The LÂ´evy
collapse (Theorem 15.22) was constructed by LÂ´evy; cf. [1970].
Suslinâ€™s Problem was formulated by Suslin in [1920]. Tennenbaum [1968] and
Jech [1967] discovered models of set theory in which a Suslin line exists; Solovay and
Tennenbaum [1971] proved that existence of a Suslin line is not provable in ZFC.
Subsequently, Jensen proved that a Suslin line exists in the constructible universe
(cf. [1968, 1972]).
The present proof of Theorem 15.23 is as in Jech [1967] (countable conditions);
Tennenbaumâ€™s proof (ï¬nite conditions) is presented in Exercises 15.21 and 15.22.
Random reals were introduced by Solovay [1970]. Forcing with perfect trees to
obtain a minimal degree (Theorem 15.34) is due to Sacks [1971].

15. Applications of Forcing
265
Theorem 15.46 is due to VopË‡enka and appears in the book [1972] of VopË‡enka
and HÂ´ajek.
The idea of using symmetry arguments to construct models in which the Axiom
of Choice fails goes back to Fraenkel [1922b]; the two examples of models of ZFA (an
inï¬nite set of atoms without a countable subset, and a countable set of pairs that
has no choice function) are basically due to him. Further examples of permutation
models were given by Mostowski who (in [1939]) developed a theory of such models.
The present deï¬nition using ï¬lters was given by Specker [1957].
Cohen incorporated the symmetry arguments into his method and constructed
the model in Example 15.52. The formulation of Cohenâ€™s method in terms of sym-
metric submodels of Boolean-valued models is due to Scott (unpublished) and
Jech [1971a]; the latterâ€™s version was a reformulation of a topological version of
VopË‡enka and HÂ´ajek [1965].
Theorem 15.53 is due to Jech and Sochor [1966a, 1966b]. Numerous applications
of the theorem are given in the second paper [1966b]. The method has been gen-
eralized by Pincus in [1971] and in [1972], extending further the analogy between
permutations models of ZFA and symmetric models of ZF.
LÂ´evy showed that in Cohenâ€™s model in Example 15.52 every set can be linearly
ordered; consequently, Halpern and LÂ´evy [1971] proved that the Prime Ideal Theo-
rem holds in the model. Example 15.57 (singularity of â„µ1) is due to Feferman and
LÂ´evy [1963]. Example 15.59 (independence of the Prime Ideal Theorem) is due to
Feferman [1964/65]. A. Blass constructed in [1977] a model, similar to Fefermanâ€™s
model, in which every ultraï¬lter is principal.
Exercise 15.15: Jensen [1965].
Exercise 15.20: Fukson [1971].
Exercises 15.25â€“15.28: Jensen [1969].
The results in Exercises 15.31 and 15.32 had been known before forcing; see
Sikorski [1964].

16. Iterated Forcing and Martinâ€™s Axiom
In this chapter we introduce two related concepts: iterated forcing and Mar-
tinâ€™s Axiom. Iteration of forcing is one of the basic techniques used in appli-
cations of forcing. It was ï¬rst used by Solovay and Tennenbaum in their proof
of the independence of Suslinâ€™s Hypothesis. The idea is to repeat the generic
model construction transï¬nitely many times. Such iterations are described in
the ground model.
Martin observed that many properties of a generic extension obtained by
iteration follow from a single axiom that captures the combinatorial content
of the model. The general principle has become known as Martinâ€™s Axiom.
Martinâ€™s Axiom has become a favorite tool in combinatorial set theory and
set-theoretic topology. Its consistency is proved by iterated forcing.
Two-Step Iteration
The basic observation is that a two-step iteration can be represented by
a single forcing extension. Let P be a notion of forcing, and let Ë™Q âˆˆV P be
a name for a partial ordering in V P .
Deï¬nition 16.1.
(i) P âˆ—Ë™Q = {(p, Ë™q) : p âˆˆP and âŠ©P Ë™q âˆˆË™Q},
(ii) (p1, Ë™q1) â‰¤(p2, Ë™q2) if and only if p1 â‰¤p2 and p1 âŠ©Ë™q1 â‰¤Ë™q2.
In (i), âŠ©P Ï• means that every condition in P forces Ï•; equivalently,
âˆ¥Ï•âˆ¥B(P ) = 1.

16. Iterated Forcing and Martinâ€™s Axiom

We use the notation D = B âˆ—Ë™C. If B = B(P) and in V B, Ë™C = B( Ë™Q),
then P âˆ—Ë™Q embeds densely in B âˆ—Ë™C (Exercise 16.1).
Two-step iteration is a generalization of product: If P and Q are two
notions of forcing then P Ã— Q embeds densely in P âˆ—Ë‡Q (Exercise 16.2).
If B and D are complete Boolean algebras and B is a complete subalgebra
of D then there exists a Ë™C âˆˆV B that is a complete Boolean algebra in V B,
such that D = B âˆ—Ë™C: In V B, let Ë™F be the ï¬lter on Ë‡D generated by the
generic ultraï¬lter Ë™G on Ë‡B, and let Ë™C be the quotient of Ë‡D by Ë™F. We denote
this algebra (in V B) Ë™C = D : B. D : B is a complete Boolean algebra in V B,
and B âˆ—(D : B) = D (Exercises 16.3 and 16.4).
It follows that if V [G] and V [H] are two generic extensions of V such that
V [G] âŠ‚V [H], then V [H] is a generic extension of V [G].
Theorem 16.4. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal. If P satisï¬es the
Îº-chain condition and if in V P , Ë™Q satisï¬es the Îº-chain condition, then P âˆ—Ë™Q
satisï¬es the Îº-chain condition.
Proof. Assume that (pÎ±, Ë™qÎ±), Î± < Îº, are mutually incompatible in P âˆ—Ë™Q.
Let Ë™Z âˆˆV P be the canonical name for the set {Î± : pÎ± âˆˆG} (where G is

Ë™Z âŠ‚Î³.
This is a contradiction, since pÎ³ âŠ©Î³ âˆˆË™Z.

Iteration with Finite Support
The idea of transï¬nite iteration of forcing is to construct sequences {PÎ±}Î±<Î¸
of forcing notions so that for every Î±, PÎ±+1 = PÎ± âˆ—Ë™QÎ± where Ë™Q âˆˆV PÎ±, and
that at limit stages, PÎ± is a â€œlimitâ€ of {PÎ²}Î²<Î±. In this section we describe
iteration with ï¬nite support, where the â€œlimitâ€ is the direct limit.
In Deï¬nition 16.8 below, Ë™QÎ± is assumed to be a forcing notion in V PÎ±,
with greatest element 1. The symbol â‰¤Î± denotes the partial ordering of PÎ±,
and âŠ©Î± denotes the corresponding forcing relation.
Deï¬nition 16.8. Let Î± â‰¥1. A forcing notion PÎ± is an iteration (of length Î±
with ï¬nite support) if it is a set of Î±-sequences with the following properties:
(i) If Î± = 1 then for some forcing notion Q0,
(a) P1 is the set of all 1-sequences âŸ¨p(0)âŸ©where p(0) âˆˆQ0;
(b) âŸ¨p(0)âŸ©â‰¤1 âŸ¨q(0)âŸ©if and only if p(0) â‰¤q(0) (in Q0).
(ii) If Î± = Î² + 1 then PÎ² = PÎ±â†¾Î² = {pâ†¾Î² : p âˆˆPÎ±} is an iteration of
length Î², and there is some forcing notion Ë™QÎ² âˆˆV PÎ² such that
(a) p âˆˆPÎ± if and only if pâ†¾Î² âˆˆPÎ² and âŠ©Î² p(Î²) âˆˆË™QÎ²;
(b) p â‰¤Î± q if and only if pâ†¾Î² â‰¤Î² qâ†¾Î² and pâ†¾Î² âŠ©Î² p(Î²) â‰¤q(Î²).
(iii) If Î± is a limit ordinal, then for every Î² < Î±, PÎ² = PÎ±â†¾Î² = {pâ†¾Î² :
p âˆˆPÎ±} is an iteration of length Î² and
(a) p âˆˆPÎ± if and only if âˆ€Î² < Î± pâ†¾Î² âˆˆPÎ² and for all but ï¬nitely
many Î² < Î±, âŠ©Î² p(Î²) = 1;

An iteration with ï¬nite support is uniquely determined by the sequence
âŸ¨Ë™QÎ² : Î² < Î±âŸ©. Thus we call PÎ± the iteration of âŸ¨Ë™QÎ² : Î² < Î±âŸ©. For each Î² < Î±,

the completion of the direct limit of the B(PÎ²), Î² < Î± (Exercise 16.8).
Finite support iteration preserves chain conditions:

Martinâ€™s Axiom
Deï¬nition 16.11 (Martinâ€™s Axiom (MA)). If (P, <) is partially ordered
set that satisï¬es the countable chain condition and if D is a collection of
fewer than 2â„µ0 dense subsets of P, then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
By Lemma 14.4, if (P, <) is any partial ordering and if D is a countable
collection of dense subsets of P, then a D-generic ï¬lter on P exists. Hence
Martinâ€™s Axiom is a consequence of the Continuum Hypothesis. Exercises
16.10 and 16.11 show that the restriction to fewer than continuum dense sets
as well as some restriction on (P, <) are necessary.
If Îº is an inï¬nite cardinal, let MAÎº be the statement
(16.4)
If (P, <) is a partially ordered set that satisï¬es the countable chain
condition, and if D is a collection of at most Îº dense subsets of P,
then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
MAâ„µ0 is true by Lemma 14.4, and Martinâ€™s Axiom states that MAÎº holds
for all Îº < 2â„µ0. Exercise 16.10 shows that MAÎº implies that Îº < 2â„µ0.
Lemma 16.12. Martinâ€™s Axiom is equivalent to its restriction to partial or-
ders of cardinality < c:
(16.5)
If (P, <) is a partially ordered set that satisï¬es the countable chain
condition and |P| < 2â„µ0, and if D is a collection of at most Îº dense
subsets of P, then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
Proof. Let P be a c.c.c. partially ordered set and let us assume that (16.5)
holds. Let D be a family of fewer than c dense subsets of P. For each D âˆˆ
D, we let WD be a maximal incompatible subset of D. Since each WD is
countable, there exists a set Q âŠ‚P of size < c such that WD âŠ‚Q for
all D âˆˆD, and if p, q âˆˆQ are compatible, then there exists some r âˆˆQ
such that r â‰¤p and r â‰¤q. Each WD is a maximal antichain in Q; let
ED = {q âˆˆQ : q â‰¤w for some w âˆˆWD}. Each ED is dense in Q.
The partially ordered set Q has size at most Îº and satisï¬es the countable
chain condition. By (16.5) there is a ï¬lter G on Q that meets every ED.
G generates a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
âŠ“âŠ”

Independence of Suslinâ€™s Hypothesis
Suslinâ€™s Hypothesis (SH) is the statement there are no Suslin lines. In Chap-
ter 15 we showed that the negation of SH is consistent; by the following
theorem, SH is independent.
Theorem 16.16. If MAâ„µ1 holds, then there is no Suslin tree.
Proof. Let us assume that T is a normal Suslin tree and let PT be the partially
ordered set obtained from T by reversing the order. PT satisï¬es the countable
chain condition. For each Î± < Ï‰1, let DÎ± be the union of all levels above Î±:
DÎ± = {x âˆˆT : o(x) > Î±}. Each DÎ± is dense in PT ; if we let D = {DÎ± :
Î± < Ï‰1} and if G is a D-generic ï¬lter on P, then G is a branch in T of
length Ï‰1. A contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
The proof of independence of SH was the ï¬rst application of iterated
forcing (and led to the formulation of Martinâ€™s Axiom). The model for SH,
due to Solovay and Tennenbaum [1971], was constructed by iteration of the
forcing notions PT , for all prospective Suslin trees in the ï¬nal model. The
forcing PT â€œkillsâ€ the Suslin tree T by forcing an Ï‰1-branch in T .
In the proof of the following theorem, Suslin trees are killed by a diï¬€erent
method: by specializing the tree. Recalling the deï¬nition in Chapter 9 (and
Exercise 9.9), an Aronszajn tree T is special if there exists a function f :
T â†’Ï‰ such that each fâˆ’1({n}) is an antichain.
Theorem 16.17 (Baumgartner, Malitz, and Reinhardt [1970]).
If
MAâ„µ1 holds, then every Aronszajn tree is special.
Lemma 16.18. If T is an Aronszajn tree and W is an uncountable collection
of ï¬nite pairwise disjoint subsets of T , then there exist S, Sâ€² âˆˆW such that
any x âˆˆS is incomparable with any y âˆˆSâ€².

Proof. Since uncountably many elements of W have the same size, we may

Let T be an Aronszajn tree and let us consider the following notion of
forcing (P, <): Forcing conditions are functions p such that
(i) dom(p) is a ï¬nite subset of T ;
(ii) ran(p) âŠ‚Ï‰;
(iii) if x, y âˆˆdom(p) and x and y are comparable, then p(x) Ì¸= p(y);
(iv) p is stronger than q if and only if p extends q.
(16.6)
Lemma 16.19. (P, <) satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
Proof. Let W be an uncountable subset of P. Note that the set {dom(p) :
p âˆˆW} is uncountable (there are only countably many functions from a ï¬-
nite set into Ï‰). By âˆ†-Lemma, there is an uncountable W1 âŠ‚W, and a ï¬-

p, q âˆˆW1. Then there is an uncountable W2 âŠ‚W1 such that pâ†¾S = qâ†¾S for
any p, q âˆˆW2. By Lemma 16.18 there exist p and q âˆˆW2 such that any
x âˆˆdom(p) âˆ’S is incomparable with any y âˆˆdom(q) âˆ’S. Then p âˆªq is
a function that satisï¬es (16.6) and extends both p and q. Thus p and q are
compatible elements of W and so (P, <) satisï¬es the countable chain condi-
tion.

Proof of Theorem 16.17. For each x âˆˆT , let Dx be the set of all p âˆˆP such
that x âˆˆdom(p); clearly, each Dx is dense in P. Let D = {Dx : x âˆˆT }.

It follows from MAâ„µ1, that (P, <) has a D-generic ï¬lter G. The elements
of G are pairwise compatible and since G is D-generic, every x âˆˆT is in the
domain of the function f =  G. The function f maps T into Ï‰ and witnesses
that T is a special Aronszajn tree.

More Applications of Martinâ€™s Axiom
Theorem 16.20 (Martin-Solovay). Martinâ€™s Axiom implies that c is reg-
ular, and 2Îº = c for all inï¬nite cardinals Îº < c.
Proof. Assuming MA, we prove that 2Îº = 2â„µ0 for every Îº < 2â„µ0. Regularity
of c follows, as cf 2â„µ0 = cf 2Îº > Îº for all Îº < 2â„µ0. Let Îº < 2â„µ0 and let
{AÎ± : Î± < Îº} be an almost disjoint family of subsets of Ï‰.

Let (P, <) be the following notion of forcing: A condition is a function p

The almost disjoint forcing deï¬ned in the proof of Theorem 16.20 is of-

following:
Let V [X] be a generic extension where X âŠ‚Ï‰1; furthermore, assume that
Ï‰V [X]

over V [X], then V [X][G] = V [X][A], where A is deï¬ned by (16.9). Note that
Ï‰V [X][A]

= Ï‰1.

extension V [A] such that A âŠ‚Ï‰ and X âˆˆV [A]. See Exercise 16.15.
The next theorem shows that under MAâ„µ1, countable chain condition is
preserved by products. Compare with Exercise 15.28.
Theorem 16.21. MAâ„µ1 implies that every partially ordered set that satisï¬es
the countable chain condition has property (K).
Proof. Let P be a partially ordered set that satisï¬es the countable chain

If f and g are functions from Ï‰ to Ï‰, we say that f eventually dominates g
if f(n) > g(n) for all but ï¬nitely many n âˆˆÏ‰ (i.e., f > g in the notation of

for all g âˆˆG.

The proof of Theorem 16.24 uses the Hechler forcing: Let G be a given

(ii) if k âˆˆdom(sâ€²) âˆ’dom(s), then s(k) > h(k) for all h âˆˆE.
(16.10)
If (s1, E1) and (s2, E2) are conditions and s1 = s2, then (s1, E1) and
(s2, E2) are compatible. Hence (P, <) satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
Let G âŠ‚P be generic; we let f = {s : (s, E) âˆˆG for some E}. We claim

condition (sâ€², Eâ€²) < (s, E) satisï¬es (16.10)(ii), and so f(k) > g(k) for all
k /âˆˆdom(s). Thus in V [G], there is f : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰ such that h < f for all h âˆˆG.
Proof of Theorem 16.24. If G âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰ and |G| < c, let P be the Hechler forcing

Iterated Forcing
We conclude this chapter with the general deï¬nition of iterated forcing. We
shall return to the general method in later chapters. Below we follow closely
Deï¬nition 16.8 of ï¬nite support iteration. As before, for each ordinal Î± â‰¥1,
PÎ± denotes an iteration of length Î±, â‰¤Î± is the partial ordering of PÎ± and âŠ©Î± is
the corresponding forcing relation, and Ë™QÎ± is a name in V PÎ± for a forcing
notion with a greatest element 1. The general deï¬nition diï¬€ers from Deï¬ni-
tion 16.8 by its handling of limit stages.

280
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Deï¬nition 16.29. Let Î± â‰¥1. A forcing notion PÎ± is an iteration (of
length Î±) if it is a set of Î±-sequences with the following properties:
(i) If Î± = 1 then for some forcing notion Q0,
(a) P1 is the set of all 1-sequences âŸ¨p(0)âŸ©where p(0) âˆˆQ0;
(b) âŸ¨p(0)âŸ©â‰¤1 âŸ¨q(0)âŸ©if and only if p(0) â‰¤q(0).
(ii) If Î± = Î² + 1 then PÎ² = PÎ±â†¾Î² = {pâ†¾Î² : p âˆˆPÎ±} is an iteration of
length Î², and there is some forcing notion Ë™QÎ² âˆˆV PÎ² such that
(a) p âˆˆPÎ± if and only if pâ†¾Î² âˆˆPÎ² and âŠ©Î² p(Î²) âˆˆË™QÎ²;
(b) p â‰¤Î± q if and only if pâ†¾Î² â‰¤Î² qâ†¾Î² and pâ†¾Î² âŠ©Î² p(Î²) â‰¤q(Î²).
(iii) If Î± is a limit ordinal, then for every Î² < Î±, PÎ² = PÎ±â†¾Î² = {pâ†¾Î² :
p âˆˆPÎ±} is an iteration of length Î² and
(a) the Î±-sequence âŸ¨1, 1, . . . , 1, . . .âŸ©is in PÎ±;
(b) if p âˆˆPÎ±, Î² < Î± and if q âˆˆPÎ² is such that q â‰¤Î² pâ†¾Î², then
r âˆˆPÎ± where for all Î¾ < Î±, r(Î¾) = q(Î¾) if Î¾ < Î² and r(Î¾) = p(Î¾) if
Î² â‰¤Î¾ < Î±;
(c) p â‰¤Î± q if and only if âˆ€Î² < Î± pâ†¾Î² â‰¤Î² qâ†¾Î².
Clearly, an iteration with ï¬nite support is an iteration. In general, prop-
erty (iii)(b) guarantees that if PÎ² = PÎ±â†¾Î² then V PÎ² âŠ‚V PÎ±; see Exer-
cise 16.17.
A general iteration depends not only on the Ë™QÎ² but also on the limit
stages of the iteration. Let PÎ± be an iteration of length Î± where Î± is a limit
ordinal. PÎ± is a direct limit if for every Î±-sequence p,
(16.11)
p âˆˆPÎ±
if and only if
âˆƒÎ² < Î± pâ†¾Î² âˆˆPÎ² and âˆ€Î¾ â‰¥Î² p(Î¾) = 1.
PÎ± is an inverse limit if for every Î±-sequence p,
(16.12)
p âˆˆPÎ±
if and only if
âˆ€Î² < Î± pâ†¾Î± âˆˆPÎ².
In practice, forcing iterations combine direct and inverse limits. Finite sup-
port iterations are exactly those that use direct limits at all limit stages. In
general, let s(p), the support of p âˆˆPÎ±, be the set of all Î² < Î± such that it is
not the case that âŠ©Î² p(Î²) = 1. If I is an ideal on Î± containing all ï¬nite sets
then an iteration with I-support is an iteration that satisï¬es for every limit
ordinal Î³ â‰¤Î±,
(16.13)
p âˆˆPÎ³
if and only if
âˆ€Î² < Î³ pâ†¾Î² âˆˆPÎ² and s(p) âˆˆI.
One of the most useful tools in forcing are iterations with countable support,
where in (16.13) I is the ideal of at most countable sets. A countable support
iteration is an iteration such that for every limit ordinal Î³ if cf Î³ = Ï‰ then PÎ³
is an inverse limit, and if cf Î³ > Ï‰ then PÎ³ is a direct limit. We shall return
to countable support iterations later in the book.
The following generalizes Theorem 16.9:

Theorem 16.30. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let Î± be a limit
ordinal. Let PÎ± be an iteration such that for each Î² < Î±, PÎ² = PÎ±â†¾Î² satisï¬es
the Îº-chain condition. If PÎ± is a direct limit, and either cf Î± Ì¸= Îº or (if
cf Î± = Îº) for a stationary set of Î² < Î±, PÎ² is a direct limit, then PÎ± satisï¬es
the Îº-chain condition.
Proof. Exactly as the proof of Theorem 16.9. The only diï¬€erence is that we
apply Fodorâ€™s Theorem not to C, but to the stationary subset of C consisting
of all Î¾ such that PÎ±Î¾ is a direct limit.
