Historical Notes
Iterated forcing was introduced by Solovay and Tennenbaum [1971]. The formu-
lation in terms of Boolean algebras is based on their paper. Our presentation of
general iteration (Deï¬nitions 16.8 and 16.29) follows Baumgartner [1983].
Following Solovay and Tennenbaumâ€™s construction of a model in which there
are no Suslin trees (Theorem 16.13), Martin formulated an axiom (MAâ„µ1) which
implies that there are no Suslin trees, and whose consistency was obtained by
Solovay-Tennenbaumâ€™s method. The consistency proof of MA + 2â„µ0 > â„µ1 appears
in Solovay and Tennenbaum [1971].
Martinâ€™s Axiom is investigated in detail in the paper [1970] of Martin and
Solovay. The paper contains various equivalent formulations of Martinâ€™s Axiom and
numerous applications (including Theorem 16.20). Theorem 16.21 was discovered
by Kunen, Rowbottom, Solovay and possibly others.

16. Iterated Forcing and Martinâ€™s Axiom
283
Baumgartner, Malitz, and Reinhardt [1970] proved that MAâ„µ1 implies that
every Aronszajn tree is special (Theorem 16.17). Special Aronszajn trees have ap-
plications in model theory (this fact is due to Rowbottom and Silver) and are
investigated in Mitchellâ€™s paper [1972/73].
Scales were investigated extensively by Hechler [1974]. Hechler introduced the
notion of forcing used in the proof of Theorem 16.24. Hechler, among others, showed
that if cf Îº > Ï‰, then there is a generic extension in which 2â„µ0 > Îº and a Îº-scale
exists.
The construction of p-points (and Ramsey ultraï¬lters) under the assumption
of Martinâ€™s Axiom is due to Booth [1970]. Our proof of Theorem 16.27 follows
Ketonen [1976].

17. Large Cardinals
The theory of large cardinals plays central role in modern set theory. In
this chapter we begin a systematic study of large cardinals. In addition to
combinatorial methods, the proofs use techniques from model theory.
Ultrapowers and Elementary Embeddings
We start with the following theorem that introduced the technique of ultra-
powers to the study of large cardinals.
Theorem 17.1 (Scott). If there is a measurable cardinal then V Ì¸= L.
Ultrapowers were introduced in Chapter 12. We now generalize the tech-
nique to construct ultrapowers of the universe. Let U be an ultraï¬lter on
a set S and consider the class of all functions with domain S. Following
(12.3) and (12.4) we deï¬ne
f =âˆ—g
if and only if
{x âˆˆS : f(x) = g(x)} âˆˆU,
f âˆˆâˆ—g
if and only if
{x âˆˆS : f(x) âˆˆg(x)} âˆˆU.
For each f, we denote [f] the equivalence class of f in =âˆ—(recall (6.4)):
[f] = {g : f =âˆ—g and âˆ€h (h =âˆ—f â†’rank g â‰¤rank h)}.
We also use the notation [f] âˆˆâˆ—[g] when f âˆˆâˆ—g.
Let Ult = UltU(V ) be the class of all [f], where f is a function on S, and
consider the model Ult = (Ult, âˆˆâˆ—). LoÂ´sâ€™s Theorem 12.3 holds in the present
context as well: If Ï•(x1, . . . , xn) is a formula of set theory, then
Ult âŠ¨Ï•([f1], . . . , [fn])
if and only if

If Ïƒ is a sentence, then Ult âŠ¨Ïƒ if and only if Ïƒ holds; the ultrapower
is elementarily equivalent to the universe (V, âˆˆ). The constant functions ca
are deï¬ned, for every set a, by (12.12), and the function j = jU : V â†’Ult,

(17.1)

whenever Ï•(x1, . . . , xn) is a formula of set theory.

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
The most important application of ultrapowers in set theory are those in
which (Ult, âˆˆâˆ—) is well-founded. As we show below, well-founded ultrapowers
are closely related to measurable cardinals.
The model UltU(V ) is well-founded if (i) every nonempty set X âŠ‚Ult
has a âˆˆâˆ—-minimal element, and (ii) ext(f) is a set for every f, where
ext(f) = {[g] : g âˆˆâˆ—f}.
The second condition is clearly satisï¬ed for any ultraï¬lter U: For every g âˆˆâˆ—f
there is some h =âˆ—g such that rank h â‰¤rank f. As for the condition (i), this
is satisï¬ed if and only if there exists no inï¬nite descending âˆˆâˆ—-sequence
f0 âˆ‹âˆ—f1 âˆ‹âˆ—. . . âˆ‹âˆ—fk âˆ‹âˆ—. . .
(k âˆˆÏ‰)
of elements of the ultrapower.
Lemma 17.2. If U is a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter, then (Ult, âˆˆâˆ—) is a well-
founded model.
Proof. We shall show that there is no inï¬nite descending âˆˆâˆ—-sequence in Ult
if U is a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter on S. Let us assume that f0, f1, . . . , fn, . . .
is such a descending sequence. Thus for each n, the set
Xn = {x âˆˆS : fn+1(x) âˆˆfn(x)}
is in the ultraï¬lter. Since U is Ïƒ-complete, the intersection X = âˆ
n=0 Xn is
also in U and hence nonempty; let x be an arbitrary element of X. Then we
have
f0(x) âˆ‹f1(x) âˆ‹f2(x) âˆ‹. . .
an inï¬nite descending âˆ‹-sequence, which is a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
By the Mostowski Collapsing Theorem every well-founded model is iso-
morphic to a transitive model. Thus if U is Ïƒ-complete, there exists a one-
to-one mapping Ï€ of Ult onto a transitive class such that f âˆˆâˆ—g if and only
Ï€([f]) âˆˆÏ€([g]). In order to simplify notation, we shall identify each [f] with
its image Ï€([f]). Thus if U is Ïƒ-complete, the symbol Ult denotes the transi-
tive collapse of the ultrapower, and for each function f on S, [f] is an element
of the transitive class Ult; we say the function f represents [f] âˆˆUlt.
Thus if U is a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter, M = UltU(V ) is an inner model and
j = jU is an elementary embedding j : V â†’M.
If Î± is an ordinal, then since j is elementary, j(Î±) is an ordinal; moreover,
Î± < Î² implies j(Î±) < j(Î²). Thus we have Î± â‰¤j(Î±) for every ordinal num-
ber Î±. Note that j(Î± + 1) = j(Î±)+1, and j(n) = n for all natural numbers n.
It is also easy to see that j(Ï‰) = Ï‰: If [f] < Ï‰, then f(x) < Ï‰ for almost
all x âˆˆS, and by Ïƒ-completeness, there exists n < Ï‰ such that f(x) = n for
almost all x. By the same argument, if U is Î»-complete, then j(Î³) = Î³ for all
Î³ < Î».

Now let Îº be a measurable cardinal, and let U be a nonprincipal Îº-com-
plete ultraï¬lter on Îº. Let d (the diagonal function) be the function on Îº
deï¬ned by
d(Î±) = Î±
(Î± < Îº).
Since U is Îº-complete every bounded subset of Îº has measure 0 and so for
every Î³ < Îº, we have d(Î±) > Î³ for almost all Î±. Hence [d] > Î³ for all Î³ < Îº
and thus [d] â‰¥Îº. However, we clearly have [d] < j(Îº) and it follows that
j(Îº) > Îº.
We have thus proved that if there is a measurable cardinal, then there
is an elementary embedding j of the universe in a transitive model M such
that j is not the identity mapping; j is a nontrivial elementary embedding of
the universe.
Proof of Theorem 17.1. Let us assume V = L and that measurable cardinals
exist; let Îº be the least measurable cardinal. Let U be a nonprincipal Îº-
complete ultraï¬lter on Îº and let j : V â†’M be the corresponding elementary
embedding. As we have shown, j(Îº) > Îº.
Since V = L, the only transitive model containing all ordinals is the
universe itself: V = M = L. Since j is an elementary embedding and Îº is the
least measurable cardinal, we have
M âŠ¨j(Îº) is the least measurable cardinal;
and hence, j(Îº) is the least measurable cardinal. This is a contradiction since
j(Îº) > Îº.
âŠ“âŠ”
If there exists a measurable cardinal, then there exists a nontrivial elemen-
tary embedding of the universe. Let us show that conversely, if j : V â†’M is
a nontrivial elementary embedding then there exists a measurable cardinal.
Lemma 17.3. If j is a nontrivial elementary embedding of the universe, then
there exists a measurable cardinal.
Proof. Let j : V â†’M be a nontrivial embedding. Notice that there exists an
ordinal Î± such that j(Î±) Ì¸= Î±; otherwise, we would have rank(jx) = rank(x)
for all x, and then we could prove by induction on rank that j(x) = x for
all x.
Thus let Îº be the least ordinal number such that j(Îº) Ì¸= Îº (and hence
j(Îº) > Îº). It is clear that j(n) = n for all n and j(Ï‰) = Ï‰ since 0, n + 1,
and Ï‰ are absolute notions and j is elementary. Hence Îº > Ï‰. We shall show
that Îº is a measurable cardinal.

We remark that the measure D = {X âŠ‚Îº : Îº âˆˆj(X)} deï¬ned from

X âˆˆD. Then (jf)(Îº) < Îº, and if Î³ = (jf)(Îº), then f(Î±) = Î³ for almost
all Î±.
Normality can be expressed in terms of ultrapowers:
Lemma 17.5. Let D be a nonprincipal Îº-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº. Then the
following are equivalent:
(i) D is normal.
(ii) In the ultrapower UltD(V ),
Îº = [d]
where d is the diagonal function.
(iii) For every X âŠ‚Îº, X âˆˆD if and only if Îº âˆˆjD(X).
Proof. (i) implies (ii): Every function f âˆˆâˆ—d is regressive, and hence repre-
sents an ordinal Î³ < Îº.

all Î±, that is, if and only if [d] âˆˆjD(X). If [d] = Îº, we get X âˆˆD if and only
if Îº âˆˆjD(X).
(iii) implies (i): If D = {X âŠ‚Îº : Îº âˆˆjD(X)} then D is normal, by the
remark preceding the lemma.

Let j : V â†’M be an elementary embedding. If X is a class deï¬ned by
a formula Ï•, then j(X) is the class of the model M, deï¬ned in M by the same

Lemma 17.6. Let j be an elementary embedding of the universe and let Îº
be the least ordinal moved (i.e., j(Îº) > Îº). If C is a closed unbounded subset
of Îº, then Îº âˆˆj(C).
Proof. Since j(Î±) = Î± for all Î± < Îº, we have j(C) âˆ©Îº = C. Thus j(C) âˆ©Îº
is unbounded in Îº; and because j(C) is closed (in j(V ) and hence in the
universe), we have Îº âˆˆj(C).
âŠ“âŠ”
A consequence of Lemma 17.6 is that the set of all regular cardinals below
a measurable cardinal Îº is stationary (cf. Lemma 10.21): Let X âŠ‚Îº be the
set of all regular cardinals below Îº. Since Îº is regular in M, we have Îº âˆˆj(X),
and Îº âˆˆj(X âˆ©C) for every closed unbounded C âŠ‚Îº. Hence X is stationary.
Similarly, as Îº is Mahlo, it is Mahlo in M, and if X is now the set of all
Mahlo cardinals below Îº, it follows that X is stationary.

where X is any class of ordinals, the above argument shows that if Îº âˆˆj(X)
then Îº âˆˆM(X) (Exercise 17.7).
The next theorem shows that there exists no nontrivial elementary em-
bedding of V into V . As the statement â€œthere exists an elementary embedding
of V â€ is not expressible in the language of set theory, the theorem needs to be
understood as a theorem in the following modiï¬cation of ZFC: The language
has, in addition to âˆˆ, a function symbol j, the axioms include Separation and
Replacement Axioms for formulas that contain the symbol j, and axioms that
state that j is an elementary embedding of V .
Theorem 17.7 (Kunen). If j : V â†’M is a nontrivial elementary embed-
ding, then M Ì¸= V .
First we prove the following lemma:
Lemma 17.8. Let Î» be an inï¬nite cardinal such that 2Î» = Î»â„µ0. There exists
a function F : Î»Ï‰ â†’Î» such that whenever A is a subset of Î» of size Î» and
Î³ < Î», there exists some s âˆˆAÏ‰ such that F(s) = Î³.
Proof. Let {(AÎ±, Î³Î±) : Î± < 2Î»} be an enumeration of all pairs (A, Î³) where
Î³ < Î» and A is a subset of Î» of size Î». We deï¬ne, by induction on Î±, a sequence
sÎ±, Î± < 2Î», of elements of Î»Ï‰ as follows: If Î± < 2Î», then since Î»â„µ0 = 2Î» > |Î±|,
there exists an sÎ± âˆˆAÏ‰
Î± such that sÎ± Ì¸= sÎ² for all Î² < Î±.
For each Î± < 2Î», we deï¬ne F(sÎ±) = Î³Î± (and let F(s) be arbitrary if s is
not one of the sÎ±). The function F has the required property: If A âŠ‚Î» has
size Î» and Î³ < Î», then (A, Î³) = (AÎ±, Î³Î±) for some Î±, and then Î³Î± = F(sÎ±).
âŠ“âŠ”
Proof of Theorem 17.7. Let us assume that j is a nontrivial elementary em-
bedding of V in V . Let Îº = Îº0 be the least ordinal moved; Îº0 is measurable,
and so are Îº1 = j(Îº0), Îº2 = j(Îº1), and every Îºn, where Îºn+1 = j(Îºn). Let
Î» = limnâ†’âˆÎºn. Since j(âŸ¨Îºn : n < Ï‰âŸ©) = âŸ¨j(Îºn) : n < Ï‰âŸ©= âŸ¨Îºn+1 : n < Ï‰âŸ©,
we have j(Î») = limnâ†’âˆj(Îºn) = Î». Let G = {j(Î±) : Î± < Î»}; we shall use the
set G and Lemma 17.8 to obtain a contradiction.
The cardinal Î» is the limit of a sequence of measurable cardinals and hence
is a strong limit cardinal. Since cf Î» = Ï‰, we have 2Î» = Î»â„µ0. By Lemma 17.8
there is a function F : Î»Ï‰ â†’Î» such that F(AÏ‰) = Î» for all A âŠ‚Î» of size Î».
Since j is elementary, and j(Ï‰) = Ï‰ and j(Î») = Î», the function j(F) has the
same property. Thus, considering the set A = G, there exists s âˆˆGÏ‰ such
that (jF)(s) = Îº.
Now, s is a function, s : Ï‰ â†’G, and hence there is a t : Ï‰ â†’Î» such
that s(n) = j(t(n)) for all n < Ï‰. It follows that s = j(t). Thus we have
Îº = (jF)(jt) = j(F(t)); in other words, Îº = j(Î±) where Î± = F(t). However,
this is impossible since j(Î±) = Î± for all Î± < Îº, and j(Îº) > Îº.

Let us recall (Lemma 10.18) that a measurable cardinal is weakly com-
pact. We now prove a stronger result:
Theorem 17.10. Every measurable cardinal Îº is weakly compact and if D is
a normal measure on Îº then the set {Î± < Îº : Î± is weakly compact} is in D.
Proof. The ï¬rst statement was proved in Lemma 10.18. Let D be a normal
measure on Îº, and let jD : V â†’M be the canonical embedding. Since
P M(Îº) = P(Îº), it follows that Îº is weakly compact in M, and since [d]D = Îº,
we have {Î± : Î± is weakly compact} âˆˆD.

The following two results show that the existence of measurable cardinals
inï¬‚uences cardinal arithmetic:
Lemma 17.11. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal. If 2Îº > Îº+, then the set
{Î± < Îº : 2Î± > Î±+} has measure one for every normal measure on Îº.
Consequently, if 2Î± = Î±+ for all cardinals Î± < Îº, then 2Îº = Îº+.
Proof. Let D be a normal measure on Îº, and let M = UltD(V ). If 2Î± = Î±+
for almost all Î±, then, since [d]D = Îº, we have M âŠ¨2Îº = Îº+. In other words,
there is a one-to-one mapping in M between P M(Îº) and (Îº+)M. However,
P M(Îº) = P(Îº) and (Îº+)M = Îº+ (because P M(Îº) = P(Îº)), and so 2Îº = Îº+.

on Îº and let j : V â†’M be the corresponding elementary embedding. Let

We have Î»Îº â‰¤(Î»Îº)M because every function f : Îº â†’Î» is in M. As for the
last inequality, we have

and since Î» < j(Î») and j(Îº) < j(Î»), we have M âŠ¨Î»j(Îº) < j(Î»).

Weak Compactness
We shall investigate weakly compact cardinals in some detail, and give a char-
acterization of weakly compact cardinals that explains the name â€œweakly
compact.â€ This aspect of weakly compact cardinals has, as many other large
cardinal properties, motivation in model theory.

17. Large Cardinals
293
We shall consider inï¬nitary languages which are generalizations of the
ordinary ï¬rst order language. Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal number. The
language LÎº,Ï‰ consists of
(i) Îº variables;
(ii) various relation, function, and constant symbols;
(iii) logical connectives and inï¬nitary connectives 
Î¾<Î± Ï•Î¾, 
Î¾<Î± Ï•Î¾ for
Î± < Îº (inï¬nite disjunction and conjunction);
(iv) quantiï¬ers âˆƒv, âˆ€v.

(v) âˆƒÎ¾<Î±vÎ¾, âˆ€Î¾<Î±vÎ¾ for Î± < Îº.

The ï¬nitary language LÏ‰,Ï‰ satisï¬es the Compactness Theorem: If Î£ is

Theorem 17.13.
(i) If Îº is a weakly compact cardinal, then the language LÎº,Îº satisï¬es the
Weak Compactness Theorem.
(ii) If Îº is an inaccessible cardinal and if LÎº,Ï‰ satisï¬es the Weak Com-
pactness Theorem, then Îº is weakly compact.
Proof. (i) The proof of the Weak Compactness Theorem for LÎº,Îº is very much

Indescribability
Let n > 0 be a natural number and let us consider the nth order predicate
calculus. There are variables of orders 1, 2, . . . , n, and the quantiï¬ers are
applied to variables of all orders. An nth order formula contains, in addition
to ï¬rst order symbols and higher order quantiï¬ers, predicates X(z) where
X and z are variables of order k + 1 and k respectively (for any k < n).
Satisfaction for an nth order formula in a model A = (A, P, . . . , f, . . . , c, . . .)
is deï¬ned as follows: Variables of ï¬rst order are interpreted as elements of
the set A, variables of second order as elements of P(A) (as subsets of A),
etc.; variables of order n are interpreted as elements of P nâˆ’1(A). The predi-
cate X(z) is interpreted as z âˆˆX. A Î n
m formula is a formula of order n + 1
of the form
(17.8)
âˆ€X âˆƒY . . .



m quantiï¬ers
Ïˆ
where X, Y , . . . are (n + 1)th order variables and Ïˆ is such that all quantiï¬ed
variables are of order at most n. Similarly, a Î£n
m formula is as in (17.8), but
with âˆƒand âˆ€interchanged.
We shall often exhibit a sentence Ïƒ and claim that it is Î n
m (or Î£n
m)
although it is only equivalent to a Î n

m (or Î£n

the equivalence Ïƒ â†”Ïƒ holds in all these models.
Note that every ï¬rst order formula is equivalent to some Î 0

Theorem 17.22. If Îº is weakly compact then Îº is weakly compact in L.

Corollary 17.26. If Îº is a Ramsey cardinal and if A âŠƒÎº is a model of

The combinatorial methods introduced in this section will now be em-
ployed to obtain a result on measurable cardinals considerably stronger than
Scottâ€™s Theorem. It will be shown that if a Ramsey cardinal exists then
V = L fails in a strong way. A more extensive theory will be developed in
Chapter 18.
Let us make a few observations about models with deï¬nable Skolem func-
tions. Let A be a model of a language L such that A âŠƒÎº and let I âŠ‚Îº be
a set of indiscernibles for A. Let us assume that the model A has deï¬nable
Skolem functions; i.e., for every formula Ï•(u, v1, . . . , vn), where n â‰¥0, there
exists an n-ary function hÏ• in A such that:
(i) hÏ• is deï¬nable in A, i.e., there is a formula Ïˆ such that
y = hÏ•(x1, . . . , xn)
if and only if
A âŠ¨Ïˆ[y, x1, . . . , xn]
for all y, x1, . . . , xn âˆˆA; and
(ii) hÏ• is a Skolem function for Ï•.
Let B âŠ‚A be the closure of I under all functions in L and the functions hÏ•
for all formulas Ï•. B is an elementary submodel of A, and in fact is the
smallest elementary submodel of A that includes the set I; we call B the
Skolem hull of I and say that I generates B.
We augment the language of A by adding function symbols for all the
Skolem functions hÏ• and call Skolem terms the terms built from variables and
constant symbols (0-ary functions) by applications of functions in L and the
Skolem functions. Since B is an elementary submodel of A, the interpretation
of each Skolem term t is the same in B as in A. For every element x âˆˆB
there is a Skolem term t and indiscernibles Î³1 < . . . < Î³n, elements of I,
such that x = tA[Î³1, . . . , Î³n] = tB[Î³1, . . . , Î³n]. Now if Ïˆ is a formula of the
augmented language, i.e., if Ïˆ also contains the Skolem terms, it still does not
distinguish between the indiscernibles: If Î±1 < . . . < Î±n and Î²1 < . . . < Î²n
are two sequences in I, then Ïˆ(Î±1, . . . , Î±n) holds (either in A or in B) if and
only if Ïˆ(Î²1, . . . , Î²n) holds.
Theorem 17.27 (Rowbottom). If Îº is a Ramsey cardinal, then the set of
all constructible reals is countable. More generally, if Î» is an inï¬nite cardinal
less than Îº, then |P L(Î»)| = Î».
Proof. Let Îº be a Ramsey cardinal and let Î» < Îº. Since Îº is inaccessible, we

This completes the proof: On the one hand, we proved that |S| â‰¤Î»; and on

âŠ“âŠ”
Every Ramsey cardinal is weakly compact. Not only is the least Ramsey
cardinal greater than the least weakly compact but, as we show below, there
is a hierarchy of large cardinals below each Ramsey cardinal, exceeding the
least weakly compact.
Deï¬nition 17.28. For every limit ordinal Î±, the ErdËos cardinal Î·Î± is the
least Îº such that Îº â†’(Î±)<Ï‰.

Î·Î± < Î·Î². Note that Îº is a Ramsey cardinal if and only if Îº = Î·Îº.

We shall now show that the least ErdËos cardinal Î·Ï‰ is greater than the
least weakly compact cardinal. We use the following lemma, of independent
interest:
Lemma 17.32. Let M and N be transitive models of ZFC and let j : M â†’
N be a nontrivial elementary embedding; let Îº be the least ordinal moved. If
P M(Îº) = P N(Îº), then Îº is a weakly compact cardinal in M.

Exercise 17.26).
Let âŸ¨AÎ± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©âˆˆM be such that AÎ± âŠ‚Î± for all Î±. We have j(AÎ±) = AÎ±
for all Î± < Îº, and hence j(âŸ¨AÎ± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©) = (âŸ¨AÎ± : Î± < j(Îº)âŸ©(for some AÎ±,
Îº â‰¤Î± < j(Îº)). The set AÎº is in M and witnesses ineï¬€ability of Îº in M.

below Î·Ï‰.

The next result shows that the ErdËos cardinal Î·Ï‰ is consistent with V = L.

Theorem 17.34. If Îº â†’(Ï‰)<Ï‰ then L âŠ¨Îº â†’(Ï‰)<Ï‰.
Proof. Let f be a constructible partition f : [Îº]<Ï‰ â†’{0, 1}. We claim that
if there is an inï¬nite homogeneous set for f, then there is one in L. Let T
be the set of all ï¬nite increasing sequences t = âŸ¨Î±0, . . . , Î±nâˆ’1âŸ©in Îº such that
for every k â‰¤n, f is constant on [{Î±0, . . . , Î±nâˆ’1}]k, and let us consider the

set for f exists if and only if (T, âŠƒ) is not well-founded. However, being well-
founded is an absolute property for models of ZFC; and so if the tree is not
well-founded, then it is not well-founded in L, and the claim follows.

Deï¬nition 17.35. A cardinal Îº > â„µ1 is a Rowbottom cardinal if for every
uncountable Î» < Îº, every model of type (Îº, Î») has an elementary submodel
of type (Îº, â„µ0).
An inï¬nite cardinal is a JÂ´onsson cardinal if every model of size Îº has
a proper elementary submodel of size Îº.
Every Rowbottom cardinal is a JÂ´onsson cardinal and the following lemma,
a variation on Rowbottomâ€™s Theorem, shows that every Ramsey cardinal is
a Rowbottom cardinal.

X âŠ‚B.

some Skolem functions hÏ• (in (A, . . . , P, x)xâˆˆX) for every formula Ï•, and

Historical Notes
In [1963/64] Keisler and Tarski introduced the method of ultraproducts in the
study of measurable cardinals, and it was established that the least measurable

17. Large Cardinals
309
cardinal is greater than the least inaccessible cardinal. Scott used the method of ul-
trapowers to prove that existence of measurable cardinals contradicts the Axiom of
Constructibility. Rowbottom and Silver initiated applications of inï¬nitary combina-
torics developed by ErdËos and his collaborators. Scottâ€™s Theorem appeared in [1961]
and Kunenâ€™s Theorem in [1971a]. (Lemma 17.8 is due to ErdËos and Hajnal [1966].)
In [1963/64a] Hanf studied compactness of inï¬nitary languages; his work let to
the systematic study of Keisler and Tarski. Hanf proved that the least inaccessible
cardinal is not measurable (in fact not weakly compact); ErdËos and Hajnal then
pointed out (cf. [1962]) that the same result can be proved using inï¬nitary combi-
natorics. Keisler and Tarski introduced the Mahlo operation and showed that the
least measurable cardinal is much greater than, e.g., the least Mahlo cardinal, etc.
The equivalence of various formulations of weak compactness is a result of
several papers. In [1963/64a] Hanf initiated investigations of compactness of in-
ï¬nitary languages. ErdËos and Tarski listed in [1961] several properties that were
subsequently shown mutually equivalent (for inaccessible cardinals) and proved
several implications. These properties included the partition property Îº â†’(Îº)2
2,
the tree property, and several other properties. Hanf and Scott [1961] introduced
Î n
m-indescribability and announced Theorem 17.18. Further contributions were
made in the papers Hanf [1963/64b], Hajnal [1964], Keisler [1962], Monk and
Scott [1963/64], Tarski [1962], and Keisler and Tarski [1963/64]. A complete list of
equivalent formulations with the proofs appeared in Silver [1971b]. Theorem 17.22
is due to Silver [1971b]. Rowbottomâ€™s Theorem (as well as Lemma 17.36) are due
to Rowbottom [1971].
The main results on ErdËos cardinals are due to Rowbottom, Reinhardt, and
Silver. Rowbottom proved that if Î·Ï‰1 exists, then there are only countably many
constructible reals (see [1971]); Theorem 17.33 is due to Reinhardt and Silver [1965],
and Theorem 17.34 is due to Silver [1970a].
Exercise 17.10: Ketonen [1973].
Ineï¬€able cardinals were introduced by Jensen; Exercises 17.26 and 17.27 are
due to Kunen and Jensen.
Exercise 17.29: Reinhardt and Silver [1965].

18. Large Cardinals and L
In Chapter 17 we proved that while â€œsmallerâ€ large cardinals (inaccessible,
Mahlo, weakly compact) can exist in L, the â€œbiggerâ€ large cardinals (measur-
able, Ramsey) cannot. In this chapter we isolate and investigate the concept
of 0â™¯(zero-sharp), a great divide in the landscape of large cardinals.
Silver Indiscernibles
Theorem 18.1 (Silver). If there exists a Ramsey cardinal, then:
(i) If Îº and Î» are uncountable cardinals and Îº < Î», then (LÎº, âˆˆ) is an
elementary submodel of (LÎ», âˆˆ).
(ii) There is a unique closed unbounded class of ordinals I containing all
uncountable cardinals such that for every uncountable cardinal Îº:
(a) |I âˆ©Îº| = Îº,
(b) I âˆ©Îº is a set of indiscernibles for (LÎº, âˆˆ), and
(c) every a âˆˆLÎº is deï¬nable in (LÎº, âˆˆ) from I âˆ©Îº.
The elements of the class I are called Silver indiscernibles. Before giving
the proof of Theorem 18.1 we state some consequences of the existence of
Silver indiscernibles.
By the Reï¬‚ection Principle, if Ï• is a formula, then there exists an un-
countable cardinal Îº such that

for all x1, . . . , xn âˆˆLÎº. By (i), the right hand side holds in and only if
LÎ» âŠ¨Ï•(x1, . . . , xn) for all cardinals Î» â‰¥Îº. In view of this, we can deï¬ne
satisfaction in L for all formulas Ï• âˆˆForm: If Ï•(v1, . . . , vn) is a formula of
the language L = {âˆˆ} and if âŸ¨a1, . . . , anâŸ©is an n-termed sequence in L, we
deï¬ne

Corollary 18.2. Every constructible set deï¬nable in L is countable.
Proof. If x âˆˆL is deï¬nable in L by a formula Ï•, then the same formula
deï¬nes x in Lâ„µ1 and hence x âˆˆLâ„µ1.

Corollary 18.3. Every uncountable cardinal is inaccessible in L.

L âŠ¨â„µÎ± is regular

Models with Indiscernibles
The proof of Silverâ€™s Theorem is based on a theorem of Ehrenfeucht and
Mostowski in model theory, stating that every inï¬nite model is elementarily
equivalent to a model that has a set of indiscernibles of prescribed order-type.
We shall deal only with models (LÎ», âˆˆ) (and models elementarily equivalent
to these); we shall prove below a special case of the Ehrenfeucht-Mostowski
Theorem.
We shall use the canonical well-ordering of L to endow the models (LÎ», âˆˆ)
with deï¬nable Skolem functions. For each formula Ï•(u, v1, . . . , vn), let hÏ• be
the n-ary function deï¬ned as follows:
(18.5)

otherwise.

For each limit ordinal Î», hLÎ»

involving the hÏ• since they as deï¬nable functions can be eliminated and
the formulas can be replaced by âˆˆ-formulas. For each limit ordinal Î», the
functions hLÎ»

M âŠ‚LÎ» is an elementary submodel of (LÎ», âˆˆ) if and only if M is closed
under the hLÎ»

elements of LÎ» deï¬nable in LÎ» from X.

A set of formulas Î£ is called an E.M. set (Ehrenfeucht-Mostowski) if there
exists a model A elementarily equivalent to some LÎ», Î» a limit ordinal, and
an inï¬nite set I of indiscernibles for A such that Î£ = Î£(A, I).
Lemma 18.7. If Î£ is an E.M. set and Î± an inï¬nite ordinal number, then

We shall eventually show that the existence of Ramsey cardinal implies

316
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Lemma 18.9. The following are equivalent, for an E.M. set Î£:
(i) For every ordinal Î±, the (Î£, Î±)-model is well-founded.
(ii) For some ordinal Î± â‰¥Ï‰1, the (Î£, Î±)-model is well-founded.
(iii) For every ordinal Î± < Ï‰1, the (Î£, Î±)-model is well-founded.
Proof. (i) â†’(ii) is trivial.
(ii) â†’(iii): If (A, I) is the (Î£, Î±)-model and if Î² â‰¤Î±, let J be the initial
segment of the ï¬rst Î² elements of I; let B = HA(J). Clearly, (B, J) is the
(Î£, Î²)-model. Since a submodel of a well-founded model is well-founded, it
follows that if Î² â‰¤Î± and the (Î£, Î±)-model is well-founded, then the (Î£, Î²)-
model is also well-founded, and thus (ii) implies (iii).
(iii) â†’(i): Let us assume that there is a limit ordinal Î± such that the
(Î£, Î±)-model is not well-founded; let (A, I) be the model. There is an inï¬nite
sequence a0, a1, a2, . . . in A such that a1 E a2, a2 E a1, etc. Each an is
deï¬nable from I; that is, for each n there is a Skolem term tn such that an =
tA
n[x1, . . . , xkn] for some x1, . . . , xkn âˆˆI. Therefore there is a countable subset
I0 of I such that an âˆˆHA(I0) for all n âˆˆÏ‰. The order-type of I0 is a countable

We shall now deï¬ne remarkability. We consider only (Î£, Î±)-models where
Î± is an inï¬nite limit ordinal.
Let us say that a (Î£, Î±)-model (A, I) is unbounded if the set I is un-
bounded in the ordinals of A, that is, if for every x âˆˆOrdA there is y âˆˆI
such that x < y.
Lemma 18.10. The following are equivalent, for any E.M. set Î£:
(i) For all Î±, (Î£, Î±) is unbounded.
(ii) For some Î±, (Î£, Î±) is unbounded.
(iii) For every Skolem term t(v1, . . . , vn) the set Î£ contains the formula
(18.12)
if t(v1, . . . , vn) is an ordinal, then t(v1, . . . , vn) < vn+1.
Proof. (i) â†’(ii) is trivial.
(ii) â†’(iii): Let (A, I) be a (Î£, Î±)-model, where Î± is a limit ordinal,
and assume that I is unbounded in OrdA. To prove (iii), it suï¬ƒces to show
that for any term t, (18.12) is true in A for some increasing sequence x1 <
. . . < xn+1 in I. Let t be a Skolem term. Let us choose x1 < . . . < xn âˆˆI
and let y = tA[x1, . . . , xn]. If y /âˆˆOrdA, then (18.12) is vacuously true; if
y âˆˆOrdA, then there exists xn+1 âˆˆI such that y < xn+1, and we have
A âŠ¨t[x1, . . . , xn] < xn+1.
(iii) â†’(i): Let (A, I) be a (Î£, Î±)-model, where Î± is a limit ordinal, and
assume (iii). To prove that I is unbounded in OrdA, let y âˆˆOrdA. There exist
a Skolem term t and x1 < . . . < xn âˆˆI such that y = tA[x1, . . . , xn]. Now if
xn+1 is any element of I greater than xn, (iii) implies that y < xn+1.

Let Î± be a limit ordinal, Î± > Ï‰, and let (A, I) be the (Î£, Î±)-model.

Thus we say that an E.M. set Î£ is remarkable if it is unbounded and
contains the formulas (18.13) for all Skolem terms t.
An important consequence of remarkability is the following: Let (A, I) be
a remarkable (Î£, Î±)-model and let Î³ < Î± be a limit ordinal. Let J = {iÎ¾ :
Î¾ < Î³} and let B = HA(J). Then (B, J) is the (Î£, Î³)-model, and the ordinals
of B form an initial segment of the ordinals of A.
Another consequence of remarkability is that the indiscernibles form
a closed unbounded subset of ordinals. Let (A, I) be the (Î£, Î±)-model. We
say that the set I is closed in OrdA if for every limit Î³ < Î±, iÎ³ is the least
upper bound (in the linearly ordered set OrdA) of the set {iÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î³}.
Lemma 18.12. If (A, I) is remarkable, then I is closed in OrdA.
Proof. Let Î³ < Î± be a limit ordinal. If x is an ordinal of A less than iÎ³, then
by remarkability, x is in the (Î£, Î³)-model B = HA({iÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î³}). However,
since Î£ is unbounded, B is an unbounded (Î£, Î³)-model and hence x < iÎ¾ for
some Î¾ < Î³. Hence iÎ³ is the least upper bound of {iÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î³}.

Proof of Silverâ€™s Theorem and 0â™¯
Let us call an E.M. set Î£ well-founded if every (Î£, Î±)-model is well-founded,
and let us consider the statement:
(18.15)

We shall prove Theorem 18.1 in two steps: First we shall show that both (i)
and (ii) are consequences of the assumption that there exists a well-founded
remarkable E.M. set, and then we shall show that if there exists a Ramsey
cardinal, then (18.15) holds. (Note that by Lemma 18.9 it suï¬ƒces to ï¬nd
a well-founded remarkable model with uncountably many indiscernibles.)
Thus let us assume that there exists a well-founded remarkable E.M. set
and let Î£ be such a set.
For every limit ordinal Î±, the (Î£, Î±)-model is a well-founded model el-
ementarily equivalent to some LÎ³, and so by (13.13) is (isomorphic to)
some LÎ².

Lemma 18.13. If Îº is an uncountable cardinal, then the universe of the
(Î£, Îº)-model is LÎº.
Proof. The (Î£, Îº)-model is (LÎ², I) for some Î²; since |I| = Îº, we clearly have

The set 0â™¯is, strictly speaking, a set of formulas. But as formulas can

Lemma 18.19. The property â€œÎ£ is a well-founded remarkable E.M. setâ€ is
absolute for every inner model of ZF. Hence M âŠ¨0â™¯exists if and only if
0â™¯âˆˆM in which case (0â™¯)M = 0â™¯.
Proof. We ï¬rst replace the property â€œÎ£ is an E.M. setâ€ by a syntactical

of Ë†L. For each set of formulas Î£, let Ë†Î£ be the set containing (i) all Ë†Ï• for

j1 < . . . < jn, (iv) all axioms of ZFC + V = L. Let us consider the condition
(18.23)
Ë†Î£ is consistent.
Clearly, if Î£ is an E.M. set, then Ë†Î£ is consistent, for we simply interpret
the constants cn, n < Ï‰, as some Silver indiscernibles. Conversely, if Ë†Î£ is

As remarkability can also be expressed as a syntactical property, it follows
that â€œÎ£ is a remarkable E.M. setâ€ can be written as a âˆ†0 property (with
parameters VÏ‰ and Form). As such it is absolute for transitive models.
If Î£ is a remarkable E.M. set, then for every limit ordinal Î± there is
a unique (up to isomorphism) (Î£, Î±)-model and we can ï¬nd one ((A, E), I)

(18.24)
âˆ€Î± âˆ€(A, E) (if ((A, E), Î±) is a (Î£, Î±)-model, then (A, E) is well-
founded).
As well-foundedness is absolute for transitive models of ZF, it follows that
(18.24) is absolute for inner models of ZF (which contain all ordinals), and
therefore â€œÎ£ = 0â™¯â€ is absolute.

Elementary Embeddings of L
In Chapter 17 we proved that a well-founded ultrapower of the universe
induces an elementary embedding jU : V â†’Ult, and conversely, if j : V â†’M

323
is a nontrivial elementary embedding, then (17.2) deï¬nes a normal measure
on the least ordinal moved by j.
Let j be a nontrivial elementary embedding of the universe, and let M
be a transitive model of ZFC, containing all ordinals. Let N = j(M) =

Î±âˆˆOrd j(M âˆ©VÎ±). Then N is a transitive model of ZF and j : M â†’N is
elementary:
(18.25)

if and only if
N âŠ¨Ï•(j(a1), . . . , j(an)).
((18.25) is proved by induction on the complexity of Ï•). In particular, if

jâ†¾L is an elementary embedding of L in L. Note that by Scottâ€™s Theorem, the
function jâ†¾L is not a class in L; thus if there exists an elementary embedding
of L (into L), then V Ì¸= L.
If 0â™¯exists, then there are nontrivial elementary embeddings of L. In
fact, let j be any order-preserving function from the class I of all Silver
indiscernibles into itself. Then j can be extended to an elementary embedding
of L; we simply let

Theorem 18.20 (Kunen). The following are equivalent:
(i) 0â™¯exists.

dinal in M. An M-ultraï¬lter on Îº is a collection D âŠ‚P M(Îº) that is an

(i) Îº âˆˆD and âˆ…/âˆˆD;

(18.27)

18. Large Cardinals and L
329
Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem
The theorem presented in this section shows that in the absence of 0â™¯the
universe does not diï¬€er drastically from the constructible model. In partic-
ular, the coï¬nality function is closely related to the coï¬nality function in L,
and every singular cardinal is a singular cardinal in L. Moreover, the Singular
Cardinal Hypothesis holds and cardinal exponentiation is determined by the
continuum function on regular cardinals.
Theorem 18.30 (Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem). If 0â™¯does not exist,
then for every uncountable set X of ordinals there exists a constructible set
Y âŠƒX such that |Y | = |X|.
The Covering Theorem expresses the closeness between V and L: Every
uncountable set of ordinals can be covered by a constructible set of the same
cardinality. In other words, every set X of ordinals can be covered by some
Y âˆˆL such that |Y | â‰¤|X| Â· â„µ1. (This is best possible: In Chapter 28 we give
an example of a forcing extension of L in which there is a countable set of
ordinals that cannot be covered by a countable (in V ) constructible set.)
The converse of the Covering Theorem is also true: If 0â™¯exists then every
uncountable cardinal is regular in L, and in particular, since â„µÏ‰ is regular
in L, the countable set {â„µn : n < Ï‰} cannot be covered by a constructible
set of cardinality less than â„µÏ‰. This shows:
0â™¯exists if and only if â„µÏ‰ is regular in L.
Corollary 18.31. If 0â™¯does not exist then for every Î» â‰¥â„µ2, if Î» is a reg-
ular cardinal in L then cf Î» = |Î»|. Consequently, every singular cardinal is
a singular cardinal in L.
The assumption Î» â‰¥â„µ2 is necessary: The forcing mentioned above yields
a model where Î» = â„µL
2 is such that |Î»| = â„µ1 and cf Î» = Ï‰.
Proof. Let Î» be a limit ordinal such that Î» â‰¥Ï‰2 and that Î» is a regular
cardinal in L. Let X be an unbounded subset of Î» such that |X| = cf Î». By the
Covering Theorem, there exists a constructible set Y such that X âŠ‚Y âŠ‚Î»
and that |Y | = |X|Â·â„µ1. Since Y is unbounded in Î» and Î» is a regular cardinal
in L, we have |Y | = |Î»|. This gives |Î»| = â„µ1 Â· cf Î» and since Î» â‰¥â„µ2, we have
|Î»| = cf Î».
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 18.32. If 0â™¯does not exist then for every singular cardinal Îº,
(Îº+)L = Îº+.
Proof. Let Îº be a singular cardinal and let Î» be the successor cardinal of Îº
in L; we want to show that Î» = Îº+. If not, then |Î»| = Îº, and since Îº is singular,
we have cf Î» < Îº. However, this means that cf Î» < |Î»| which contradicts
Corollary 18.31.
âŠ“âŠ”

330
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Corollary 18.33. If 0â™¯does not exist then the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis
holds.
Proof. Let Îº be such that 2cf Îº < Îº, and let A = [Îº]cf Îº be the set of all subsets
of Îº of size cf Îº. We shall show that |A| â‰¤Îº+. By the Covering Theorem,
for every X âˆˆA there exists a constructible Y âŠ‚Îº such that X âŠ‚Y and
|Y | = Î» where Î» = â„µ1 Â· cf Îº. Thus
(18.33)
A âŠ‚{[Y ]cf Îº : Y âˆˆC}
where C = {Y âŠ‚Îº : |Y | = Î» and Y âˆˆL}. If Y âˆˆC, then |[Y ]cf Îº| = Î»cf Îº =
(â„µ1 Â· cf Îº)cf Îº = 2cf Îº < Îº. Since |C| â‰¤|P L(Îº)| = |(Îº+)L| â‰¤Îº+ it follows
from (18.33) that |A| â‰¤Îº+.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 18.34. If 0â™¯does not exist then if Îº is a singular cardinal and if
there exists a nonconstructible subset of Îº, then some Î± < Îº has a noncon-
structible subset.
Proof. Let Îº be a singular cardinal and assume that each Î± < Îº has only
constructible subsets; we shall show that every subset of Îº is constructible.
It suï¬ƒces to show that each subset of Îº of size cf Îº is constructible: If A âŠ‚Îº,
let {Î±Î½ : Î½ < cf Îº} be such that limÎ½ Î±Î½ = Îº; then A = {A âˆ©Î±Î½ : Î½ < cf Îº}
is a subset of LÎº of size â‰¤cf Îº and hence constructible. It follows that A is
constructible.
Let X âŠ‚Îº be such that |X| â‰¤cf(Îº). By the Covering Theorem, there
exists a constructible set of ordinals Y âŠƒX such that |Y | < Îº. Let Ï€ be the
isomorphism between Y and its order-type Î±; the function Ï€ is constructible
and one-to-one. Since |Î±| = |Y | < Îº, we have Î± < Îº.
Let Z = Ï€(X). Then Z âŠ‚Î± is constructible by the assumption, and hence
X = Ï€âˆ’1(Z) is also constructible.
âŠ“âŠ”
The rest of this chapter is devoted to the proof of the Covering Theorem.
Jensenâ€™s proof of the Covering Theorem used a detailed analysis of construc-
tion of sets in L, the ï¬ne structure theory, see [1972]. The proof appeared in
Devlin and Jensen [1975]. Subsequently, Silver and Magidor gave proofs that
did not use the ï¬ne structure. The outline below is based on Magidor [1990]
(and on Kanamoriâ€™s presentation in [âˆ]).
Let us assume that there exists an uncountable set X of ordinals that can-
not be covered by a constructible set of the same size. The goal is to produce
a nontrivial elementary embedding from L into L. In fact, by Theorem 18.27
it suï¬ƒces to ï¬nd some j : LÎ± â†’LÎ² with critical point below |Î±|.
Let Ï„ be the least ordinal such that there exists a set X âŠ‚Ï„ that cannot
be covered, and let X âŠ‚Ï„ be such a set with |X| least possible. Let Î½ = |X|.

18. Large Cardinals and L
331
Lemma 18.35.
(i) Ï„ is a cardinal in L.
(ii) If Y âˆˆL covers X then |Y |L â‰¥Ï„.
(iii) Î½ is a regular cardinal, Î½ < Ï„, and Î½ = â„µ1 Â· cf Ï„.
Proof. (i) and (ii) follow from the minimality of Ï„.
(iii) |X| < Ï„, because otherwise, Y = Ï„ would cover X. Clearly, |X| â‰¥

to indicate that M satisï¬es (18.41).

Historical Notes
Theorem 18.1 was discovered by Gaifman (assuming the existence of a measurable
cardinal). Gaifmanâ€™s results were announced in [1964] and the proof was published
in [1974], Gaifmanâ€™s proof used iterated ultrapowers (see also Gaifman [1967]).
Silver in his thesis (1966, published in [1971b]) developed the present method of
proof, using inï¬nitary combinatorics, and proved the theorem under the weaker
assumption of existence of Îº with the property Îº â†’(â„µ1)<Ï‰. Gaifman proved that
if there is a measurable cardinal, then there exists A âŠ‚Ï‰ such that the conclusion
of Theorem 18.1 holds in L[A]. Solovay formulated 0â™¯and proved that it is a âˆ†1
3 set
of integers; Silver deduced the existence of 0â™¯under weaker assumptions.
Construction of models with indiscernibles was introduced by Ehrenfeucht and
Mostowski in [1956].
The equivalence of the existence of 0â™¯with the existence of a nontrivial elemen-
tary embedding of L (Theorem 18.20) is due to Kunen; the present proof is due
to Silver. Kunen also derived 0â™¯from the existence of JÂ´onsson cardinals and from
Changâ€™s Conjecture.
Theorem 18.30 (and its corollaries) is due to Jensen. A proof of the theorem
appeared in Devlin and Jensen [1975]. Jensenâ€™s proof makes use of his ï¬ne structure
theory, see Jensen [1972]. The present proof is due to Magidor [1990]. Lemma 18.38
appears in Magidor [1990] and in Kanamoriâ€™s book [âˆ]; Magidor attributes the
proof to Boolos [1970].
Exercise 18.3: Solovay.
Exercise 18.6: Kunen.
Exercise 18.12: Magidor.

19. Iterated Ultrapowers and L[U]
In this chapter we investigate inner models for measurable cardinals, using
Kunenâ€™s technique of iterated ultrapowers.
The Model L[U]
Let Îº be a measurable cardinal and let U be a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultra-
ï¬lter on Îº. Let us consider the model L[U]. By Lemma 13.23, L[U] = L[ Â¯U],
where Â¯U = U âˆ©L[U].
Lemma 19.1. In L[U], Â¯U is a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Îº.
Moreover, if U is normal, then L[U] âŠ¨Â¯U is normal.
Proof. A straightforward veriï¬cation. For instance if U is normal and f âˆˆ
L[U] is a regressive function on Îº, then for some Î³ < Îº, the set X = {Î± :
f(Î±) = Î³} is in U; since X âˆˆL[U], L[U] âŠ¨f is constant on some X âˆˆÂ¯U.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall eventually prove, among others, that the model L[U] satis-
ï¬es GCH. For now, we recall Theorem 13.22(iv) by which 2â„µÎ± = â„µÎ±+1
holds in L[U] for all suï¬ƒciently large Î±. Speciï¬cally, using the Condensa-
tion Lemma 13.24, we get:
Lemma 19.2. If V = L[A], and if A âŠ‚P(Ï‰Î±), then 2â„µÎ± = â„µÎ±+1.
Proof. Let X be a subset of Ï‰Î±. Let Î» be a cardinal such that A âˆˆLÎ»[A]
and X âˆˆLÎ»[A]. Let M be an elementary submodel of (LÎ»[A], âˆˆ) such that
Ï‰Î± âŠ‚M, A âˆˆM, X âˆˆM, and |M| = â„µÎ±. Let Ï€ be the transitive collapse
of M, and let N = Ï€(M). Since Ï‰Î± âŠ‚M, we have Ï€(Z) = Z for every Z âŠ‚Ï‰Î±
that is in M and in particular Ï€(X) = X; also, Ï€(A) = Ï€(A âˆ©M) = A âˆ©N.

is in LÏ‰Î±+1[A] and therefore 2â„µÎ± = â„µÎ±+1.

Theorem 19.3 (Silver). If V = L[D] where D is a normal measure on
a measurable cardinal Îº, then the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis holds.

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Proof. If Î» â‰¥Îº, then D âŠ‚P(Î») and hence 2Î» = Î»+ by Lemma 19.2. Thus
it suï¬ƒces to show that 2Î» = Î»+ for every inï¬nite cardinal Î» < Îº. Let Î» < Îº
and let us assume that there are more than Î»+ subsets of Î»; we shall reach
a contradiction. If 2Î» > Î»+, then there exists a set X âŠ‚Î» that is the Î»+th
subset of Î» in the canonical well-ordering <L[D] of L[D]. Let Î± be the least
ordinal such that X âˆˆLÎ±[D]. Since the well-ordering <L[D] has the property
that each LÎ¾[D] is an initial segment of <L[D] every subset of Î» preceding X
is also in LÎ±[D] and hence the set P(Î») âˆ©LÎ±[D] has size at least Î»+.
We shall now apply Lemma 17.36. Let Î· be a cardinal such that Î· > Î±
and that D âˆˆLÎ·[D], and consider the model A = (A, âˆˆ) where A = LÎ·[D].
We have Îº âŠ‚A, and we consider the set P = P(Î»)âˆ©A. Since 2Î» < Îº, we have
|P| < Îº. By Lemma 17.36, there is an elementary submodel B = (B, âˆˆ) â‰ºA
such that Î» âˆª{D, X, Î±} âŠ‚B, Îº âˆ©B âˆˆD and |P âˆ©B| â‰¤Î». Let Ï€ be the
transitive collapse of B onto a transitive set M; we have M = LÎ³[Ï€(D)] for
some Î³.
Using the normality of D, we show that Ï€(D) = Dâˆ©M. Clearly, Ï€(Îº) = Îº
because |Îº âˆ©B| = Îº. The function Ï€ is one-to-one, and for every Î¾ < Îº,
Ï€(Î¾) â‰¤Î¾. Since D is normal, there is a set Z âˆˆD such that Ï€(Î¾) = Î¾ for all
Î¾ âˆˆZ. Hence if Y âˆˆB is a set in D, then Ï€(Y ) âŠƒÏ€(Y âˆ©Z) = Y âˆ©Z, and so
Ï€(Y ) is also in D; similarly, if Y âˆˆB and Ï€(Y ) âˆˆD, then Y âˆˆD. It follows
that Ï€(D) = D âˆ©M.
Hence M = LÎ³[D]. Since Î» âŠ‚B, Ï€ maps every subset of Î» onto itself,
and so P(Î») âˆ©M = P(Î») âˆ©B. In particular, we have Ï€(X) = X and so

hand |P(Î») âˆ©LÎ³[D]| â‰¤Î».

One proves rather easily that the model L[D] has only one measurable
cardinal:
Lemma 19.4. If V = L[D] and D is a normal measure on Îº, then Îº is the
only measurable cardinal.
Proof. Let us assume that there is a measurable cardinal Î» Ì¸= Îº and let us

D and so M = L[D]. Thus assume that Î» < Îº.

belongs to D. By Lemma 17.9(v), j(Îº) = Îº and j(Î±) = Î± for all Î± âˆˆZ. We
shall show that j(D) = D âˆ©M. It suï¬ƒces to show that j(D) âŠ‚D âˆ©M since

19. Iterated Ultrapowers and L[U]

Iterated Ultrapowers
Let Îº be a measurable cardinal and let U be a Îº-complete nonprincipal ul-
traï¬lter on Îº. Using U, we construct an ultrapower of V mod U; and since
the ultrapower is well-founded, we identify the ultrapower with its transi-
tive collapse, a transitive model M = UltU(V ). Let us denote this transitive
model Ult(1)
U (V ) or just Ult(1). Let j(0) = jU be the canonical embedding
of V in Ult(1), and let Îº(1) = j(0)(Îº) and U (1) = j(0)(U).
In the model Ult(1), the ordinal Îº(1) is a measurable cardinal and U (1) is
a Îº(1)-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Îº(1). Thus working inside Ult(1),
we can construct an ultrapower mod U (1): UltU(1)(Ult(1)). Let us denote this
ultrapower Ult(2), and let j(1) be the canonical embedding of Ult(1) in Ult(2)
given by this ultrapower. Let Îº(2) = j(1)(Îº1) and U (2) = j(1)(U (1)).
We can continue this procedure and obtain transitive models
Ult(1),
Ult(2),
. . . ,
Ult(n),
. . .
(n < Ï‰).
[That we can indeed construct such a sequence of classes follows from the
observation that for each Î±, the initial segment VÎ±âˆ©Ult(n) of each ultrapower
in the sequence is deï¬ned from an initial segment VÎ² of the universe (where
Î² is something like Îº + Î± + 1).]
Thus we get a sequence of models Ult(n), n < Ï‰ (where Ult(0) = V ). For
any n < m, we have an elementary embedding in,m : Ult(n) â†’Ult(m) which

in,m(x) = j(mâˆ’1)j(mâˆ’2) . . . j(n)(x)
(x âˆˆUlt(n)).
These embeddings form a commutative system; that is,
im,k â—¦in,m = in,k
(m < n < k).
We also let Îº(n) = i0,n(Îº), and U (n) = i0,n(U). Note that Îº(0) < Îº(1) < . . . <
Îº(n) < . . ., and Ult(0) âŠƒUlt(1) âŠƒ. . . âŠƒUlt(n) âŠƒ. . ..
Thus we have a directed system of models and elementary embeddings
(19.1)

Even though the models are proper classes, the technique of Lemma 12.2 is
still applicable and we can consider the direct limit

Ult(n) for every n.)

Representation of Iterated Ultrapowers

means of a single ultrapower of the universe, using an ultraï¬lter on a certain
Boolean algebra of subsets of ÎºÎ±. This will enable us to obtain more precise
information about the embeddings i0,Î± : V â†’Ult(Î±).

â†”âˆ€âˆ—t {Î¾ < Îº : f(t)(Î¾) = g(t)(Î¾)} âˆˆU

â†”Ult(n) âŠ¨{Î¾ < Îº(n) : Ëœf(Î¾) = Ëœg(Î¾)} âˆˆU (n)
â†”[ Ëœf]U(n) = [Ëœg]U(n)
and similarly for âˆˆin place of =.
Thus UltUn+1 = Ult(n+1). To show that jUn+1 = i0,n+1, let f = cx be
the constant function on Îºn+1 with value x. It follows that Ëœf is the constant

jUn+1(x) = [cx]Un+1 = in,n+1(i0,n(x)) = i0,n+1(x).

The inï¬nite iterations are described with the help of ultraï¬lters UE on ÎºE,
where E ranges over ï¬nite sets of ordinal numbers. If E is a ï¬nite set of

a natural way, an ultraï¬lter UE corresponding to Un:
UE = {Ï€(X) : X âŠ‚Îºn}
where Ï€(âŸ¨Î±0, . . . , Î±nâˆ’1âŸ©) = t âˆˆÎºE with t(Ï€(k)) = Î±k for all k = 0, . . . , n âˆ’1.
If S is any set of ordinals and E âŠ‚S is a ï¬nite set, we deï¬ne a mapping
inE,S (an inclusion map) of P(ÎºE) into P(ÎºS) as follows:
inE,S(X) = {t âˆˆÎºS : tâ†¾E âˆˆX}
(all X âŠ‚ÎºE).
Lemma 19.12. If E âŠ‚F are ï¬nite sets of ordinals, then for each X âŠ‚ÎºE,
X âˆˆUE
if and only if
inE,F (X) âˆˆUF .
Proof. By induction on (m, n) where m = |E| and n = |F|. Let E âŠ‚F be

19. Iterated Ultrapowers and L[U]

Let us now consider an ordinal number Î±. If E âŠ‚Î± is a ï¬nite set, let us
say that a set Z âŠ‚ÎºÎ± has support E if Z = inE,Î±(X) for some X âŠ‚ÎºE.
Note that if Z has support E and E âŠ‚F, then Z also has support F. Let BÎ±

a Boolean algebra.

X âˆˆUE.
By Lemma 19.12, the deï¬nition of UÎ± does not depend on the choice of
support E of Z.
We shall now construct an ultrapower mod UÎ±. If f is a function on ÎºÎ±, let

for all t âˆˆÎºÎ±. Let us consider only functions f on ÎºÎ± with ï¬nite support and

(19.7)

if and only if
{t : f(t) = g(t)} âˆˆUÎ±,

if and only if
{t : f(t) âˆˆg(t)} âˆˆUÎ±.
The sets on the right-hand side of (19.7) have ï¬nite support, namely E âˆªF
where E and F are, respectively, supports of f and g.
Let (UltUÎ±(V ), EÎ±) be the model whose elements are equivalence classes
mod =Î± of functions on ÎºÎ± with ï¬nite support.
We are now in a position to state the main lemma.
Lemma 19.13 (The Representation Lemma). For every Î±, the model
(UltUÎ±(V ), EÎ±) is (isomorphic to) the Î±th iterated ultrapower Ult(Î±)
U (V ), and
the canonical embedding jUÎ± : V â†’UltUÎ± is equal to i0,Î±. Moreover, if Î± â‰¤Î²
and [f]UÎ± âˆˆUlt(Î±), then iÎ±,Î²([f]UÎ±) = [g]UÎ² where g is deï¬ned by g(t) =

Proof. By induction on Î±. The induction step from Î± to Î± + 1 follows closely

the corresponding [ Ëœf]U(Î±) in Ult(Î±+1). Let f be a function on ÎºÎ±+1 with

Î¾ < Îº, and let F be a function on ÎºÎ± (with support E) such that F(t) = f(t)
for all t âˆˆÎºÎ±. Let Ëœf = [F]UÎ±; Ëœf is in Ult(Î±) and is a function on Îº(Î±).
When Î» is a limit ordinal, a routine veriï¬cation shows that UltUÎ» is the
direct limit of {UltUÎ±, iÎ±,Î² : Î±, Î² < Î»} and that the embeddings iÎ±,Î» commute
with the iÎ±,Î².

Uniqueness of the Model L[D]
Theorem 19.14 (Kunen).
(i) If V = L[D] and D is a normal measure on Îº, then Îº is the only
measurable cardinal and D is the only normal measure on Îº.
(ii) For every ordinal Îº, there is at most one D âŠ‚P(Îº) such that D âˆˆL[D]
and
L[D] âŠ¨D is a normal measure on Îº.
(iii) If Îº1 < Îº2 are ordinals and if D1, D2 are such that
L[Di] âŠ¨Di is a normal measure on Îºi
(i = 1, 2)
then L[D2] is an iterated ultrapower of L[D1]; i.e., there is Î± such that
L[D2] = Ult(Î±)
D1 (L[D1]), and D2 = i0,Î±(D1).
The proof of Theorem 19.14 uses iterated ultrapowers. The following
lemma uses the representation of iterated ultrapowers.
Lemma 19.15. Let U be a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Îº and let,
for each Î±, i0,Î± : V â†’Ult(Î±) be the embedding of V in its Î±th iterated
ultrapower.
(i) If Î± is a cardinal and Î± > 2Îº, then i0,Î±(Îº) = Î±.
(ii) If Î» is a strong limit cardinal, Î» > Î±, and if cf Î» > Îº, then i0,Î±(Î») = Î».
Proof. It follows from the Representation Lemma that for all Î¾, Î·, the ordinals
below i0,Î¾(Î·) are represented by functions with ï¬nite support from ÎºÎ¾ into Î·
and hence |i0,Î¾(Î·)| â‰¤|Î¾| Â· |Î·|Îº.
(i) We have i0,Î±(Îº) = limÎ¾â†’Î± i0,Î¾(Îº), and for each Î¾ < Î±, |i0,Î¾(Îº)| â‰¤
|Î¾| Â· 2Îº < Î±. Hence i0,Îº(Îº) = Î±.

bounded below Î»: There exists Î³ < Î» such that f(t) < Î³ for all t âˆˆÎºÎ±. Hence
i0,Î±(Î») = limÎ³â†’Î» i0,Î±(Î³). Since Î» is strong limit, we have |i0,Î±(Î³)| < Î» for all
Î³ < Î» and hence i0,Î» = Î».

It is clear from the proof that in (ii) it is enough to assume that Î³Îº < Î»
for all cardinals Î³ < Î», instead of that Î» is a strong limit cardinal.
Let U âŠ‚P(Îº). If Î¸ is a cardinal and U âˆˆLÎ¸[U], then by absoluteness of
relative constructibility, every elementary submodel of (LÎ¸[U], âˆˆ) that con-

Thus we have proved that the model V = L[D] (where D is a normal
measure on Îº) is unique, has only one measurable cardinal and only one
normal measure on Îº, and it satisï¬es the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis.
The next lemma completes the characterization of L[D] by showing that for
every Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter U on Îº, L[U] is equal to L[D].

Indiscernibles for L[D]
If there exist two measurable cardinals, Îº < Î», then it is possible to prove
analogous theorems for the model L[D] as we did in Chapter 18 for L under
the assumption of one measurable cardinal. More speciï¬cally, one can prove
the existence of a closed unbounded set I âŠ‚Îº and a closed unbounded class J
of ordinals bigger than Îº, such that I âˆªJ contains all uncountable cardinals
except Îº, that every X âˆˆL[D] is deï¬nable in D from I âˆªJ, and that the
elements of I âˆªJ are indiscernibles for L[D] in the following sense: The truth
value of
L[D] âŠ¨Ï•[Î±1, . . . , Î±n, Î²1, . . . , Î²m]
is independent of the choice of Î±1 < . . . < Î±n âˆˆI and Î²1 < . . . < Î²m âˆˆJ. In
analogy with Silver indiscernibles, the above situations can be described by
means of a certain set of formulas Ï•(x1, . . . , xn, y1, . . . , ym), which is called 0â€ 
(zero-dagger).
If 0â€  exists, then one can prove the consistency of the theory ZFC +
â€œthere exists a measurable cardinal;â€ and hence one cannot prove the relative
consistency of â€œ0â€  existsâ€ with ZFC + â€œthere exists a measurable cardinal.â€
We shall not give details of the theory of indiscernibles for L[D]. Instead,
let us present an argument showing that if there exist two measurable car-
dinals, Îº < Î», then there is a proper class of cardinals that are inaccessible
in L[D].
Let U be a normal measure on Î» and let for each Î±, i0,Î± be the elementary
embedding of V in Ult(Î±)
U ; let iÎ±,Î² : Ult(Î±) â†’Ult(Î²). Let C be the class of all
cardinals Î± such that cf Î± > Î» and Î³Î» < Î± for all Î³ < Î±. By Lemma 19.15, if
Î± âˆˆC, then i0,Î±(Îº) = Î± and i0,Î±(Î²) = Î² for all Î² âˆˆC greater than Î±. Hence
if Î±, Î² âˆˆC, then iÎ±,Î²(Î±) = Î² and iÎ±,Î²(Î³) = Î³ for all Î³ âˆˆC that are greater
than Î² or less than Î±.
Now if D is a normal measure on Îº, then because Îº < Î», we have iÎ±,Î²(D) =
D for all Î±, Î² âˆˆC. Thus each iÎ±,Î² (Î±, Î² âˆˆC), restricted to L[D], is an
elementary embedding of L[D] in L[D] such that iÎ±,Î²(Î±) = Î² and iÎ±,Î²(Î³) = Î³
for all Î³ âˆˆC below Î± or above Î². Using these embeddings iÎ±,Î² (as in the
proof of Lemma 18.26), one shows that the elements of C are indiscernibles
for the model L[D].
Since some elements of C are regular cardinals, and some are limit cardi-
nals, it follows that all elements of C are inaccessible cardinals in L[D].
In the above argument, it was not necessary that Îº be a measurable
cardinal, only that Îº be measurable in L[D]. Thus we have proved:
Lemma 19.23. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal, and assume that:
(19.16)
For some Î³ < Îº, there exists a D âŠ‚P(Î³) such that L[D] âŠ¨D is
a normal measure on Î³.
Then there are arbitrarily large successor cardinals that are inaccessible
in L[D].

General Iterations
We shall now describe two generalizations of iterated ultrapowers. The ï¬rst
deals with iteration of ultrapowers of transitive models by ultraï¬lters that
are not necessarily members of the model.
Let M be a transitive model of set theory. In fact, it is not necessary
for the theory of iterated ultrapowers to assume that M satisï¬es all axioms
of ZFC. It is enough to assume that M is a model of ZFCâˆ’, set theory without
the Power Set Axiom. Thus M can be a set (e.g., (LÎ±, âˆˆ) is a model of ZFCâˆ’
when Î± is a regular uncountable cardinal in L).
Let Îº be a cardinal in M, and let U be an M-ultraï¬lter on Îº (Deï¬ni-
tion 18.21).

(19.17)

whenever

are nonprincipal, Îº-complete, normal (as in Deï¬nition 18.21) and iterable.
Let U be a normal iterable M-ultraï¬lter on Îº. Using functions in M, we

The Mitchell Order
Deï¬nition 19.31. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal. If U1 and U2 are normal
measures on Îº, let
U1 < U2
if and only if
U1 âˆˆUltU2(V ).

358
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
The relation U1 < U2 is called the Mitchell order.
The Mitchell order is transitive, and by Lemma 17.9(ii) is irreï¬‚exive.
Moreover, it is well-founded:
Lemma 19.32. The Mitchell order is well-founded.
Proof. Toward a contradiction, let Îº be the least measurable cardinal on
which the Mitchell order is not well-founded, and let U0 > U1 > . . . > Un >
. . . be a descending sequence of normal measures on Îº. Let M = UltU0(V )
and let j : V â†’M be the canonical elementary embedding. As Îº < j(Îº),
and j(Îº) is the least measurable cardinal in M on which the Mitchell order
is not well-founded, we reach a contradiction once we show that U1 > U2 >
. . . > Un > . . . is a descending sequence in M.
The measures Un, n â‰¥1, are in M, and so is the sequence {Un}âˆ
n=1, so
we need to verify that Un+1 < Un still holds in M. Since Un+1 âˆˆUltUn(V ),
Un+1 is represented in the ultrapower by a function f = âŸ¨uÎ± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©. As
P M(Îº) = P(Îº) and M Îº âŠ‚M, the function f is in M, and represents Un+1
in the ultrapower UltM
Un(M). Hence M âŠ¨Un+1 < Un.
âŠ“âŠ”
Deï¬nition 19.33. If U is a normal measure on Îº, let o(U), the order of U,
denote the rank of U in <. Let o(Îº), the order of Îº, denote the height of <.
Lemma 19.34. Let o be the function âŸ¨o(Î±) : Î± < ÎºâŸ©. If U is a normal
measure on Îº then o(U) = [o]U.
Proof. Clearly, [o]U = oM(Îº) where M = UltU(V ). The set {U â€² : U â€² < U}
is the set of all normal measures in M, and since < is absolute for M (see
Lemma 19.32), the order of U in V is the order of Îº in M.
âŠ“âŠ”
Thus o(U) > 0 if and only if U-almost all Î± < Îº are measurable. If
Îº is a measurable cardinal of order â‰¥2 then Îº has a normal measure that
concentrates on measurable cardinals Î± < Îº. Thus the consistency strength
of o(Îº) â‰¥2 is more than measurability. Measurable cardinals of higher order
provide a hierarchy of large cardinal axioms. A consequence of Lemma 19.34
is that |o(U)| â‰¤2Îº and therefore o(Îº) â‰¤(2Îº)+. In particular, if GCH holds,
then o(Îº) â‰¤Îº++ for every measurable cardinal Îº.
There exist canonical inner models for measurable cardinals of higher
order, analogous to the model L[U]. We shall now outline the theory of these
inner models.
The key technical device is the technique of coiteration. It is the method
used in the proof of Lemma 19.35 below. Let U be a set of normal measures
(on possibly diï¬€erent cardinals). U is closed if for every measure U âˆˆU
on Îº, every normal measure on Îº in jU(U) is in U. If U is a closed set of
normal measures and U, W âˆˆU, let U <U W mean that U âˆˆjW (U). As
<U is a suborder of the Mitchell order it is well-founded and we deï¬ne oU(U)

19. Iterated Ultrapowers and L[U]
359
and oU(Îº) accordingly. The length of U, l(U), is the least Ï‘ such that Îº < Ï‘
for all Îº with oU(Îº) > 0.
Let M and N be inner models of ZFC, and let U âˆˆM and W âˆˆN be
closed sets of normal measures in M and N, respectively. We say that U is
an initial segment of W if
(i) l(U) â‰¤l(W),
(ii) for every Î± < l(U), oU(Î±) = oW(Î±),
(iii) for every Îº < l(U), if U âˆˆM and W âˆˆN are on Îº and
oU(U) = oW(W), then U âˆ©M âˆ©N = W âˆ©M âˆ©N.
(19.20)
Lemma 19.35. Let M and N be inner models of ZFC and let U and W be

(19.21)
If (i) occurs, let iÎ³,Î³+1 be the identity and jÎ³,Î³+1 : NÎ³ â†’NÎ³+1 = UltW (NÎ³)

agree.
We will show that the process eventually stops. Thus assume the contrary.
For every limit ordinal Î³, MÎ³ is a direct limit, and so there exists some
Î² = Î²(Î³) < Î³ such that Î±Î³ is in the range of iÎ²,Î³, Î±Î³ = iÎ²,Î³(Î±) for some

that jÎ²,Î³(Î±Î²) = Î±Î³ whenever Î² < Î³ are in Î“3. Continuing in this manner,

Let Î² âˆˆÎ“ and assume that (19.21)(i) occurs. Let Î³ âˆˆÎ“ be greater than Î².
Since iÎ²,Î²+1 is the identity, and crit(UÎ¾) = Î±Î¾ â‰¥Î±Î²+1 > Î±Î² for all Î¾ > Î²,
we have iÎ²,Î³(Î±Î²) = Î±Î², while jÎ²,Î³(Î±Î²) â‰¥jÎ²,Î²+1(Î±Î²) > Î±Î², contrary to
iÎ²,Î³(Î±Î²) = jÎ²,Î³(Î±Î²). Thus (i) does not occur, and similarly, (ii) leads to
a contradiction.
Case (iii) gives a contradiction as follows: Let Î³ > Î² be in Î“. Since XÎ² âˆˆ
UÎ², we have Î±Î² âˆˆiÎ²,Î³(XÎ²), and since XÎ² /âˆˆWÎ², we have Î±Î² /âˆˆjÎ²,Î³(XÎ²). This
contradicts iÎ²,Î³(XÎ²) = jÎ²,Î³(XÎ²), and therefore the process must eventually
stop.
âŠ“âŠ”
The Models L[U]

If ÎºÎ±, Î± < Î¸, is a sequence of measurable cardinals, and for each Î±, UÎ± is

More generally, let U be a set of normal measures indexed by pairs of

The technique described in the preceding section can be used to gener-

Theorem 19.38 (Mitchell). In L[U], Îº and Î± âˆˆA are the only measurable
cardinals, and UÎ±, U 0 and U 1 are the only normal measures.
Proof. For every ordinal Î³ â‰¤Îº, let Uâ†¾Î³ = âŸ¨UÎ± : Î± âˆˆAâˆ©Î³âŸ©; if Î³ > Îº, Uâ†¾Î³ = U.

If Î± /âˆˆA âˆª{Îº}, let M = L[D], N = UltD(L[D]) = L[jD(D)], and apply

but D /âˆˆN.
The same argument works if Î± âˆˆA and UÎ± < D, or if Î± = Îº and U 1 < D.
If Î± âˆˆA and o(D) = 0, let U = UÎ±; if Î± = Îº and o(D) = Îµ (Îµ = 0, 1), let

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Historical Notes
Most of the results in the ï¬rst part of Chapter 19 are due to Kunen, who
in [1970] developed the method of iterated ultraproducts invented by Gaifman
(cf. [1964] and [1974]). Kunen found the representation of iterated ultraproducts
(Lemma 19.13) and generalized the construction for M-ultraï¬lters. Kunen applied
the method to obtain the main results of the model L[D] (Theorem 19.14).
Theorem 19.3 (the proof of the GCH in L[D]) is due to Silver [1971d].
The description of Îº-complete ultraï¬lters on Îº in L[D] (Lemma 19.21) is due
to Kunen [1970] and Paris [1969]. Lemma 19.4 was ï¬rst proved by Solovay. The-
orem 19.7 is due to Gaifman; cf. [1974]. The proof of well-foundedness in Exer-
cise 19.10 is due to Kunen. Lemmas 19.20 and 19.24 are results of Kunen [1970].
0â€  was formulated by Solovay.
Kunen generalized the basic results on L[D] to the model LâŸ¨DÎ± : Î± < Î¸âŸ©
constructed from a sequence of measures (with Î¸ < the least measurable cardinal
in the sequence). Mitchell [1974] and [1983] generalized the theory of L[D] to inner
models for sequences of measures. The deï¬nition of o(Îº), Theorem 19.30 (well-
foundedness of iterated ultrapowers) as well as the results on L[U] are all due to
Mitchell.
The results in Exercises 19.9, 19.10 and 19.11 are due to Kunen [1970].
Exercise 19.7: Jech [1972/73].

20. Very Large Cardinals
This chapter studies properties of large cardinals that generalize measurabil-
ity. We are particularly interested in the method of elementary embeddings,
and introduce two concepts that have become crucial in the theory of large
cardinals: supercompact and Woodin cardinals.
Strongly Compact Cardinals
In Chapter 9 we proved that weakly compact cardinals are inaccessible car-
dinals satisfying the Weak Compactness Theorem for the inï¬nitary lan-
guage LÎº,Ï‰. If we remove the restriction on the size of sets of sentences in
the model theoretic characterization of weakly compact cardinals, we obtain
a considerably stronger notion. This notion, strong compactness, turns out to
be much stronger than measurability.
Strongly compact cardinals can be characterized in several diï¬€erent ways.
Let us use, as a deï¬nition, the property that is a natural generalization of
the Ultraï¬lter Theorem:
Deï¬nition 20.1. An uncountable regular cardinal Îº is strongly compact if
for any set S, every Îº-complete ï¬lter on S can be extended to a Îº-complete
ultraï¬lter on S.
Obviously, every strongly compact cardinal Îº is measurable, for any ul-
traï¬lter on Îº that extends the ï¬lter {X : |Îº âˆ’X| < Îº} is nonprincipal.
Let us say that the language LÎº,Ï‰ (or LÎº,Îº) satisï¬es the Compactness
Theorem if whenever Î£ is a set of sentences of LÎº,Ï‰ (LÎº,Îº) such that every
S âŠ‚Î£ with |S| < Îº has a model, then Î£ has a model.
Let A be a set of cardinality greater than or equal to Îº. For each x âˆˆ
PÎº(A), let Ë†x = {y âˆˆPÎº(A) : x âŠ‚y}, and let us consider the ï¬lter on PÎº(A)
generated by the sets Ë†x for all x âˆˆPÎº(A); that is, the ï¬lter
(20.1)
{X âŠ‚PÎº(A) : X âŠƒË†x for some x âˆˆPÎº(A)}.
If Îº is a regular cardinal, then the ï¬lter (20.1) is Îº-complete. We call U a ï¬ne
measure on PÎº(A) if U is a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter on PÎº(A) that extends the
ï¬lter (20.1); i.e., Ë†x âˆˆU for all x âˆˆPÎº(A).

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Lemma 20.2. The following are equivalent, for any regular cardinal Îº:
(i) For any set S, every Îº-complete ï¬lter on S can be extended to a Îº-
complete ultraï¬lter on S.
(ii) For any A such that |A| â‰¥Îº, there exists a ï¬ne measure on PÎº(A).
(iii) The language LÎº,Ï‰ satisï¬es the compactness theorem.

on PÎº(Î£), and let us consider the ultraproduct A = UltU{AS : S âˆˆPÎº(Î£)}.

connective 

sentence Ïƒ of LÎº,Ï‰,

if and only if
{S : AS âŠ¨Ïƒ} âˆˆU.

that Ïƒ holds in A. Hence A is a model of Î£.
(iii) â†’(i): Let S be a set and let F be a Îº-complete ï¬lter on S. Let us
consider the LÎº,Ï‰-language which has a unary predicate symbol Ë™X for each

such c exists.
Hence Î£ has a model A = (A, XA, c)XâŠ‚S. Let us deï¬ne U âŠ‚P(S) as

âŠ“âŠ”
Every strongly compact cardinal is measurable, but not every measurable
cardinal is strongly compact (although it is consistent that there is exactly one
measurable cardinal which is also strongly compact). We shall show that the
existence of strongly compact cardinals is a much stronger assumption than
the existence of measurable cardinals. We start with the following theorem:
Theorem 20.3 (VopË‡enka-HrbÂ´aË‡cek). If there exists a strongly compact
cardinal, then there is no set A such that V = L[A].

20. Very Large Cardinals
367
Proof. Let us assume that V = L[A] for some set A. Since there is a set of
ordinals Aâ€² such that L[A] = L[Aâ€²], we may assume that A is a set of ordinals.
Let Îº be a strongly compact cardinal, and let Î» â‰¥Îº be a cardinal such that
A âŠ‚Î». There exists a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter U on Î»+ such that |X| = Î»+ for
every X âˆˆU (let U extend the ï¬lter {X : |Î»+ âˆ’X| â‰¤Î»}).
Since U is Îº-complete, the ultrapower UltU(V ) is well-founded, and thus
can be identiï¬ed with a transitive model M. As usual, if f is a function
on Î»+, then [f] denotes the element of M represented by f. Let j = jU be
the elementary embedding of V into M given by U.
Let us now consider another version of ultrapower. Let us consider only
those functions on Î»+ that assume at most Î» values. For these functions, we
still deï¬ne f =âˆ—g (mod U) and f âˆˆâˆ—g (mod U) in the usual way, and there-
fore obtain a model of the language of set theory, which we denote Ultâˆ’
U(V ).
LoÂ´sâ€™s Theorem holds for this version of ultrapower too: If f, . . . are functions
on Î»+ with | ran(f)| â‰¤Î», then
(20.3)

Similarly, i(A) = j(A), and we have M = L[j(A)] = L[i(A)] = N.
Now we reach a contradiction by observing that j(Î»+) > i(Î»+): Since
the diagonal function d(Î±) = Î± represents in M an ordinal greater than
each j(Î³), Î³ < Î»+, we have j(Î»+) > limÎ³â†’Î»+ j(Î³). While N thinks that
i(Î»+) is the successor of i(Î»), M thinks that j(Î»+) is the successor of j(Î»)
(and j(Î») = i(Î»)). Thus M Ì¸= N, a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
The following theorem shows that the consistency strength of strong com-
pactness exceeds the strength of measurability:
Theorem 20.4 (Kunen). If there exists a strongly compact cardinal then
there exists an inner model with two measurable cardinals.

368
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Kunen proved a stronger version (and the proof can be so modiï¬ed): For
every ordinal Ï‘ there exists an inner model with Ï‘ measurable cardinals.
This was improved by Mitchell who showed that the existence of a strongly
compact cardinal leads to an inner model that has a measurable cardinal Îº
of Mitchell order Îº++.
We begin with a combinatorial lemma:
Lemma 20.5. Let Îº be an inaccessible cardinal. There exists a family G of
functions g : Îº â†’Îº such that |G| = 2Îº, and whenever H âŠ‚G is a subfamily
of size < Îº and {Î²g : g âˆˆH} is any collection of ordinals < Îº, then there
exists an Î± such that g(Î±) = Î²g for all g âˆˆH.
Proof. Let A be a family of almost disjoint subsets of Îº (i.e., |A| = Îº for each
A âˆˆA and |A âˆ©B| < Îº for any distinct A, B âˆˆA), such that |A| = 2Îº. For
each A âˆˆA, let fA be a mapping of A onto Îº such that for each Î² < Îº, the
set {a âˆˆA : fA(a) = Î²} has size Îº. Let sÎ±, Î± < Îº, enumerate all subsets
s âŠ‚Îº of size < Îº.
For each A âˆˆA, let gA : Îº â†’Îº be deï¬ned as follows: If sÎ± âˆ©A = {x},
then gA(Î±) = fA(x); gA(Î±) = 0 otherwise. Let G = {gA : A âˆˆA}.
If A Ì¸= B âˆˆA, then it is easy to ï¬nd sÎ± such that gA(Î±) Ì¸= 0 and
gB(Î±) = 0; hence |G| = 2Îº. If H âŠ‚A has size < Îº and if {Î²A : A âˆˆH} are
given, then for each A âˆˆH we choose xA âˆˆA such that xA /âˆˆB for any other
B âˆˆH and that fA(xA) = Î²A. Then if Î± is such that sÎ± = {xA : A âˆˆA}, we
have gA(Î±) = Î²A for every A âˆˆH.

Lemma 20.6. Let Îº be a strongly compact cardinal. For every Î´ < (2Îº)+
there exists a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter U on Îº such that jU(Îº) > Î´.

ultraï¬lter U extending F. It is clear that if Î± < Î² â‰¤Î´, then gÎ± < gÎ² mod U,

Combining Lemma 20.6 with Lemmas 19.23 and 19.24, we already have
a strong consequence of strong compactness.

The following theorem provides further evidence of the eï¬€ect of large
cardinals on cardinal arithmetic.
Theorem 20.8 (Solovay). If Îº is a strongly compact cardinal, then the
Singular Cardinal Hypothesis holds above Îº. That is, if Î» > Îº is a singu-
lar cardinal, then 2cf Î» < Î» implies Î»cf Î» = Î»+. (Consequently, if Î» > Îº is
a singular strong limit cardinal, then 2Î» = Î»+.)
We shall prove the theorem in a sequence of lemmas. An ultraï¬lter on Î»
is uniform if every set in the ultraï¬lter has size Î».
Lemma 20.9. If Îº is a strongly compact cardinal and Î» > Îº is a regular
cardinal, then there exists a Îº-complete uniform ultraï¬lter D on Î» with the
property that almost all (mod D) ordinals Î± < Î» have coï¬nality less than Îº.
Proof. Let U be a ï¬ne measure on PÎº(Î»). Since U is ï¬ne, every Î± < Î» belongs

âŠ“âŠ”
Supercompact Cardinals
We proved in Lemma 20.2 that a strongly compact cardinal Îº is characterized
by the property that every PÎº(A) has a ï¬ne measure. If we require the ï¬ne

374
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
measure to satisfy a normality condition, then we obtain a stronger notionâ€”
a supercompact cardinal. Ultrapowers by normal measures on PÎº(A) induce
elementary embeddings that can be used to derive strong consequences of su-
percompact cardinals. For instance, Theorems 20.3 and 20.4 become almost
trivial if the existence of a strongly compact cardinal is replaced by the exis-
tence of a supercompact cardinal. It is consistent to assume that a strongly
compact cardinal is not supercompact, or that every strongly compact car-
dinal is supercompact, but it is not known whether supercompact cardinals
are consistent relative to strongly compact cardinals.
Deï¬nition 20.12. A ï¬ne measure U on PÎº(A) is normal if whenever f :
PÎº(A) â†’A is such that f(x) âˆˆx for almost all x, then f is constant on a set
in U. A cardinal Îº is supercompact if for every A such that |A| â‰¥Îº, there
exists a normal measure on PÎº(A).
Let Î» â‰¥Îº be a cardinal and let us consider the ultrapower UltU(V ) by
a normal measure U on PÎº(Î»); let j = jU be the corresponding elementary
embedding. Clearly, a set X âŠ‚PÎº(Î») belongs to U if and only if [d] âˆˆj(X),
where d, the diagonal function, is the function d(x) = x.
Lemma 20.13. If U is a normal measure on PÎº(Î»), then [d] = {j(Î³) : Î³ <
Î»} = jâ€œÎ», and hence for every X âŠ‚PÎº(Î»),
(20.21)
X âˆˆU
if and only if
jâ€œÎ» âˆˆj(X).
Proof. On the one hand, if Î³ < Î», then Î³ âˆˆx for almost all x and hence
j(Î³) âˆˆ[d]. On the other hand, if [f] âˆˆ[d], then f(x) âˆˆx for almost all x and
by normality, there is Î³ < Î» such that [f] = j(Î³).
âŠ“âŠ”
It follows from (20.21) that if f and g are functions on PÎº(Î»), then
[f] = [g]
if and only if
(jf)(jâ€œÎ») = (jg)(jâ€œÎ»).
and
[f] âˆˆ[g]
if and only if
(jf)(jâ€œÎ») âˆˆ(jg)(jâ€œÎ»).

(20.22)

for every function f on PÎº(Î»).
For each x âˆˆPÎº(Î»), let us denote

Îºx = x âˆ©Îº,
and
Î»x = the order-type of x.

This gives the following characterization of supercompact cardinals:
Lemma 20.14. Let Î» â‰¥Îº. A normal measure on PÎº(Î») exists if and only if
there exists an elementary embedding j : V â†’M such that
(i) j(Î³) = Î³ for all Î³ < Îº;
(ii) j(Îº) > Î»;
(iii) M Î» âŠ‚M; i.e., every sequence âŸ¨aÎ± : Î± < Î»âŸ©of elements of M
is a member of M.
(20.24)
A cardinal Îº is called Î»-supercompact if it satisï¬es (20.24).
Proof. (a) Let U be a normal measure on PÎº(Î»). We let M = UltU(V ) and
let j be the canonical elementary embedding j : V â†’Ult. We have already

Î± < Î»âŸ©is such that aÎ± âˆˆM for all Î± < Î», then the set {aÎ± : Î± < Î»} belongs
to M. Let fÎ±, Î± < Î», be functions representing elements of M: [fÎ±] âˆˆM. We

we claim that [f] = {aÎ± : Î± < Î»}.
On the one hand, if Î± < Î», then Î± âˆˆx for almost all x and hence [fÎ±] âˆˆ[f].
On the other hand, if [g] âˆˆ[f], then for almost all x, g(x) = fÎ±(x) for some
Î± âˆˆx. By normality, there exists some Î³ < Î» such that g(x) = fÎ³(x) for
almost all x, and hence [g] = aÎ³.
(b) Let j : V â†’M be an elementary embedding that satisï¬es (i), (ii),
and (iii). By (iii), the set {j(Î³) : Î³ < Î»} belongs to M and so the following

(20.25)

if and only if
jâ€œÎ» âˆˆj(X).
A standard argument shows that U is a Îº-complete ultraï¬lter. U is a ï¬ne
measure because for every Î± âˆˆÎ», {x : Î± âˆˆx} is in U. Finally, U is normal: If
f(x) âˆˆx for almost all x, then (jf)(jâ€œÎ») âˆˆjâ€œÎ». Hence (jf)(jâ€œÎ») = j(Î³) for
some Î³ < Î», and so f(x) = Î³ for almost all x.

We have seen several examples how large cardinals restrict the behavior of
the continuum function (e.g., if Îº is measurable and 2Îº > Îº+, then 2Î± > Î±+
for coï¬nally many Î± < Îº). This is more so for supercompact cardinals:
Lemma 20.15. If Îº is Î»-supercompact and 2Î± = Î±+ for every Î± < Îº, then
2Î± = Î±+ for every Î± â‰¤Î».
Proof. Let j : V â†’M witness that Îº is Î»-supercompact. If Î± â‰¤Î», then
because Î» < j(Îº) and by elementarity, (2Î±)M = (Î±+)M. Now M Î» âŠ‚M
implies that P M(Î±) = P(Î±) and so 2Î± â‰¤(2Î±)M = (Î±+)M = Î±+.

Lemma 20.16. If Îº is supercompact, then there exists a normal measure D
on Îº such that almost every Î± < Îº (mod D) is measurable. In particular, Îº is
the Îºth measurable cardinal.
Proof. Let Î» = 2Îº and let j : V â†’M witness the Î»-supercompactness of Îº.

In contrast to Lemma 20.16, it is consistent that the least strongly com-
pact cardinal is the least measurable. The following lemma and corollary also
show that strongly compactness and supercompactness are not equivalent.
Lemma 20.17. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal such that there are Îº strongly
compact cardinals below Îº. Then Îº is strongly compact.
Proof. Let F be a nonprincipal Îº-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº such that C âˆˆF
where C = {Î± < Îº : Î± is strongly compact}. Let A be such that |A| â‰¥Îº; we

U âŠ‚PÎº(A) as follows:
X âˆˆU
if and only if
{Î± âˆˆC : X âˆ©PÎ±(A) âˆˆUÎ±} âˆˆF.
It is easy to verify that U is a ï¬ne measure on PÎº(A).
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 20.18. If there exists a measurable cardinal that is a limit of
strongly compact cardinals, then the least such cardinal is strongly compact
but not supercompact.
Proof. Let Îº be the least measurable limit of compact cardinals. By Lem-
ma 20.17, Îº is strongly compact. Let us assume that Îº is supercompact. Let
Î» = 2Îº and let j : V â†’M be an elementary embedding such that Îº is the
least ordinal moved, and that M Î» âŠ‚M. If Î± < Îº is strongly compact, then
M âŠ¨j(Î±) is strongly compact, but j(Î±) = Î± and therefore M âŠ¨Îº is a limit of
strongly compact cardinals. Since every U âŠ‚P(Îº) is in M, Îº is measurable
in M and hence in M, Îº is a measurable limit of strongly compact cardinals.
This is a contradiction because M thinks that j(Îº) is the least measurable
limit of strongly compact cardinals.

We conclude this section with the following theorem reminiscent of the
Diamond Principle.
Theorem 20.21 (Laver). Let Îº be a supercompact cardinal. There exists
a function f : Îº â†’VÎº such that for every set x and every Î» â‰¥Îº such that Î» â‰¥
| TC(x)| there exists a normal measure U on PÎº(Î») such that jU(f)(Îº) = x.
(Such an f is called a Laver function.)
Proof. Assume that the theorem is false. For each f : Îº â†’VÎº, let Î»f be the
least cardinal Î»f â‰¥Îº for which there exists an x with | TC(x)| â‰¤Î»x such
that jU(f)(Îº) Ì¸= x for every normal measure U on PÎº(Î»f). Let Î½ be greater
than all the Î»f and let j : V â†’M be a witness to the Î½-supercompactness
of Îº.

Î´ is the least cardinal Î´ â‰¥Î± for which there exists an x with | TC(x)| â‰¤Î´
such that there is no normal measure U on PÎ±(Î´) with (jUg)(Î±) = x. (Let Î»g
denote this Î´.) Since M Î½ âŠ‚M, we have M âŠ¨Ï•(f, Î»f), for all f : Îº â†’VÎº.
Let A be the set of all Î± < Îº such that Ï•(g, Î»g) holds for all g : Î± â†’VÎ±.
Clearly, Îº âˆˆj(A).

Beyond Supercompactness
Elementary embeddings can be used to deï¬ne large cardinals that are stronger
than supercompact.
Deï¬nition 20.22. A cardinal Îº is extendible if for every Î± > Îº there exist
an ordinal Î² and an elementary embedding j : VÎ± â†’VÎ² with critical point Îº.
Lemma 20.23. Let Î» â‰¥Îº be a regular cardinal and let Îº be Î»-supercompact.
Let Î± < Îº. If Î± is Î³-supercompact for all Î³ < Îº, then Î± is Î»-supercompact.
Proof. Let U be a normal measure on PÎº(Î»), and let us consider jU : V â†’
UltU. Since j(Î±) = Î±, we have Ult âŠ¨(Î± is Î³-supercompact for all Î³ < j(Îº)); in
particular, Ult âŠ¨Î± is Î»-supercompact. Hence there is D such that Ult âŠ¨D is
a normal measure on PÎ±(Î»). Now, |PÎ±(Î»)| = Î» and UltÎ» âŠ‚Ult, and hence
every subset of PÎ±(Î») is in Ult. It follows that D is a normal measure on PÎ±(Î»).
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 20.24.
(i) If Îº is extendible, then Îº is supercompact.
(ii) If Îº is extendible, then there is a normal measure D on Îº such that
{Î± < Îº : Î± is supercompact} âˆˆD.
Proof. (i) Let Î± > Îº be a limit cardinal with the property that if VÎ± âŠ¨(Îº is
Î»-supercompact for all Î»), then Îº is supercompact. (Such an Î± exists by the
Reï¬‚ection Principle.) Thus it suï¬ƒces to show that Îº is Î»-supercompact for
all regular Î» < Î±.
Let j : VÎ± â†’VÎ² be such that Îº is the critical point. Consider the sequence
Îº0 = Îº, Îº1 = j(Îº), . . . , Îºn+1 = j(Îºn), . . . , as long as j(Îºn) is deï¬ned. First
we note that by Exercise 17.8 either there is some n such that Îºn < Î± â‰¤j(Îºn)
or Î± = limnâ†’âˆÎºn. Therefore, it is suï¬ƒcient to prove, by induction on n, that
Îº is Î»-supercompact for each regular Î» < Îºn (if Î» < Î±).
Clearly, Îº is Î»-supercompact for each Î» < Îº1. Thus let n â‰¥1 and let
us assume that Îº is Î»-supercompact for all Î» < Îºn. Applying j, we get:
VÎ² âŠ¨(j(Îº) is Î»-supercompact for all regular Î» < Îºn+1). Now we also have

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
VÎ² âŠ¨(Îº is Î³-supercompact for all Î³ < j(Îº)) and we can apply Lemma 20.23
(in VÎ²) to conclude that VÎ² âŠ¨(Îº is Î»-supercompact for all regular Î» < Îºn+1).
This completes the induction step.
(ii) Let Î± be some limit ordinal greater than Îº and let j : VÎ± â†’VÎ² be

Let us consider now the following axiom schema called VopË‡enkaâ€™s Prin-
ciple (VP):
(20.29)
Let C be a proper class of models of the same language. Then
there exist two members A, B of the class C such that A can be
elementarily embedded in B.
Lemma 20.25. If VopË‡enkaâ€™s Principle holds, then there exists an extendible
cardinal.
Proof. Let A be the class of all limit ordinals Î± such that cf Î± = Ï‰ and that for

see that A is a proper class. Let C consist of the models (VÎ±+1, âˆˆ), for Î± âˆˆA.
By VopË‡enkaâ€™s Principle, there exist Î±, Î² âˆˆA and an elementary embed-
ding j : VÎ±+1 â†’VÎ²+1. Since j(Î±) = Î², j moves some ordinal; its critical
point is measurable and so it is not Î± (which has coï¬nality Ï‰). Let Îº be the
critical point.
Now VÎ± âŠ¨(Îº is extendible) because for every Î³ < Î±, jâ†¾VÎ³ reï¬‚ects to
a witness to extendibility. By deï¬nition of A, Îº is extendible.
âŠ“âŠ”
A similar argument shows that VopË‡enkaâ€™s Principle implies existence of
arbitrarily large extendible cardinals.
Deï¬nition 20.26. A cardinal Îº is huge if there exists an elementary em-

â€œHugeâ€ is expressible in ZF: see Exercise 20.11.
