While the least huge cardinal is greater than the least measurable cardinal
(see Exercise 20.13), it is smaller than the least supercompact cardinal (if

Finally, consider the following axiom:
(20.30)

huge (by Exercise 20.11), in fact n-huge for all n; see Exercise 20.15.
In view of Kunenâ€™s Theorem 17.7, axiom (20.30) (and its variants) is the
strongest possible large cardinal axiom.
Extenders and Strong Cardinals
In this section we show how elementary embeddings can be analyzed using
direct limits of ultrapowers. An elementary embedding can be approximated
by a system of measures called extenders. The theory of extenders plays
a crucial role in the inner model theory. While this theory is too weak to
describe supercompactness, it is strong enough to describe a weak version of
it that is considerably stronger than measurability.
Deï¬nition 20.28. A cardinal Îº is a strong cardinal if for every set x there
exists an elementary embedding j : V â†’M with critical point Îº such that
x âˆˆM.

382
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Clearly, every supercompact cardinal is strong. Strong cardinals have
more consistency strength than measurable cardinals, and allow some of the
techniques associated with supercompactness; see Exercises 20.16â€“20.19.
It follows from the theory of extenders below that â€œstrongnessâ€ is express-
ible in ZF. As with supercompactness, one can also deï¬ne local versions of
strongness: Îº is Î»-strong, where Î» â‰¥Îº, if there exists some j : V â†’M with
critical point Îº such that j(Îº) > Î» and VÎ» âŠ‚M. A cardinal Îº is strong if and
only if it is Î»-strong for all Î» â‰¥Îº.
Let j : V â†’M be an elementary embedding with critical point Îº and let
Îº â‰¤Î» â‰¤j(Îº). We shall deï¬ne the (Îº, Î»)-extender derived from j.
For every ï¬nite subset a âŠ‚Î», let Ea be the measure on [Îº]<Ï‰ deï¬ned as
follows:
(20.31)
X âˆˆEa
if and only if
a âˆˆj(X);
note that Ea concentrates on [Îº]|a|. The (Îº, Î»)-extender derived from j is the
collection
(20.32)
E = {Ea : a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰};
Îº is the critical point of E and Î» is the length of the extender.
Let a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰. The measure Ea on [Îº]<Ï‰ is Îº-complete; let UltEa denote
the ultrapower of V by Ea and let ja : V â†’UltEa be the corresponding ele-
mentary embedding. If for each equivalence class [f] of a function f on [Îº]<Ï‰
we let
(20.33)
ka([f]) = j(f)(a),
then ka is an elementary embedding ka : UltEa â†’M and ka â—¦ja = j.
The measures Ea, a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰, are coherent, in the following sense: Let
a âŠ‚b, where b = {Î±1, . . . , Î±n} with Î±1 < . . . < Î±n. Then Ï€b,a : [Î»]|b| â†’[Î»]|a|
is deï¬ned by
(20.34)

(Î¾1 < . . . < Î¾n)
where a = {Î±i1, . . . , Î±im}, and
(20.35)

if and only if

ia,b([f]Ea) = [f â—¦Ï€b,a]Eb
is an elementary embedding, and
(20.36)
{UltEa, ia,b : a âŠ‚b âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰}
is a directed system. The direct limit UltE of (20.36) is well-founded: Note
that the embeddings ka have a direct limit k : UltE â†’M such that kâ—¦jE = j
where jE is the elementary embedding jE : V â†’UltE.

There is another description of the direct limit UltE: The elements of UltE
are equivalence classes [a, f]E where a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰ and f : [Îº]|a| â†’V . Here

k([a, f]) = j(f)(a).
Now k â—¦jE = j follows.
Lemma 20.29.
(i) k(Î±) = Î± for all Î± < Î».
(ii) jE has critical point Îº and jE(Îº) â‰¥Î».
(iii) UltE = {jE(f)(a) : a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰, f : [Îº]<Ï‰ â†’V }.
Proof. For each a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰, let ja,âˆ: UltEa â†’UltE be the direct limit

x = ja,âˆ([f]) for some [f] âˆˆUltEa, and
k(x) = k(ja,âˆ([f])) = ka([f]) = j(f)(a)
(see also (20.37)). Hence
(20.38)
kâ€œ UltE = {j(f)(a) : a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰, f âˆˆ[Îº]<Ï‰ â†’V }.
(i) By letting f be the identity function, we get from (20.38) that a âˆˆ
kâ€œ UltE, for each a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰. Hence Î» âŠ‚kâ€œ UltE, and therefore k(Î±) = Î± for
all Î± < Î».
(ii) This follows from (i), because j = k â—¦jE.

and f, and hence x = jE(f)(a).
âŠ“âŠ”
Hence jE is an elementary embedding, jE : V â†’UltE, with critical
point Îº. Since j = k â—¦jE and since k(a) = a for all a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰, it follows that
for all X âˆˆ[Îº]|a|, a âˆˆjE(X) if and only if a âˆˆj(X). Hence E is the extender
derived from jE.
Extenders can be deï¬ned directly, without reference to an embedding j.
The following, somewhat technical, properties guarantee that the (Îº, Î»)-
extender is derived from the direct limit embedding jE: Let Îº â‰¤Î», and

384
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
let E = {Ea : a âˆˆ[Î»]<Ï‰}. E is a (Îº, Î»)-extender if
(i) Each Ea is a Îº-complete measure on [Îº]|a|, and
(a) at least one Ea is not Îº+-complete,
(b) for each Î± âˆˆÎº, at least one Ea contains the set {s âˆˆ[Îº]|a| :
Î± âˆˆs}.
(ii) (Coherence) The Eaâ€™s are coherent, i.e., satisfy (20.35).
(iii) (Normality) If {s âˆˆ[Îº]|a| : f(s) âˆˆmax s} âˆˆEa, then for some
b âŠƒa, {t âˆˆ[Îº]|b| : (f â—¦Ï€b,a)(t) âˆˆt} âˆˆEb.
(iv) The limit ultrapower UltE is well-founded.
(20.39)
We leave out the veriï¬cation that the extender derived from some j satis-
ï¬es (20.39), and that the properties (20.39) suï¬ƒce to prove (ii) and (iii) of
Lemma 20.29, and that E is derived from jE.
An immediate consequence of the above technique is the following char-
acterization of strong cardinals:
Lemma 20.30. A cardinal Îº is strong if and only if for every Î» â‰¥Îº there
is a (Îº, |VÎ»|+)-extender E such that VÎ» âŠ‚UltE and Î» < jE(Îº).
âŠ“âŠ”
Hence â€œstrongnessâ€ is expressible in ZFC.
We conclude by introducing a large cardinal property that was isolated
by Woodin and that has played a central role in the study of determinacy
and inner models:
Deï¬nition 20.31. A cardinal Î´ is a Woodin cardinal if for all A âŠ‚VÎ´ there
are arbitrarily large Îº < Î´ such that for all Î» < Î´ there exists an elementary
embedding j : V â†’M with critical point Îº, such that j(Îº) > Î», VÎ» âŠ‚M,
and A âˆ©VÎ» = j(A) âˆ©VÎ».
Being a Woodin cardinal is expressible in ZFC, in terms of extenders. Ev-
ery supercompact cardinal is Woodin, and below a Woodin cardinal Î´, there
are Î´ cardinals that are Î»-strong for every Î» < Î´. While Woodin cardinals are
inaccessible (and Mahlo), the least Woodin cardinal is not weakly compact,
as Î´ being Woodin is a Î 1
1 property of (VÎ´, âˆˆ).

Historical Notes
Strongly compact cardinals were introduced by Keisler and Tarski in [1963/64];
supercompact cardinals were deï¬ned by Reinhardt and Solovay. Theorem 20.3 is
due to VopË‡enka and HrbÂ´aË‡cek [1966]; Theorem 20.4 is due to Kunen [1971b].

20. Very Large Cardinals
387
Solovay discovered that the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis holds above a compact
cardinal (Theorem 20.8); see [1974].
Menas and Magidor obtained several results on the relative strength of compact
and supercompact cardinals. Menas in [1974/75] showed that it is consistent (rela-
tive to existence of compact cardinals) that there is a compact cardinal that is not
supercompact. Magidor in [1976] improved Menasâ€™ result by showing that it is pos-
sible that the least measurable cardinal is strongly compact (while by Lemma 20.16
it is not supercompact) and also showed that it is consistent (relative to supercom-
pact cardinals) that there exists just one compact cardinal and is supercompact.
Kunenâ€™s proof of Theorem 20.4 uses a lemma of Ketonen (Lemma 20.5); Lemmas
20.9 and 20.10 which Solovay used in his proof of Theorem 20.8, are also due to
Ketonen; see [1972/73].
Most results on supercompact cardinals (e.g., Lemmas 20.16 and 20.19) are due
to Solovay; see Solovay, Reinhardt, and Kanamori [1978]; Magidorâ€™s paper [1971a]
gives a number of normal measures on PÎº(Î») (Corollary 20.20(ii)). The example of
a strongly compact nonsupercompact cardinal (Lemma 20.17 and Corollary 20.18)
is due to Menas [1974/75]. Theorem 20.21 is due to Laver [1978].
Extendible cardinals were introduced by Reinhardt; he proved that extendible
cardinals are supercompact; see [1974]. The present proof of Theorem 20.24, as well
as Lemmas 20.23 and 20.25 are due to Magidor [1971b].
Lemma 20.27: Powell [1972].
A good source for further results on very large cardinals is the paper [1978] of
Kanamori and Magidor, as well as Kanamoriâ€™s book [1994].
Strong cardinals were used by Mitchell [1979a] to develop a theory of inner mod-
els for weak versions of supercompactness, and further studied by Baldwin [1986].
Extenders were introduced by Jensen and Dodd; see Dodd [1982].
Woodin cardinals were introduced by Woodin in 1984. They were used, among
others, in the proof of projective determinacy by Martin and Steel [1989].
Exercises 20.7, 20.10, 20.11, 20.14, and 20.15: Solovay, Reinhardt and Kanamori
[1978].
Exercise 20.9: Solovay.
Exercise 20.12: Morgenstern [1977].
Exercise 20.19: Gitik and Shelah [1989].

21. Large Cardinals and Forcing
Many forcing techniques have been developed speciï¬cally for use with large
cardinals. Firstly, when investigating the eï¬€ect of large cardinals on cardinal
arithmetic, it is desirable to establish the relative consistency of statements
about the continuum function with the existence of various large cardinals.
The main technical question here is whether large cardinal properties are pre-
served under various forcing extensions. Secondly, it follows from the Cover-
ing Theorem that an attempt to violate the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis, or
even to change coï¬nalities, necessarily involves large cardinals. Indeed, forc-
ing techniques have been developed for changing coï¬nalities and for violating
SCH that use large cardinals. And thirdly, as the large cardinal hierarchy
serves as a gauge of consistency strength, forcing that uses large cardinals
provides an upper bound for the consistency strength of the problems that
the forcing proves consistent.
Mild Extensions
We begin with an early discovery that â€œmildâ€ forcing extensions do not eï¬€ect
large cardinal properties, i.e., whether Îº is a large cardinal is not changed by
forcing of size less than Îº.
Theorem 21.1 (LÂ´evy-Solovay). Let Îº be a measurable cardinal in the
ground model. Let (P, <) be a notion of forcing such that |P| < Îº. Then
Îº is measurable in the generic extension.
Proof. We give a proof using elementary embeddings since similar arguments
will be used in subsequent constructions; for a direct proof, see Exercise 21.1.
Let B = B(P); since |B| < Îº, we may assume B âˆˆVÎº. We can also assume
that P is a dense subset of B. Let G be a generic ultraï¬lter on B; let us work
in V [G].
Since Îº is measurable in V , there is an elementary embedding j : V â†’M
with critical point Îº, and M transitive. We shall extend j to an elemen-
tary embedding (denoted also j) of V [G] into M[G], thus showing that Îº is
measurable in V [G].
Since B âˆˆVÎº, we have j(B) = B, and B is a complete Boolean algebra
in M. Since G is generic over V , G is also generic over M. Note that the

390
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
interpretation of Boolean names in M B by G is the same whether computed
in V or in M. We deï¬ne j(x) for x âˆˆV [G] as follows: Let Ë™x âˆˆV B be a name
for x, x = Ë™xG. Let
(21.1)
j(x) = (j( Ë™x))G.
Since Ë™x âˆˆV B, we have j( Ë™x) âˆˆM B and so (j( Ë™x))G âˆˆM[G]. However, we have
to show that the deï¬nition (21.1) does not depend on which name for x we
choose.
Let Ë™y be another B-valued name and let p âˆˆG be such that
(21.2)
p âŠ©Ë™x = Ë™y.
When we apply j to (21.2), we have (in M)
j(p) âŠ©j( Ë™x) = j( Ë™y).
But j(p) = p âˆˆG and therefore
(j( Ë™x))G = (j( Ë™y))G.
Finally we show that j : V [G] â†’M[G] is elementary. Let Ï• be a formula
such that
V [G] âŠ¨Ï•(x, . . .).
Let Ë™x, . . . be such that ( Ë™x)G = x, . . . . There is some p âˆˆG such that
(21.3)
p âŠ©Ï•( Ë™x, . . .).
Applying j to (21.3), we get (in M)
p âŠ¨Ï•(j( Ë™x), . . .)
(because j(p) = p). Hence
M[G] âŠ¨Ï•(j( Ë™x), . . .)
and since Ï• was arbitrary, j is elementary.
âŠ“âŠ”
It turns out that practically every large cardinal property is unchanged
by mild extension:
Theorem 21.2. Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal, and let (P, <) be a notion
of forcing such that |P| < Îº. Let G be a V -generic ï¬lter on P. Then Îº is
inaccessible (Mahlo, weakly compact, Ramsey, measurable, strongly compact,
supercompact, huge, strong, Woodin) in V if and only if it is inaccessible
(Mahlo, weakly compact, Ramsey, measurable, strongly compact, supercom-
pact, huge, strong, Woodin) in V [G].

21. Large Cardinals and Forcing
391
Proof. If Îº is inaccessible in V , then ï¬rstly Îº is regular in V [G] because all
cardinals and coï¬nalities above |P| are preserved. Secondly, if Î± < Îº, then
(2Î±)V [G] â‰¤|B(P)|Î± < Îº and hence Îº is inaccessible in V [G]. Conversely, if
Îº is inaccessible in V [G], then Îº is inaccessible in V .
If Îº is Mahlo in V , then ï¬rstly Îº is inaccessible in V [G]. Secondly, every
Î± > |P| is a regular cardinal in V [G] if and only if it is a regular cardinal in V
and so the set S = {Î± < Îº : |P| < Î± and Î± is regular in V [G]} is stationary
in V . It is easy to see that every closed unbounded set C âŠ‚Îº in V [G] has
a closed unbounded subset D in V (Exercise 21.2). Thus, S is also stationary
in V [G] and hence Îº is Mahlo in V [G]. Conversely, if Îº is Mahlo in V [G],
then Îº is Mahlo in V because V âŠ‚V [G].
If Îº is weakly compact in V , let F : [Îº]2 â†’{0, 1} be a partition of [Îº]2
in V [G]. Let Ë™F âˆˆV B be its name such that âˆ¥Ë™F : [Îº]2 â†’{0, 1}âˆ¥= 1. For all
Î± Ì¸= Î² âˆˆÎº, let G(Î±, Î²) = âˆ¥Ë™F(Î±, Î²) = 0âˆ¥; G is (in V ) a partition of [Îº]2 into
|B(P)| pieces. Since |B(P)| < Îº, there is an H âŠ‚Îº of size Îº homogeneous
for G, and it is easy to see that H is homogeneous for F.
Conversely, if Îº is weakly compact in V [G], let F : [Îº]2 â†’{0, 1} be
a partition of [Îº]2 in V . There is, in V [G], a set K âŠ‚Îº of size Îº, homogeneous
for F. As in Exercise 21.2, K has an unbounded subset H âˆˆV ; hence F has
in V a homogeneous set of size Îº.
The argument for Ramsey cardinals is exactly the same as for weakly
compact cardinals.
If Îº is measurable in V , then it is measurable in V [G] by Theorem 21.1.
Conversely, if Îº is measurable in V [G], let U âˆˆV [G] be a Îº-complete non-
principal ultraï¬lter on Îº, let J be the dual prime ideal, and let Ë™J âˆˆV B be
its name. (Without loss of generality we assume that âˆ¥Ë™J is a Îº-complete non-
principal prime idealâˆ¥= 1.) Let I = {X âŠ‚Îº : âˆ¥X âˆˆË™Jâˆ¥= 1}. It is easy to
verify that I is a Îº-complete ideal containing all singletons. We claim that I is
|P|+-saturated: If p âŠ©Ë‡X /âˆˆË™J and p âŠ©Ë‡Y /âˆˆË™J, then p âŠ©Ë‡X âˆ©Ë‡Y /âˆˆË™J (because
Ë™J is prime). Hence if X and Y are such that X /âˆˆI, Y /âˆˆI, and X âˆ©Y âˆˆI,
then âˆ¥Ë‡X /âˆˆË™Jâˆ¥Â·âˆ¥Ë‡Y /âˆˆË™Jâˆ¥= 0, and it follows that I is |P|+-saturated. However,
since I is Î½-saturated for some Î½ < Îº and Îº is inaccessible, Îº is measurable,
by Exercise 21.3.
If Îº is strongly compact, let Î» â‰¥Îº and let us show that in V [G], there
is a ï¬ne measure on PÎº(Î»). Let U be a ï¬ne measure on PÎº(Î») in V , and
let j = jU be the canonical elementary embedding jU : V â†’UltU(V ). The
standard argument shows that X âˆˆU if and only if H âˆˆj(X), where H is
the set in UltU(V ) represented by the function d(Z) = Z on PÎº(Î±); also,
H âŠƒjâ€œÎ» (and is equal to it if U is normal). Similarly, as in the proof of
Theorem 21.1 we extend j to V [G] as follows:
j(x) = (j( Ë™x))G
where Ë™x is a name for x; the deï¬nition is legitimate because we assume,
without loss of generality, that P âˆˆVÎº and hence j(p) = p for all p âˆˆP, and

392
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
j(P) = P. Now we deï¬ne, in V [G], an ultraï¬lter W on PÎº(Î») as follows:
X âˆˆW
if and only if
H âˆˆj(X).

The proofs for the remaining large cardinal properties are similar.

There are numerous examples when Îº ceases to be large when we use a no-

any notion of forcing that is Î±-distributive for all Î± < Îº.
Kunen-Paris Forcing
It is an immediate consequence of the LÂ´evy-Solovay Theorem that if Îº is
a measurable cardinal, Î» < Îº, and F is a function on regular cardinals below Î»
such that (i) F(Î±) â‰¤F(Î²) if Î± â‰¤Î², (ii) cf(F(Î±)) > Î±, and (iii) F(Î±) < Îº
for all Î± in its domain, then there is a model in which Îº is measurable and
2Î± = F(Î±) for all Î± âˆˆdom(F).
One can also prescribe the values of the continuum function on regular
cardinals greater than the measurable cardinal; this can be done by a Îº-closed
forcing; see Exercise 21.5.
The proof of the next theorem uses a method that preserves measurability
of Îº while adding subsets to an unbounded set of cardinals below Îº. It is vital
however that the set A âŠ‚Îº has a normal measure 0.

Silverâ€™s Forcing
We shall now construct a model that has a measurable cardinal Îº for which
2Îº > Îº+. By Corollary 19.25, the consistency strength of this is more than
measurability. It has been established that the failure of GCH at a measurable

21. Large Cardinals and Forcing
395
cardinal is equiconsistent with the existence of a measurable cardinal Îº of
Mitchellâ€™s order Îº++. The lower bound is obtained by Mitchellâ€™s method of
iterated ultrapowers from Chapter 19, while the upper bound follows from
improvements (due to Woodin and Gitik) on Silverâ€™s forcing construction
presented below.
Theorem 21.4 (Silver). If there exists a supercompact cardinal Îº, then
there is a generic extension in which Îº is a measurable cardinal and 2Îº > Îº+.
Silverâ€™s construction uses iterated forcing. As 2Îº > Îº+ for a measurable
cardinal implies that 2Î± > Î±+ for many Î± below Îº, the iteration adjoins not
only subsets of Îº, but, iteratively, subsets of regular cardinals below Îº. The
iteration combines direct and inverse limits, in a manner similar to Eastonâ€™s
forcing.
Deï¬nition 21.5. Let Î± â‰¥1, and let PÎ± be an iterated forcing of length Î±
(see Deï¬nition 16.29). PÎ± is an iteration with Easton support if for every
p âˆˆPÎ± and every regular cardinal Î³ â‰¤Î±, |s(p) âˆ©Î³| < Î³. Equivalently, for
every limit ordinal Î³ â‰¤Î±, PÎ³ is a direct limit if Î³ is regular, and an inverse
limit otherwise.
When using iterated forcing that combines direct and inverse limits, we
can apply Theorem 16.30 to calculate the chain condition, and Exercise 16.19
to calculate the degree of closedness. We shall need the following variant:
Deï¬nition 21.6. A notion of forcing (P, <) is Î»-directed closed if whenever
D âŠ‚P is such that |D| â‰¤Î» and for any d1, d2 âˆˆD there is some e âˆˆD with
e â‰¤d1 and e â‰¤d2, then there exists a p âˆˆP such that p â‰¤d for all d âˆˆD.

Prikry Forcing
Let us address the following problem: Can one construct a generic extension
in which all cardinals are preserved but the coï¬nality of some cardinals is
diï¬€erent from their coï¬nality in the ground model? Obviously, in order to
do this we have to change some (weakly) inaccessible cardinal into a singular

21. Large Cardinals and Forcing
401
cardinal. Corollary 18.31 of Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem tells us that for this,
it is necessary to assume at least 0â™¯in the ground model. Thus we formulate
the problem as follows: Let Îº be some large cardinal and let Î» < Îº be a regular
cardinal. Find a cardinal preserving generic extension, in which cf Îº = Î».
The forcing presented below was devised by Karel Prikry and has become
a standard tool of the large cardinal theory.
Theorem 21.10 (Prikry). Let Îº be a measurable cardinal. There is a generic
extension in which cf Îº = Ï‰ and no cardinals are collapsed. Moreover, every
bounded subset of Îº in V [G] is in the ground model.
Proof. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal and let D be a normal measure on Îº.
Let (P, <) be the following notion of forcing. A forcing condition is a pair
p = (s, A) where s âˆˆ[Îº]<Ï‰, i.e., s is a ï¬nite subset of Îº, and A âˆˆD.
A condition (s, A) is stronger than a condition (t, B) if:
(i) t is an initial segment of s, i.e., t = s âˆ©Î± for some Î±;
(ii) A âŠ‚B;
(iii) s âˆ’t âŠ‚B.
(21.15)
We immediately note that any two conditions (s, A), (s, B) with the same
ï¬rst coordinate are compatible, and hence any antichain W âŠ‚P has size at
most Îº. We also note that if (s, A) and (t, B) are compatible, then either s is
an initial segment of t, or t is an initial segment of s.
Let G be a generic ï¬lter on P. We shall show that in V [G], Îº has coï¬-
nality Ï‰, that every bounded subset of Îº is in V , and that all cardinals and
coï¬nalities above Îº are preserved.
The last statement is immediate since P satisï¬es the Îº+-chain condition.
It is also easy to show that cf Îº = Ï‰ in V [G]: If (s, A) and (t, B) are in G, then
either s is an initial segment of t or vice versa; hence S = {s : (s, A) âˆˆG
for some A} is a subset of Îº of order type Ï‰. By the genericity of G, S is
clearly an unbounded subset of Îº, and hence cf Îº = Ï‰.
It remains to show that if X âˆˆV [G] is such that X âŠ‚Î» for some Î» < Îº,
then X âˆˆV . For this, we need the property of P stated in Lemma 21.12 be-
low. The proof uses Theorem 10.22 which states that every partition of [Îº]<Ï‰
into less than Îº pieces has a homogeneous set H âˆˆD.
Lemma 21.11. Let Ïƒ be a sentence of the forcing language. There exists
a set A âˆˆD such that the condition (âˆ…, A) decides Ïƒ, i.e., either (âˆ…, A) âŠ©Ïƒ,
or (âˆ…, A) âŠ©Â¬Ïƒ.
Proof. Let S+ be the set of all s âˆˆ[Îº]<Ï‰ such that (s, X) âŠ©Ïƒ for some X and

there is a set A âˆˆD such that for every n, either [A]n âŠ‚S+ or [A]n âŠ‚Sâˆ’or
[A]n âŠ‚T . We shall prove that (âˆ…, A) decides Ïƒ.
If not, then there are conditions (s, X) and (t, Y ), both stronger than (âˆ…, A)
such that one forces Ïƒ and the other forces Â¬Ïƒ. We may assume that |s| = |t|,

say |s| = |t| = n. Since (s, X) â‰¤(âˆ…, A), we have s âˆˆ[A]n; and similarly,
t âˆˆ[A]n. But s âˆˆS+ and t âˆˆSâˆ’, which is a contradiction since S+
and Sâˆ’are disjoint and therefore cannot both have a nonempty intersec-

Lemma 21.12. Let Ïƒ be a sentence of the forcing language and let (s0, A0)

S+ and Sâˆ’. It follows that (s0, A) decides Ïƒ.
âŠ“âŠ”
Now let Î» < Îº and let X âŠ‚Î»; we will show that X âˆˆV . Let Ë™X be a name

Ë™X. Let

This completeness the proof of Theorem 21.10.

An immediate consequence of Theorems 21.4 and 21.10 is the indepen-
dence of SCH:
Corollary 21.13. It is consistent (relative to the existence of a supercom-
pact cardinal) that there is a strong limit singular cardinal Îº such that
2Îº > Îº+.
Proof. Let Îº be a supercompact cardinal. First we construct a generic ex-
tension in which Îº is measurable and 2Îº > Îº+. Then we extend the model
further to make Îº a singular cardinal. The new model still satisï¬es 2Îº > Îº+,
and Îº is a strong limit cardinal.

Measurability of â„µ1 in ZF
In ZF (without the Axiom of Choice), one can still deï¬ne measurability in
the usual way: An uncountable cardinal Îº is measurable if there exists a Îº-
complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Îº. In the absence of the Axiom of Choice,
a measurable cardinal is still regular, but not necessarily a limit cardinal. The
absence of AC has no eï¬€ect on the consistency strength: If U is a nonprin-
cipal Îº-complete ultraï¬lter on Îº > Ï‰, then in L[U] (a model of ZFC), Îº is
a measurable cardinal. The following theorem shows that in ZF, â„µ1 can be
measurable:
Theorem 21.16. Let M be a transitive model of ZFC+â€œthere is a measur-
able cardinal.â€ There is a symmetric model N âŠƒM of ZF such that N âŠ¨â„µ1 is
measurable.
We shall construct a symmetric extension of M. Recall the theory of
symmetric models from Chapter 15. We consider a complete Boolean al-
gebra B, a group G of automorphisms of B, and a normal ï¬lter F on G
(see (15.34)). For every Ë™x âˆˆM B we let sym( Ë™x) be the symmetry group of Ë™x,
sym( Ë™x) = {Ï€ âˆˆG : Ï€( Ë™x) = Ë™x}, and call Ë™x symmetric if sym( Ë™x) âˆˆF. We denote
HS the class of all hereditarily symmetric names. If G is an M-generic ultra-
ï¬lter on B, we let N be the G-interpretation of the class HS; N is a model
of ZF and N âŠƒM.
Let us call a subset A âŠ‚B symmetric if
{Ï€ âˆˆG : Ï€(a) = a for all a âˆˆA} âˆˆF.

405
Lemma 21.17. Let Îº be measurable in M, and let N be a symmetric exten-
sion of M (via B, G, F, G). If every symmetric subset of B has size < Îº,
then Îº is measurable in N.
Proof. Let U be, in M, a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Îº. We show
that U generates a Îº-complete nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on Îº in N. It suï¬ƒces
to show that if Î³ < Îº and {XÎ± : Î± < Î³} is a partition of Îº in N, then for
some Î± < Î³, XÎ± includes some Y âˆˆU.
We give the proof for Î³ = 2 since the general case is analogous. Let
X âˆˆN be a subset of Îº, and let Ë™X âˆˆHS be a symmetric name for X. Let
A = {âˆ¥Î± âˆˆË™Xâˆ¥: Î± < Îº}. If Ï€ âˆˆG is such that Ï€( Ë™X) =
Ë™X, then (because
Ï€(Ë‡Î±) = Ë‡Î± for all Î±) Ï€(a) = a for all a âˆˆA; thus A is a symmetric subset of B.
Hence |A| < Îº. For each a âˆˆA, let Ya = {Î± : âˆ¥Î± âˆˆË™Xâˆ¥= a}. Clearly,
{Ya : a âˆˆA} is a partition of Îº into fewer than Îº pieces, and hence one
Y = YÎ± is in U. Now if a âˆˆG, then we have Y âŠ‚X, and if a /âˆˆG, then
Y âŠ‚Îº âˆ’X. Hence either X or Îº âˆ’X has a subset that is in U.
âŠ“âŠ”
Proof of Theorem 21.16. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal in M. Let P be the
set of all one-to-one ï¬nite sequences p = âŸ¨Î±0, Î±1, . . . , Î±nâˆ’1âŸ©of ordinals less
than Îº; p is stronger than q if p extends q (P collapses Îº; cf. Example 15.20).

Ï€(âŸ¨Î±0, . . . , Î±nâˆ’1âŸ©) = âŸ¨Ï€(Î±0), . . . , Ï€(Î±nâˆ’1)âŸ©
and, in turn, an automorphism of B = B(P). Thus we identify G with the
group of automorphisms so induced.
For each Î³ < Îº, let

and let F be the normal ï¬lter on G generated by {HÎ³ : Î³ < Îº}. Thus Ë™x âˆˆM B
is symmetric if and only if there is some Î³ < Îº such that Ï€( Ë™x) = Ë™x whenever
Ï€(Î±) = Î± for all Î± < Î³.
Let G be an M-generic ï¬lter on B and let N be the symmetric model
given by B, G, F, G. We shall show that Îº = (â„µ1)N and that Îº is measurable
in N.
If Î³ < Îº, then Î³ is countable in N: Let Ë™f be the name such that
âˆ¥Ë™f(n) = Î±âˆ¥= {p âˆˆP : p(n) = Î±}
for all n < Ï‰ and Î± < Î³. Clearly, Ë™f is symmetric because Ï€( Ë™f) = Ë™f for every
Ï€ âˆˆHÎ³, and hence Ë™f âˆˆHS. The interpretation of Ë™f is a one-to-one function
of a subset of Ï‰ onto Î³.

There exists a Î³ < Îº such that Ï€(a) = a for all a âˆˆA and all Ï€ âˆˆHÎ³.

22. Saturated Ideals
One of the key concepts in the theory of large cardinals is saturation of ideals.
In this chapter we investigate Ïƒ-saturated, Îº-saturated and Îº+-saturated Îº-
complete ideals on Îº.
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal. Let I be a Îº-complete ideal on Îº
containing all singletons; thus X âˆˆI whenever X âŠ‚Îº is such that |X| < Îº.
We shall be using the following terminology: X has measure zero if X âˆˆI,
measure one if Îº âˆ’X âˆˆI, and positive measure if X /âˆˆI; the phrase almost
all Î± means that the set of all contrary Î±â€™s has measure 0.
Let us consider the Boolean algebra B = P(Îº)/I. Recall that if Î» is
a cardinal, then B is called Î»-saturated if every pairwise disjoint family of
elements of B has size less than Î»; sat(B) is the least Î» such that B is
Î»-saturated. Let us say that I is Î»-saturated if B is Î»-saturated and let
sat(I) = sat(B).
In other words, I is Î»-saturated just in case there exists no collection W of
size Î» of subsets of Îº such that X /âˆˆI for all X âˆˆW and X âˆ©Y âˆˆI whenever
X and Y are distinct members of W. If sat(I) is ï¬nite, then Îº is the union
of ï¬nitely many atoms of I; if sat(I) is inï¬nite, then it is uncountable and
regular, by Theorem 7.15. If Î» â‰¤Îº, then I is Î»-saturated if and only if there
is no disjoint collection W of size Î» of subsets X of Îº such that X /âˆˆI (see
Exercise 22.1). Clearly, every I on Îº is (2Îº)+-saturated. Thus if I is atomless,
then sat(I) is a regular cardinal and
â„µ1 â‰¤sat(I) â‰¤(2Îº)+.
Since I is Îº-complete, it follows that B = P(Îº)/I is a Îº-complete Boolean
algebra.
Real-Valued Measurable Cardinals
By Ulamâ€™s Theorem 10.1, if there exists a nontrivial Ïƒ-additive measure then
either there exists a measurable cardinal or there exists a real-valued mea-
surable cardinal.
In this section we prove the following theorems:

Theorem 22.1 (Solovay).
(i) If Îº is a real-valued measurable cardinal, then there is a transitive
model of set theory in which Îº is measurable.
(ii) If Îº is a measurable cardinal, then there exists a generic extension in
which Îº = 2â„µ0 and Îº is real-valued measurable.
Theorem 22.2 (Prikry). If 2â„µ0 is real-valued measurable, then 2Î» = 2â„µ0
for all inï¬nite Î» < 2â„µ0.
If Âµ is a Îº-additive real-valued measure on Îº, then the ideal IÂµ of all sets
of measure 0 is a Ïƒ-saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº. We have proved that if
an uncountable cardinal Îº carries a Ïƒ-saturated Îº-complete ideal, then Îº is
weakly inaccessible.
We shall prove Theorem 22.1(i) and Theorem 22.2 for this generalization

cardinal and let I be a Ïƒ-saturated Îº-complete ideal. Thus let Îº be an un-

then Îº â‰¤2â„µ0. It follows that if 2â„µ0 < Îº, then every set X of positive measure

collection W of atoms such that Îº = {A : A âˆˆW}.

Corollary 22.5. If Îº is real-valued measurable (or if Îº carries a Ïƒ-saturated
Îº-complete ideal), then Îº is a weakly Mahlo cardinal.
Proof. Let I be a normal Ïƒ-saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº. Since I is normal,

Îº is weakly inaccessible, it suï¬ƒces to show that the set of all regular cardinals
Î± < Îº has measure one.

Î± âˆˆT , Î± = limÎ½ Î±Î½ â‰¤Î³. This is a contradiction since T is unbounded.
âŠ“âŠ”
Since every closed unbounded set has measure one (if I is a normal Ïƒ-
saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº), every set of positive measure is stationary.
It can even be proved that if S has positive measure, then S âˆ©Î± is stationary
in Î± for almost all Î±. Then it follows that Îº is the Îºth weakly Mahlo cardinal,
Îºth cardinal which is a limit of weakly Mahlo cardinals, etc. We shall return
to this subject later in this chapter.
We shall now show that every real-valued measurable cardinal is a Row-
bottom cardinal; we shall show that the statement of Lemma 17.36 for
a measurable cardinal holds under the weaker assumption that Îº carries a Ïƒ-
saturated Îº-complete ideal.

Lemma 22.8. Let Î½ < Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal, and let I be
a normal Î½-saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº; let F be the dual ï¬lter. Then
in L[F], F âˆ©L[F] is a normal measure on Îº (and L[F] is the model L[D] of

Proof. It is easy to verify that L[F] = L[I], and that in L[F], I âˆ©L[I] is

We know that Îº is the union of a disjoint family W of atoms. (What we
want to show is that W has only one element.) For A âˆˆW, let
FA = {X âŠ‚Îº : X âˆ©A has positive measure}.
Since A is an atom, FA is a ï¬lter, and FA is in fact a normal measure on Îº.
Hence FA âˆ©L[FA] is the unique normal measure D in L[FA], and L[FA] is
the model L[D].
We shall now show that F âˆ©L[D] = D. Let X âˆˆL[D] be a subset of Îº. If
X âˆˆF, then X âˆˆFA for all A âˆˆW and hence X âˆˆFAâˆ©L[FA] = D. If X /âˆˆF,
then there is A âˆˆW such that X /âˆˆFA and hence X /âˆˆFA âˆ©L[FA] = D. It
follows that F âˆ©L[D] = D and so F âˆ©L[D] âˆˆL[D].
Consequently, L[F] = L[D]; since we assumed that V = L[F] and because
F âˆ©L[D] = D, we have F = D.

n=0 Xn]. Since Âµ is a measure, I is countably
saturated and so B satisï¬es the countable chain condition. Now a Boolean
algebra that is both Ïƒ-complete and Ïƒ-saturated is complete, and so B is
a complete Boolean algebra.

A Boolean algebra B with a measure m (satisfying (22.1)) is called a measure

We need from measure theory the following basic fact about products of

Generic Ultrapowers
We shall now introduce a powerful method for dealing with ideals on regu-
lar uncountable cardinals. The method is a generalization of the method of
ultrapowers from Chapter 10.
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let I be an ideal on Îº. Let
us view the universe as a ground model, let us denote this ground model M
and let us consider the generic extension of M given by the completion of
the Boolean algebra P(Îº)/I. In other words, consider the notion of forcing
(P, âŠ‚), where P is the collection of all subsets of Îº of positive measure:
(i) X âˆˆP if and only if X /âˆˆI;
(ii) X is stronger than Y if and only if X âŠ‚Y
(22.15)
Let G be a generic ï¬lter on P.
Lemma 22.13.
(i) G is an M-ultraï¬lter on Îº extending the ï¬lter dual to I.
(ii) If I is Îº-complete in M, then G is a Îº-complete M-ultraï¬lter.
(iii) If I is normal, then G is normal.
Proof. (i) If X âŠ‚Îº has measure one, then {Y âˆˆP : Y âŠ‚X} is dense in P
and hence X âˆˆG. That G is an M-ultraï¬lter is obvious.
(ii) If {XÎ± : Î± < Î³}, Î³ < Îº, is (in M) a partition of Îº, then by the Îº-
completeness of I, the set {Y âˆˆP : Y âŠ‚some XÎ±} is dense in P and hence
XÎ± âˆˆG for some Î±.

421
(iii) If X âˆˆG and if f âˆˆM is a regressive function on X, then {Y âŠ‚X :
f is constant on Y } is dense below X, and hence f is constant on some
Y âˆˆG.
âŠ“âŠ”
From now on assume that I is a Îº-complete ideal on Îº containing all
singletons. Then G is a nonprincipal Îº-complete M-ultraï¬lter on Îº. Note
that if I is atomless, then G /âˆˆM (if I is prime, then G is the dual of I and
so G âˆˆM).
Let us consider (in M[G]) the ultrapower UltG(M); let us call this ultra-
power a generic ultrapower. The generic ultrapower is a model of ZFC, but
is not necessarily well-founded. We have the analog of LoÂ´sâ€™s Theorem, in this
form
(22.16)
UltG(M) âŠ¨Ï•([f1], . . . , [fn])
if and only if
{Î± : M âŠ¨Ï•(f1(Î±), . . . , fn(Î±))} âˆˆG
whenever f1, . . . , fn âˆˆM are functions deï¬ned on a set X âˆˆG. In particu-
lar, we have an elementary embedding, the canonical embedding jG : M â†’
UltG(M), deï¬ned by
jG(x) = [cx]
where cx is the constant function on Îº with value x, and [cx] is its equivalence
class in the ultrapower.
Let us denote the generic ultrapower by N and jG = j. The ordinal
numbers of the model N form a linearly ordered class, not necessarily well-
ordered, but we shall show that (because I is Îº-complete), OrdN has an
initial segment of order-type Îº. If x âˆˆOrdN, let us call the order-type of x
the order-type of the set {y âˆˆOrdN : y <N x}. If the order-type of x is an
ordinal number, we take the liberty of identifying x with this ordinal.
Lemma 22.14.
(i) For every Î³ < Îº, j(Î³) = Î³; hence OrdN has an initial segment of
order-type Îº.
(ii) j(Îº) Ì¸= Îº.
(iii) If I is normal, then there exists x âˆˆOrdN such that x = Îº; in fact
[d] = Îº where d is the diagonal function d(Î±) = Î±.
Proof. G is Îº-complete, nonprincipal, and if I is normal then G is normal.
âŠ“âŠ”
Let us mention again the fact that we already mentioned and that is fairly
easy to verify: If P is the notion of forcing (22.15) then B(P) = B(P(Îº)/I);
the mapping X â†’[X] gives the natural correspondence.
To illustrate the method of generic ultrapowers we present two examples.
The ï¬rst is (a modiï¬cation of) Silverâ€™s proof of Theorem 8.12; the other is
a theorem of Jech and Prikry.

Precipitous Ideals
In an early application of generic ultrapowers, Solovay proved that if I is
Îº+-saturated then the generic ultrapower is well-founded (see Lemma 22.22
in the next section). It has been recognized that this property of ideals is
important enough to single out and study such ideals.
Deï¬nition 22.18. A Îº-complete ideal on Îº is precipitous if the generic ul-
trapower UltG(M) is well-founded.
We give below several necessary and suï¬ƒcient (combinatorial) conditions
on I to be precipitous.
Let I be a Îº-complete ideal on Îº containing all singletons. Let S be a set
of positive measure. An I-partition of S is a maximal family W of subsets
of S of positive measure such that X âˆ©Y âˆˆI for any distinct X, Y âˆˆW. An
I-partition W1 of S is a reï¬nement of an I-partition W2 of S, W1 â‰¤W2, if
every X âˆˆW1 is a subset of some Y âˆˆW2. A functional on S is a collection F
of functions such that WF = {dom(f) : f âˆˆF} is an I-partition of S and
dom(f) Ì¸= dom(g) whenever f Ì¸= g âˆˆF.
We deï¬ne F < G for two functionals on S to mean that:
(i) each f âˆˆF âˆªG is a function into the ordinals;
(ii) WF â‰¤WG; and
(iii) if f âˆˆF and g âˆˆG are such that dom(f) âŠ‚dom(g), then f(Î±) < g(Î±)
for all Î± âˆˆdom(f).
The reason we deï¬ne functionals is that they represent functions in the
Boolean-valued model M B (and so are canonical representatives for elements
of UltG(M)): Let Ë™f âˆˆM B be such that
(22.19)
S âŠ©Ë™f is a function with dom( Ë™f) âˆˆË™G and Ë™f âˆˆM.
Then there is an I-partition W of S, and for each X âˆˆW a function fX on X
such that for all X âˆˆW, X âŠ©Ë™fâ†¾Ë‡X = Ë‡fX. Thus the functional {fX : X âˆˆW}
represents the Boolean-valued Ë™f on S.
Conversely, if F is functional on S, then there is some Ë™f âˆˆM B such that
(22.19) holds; and for each f âˆˆF, if X = dom(f), then X âŠ©Ë™fâ†¾Ë‡X = Ë‡f.
Note also that if F < G are functionals on S and Ë™f, Ë™g are corresponding
Boolean-valued names, then
(22.20)
S âŠ©Ë™f, Ë™g âˆˆM and dom( Ë™f) âŠ‚dom Ë™g and Ë™f(Î±) < Ë™g(Î±) for all Î± âˆˆ
dom( Ë™f).
Conversely, if Ë™f and Ë™g satisfy (22.20), then there are functionals F and G
that represent Ë™f and Ë™g, and F < G.
Lemma 22.19. The following are equivalent:

(i) I is precipitous.
(ii) Whenever S is a set of positive measure and {Wn : n < Ï‰} are I-

each n, and âˆ

on S such that F0 > F1 > . . . > Fn > . . ..
Proof. In view of the preceding discussion on functionals, (ii) is equivalent
to (i): If F0 > F1 > . . . are functionals on S, and Ë™f0, Ë™f1, . . . , the corresponding

a descending sequence of ordinals, we construct F0, F1, . . . on S such that
F0 > F1 > . . ..

on S, then the partitions WF0, WF1, . . . constitute a counterexample: If

Lemma 22.20. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal. The ideal I =
{X âŠ‚Îº : |X| < Îº} is not precipitous.
Proof. Let I = {X âŠ‚Îº : |X| < Îº}. A set X âŠ‚Îº has positive measure just
in case |X| = Îº. For each such X, let fX be the unique order-preserving
function from X onto Îº.

{Î± âˆˆX : fX(Î±) is a successor ordinal}, then fX(Î±) = fY (Î±) + 1 for all

An alternate characterization of precipitousness is in terms of inï¬nite
games. GI is the inï¬nite game played by two players, Empty and Nonempty,
who alternately choose sets Sn of positive I-measure such that Sn+1 âŠ‚Sn.

n=0 Sn = âˆ….
Lemma 22.21. I is precipitous if and only if Empty has no winning strategy
in the game GI.
Proof. If I is not precipitous then there is a set S of positive measure and
a sequence of functionals on S such that F0 > F1 > . . . > Fn > . . .. Empty
chooses S0 = S for his ï¬rst move. When Nonempty plays S2nâˆ’1, Empty ï¬nds
some f âˆˆFn such that the set X = dom(f)âˆ©S2nâˆ’1 has positive measure and
chooses S2n = X for his move. It follows that âˆ
n=0 Sn is empty, and hence
Empty wins.
Now suppose that I is precipitous and Ïƒ is a strategy for Empty; we will
show that Ïƒ is not a winning strategy. Let S0 be Emptyâ€™s ï¬rst move by Ïƒ.
Then S0 forces that in M[G] there is an inï¬nite sequence âŸ¨Sn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©of
moves in which Empty follows Ïƒ and each Sn âˆˆG. If j : M â†’UltG(M) is
the canonical embedding then âŸ¨j(Sn) : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©is an inï¬nite sequence of moves
(of j(GI)) in which Empty follows j(Ïƒ) and Îº âˆˆâˆ
n=0 j(Sn). Since UltG(M) is

since j is elementary, there exists a sequence âŸ¨Sn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©in M in which
Empty follows Ïƒ but for some Î± < Îº, Î± âˆˆâˆ
n=0 Sn. Thus Ïƒ is not a winning

Saturated Ideals
Results from Chapter 10 and those proved earlier in this chapter establish the
following facts about the existence of a Ïƒ-saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº:
If Îº carries a Ïƒ-saturated Îº-complete ideal then either Îº is measurable, or
Îº â‰¤2â„µ0 and Îº is weakly inaccessible (Lemma 10.9 and 10.14). If a Ïƒ-saturated
ideal exists then there exists a normal one (Lemma 22.3), and its consistency
strength is that of a measurable cardinal (Lemma 22.8). These results gener-
alize easily to Î½-saturated ideals for Î½ < Îº; the analog of Lemma 10.9 (with
the same proof) is that either Îº is measurable, or Îº â‰¤2<Î½.
In this section we investigate Îº-saturated and Îº+-saturated ideals. We
shall employ the technique of generic ultrapowers; this is particularly useful
because the generic ultrapower is well-founded:

âŠ“âŠ”
It is consistent (relative to the existence of a measurable cardinal) that
an inaccessible cardinal Îº carries an ideal I such that sat(I) = Îº. (Such Îº
cannot be weakly compact, see Exercise 22.13.)
We shall now prove the main result on Îº-saturated ideals, using generic
ultrapowers. First we need a lemma on preservation of stationary sets by

Lemma 22.25. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal. Let V [G] be a generic
extension of V by a Îº-c.c. notion of forcing. Then every closed unbounded
C âŠ‚Îº in V [G] has a closed unbounded subset D âˆˆV . Consequently, if S âˆˆV
is stationary in V , then S remains stationary in V [G].

unbounded subset of Îº. Let D = {Î± : âˆ¥Î± âˆˆË™Câˆ¥= 1}. Clearly, D is a subset
of C and is closed; we have to prove only that D is unbounded.
Let Î±0 < Îº; we wish to ï¬nd Î± > Î±0 such that every condition forces Î± âˆˆË™C.

Î² = Î²q such that q âŠ©Î² âˆˆË™C. Since |W| < Îº, we let Î±1 = sup{Î²q : q âˆˆW};
we have Î±1 < Îº and

for all conditions p. Similarly, we ï¬nd Î±1 < Î±2 < Î±3 < . . . such that for

Theorem 22.26 (Solovay). Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and
assume that Îº carries a Îº-saturated ideal.
(i) Îº is weakly Mahlo;
(ii) {Î± < Îº : Î± is weakly Mahlo} is stationary;
(iii) if X âŠ‚Îº has measure one in a normal Îº-saturated ideal, then X âˆ©

Proof. If there exists a Îº-saturated ideal on Îº, then Îº is weakly inaccessi-

Lemma 22.23). Let I be a normal Îº-saturated ideal on Îº. We ï¬rst prove:
Lemma 22.27. If S âŠ‚Îº is stationary, then for I-almost all Î± < Îº, S âˆ©Î± is
stationary in Î±.
Proof. If not, then there is a set X of positive measure such that S âˆ©Î± is not

cardinal in M[G], and by Lemma 22.25, M[G] âŠ¨S is stationary. Now N âŠ‚
M[G] and so N âŠ¨S is stationary. A contradiction.

Since I is normal, every set of positive measure is stationary. Thus (iii) fol-
lows since if X has measure one then M(X) has measure one by Lemma 22.27,
and so does X âˆ©M(X).
To prove (i), it suï¬ƒces to show that almost all Î± < Îº are regular cardinals.
Otherwise, let X be a set of positive measure such that all Î± âˆˆX are singular.
Let G âˆ‹X be generic and let N = UltG(M). Then N âŠ¨Îº is singular, contrary
to the fact that Îº is regular in M[G] and N âŠ‚M[G].
Now (ii) follows by an application of (iii): Let X = {Î± < Îº : Î± is regular},
then X âˆ©M(X) = {Î± < Îº : Î± is weakly Mahlo}.

As a corollary of Theorem 22.26 we have Solovayâ€™s original proof of The-
orem 8.10:
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let S be a stationary subset
of Îº. We claim that S is the disjoint union of Îº stationary subsets.
Otherwise, the ideal I = {X âŠ‚Îº : X âˆ©S is nonstationary} is a normal
Îº-saturated ideal. By Lemma 22.27, S âˆ’M(S) has measure zero and hence
is nonstationary, which contradicts Lemma 8.9.

Now let us consider Îº+-saturated ideals.
Lemma 22.28. Let I be a Îº+-saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº.
(i) There exists a least unbounded function, i.e., a function f : Îº â†’Îº such

on S (unbounded) and that for any g : Îº â†’Îº, if g(Î±) < f(Î±) on a set

Proof. By Lemma 22.22 I is precipitous. Since I is Îº+-saturated, the Boolean-

function.

is a normal Îº-complete ideal and is Îº+-saturated.
âŠ“âŠ”
Unlike Îº-saturation, the existence of a Îº+-saturated ideal on Îº does not
imply that Îº be a limit cardinal. However, the consistency strength of a Îº+-
saturated ideal on a successor cardinal Îº is considerably stronger than mea-
surability (while the existence of an ideal I on an inaccessible Îº such that

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
sat(I) = Îº+ is equiconsistent with measurability). It is consistent, relative
to a Woodin cardinal, that the nonstationary ideal on â„µ1 is â„µ2-saturated; we
shall study this problem in Part III. We shall also return to the subject of
saturation of the nonstationary ideal in general in Chapter 23.
Saturated ideals have inï¬‚uence on cardinal arithmetic, similar to measur-
able cardinals:
Lemma 22.29. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let I be a Îº+-
saturated ideal on Îº. If 2Î» = Î»+ for all Î» < Îº, then 2Îº = Îº+.

because X = j(X) âˆ©Îº. Thus P M(Îº) âŠ‚P N(Îº).

and since all cardinals above Îº+ in M are preserved, the last formula is also

Theorem 22.33.
(i) If Îº is a regular uncountable cardinal that carries a precipitous ideal,
then Îº is measurable in an inner model of ZFC.

which Îº = â„µ1, and Îº carries a precipitous ideal.

First we observe that the ultrapower UltW (V [G]) is well-founded. This is

Historical Notes
Saturated ideals, a concept introduced by Tarski in [1945], were brought to promi-
nence in Solovayâ€™s work [1971]. Solovay introduced the technique of generic ultra-
powers and proved Theorems 22.1 and 22.26 (as well as Theorem 8.10).
Theorem 22.2 is due to Prikry [1975], and so is the model in Example 22.10 in
which Îº carries a Ïƒ-saturated ideal [1970]. Theorem 22.16 is due to Jech and Prikry
([1976] and [1979]).
Precipitous ideals were introduced by Jech and Prikry in [1976]; their pa-
per [1979] investigates generic ultrapowers. Lemma 22.21: Jech [1976]. Lemma 22.28:
Solovay [1971]. Lemmas 22.29 and 22.30: Jech and Prikry [1976, 1979].
Kunenâ€™s paper [1978] contains a number of results on saturated ideals. Kunen
constructs several generic extensions with saturated ideals, including a model (using
a huge cardinal) in which â„µ1 carries an â„µ2-saturated ideal. In [1970], Kunen proves
that if Îº carries a Îº+-saturated ideal then there is an inner model with a measurable
cardinal; in [1971a] Kunen shows that if moreover Îº is a successor cardinal then
there is an inner model with many measurable cardinals. Mitchell [1983] improved
this to measurable cardinals of order Îº+. Part (i) of Theorem 22.33 is due to Jech
and Prikry and part (ii) was proved by Mitchell; see Jech et al. [1980].
Exercise 22.4: Silver.
Exercises 22.5, 22.6 and 22.7: Prikry [1970].
Exercise 22.8: Smith and Tarski.

22. Saturated Ideals
439
Exercise 22.9: Solovay [1971].
Exercise 22.11: Baumgartner, Hajnal, and MÂ´atÂ´e [1975].
Exercise 22.12: Kanamori [1976]
Exercise 22.13: LÂ´evy, Silver.

23. The Nonstationary Ideal
Stationary sets play a fundamental role in modern set theory. In particular,
the analysis of the nonstationary ideal INS on Ï‰1 has been used in the study
of forcing axioms, large cardinals and determinacy. These will be dealt with in
later chapters; this chapter continues the investigations began in Chapters 8
and 22. Throughout this chapter â€œalmost allâ€ means all except nonstationary
many.
Some Combinatorial Principles
We begin with combinatorial principles that involve stationary sets. Let us
recall Jensenâ€™s Principle (â™¦): There exist sets SÎ± âŠ‚Î± such that for every
X âŠ‚Ï‰1, the set {Î± < Ï‰1 : X âˆ©Î± = SÎ±} is stationary. There are several vari-
ants of â™¦(see e.g. Exercise 15.25); most notably the following weak version:
Lemma 23.1. The following principle is equivalent to â™¦: There exists a se-
quence âŸ¨SÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©of countable sets such that for each X âŠ‚Ï‰1 the set
{Î± < Ï‰1 : X âˆ©Î± âˆˆSÎ±} is stationary.
Proof. Let âŸ¨SÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©be a sequence as in the lemma; we shall produce
a diamond sequence. First, let f be a one-to-one mapping of Ï‰1 onto Ï‰1 Ã— Ï‰
such that fâ€œÎ± = Î± Ã— Ï‰ for all limit ordinals Î±. For every limit ordinal Î±, let
AÎ± = {fâ€œx : x âˆˆSÎ±} (and AÎ± = âˆ…otherwise). Note that for each Y âŠ‚Ï‰1 Ã—Ï‰
the set {Î± < Ï‰1 : Y âˆ©(Î± Ã— Ï‰) âˆˆAÎ±} is stationary.
For each Î±, let AÎ± = {an
Î± : n âˆˆÏ‰}. It follows that for each X âŠ‚Ï‰1 Ã— Ï‰
there exists some n such that the set {Î± : X âˆ©(Î± Ã— Ï‰) = an
Î±} is stationary.
For each Î± < Ï‰1 and each n, let Sn
Î± = {Î¾ < Î± : (Î¾, n) âˆˆan
Î±}. We complete
the proof by showing that for some n, âŸ¨Sn
Î± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©is a diamond sequence.
If not, there exist sets Xn âŠ‚Ï‰1 such that {Î± < Ï‰1 : Xn âˆ©Î± = Sn
Î±} are
nonstationary. Letting X = 
nâˆˆÏ‰(Xn Ã— {n}), it follows that for each n,
{Î± < Ï‰1 : X âˆ©(Î± Ã— Ï‰) Ì¸= an
Î±} is nonstationary; a contradiction.

cardinal Îº. Even more generally, let E be a stationary subset of a regular

One of the most fundamental combinatorial principles is Jensenâ€™s Square
Principle. Let Îº be an uncountable cardinal; â–¡Îº (square-kappa) is as follows:
(â–¡Îº) There exists a sequence âŸ¨CÎ± : Î± âˆˆLim(Îº+)âŸ©such that
(i) CÎ± is a closed unbounded subset of Î±;
(ii) if Î² âˆˆLim(CÎ±) then CÎ² = CÎ± âˆ©Î²;
(iii) if cf Î± < Îº then |CÎ±| < Îº.
(23.4)
The sequence âŸ¨CÎ± : Î± âˆˆLim(Îº+)âŸ©is called a square-sequence. Note that by
(ii) and (iii), the order-type of every CÎ± is at most Îº.
Using the ï¬ne structure theory of L, Jensen proved that in L, â–¡Îº holds
for every uncountable cardinal Îº. (We elaborate on this in Part III). This has

444
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
been extended to most inner models for large cardinals: the Square Principles
hold in L[U], L[U], an in more general inner models.
Squares are relatively easy to obtain by forcing; as an example, see Exer-
cise 23.3.
Deï¬nition 23.5. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let Î± < Îº be
a limit ordinal of uncountable coï¬nality. We say that a stationary set S âŠ‚Îº
reï¬‚ects at Î± if S âˆ©Î± is a stationary subset of Î±.
Corollary 17.20 states that if Îº is a weakly compact cardinal then every
stationary subset of Îº reï¬‚ects. We address the subject of reï¬‚ection of sta-
tionary sets later in this chapter. See also Exercises 23.4 and 23.5. In general,
squares provide examples of nonreï¬‚ecting stationary sets:
Lemma 23.6. â–¡Ï‰1 implies that there exists a stationary set S âŠ‚Eâ„µ2
â„µ0 that
does not reï¬‚ect.
Proof. Let âŸ¨CÎ± : Î± âˆˆLim(Ï‰2)âŸ©be a square-sequence. For each Î± < Ï‰2 of
coï¬nality Ï‰1, the order-type of CÎ± is Ï‰1. It follows that there exists a count-
able limit ordinal Î· such that the set S = {Î³ âˆˆEâ„µ2
â„µ0 : Î³ is the Î·th element of
some CÎ±} is stationary. But for every Î± of coï¬nality Ï‰1, S has at most one
element in common with CÎ±. Hence S does not reï¬‚ect.
âŠ“âŠ”
Stationary Sets in Generic Extensions
If Îº is a regular uncountable cardinal then a closed unbounded subset of Îº
in the ground model remains a closed unbounded subset of Îº in a generic
extensions (but Îº may fail to remain a cardinal or its coï¬nality may change).
It follows that if S âˆˆV is stationary in V [G] then S is stationary in V .
A stationary set in V may, however, be no longer stationary in V [G], as
there may exist a new closed unbounded set in V [G] that is disjoint from it.
We recall Lemma 22.25 that states that if the forcing satisï¬es the Îº-chain
condition then every stationary subset of Îº in V is preserved; i.e., remains
stationary in V [G]. Another condition on preservation of stationary sets is
the following:
Lemma 23.7. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let P be a notion
of forcing. If P is <Îº-closed then every stationary S âŠ‚Îº remains stationary
in V [G].
Proof. Let p âŠ©Ë™C is closed unbounded; we ï¬nd a Î³ âˆˆS and a q â‰¤p such
that q âŠ©Î³ âˆˆË™C as follows: We construct an increasing continuous ordinal
sequence âŸ¨Î³Î± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©and a decreasing sequence âŸ¨pÎ± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©of conditions
such that pÎ±+1 âŠ©Î³Î±+1 âˆˆË™C. If Î± is a limit ordinal then Î³Î± = limÎ¾<Î± Î³Î¾ and
pÎ± is a lower bound of {pÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±}. There exists a limit ordinal Î± such that
Î³Î± âˆˆS. It follows that pÎ± âŠ©Î³Î± âˆˆË™C.
âŠ“âŠ”

23. The Nonstationary Ideal
445
The basic method for destroying stationary sets by forcing is the following
forcing known as â€œshooting a closed unbounded set.â€
Theorem 23.8. Let S be a stationary subset of Ï‰1. There is a notion of
forcing PS that adds generically a closed unbounded set C âŠ‚Ï‰1 such that
C âŠ‚S, and such that PS adds no new countable sets.
Since PS adds no countable sets, â„µ1 is preserved. The set Ï‰1 âˆ’S is non-
stationary in V [G]; thus if S is chosen so that its complement is stationary,
the forcing destroys some stationary set.
Proof. PS consists of all bounded closed sets of ordinals p such that p âŠ‚S;
p is stronger than q if p is an end-extension of q (if q = p âˆ©Î± for some Î±).
If G is a generic ï¬lter, let C =  G. Clearly, C is a subset of S, and
because for every Î± < Ï‰1 the set {p âˆˆP : max(p) â‰¥Î±} is dense in PS, C is
an unbounded subset of Ï‰1. Also, sup(C âˆ©Î±) âˆˆC holds for every Î± < Ï‰1,
and so C is a closed unbounded set. It remains to prove that â„µ1 is preserved
and that there are no new countable sets of ordinals.
Lemma 23.9. PS is Ï‰-distributive.
Proof. Let p âŠ©Ë™f : Ï‰ â†’Ord; we shall ï¬nd a q â‰¤p and some f so that
q âŠ©Ë™f = f.
By induction on Î± we construct a chain {AÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} of countable
subsets of PS. Let A0 = {p}, and AÎ± = 
Î²<Î± AÎ² if Î± is a limit ordinal.
Given AÎ±, let Î³Î± = sup{max(q) : q âˆˆAÎ±}. For each q âˆˆAÎ± and each n, we
choose some r = r(q, n) âˆˆPS so that r â‰¤q, r decides Ë™f(n), and max(r) > Î³Î±.
Then we let AÎ±+1 = AÎ± âˆª{r(q, n) : q âˆˆAÎ±, n < Ï‰}.
The sequence âŸ¨Î³Î± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©is increasing and continuous. Let C = {Î» : if
Î± < Î» then Î³Î± < Î»}. As C is closed unbounded, there exists a limit ordinal Î»
such that Î» âˆˆC âˆ©S. Let âŸ¨Î±n : n < Ï‰âŸ©be an increasing sequence with limit Î»;
then limn Î³Î±n = Î» as well.
There is a sequence of conditions âŸ¨pn : n < Ï‰âŸ©such that p0 = p and
that for every n, pn+1 âˆˆAÎ±n+1, pn+1 â‰¤pn, and pn+1 decides Ë™f(n). Since
Î³Î±n < max(pn+1) â‰¤Î³Î±n+1, we have limn max(pn) = Î», and because Î» âˆˆS,
the closed set q âˆˆâˆ
n=0 pn âˆª{Î»} is a condition. Since q â‰¤pn for all n,
q decides each Ë™f(n), and so there exists some f such that q âŠ©Ë™f = f.

The forcing PS can be generalized for cardinals Îº greater than â„µ1 but
additional assumptions on S must be made in order to preserve Îº. See, e.g.,
Exercises 23.7 and 23.8.
Precipitousness of the Nonstationary Ideal
In Theorem 22.33(ii) we showed that if Îº is a measurable cardinal and P is
the LÂ´evy collapse (with ï¬nite conditions, making Îº = â„µ1) then in V [G],

there exists a precipitous ideal on â„µ1. We now improve this to making the
nonstationary ideal precipitous:
Theorem 23.10 (Magidor). It is consistent, relative to the existence of
a measurable cardinal, that the nonstationary ideal on â„µ1 is precipitous.

Thus the consistency strength of â€œINS on Ï‰1 is precipitousâ€ is exactly
the existence of a measurable cardinal. For cardinals greater than Ï‰1 the
consistency is considerably stronger. For instance, â€œINS on Ï‰2 is precipitousâ€
is equiconsistent with a measurable cardinal of order 2 (Gitik); for larger
cardinals it is much stronger. Most of the best results to date are due to
Gitik.
Saturation of the Nonstationary Ideal
By Solovayâ€™s Theorem 8.10, the nonstationary ideal INS on Îº is nowhere Îº-
saturated. For Îº = â„µ1 it is consistent that INS is Îº+-saturated; its consistency
strength is roughly that of a Woodin cardinal. We shall return to this subject
in Part III.
For Îº greater than â„µ1, the nonstationary ideal is not Îº+-saturated:
Theorem 23.17 (Gitik-Shelah). For every regular cardinal Îº â‰¥â„µ2, the
ideal INS on Îº is not Îº+-saturated.
The proof of Theorem 23.17 appears in Gitik and Shelah [1997]. Most
special cases were proved earlier by Shelah, and we present this proof ï¬rst,
as it is somewhat easier. The complete proof will follow.
The results presented here are somewhat more general as they apply to
other normal ideals. If I is a normal ideal, I+ denotes the collection {S âŠ‚Îº :
S /âˆˆI} of sets of positive I-measure. For S âˆˆI+, Iâ†¾S denotes the ideal
{X âŠ‚Îº : X âˆ©S âˆˆI}; we say that Iâ†¾S concentrates on S.
We shall use the method of generic ultrapowers, and start with several ob-
servations. Let I be a normal Îº+-saturated Îº-complete ideal on a regular un-
countable cardinal Îº. The generic ultrapower M = UltG(V ) is well-founded,
and since the forcing with sets of positive I-measure satisï¬es the Îº+-chain
condition, Îº+ is a cardinal in V [G], and hence in M.

23. The Nonstationary Ideal
451
Lemma 23.18. Let I be a normal Îº+-saturated Îº-complete ideal on Îº, let
R(I) be the forcing with I-positive sets, let G be the R(I)-generic ultraï¬lter
and let M = UltG(V ). Then P M(Îº) = P V [G](Îº), and all cardinals (and
coï¬nalities) < Îº are preserved in V [G].
Proof. The Boolean algebra B = P(Îº)/I is complete (see Exercise 22.9). If
Ë™A is a name for a subset A = Ë™AG of Îº in V [G], let SÎ± âˆˆI+ be, for each
Î± < Îº, such that âˆ¥Î± âˆˆË™Aâˆ¥= [SÎ±]. If j : V â†’M is the canonical embedding,
we have, for each Î±, Î± âˆˆA if and only if SÎ± âˆˆG if and only if Îº âˆˆj(SÎ±),

We shall use a combinatorial lemma due to Shelah. Let Î» be a cardinal
and let Î± < Î»+ be a limit ordinal. A family {XÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î»+} of subsets of Î± is
strongly almost disjoint if every XÎ¾ âŠ‚Î± is unbounded, and if for every Ï‘ < Î»+
there exist ordinals Î´Î¾ < Î±, for Î¾ < Ï‘, such that the sets XÎ¾ âˆ’Î´Î¾, Î¾ < Ï‘, are
pairwise disjoint. If Îº is a regular cardinal then there exists a strongly almost
disjoint family of Îº+ subsets of Îº (see Exercise 23.10).
Lemma 23.19. If Î± < Î»+ and cf Î± Ì¸= cf Î» then there exists no strongly
almost disjoint family of subsets of Î±.
Proof. Assume to the contrary that {XÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î»+} is a strongly almost
disjoint family of subsets of Î±. We may assume that each XÎ¾ has order-
type cf Î±. Let f be a function that maps Î» onto Î±. Since cf Î» Ì¸= cf Î± there
exists for each Î¾ some Î³Î¾ < Î» such that XÎ¾ âˆ©fâ€œÎ³Î¾ is coï¬nal in Î±. There exist
some Î³ and a set W âŠ‚Î»+ of size Î» such that Î³Î¾ = Î³ for all Î¾ âˆˆW. Let

such that the XÎ¾ âˆ’Î´Î¾ are pairwise disjoint. Thus f âˆ’1(XÎ¾ âˆ’Î´Î¾), Î¾ âˆˆW, are
Î» pairwise disjoint nonempty subsets of Î³. A contradiction.

Corollary 23.20. If Îº is a regular cardinal and if a notion of forcing P
makes cf Îº Ì¸= cf |Îº|, then P collapses Îº+.
Proof. Assume that Îº+ is preserved; thus in V [G], (Îº+)V = Î»+ where Î» = |Îº|.
In V there is a strongly almost disjoint family {XÎ¾ : Î¾ < (Îº+)V }, and it
remains strongly almost disjoint in V [G], and has size Î»+. Since cf Îº Ì¸= cf Î»
(in V [G]), this contradicts Lemma 23.19.

The question whether various restrictions of the nonstationary ideal can

This completes the proof that the existence of a weakly compact cardinal
is necessary for the consistency of (ii). We shall not present the consistency

One starts with a ground model where Îº is a weakly compact cardinal,
and GCH holds. First one uses the LÂ´evy collapse Q with countable conditions
that makes Îº = â„µ2 (all cardinals between â„µ1 and Îº are collapsed). In V Q,
one constructs a forcing iteration P of length Îº+, with â„µ1-support. At every
stage Î± of the iteration, one considers (in V Q) a PÎ±-name for a stationary set
S âŠ‚EÎº
Ï‰ and shoots a closed unbounded set through the set T = Tr(S) âˆªEÎº
Ï‰.
Forcing conditions are closed bounded subsets of T . It is not diï¬ƒcult to

chain condition. Thus one can arrange the iteration so that every potential
stationary set S âŠ‚EÎº
Ï‰ is considered.
The main point of the proof is to show that â„µ1 is preserved by the iter-
ation, and that at each stage, if S âŠ‚EÎº
Ï‰ is stationary then Tr(S) âˆ©EÎº
Ï‰1 is
unbounded. This is proved using arguments similar to those used in Theo-
rem 23.10.
Weak compactness of Îº is used as follows: At a given stage Î± of the
iteration, there is a transitive model M âŠƒÎ± of size Îº of a suï¬ƒciently large
fragment of ZFC, and (by weak compactness) there is an elementary j :
M â†’N, cf. Lemma 17.17. This j extends to j : M Q â†’N j(Q).

Historical Notes
The equivalence in Lemma 23.1 is due to Kunen. Theorem 23.2 is due to Gre-
gory [1976]. Club-guessing principles were introduced by Shelah; see Gitik and
Shelah [1997] for details. Lemma 23.6 is due to Jensen.
The construction in Theorem 23.8 (shooting a closed unbounded set) appears
in Baumgartner et al. [1976]. Theorem 23.10 uses a construction of Magidor, see
Jech et al. [1980]. There is a sequence of results on the strength of precipitousness
of INS on cardinals Îº > â„µ1: Jech [1984], Gitik [1984, 1995, 1997] See the detailed
discussion in Jech [âˆ].
Theorem 23.17 uses the work of Shelah [1982] (Lemma 23.19 and Corollaries
23.20 and 23.21) and Gitik and Shelah [1997]. The paper Jech and Woodin [1985]
investigates saturation of INSâ†¾Reg for inaccessible cardinals.
Theorem 23.23 appears in Magidor [1982].
Exercise 23.2: Gitik and Shelah [1997].
Exercise 23.9: Baumgartner et al. [1977],
Exercise 23.11: Baumgartner.
Exercise 23.12: Shelah.

24. The Singular Cardinal Problem
In this chapter we use combinatorial methods to prove theorems (in ZFC) on
cardinal arithmetic of singular cardinals. We introduce a powerful theory of
Shelah, the pcf theory, and apply the theory to present a most remarkable
result of Shelah on powers of singular cardinals.
The Galvin-Hajnal Theorem
Following Silverâ€™s Theorem 8.12 on singular cardinals of uncountable coï¬nal-
ity, Galvin and Hajnal proved a related result:
Theorem 24.1 (Galvin-Hajnal [1975]). Let â„µÎ± be a strong limit singular
cardinal of uncountable coï¬nality. Then 2â„µÎ± < â„µÎ³ where Î³ = (2|Î±|)+.
Note that the theorem gives a nontrivial information only if â„µÎ± is not
a ï¬xed point of the aleph function.
In order to simplify the notation, we consider the special case Î± = Ï‰1. The
following lemma implies the theorem (as in the proof of Silverâ€™s Theorem).
Two functions f and g on Ï‰1 are almost disjoint if {Î± : f(Î±) = g(Î±)} is at
most countable.
Lemma 24.2. Assume that â„µâ„µ1
Î± < â„µÏ‰1 for all Î± < Ï‰1. Let F be an almost
disjoint family of functions
F âŠ‚

Î±<Ï‰1
AÎ±
such that |AÎ±| < â„µÏ‰1 for all Î± < Ï‰1. Then |F| < â„µÎ³ where Î³ = (2â„µ1)+.
Proof. We ï¬rst introduce the following relation among functions Ï• : Ï‰1 â†’Ï‰1

inï¬nite descending sequence

Ordinal Functions and Scales
The proof of the Galvin-Hajnal Theorem suggests that ordinal functions play
an important role in arithmetic of singular cardinals. We shall now embark
on a systematic study of ordinal functions and introduce Shelahâ€™s pcf theory.
Let A be an inï¬nite set and let I be an ideal on A.
Deï¬nition 24.4. For ordinal functions f, g on A, let
f =I g
if and only if
{a âˆˆA : f(a) Ì¸= g(a)} âˆˆI,
f â‰¤I g
if and only if
{a âˆˆA : f(a) > g(a)} âˆˆI,
f <I g
if and only if
{a âˆˆA : f(a) â‰¥g(a)} âˆˆI.
If F is a ï¬lter on A, then f <F g means f <I g where I is the dual ideal,
and similarly for f â‰¤F g and f =F g.
The relation â‰¤I is a partial ordering (of equivalence classes). If S is a set
of ordinal functions on A then g is an upper bound of S if f â‰¤I g for all
f âˆˆS, and g is a least upper bound of S if it is an upper bound and if g â‰¤I h
for every upper bound h.
The relation <I is also a partial ordering (diï¬€erent from â‰¤I unless I is
a prime ideal), and if I is Ïƒ-complete then <I is well-founded. If I is the
nonstationary ideal on a regular uncountable cardinal Îº, then the rank of an
ordinal function f on Îº is the (Galvin-Hajnal) norm âˆ¥fâˆ¥.
The following lemma shows that for every Î· < Îº+ there is a canonical
function fÎ· on Îº of norm Î·:

in â‰¤INS.

âˆ¥fÎ·âˆ¥S = Î·.

âŠ“âŠ”
For Î· â‰¥Îº+, canonical functions may or may not exist. The existence of fÎ·
for all ordinals Î· is equiconsistent with a measurable cardinal. For the relation
between canonical functions and canonical stationary sets, see Exercise 24.10.
A subset A of a partially ordered set (P, <) is coï¬nal if for every p âˆˆP
there exists some a âˆˆA such that p â‰¤a. The coï¬nality of (P, <) is the small-
est size of a coï¬nal set (it need not be a regular cardinalâ€”see Exercise 24.11).
The true coï¬nality of (P, <) is the least cardinality of a coï¬nal chain (if it
existsâ€”see Exercise 24.12). The true coï¬nality is a regular cardinal (or 1 if
P has a greatest element).
Consider again an inï¬nite set A, an ideal I on A, and an indexed set
{Î³a : a âˆˆA} of limit ordinals.

aâˆˆA Î³a of size < Î³ has an upper bound. The ordinal function âŸ¨Î³a : a âˆˆAâŸ©
is the least upper bound of 
aâˆˆA Î³a; moreover, it is an exact upper bound:
Deï¬nition 24.7. In a partially ordered set (P, <), g is an exact upper bound
of a set S if S is coï¬nal in the set {f âˆˆP : f < g}.

The pcf Theory
Shelahâ€™s pcf theory is the theory of possible coï¬nalities of ultraproducts of
sets of regular cardinals. Let A be a set of regular cardinals, and let D be
an ultraï¬lter on A.  A = 
aâˆˆA{a : a âˆˆA} denotes the product {f :
dom(f) = A and f(a) âˆˆa}; the ultraproduct  A/D is linearly ordered, and
cof D = cof  A/D is its coï¬nality.
Deï¬nition 24.17. If A is a set of regular cardinals, then
pcf A = {cof D : D is an ultraï¬lter on A}.
The set pcf A is a set of regular cardinals, includes A (for every a âˆˆA
consider the principal ultraï¬lter given by a), has cardinality at most 22|A|
and satisï¬es pcf(A1 âˆªA2) = pcf A1 âˆªpcf A2.
We shall investigate the structure of pcf in the next section. In this section
we explore the relation between pcf and cardinal arithmetic. Instead of the
general theory we concentrate on the special case when A = {â„µn}âˆ
n=0. We
prove the following theorem:
Theorem 24.18 (Shelah). If â„µÏ‰ is a strong limit cardinal then
max(pcf{â„µn}âˆ
n=0) = 2â„µÏ‰.
A stronger theorem is true: If 2â„µ0 < â„µÏ‰ then max(pcf{â„µn}âˆ
n=0) = â„µâ„µ0

again, we refer the reader to Burke and Magidor [1990].

regular Î» such that min A â‰¤Î» < sup A.

The Structure of pcf
Let A be a set of regular cardinals and let pcf A denote the set of all possible
coï¬nalities of  A. First we mention some facts about pcf:
(i) A âŠ‚pcf A.
(ii) If A1 âŠ‚A2 then pcf A1 âŠ‚pcf A2.
(iii) pcf(A1 âˆªA2) = pcf A1 âˆªpcf A2.
(iv) | pcf A| â‰¤22|A|.
(v) sup pcf A â‰¤|  A|.
(24.7)
In Lemma 24.19 we showed:
(vi) If A is an interval and 2|A| < min A then pcf A is an interval.
This is true in general, under the assumption |A| < min A (see Shelah [1994]).
In the following Lemma 24.24 we prove
(vii) If | pcf A| < min A then pcf(pcf A) = pcf A.
Finally, Theorem 24.18 is true in general, and under weaker assumptions; we
state this without a proof.
(viii) If A is an interval without a greatest element and (min A)|A| <
sup A, then (sup A)|A| = max pcf A.
For proof, see e.g. Burke and Magidor [1990].
Lemma 24.24. If | pcf A| < min A then pcf(pcf A) = pcf A.
Proof. Let B = pcf A. For each Î» âˆˆB choose DÎ» on A such that cof DÎ» = Î»,
and let âŸ¨f Î»

with cof D = Âµ, and let âŸ¨gÎ± : Î± < ÂµâŸ©be coï¬nal in  B/D. Let

E is an ultraï¬lter on A and we shall show that cof E = Âµ, thus proving
Âµ âˆˆpcf A, and hence pcf B = B.

The fundamental theorem of the pcf theory is the following.
Theorem 24.25 (Shelah). If A is a set of regular cardinals such that 2|A| <
min A, then there exist sets BÎ» âŠ‚A, Î» âˆˆpcf A, such that for every Î» âˆˆpcf A
(a) Î» = max pcf BÎ».
(b) Î» /âˆˆpcf(A âˆ’BÎ»).
(c) {a : a âˆˆBÎ»} has a Î»-scale mod JÎ» where JÎ» is the ideal generated
by the sets BÎ½, Î½ < Î».
(To see that JÎ» is an ideal, we observe that if X âˆˆJÎ» then X âŠ‚BÎ½1 âˆª
. . . âˆªBÎ½k, hence pcf X âŠ‚pcf BÎ½1 âˆª. . . âˆªpcf BÎ½k and so by (a), Î» /âˆˆpcf X.
Hence X Ì¸= A.)
The theorem is true under the weaker assumption |A| < min A; see She-
lah [1994] or Burke and Magidor [1990].
Note that (a) and (b) can be formulated as follows:
(a) For every ultraï¬lter D on BÎ», cof D â‰¤Î»; and there exists some D
on BÎ» such that cof D = Î».
(b) For every ultraï¬lter D on A, if cof D = Î» then BÎ» âˆˆD.
The sets BÎ», Î» âˆˆpcf A, are called the generators of pcf A. It follows from
(a) and (b) that the coï¬nality of an ultraï¬lter on A is determined by which
generators it contains:
(24.8)
cof D = the least Î» such that BÎ» âˆˆD.
Corollary 24.26. If 2|A| < min A then | pcf A| â‰¤2|A|.
Proof. The number of generators is at most 2|A|.

Corollary 24.27. If â„µÏ‰ is strong limit then 2â„µÏ‰ < â„µ(2â„µ0 )+.

Corollary 24.28. If 2|A| < min A then pcf A has a greatest element.

an ultraï¬lter D. By (b), Bcof D âˆˆD, a contradiction.

Proof of Theorem 24.25. We shall apply the results on ordinal functions
proved earlier in this chapter. If I is an ideal on a set A of regular cardi-
nals then we say that I has a Î»-scale if  A has a Î»-scale in <I; similarly,
we say that I is Î»-directed if  A is Î»-directed in â‰¤I.
We construct the generators BÎ» by induction, so that for each cardinal Îº â‰¤
sup pcf A the following conditions are satisï¬ed:
(i) the ideal JÎº generated by {BÎ» : Î» < Îº and Î» âˆˆpcf A} is Îº-
directed;
(ii) if Îº /âˆˆpcf A then JÎº is Îº+-directed;
(iii) if Îº âˆˆpcf A and Îº is not a maximal element of pcf A then there
exists a BÎº âˆˆJ+
Îº such that JÎº has a Îº-scale on BÎº and JÎº[BÎº],
the ideal generated by JÎº âˆª{BÎº}, is a Îº+-directed ideal;
(iv) if Îº = max(pcf A) then JÎº has a Îº-scale on A (and we let
BÎº = A).
(24.9)
If the conditions (24.9) are satisï¬ed, then the sets BÎ» satisfy Theorem 24.25:
To prove (a), let Î» âˆˆpcf A. Choose an ultraï¬lter D on BÎ» that extends
the dual ï¬lter of JÎ». JÎ» has a Î»-scale on BÎ», and this scale is also a scale
for <D; therefore cof D = Î», and so Î» âˆˆpcf BÎ». Also, if D is any ultraï¬lter
on BÎ», then either D âˆ©JÎ» = âˆ…in which case cof D = Î», or else there is some
Î½ < Î» such that BÎ½ âˆˆD. If Î½ is the least such Î½ then D is an ultraï¬lter on BÎ½
and D âˆ©JÎ½ = âˆ…. Since JÎ½ has a Î½-scale on BÎ½, we have cof D = Î½. In either
case, cof D â‰¤Î».
To prove (b), let D be an ultraï¬lter on A such that BÎ» /âˆˆD; we claim
that cof D Ì¸= Î». Either D âˆ‹BÎ» for some Î½ < Î» in which case cof D < Î», or
else D âˆ©JÎ»[BÎ»] Ì¸= âˆ…, and since JÎ»[BÎ»] is Î»+-directed, D is Î»+-directed, and
we have cof D > Î».
Finally, (c) follows from (24.9)(iii) and (iv). We prove (24.9) by induction
on Îº â‰¤sup pcf A:
(i) If Îº â‰¤min A then JÎº = {âˆ…} is Îº-directed. If Îº is a limit cardinal, then
JÎº = 
Î»<Îº JÎ» and the claim follows easily. If Îº = Î»+ then either Î» /âˆˆpcf A
and JÎº = JÎ» is Î»+-directed by (ii), or Î» âˆˆpcf A and JÎº = JÎ»[BÎ»] is Î»+-
directed by (iii).
(ii) Let Îº /âˆˆpcf A and Îº â‰¥min A; hence Îº > 2|A|. If Îº is singular,
then it is easy to see that since JÎº is Îº-directed, it is Îº+-directed. If Îº is
regular, assume by contradiction that JÎº is Îº-directed but not Îº+-directed.
By Corollary 24.12, JÎº has a Îº-scale on some X âˆˆJ+
Îº . Let D be any ultraï¬lter

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
(iii) Let Îº âˆˆpcf A be such that Îº < sup pcf A. We claim that JÎº is not
Îº+-directed and that JÎº does not have a Îº-scale on A. Then a BÎº exists by
Corollary 24.12. Assume by contradiction that JÎº is Îº+-directed, and let D
be any ultraï¬lter on A. If D âˆ‹BÎ» for some Î» < Îº, then cof D < Îº. Otherwise,
D âˆ©JÎº = âˆ…and since JÎº is Îº+-directed, D is Îº+-directed and so cof D > Îº.
In either case cof D Ì¸= Îº, hence Îº /âˆˆpcf A, a contradiction.
Now assume that JÎº does have a Îº-scale on A. Then for every ultraï¬lter D
on A, either D âˆ‹BÎ» for some Î» < Îº, and then cof D < Îº, or D âˆ©JÎº = âˆ…, so
D has a Îº-scale and cof D = Îº. Hence Îº = max(pcf A), a contradiction.
(iv) Let Îº = max(pcf A) and again assume, by contradiction, that JÎº does
not have a scale on A. Then by Corollary 24.12 there exists a Y âˆˆJ+
Îº such
that JÎº[Y ] is Îº+-directed. If D is any ultraï¬lter on A such that Dâˆ©JÎº[Y ] = âˆ…
then <D is Îº+-directed and so cof D > Îº. Hence Îº is not the maximal element
of pcf A, a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
The same argument that shows that pcf A has a greatest element yields
the following property of pcf, called compactness:
Corollary 24.29. Let BÎ», Î» âˆˆpcf A, be generators of pcf A. For every X âŠ‚
A there exists a ï¬nite set {Î½1, . . . , Î½k} âŠ‚pcf X such that X âŠ‚BÎ½1 âˆª. . .âˆªBÎ½k.
Proof. Assume the contrary. Then {X âˆ’BÎ½ : Î½ âˆˆpcf X} has the ï¬nite
intersection property and there exists an ultraï¬lter D on X such that BÎ½ /âˆˆ
D for all Î½ âˆˆpcf X. If Î» = cof D then BÎ» âˆˆD by Theorem 24.25(b),
a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
We conclude this section with the following improvement of Theorem
24.16:
Corollary 24.30. Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal, and let â„µÎ· be
a singular cardinal of coï¬nality Îº such that 2Îº < â„µÎ·. Then there is a closed
unbounded set C
âŠ‚Î· such that max(pcf{â„µÎ±+1 : Î± âˆˆC}) = â„µÎ·+1;

Î±âˆˆC â„µÎ±+1 has true coï¬nality â„µÎ·+1 mod I where I is the ideal of all bounded
subsets of C.

Transitive Generators and Localization
Let A be a set of regular cardinals with 2|A| < min A, let BÎ», Î» âˆˆpcf A,

(24.10)
For every X âŠ‚A, X âˆˆJÎº if and only if cof D < Îº for every

cof D â‰¥Îº. Each generator BÎ» is uniquely determined up to equivalence

and (b) of Theorem 24.25. To see this, note that by (24.10), if X â–³Y âˆˆJÎ»

Using transitive generators we now prove the Localization Lemma:
Lemma 24.32 (Localization). Let A be a set of regular cardinals such that

Shelahâ€™s Bound on 2â„µÏ‰
As an application of the pcf theory, we shall now present the following result
of Shelah:
Theorem 24.33 (Shelah). If â„µÏ‰ is a strong limit cardinal then 2â„µÏ‰ < â„µÏ‰4.
Proof. Let us assume that â„µÏ‰ is strong limit. We already know, by Corol-
lary 24.27, that 2â„µÏ‰ = max pcf{â„µn}âˆ
n=0 < â„µâ„µÏ‰. We shall prove that
max pcf{â„µn}âˆ
n=0 < â„µÏ‰4.
Let Ï‘ be the ordinal such that 2â„µÏ‰ = â„µÏ‘+1; we shall prove that Ï‘ < Ï‰4.
Lemma 24.34. There exists an ordinal function on P(Ï‘) with the following
properties:
(i) If X âŠ‚Y then F(X) â‰¤F(Y ).
(ii) For every limit ordinal Î· < Ï‘ of uncountable coï¬nality there is
a closed unbounded set C âŠ‚Î· such that F(C) = Î·.

that F(X âˆ©Î³) â‰¥sup X.
(24.18)
Proof. Let X âŠ‚Ï‘ and consider the set A = {â„µÎ¾+1 : Î¾ âˆˆX}. As 2|A| = â„µk
for some ï¬nite k, max(pcf A) exists and is equal to some â„µÎ³+1. We deï¬ne
F(X) = Î³.
It is clear that X âŠ‚Y implies F(X) â‰¤F(Y ) and that F(X) â‰¥sup X.
Property (ii) follows from Corollary 24.30. If Îº = cf Î· then Îº < â„µÏ‰ and so
2Îº < â„µÏ‰ < â„µÎ· and the corollary applies.

then {â„µÎ¾+1 : Î¾ âˆˆX} âŠ‚pcf{â„µn}âˆ
n=0 and since 2| pcf{â„µn}n| â‰¤22â„µ0 < â„µÏ‰,
Lemma 24.32 applies (with e.g. Î» = â„µÎ·+1 where Î· = sup X) and X has
a countable subset W such that F(W) â‰¥sup X.
âŠ“âŠ”
We complete the proof of Shelahâ€™s Theorem by showing that Ï‘ < Ï‰4.

Historical Notes
The Galvin-Hajnal Theorem appeared in [1975]. Shelahâ€™s investigation leading to
the pcf theory started in [1978], and the book [1982] contains the ï¬rst proof of
a bound on 2â„µÏ‰. In a sequence of papers starting in 1978, Shelah developed the
theory of possible coï¬nalities. A complete presentation is in his book [1994].
There are several papers that give an exposition and/or simpliï¬ed proofs of
Shelahâ€™s results; we mention Burke and Magidor [1990] and Jech [1992].

25. Descriptive Set Theory
Descriptive set theory is the study of deï¬nable sets of real numbers, in par-
ticular projective sets, and is mostly interested in how well behaved these
sets are. A prototype of such results is Theorem 11.18 stating that Î£1
1 sets
are Lebesgue measurable, have the Baire property, and have the perfect set
property. This chapter continues the investigations started in Chapter 11.
Throughout, we shall work in set theory ZF + DC (the Principle of Depen-
dent Choice).
The Hierarchy of Projective Sets
Modern descriptive set theory builds on both the classical descriptive set
theory and on recursion theory. It has become clear in the 1950â€™s that the
topological approach of classical descriptive set theory and the recursion theo-
retic techniques of logical deï¬nability describe the same phenomena. Modern
descriptive set theory uniï¬ed both approaches, as well as the notation. An
additional ingredient is in the use of inï¬nite games and determinacy; we shall
return to that subject in Part III.

Î 1

We formulate a normal form for Î 1
1 sets in terms of trees. This is based on
the idea that analytic sets are projections of closed sets, and that closed sets
in N are represented by sets [T ] where T is a sequential tree; cf. (4.6). Let
us consider the product space N r, for an arbitrary integer r â‰¥1. As in the
case r = 1, the closed subsets of N r can be represented by trees: Let Seqr
denote the set of all r-tuples (s1, . . . , sr) âˆˆSeqr such that length(s1) = . . . =
length(sr). A set T âŠ‚Seqr is an (r-dimensional sequential) tree if for every
(s1, . . . , sr) âˆˆT and each n â‰¤length(s1), (s1â†¾n, . . . , srâ†¾n) is also in T . Let
(25.8)
[T ] = {(a1, . . . , ar) âˆˆN r : âˆ€n (a1â†¾n, . . . , arâ†¾n) âˆˆT }.
The set [T ] is closed, and every closed set in N r has the form (25.8), for
some tree T .
We call a sequential tree T âŠ‚Seqr well-founded if [T ] = âˆ…, i.e., if the
reverse inclusion on T is a well-founded relation. T is ill-founded if it is not
well-founded.
For T âŠ‚Seqr+1 and for each x âˆˆN, let
(25.9)
T (x) = {(s1, . . . , sr) âˆˆSeqr : (xâ†¾n, s1, . . . , sr) âˆˆT
where n = length si}.
Now if A âŠ‚N is analytic, there exists a tree T âŠ‚Seq2 such that A is the
projection of [T ]; consequently, for all x âˆˆN we have
(25.10)
x âˆˆA
if and only if
T (x) is ill-founded.
More generally, if A is Î£1
1, let R be recursive such that
x âˆˆA â†”âˆƒy âˆˆN âˆ€n R(xâ†¾n, yâ†¾n)
and deï¬ne T = {(t, s) âˆˆSeq2 : âˆ€n â‰¤length(s) R(tâ†¾n, sâ†¾n)}. For all x âˆˆN,
we have T (x) = {s âˆˆSeq : âˆ€n â‰¤length(s) R(xâ†¾n, sâ†¾n)} and x âˆˆA if and
only if T (x) is ill-founded.
Theorem 25.3 (Normal Form for Î 1
1). A set A âŠ‚N is Î 1
1 if and only if
there exists a recursive mapping x â†’T (x) such that each T (x) is a sequential
tree, and
x âˆˆA
if and only if
T (x) is well-founded.

(25.11)

One consequence of normal forms is that Î 1

Theorem 25.4 (Mostowskiâ€™s Absoluteness). If P is a Î£1
1 property then
P is absolute for every transitive model that is adequate for P.
Proof. â€œAdequateâ€ here means that the model satisï¬es enough axioms to
know that well-founded trees have a rank function, and contains the param-
eter in which P is Î£1

Let M be a transitive model and let T âˆˆM be a tree such that P =
{x : T (x) is ill-founded}. Let x âˆˆM. If M âŠ¨(T (x) is ill-founded) then

T (x) â†’Ord such that f(s) < f(t) whenever s âŠƒt) and therefore T (x) is
well-founded.

Trees, Well-Founded Relations and Îº-Suslin Sets
Much of modern descriptive set theory depends on a generalization of the
Normal Form for Î 1

sequences. We can also identify T with ï¬nite sequences of r-tuples, which
enables us to consider a more general concept:
Deï¬nition 25.5.
(i) A tree T (on a set X) is a set of ï¬nite sequences (in X) closed under
initial segments.
(ii) If s, t âˆˆT then s â‰¤t means s âŠƒt, i.e., t is an initial segment of s.
(iii) If s âˆˆT then T/s = {t : sâŒ¢t âˆˆT }.
(iv) If (T, â‰¤) is well-founded then âˆ¥T âˆ¥is the height of â‰¤, and for t âˆˆT ,
ÏT (t) is the rank of t in â‰¤.

then âˆ¥Sâˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥T âˆ¥; this is easily veriï¬ed by induction on rank. But the converse
is also true:

Projective Sets and Constructibility
We now compute the complexity of the set of all constructible reals:
Theorem 25.26 (GÂ¨odel). The set of all constructible reals is a Î£1
2 set. The
ordering <L is a Î£1
2 relation.
The ï¬eld of <L is R âˆ©L. If all reals are constructible, then <L is also Î 1

Every Î£1
1 set is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property and if un-

possible.
Corollary 25.28. If V = L then there exists a âˆ†1
2 set that is not Lebesgue

Proof. Let A = {(x, y) : x <L y}. For every y, the set {x : (x, y) âˆˆA} is

every x, the set {y : (x, y) âˆˆB} is countable, and hence null if measurable,
and meager if has the Baire property.
It clearly follows that A neither is Lebesgue measurable nor has the prop-
erty of Baire
