Scales and Uniformization
The tree analysis of Î£1
2 sets can be reï¬ned; an analysis of KondË†oâ€™s proof of
the Uniformization Theorem (Theorem 25.36) led Moschovakis to introduce
the concept of scale that pervades the modern descriptive set theory.
We start with the deï¬nition of norm and prewellordering. While in the
present chapter these concepts are applied to Î 1
1 and Î£1
2 sets, the theory
applies to more general collection of deï¬nable sets of reals.
Deï¬nition 25.31. A norm on a set A is an ordinal function Ï• on A. A pre-
wellordering of A is a transitive relation â‰¼such that a â‰¼b or b â‰¼a for all
a, b âˆˆA, and that â‰ºis well-founded.
A prewellordering of a set A induces an equivalence relation (a â‰¼bâˆ§b â‰¼a)
and a well-ordering of its equivalence classes. Its rank function is a norm, and
conversely, a norm Ï• deï¬nes a prewellordering
(25.27)
a â‰¼Ï• b
if and only if
Ï•(a) â‰¤Ï•(b).
The tree analysis of Î 1
1 and Î£1
2 sets produces well behaved prewellorder-

1 and Î£1
2 sets:
Theorem 25.32. For every Î 1
1 set A there exists a norm Ï• on A with the
property that there exist a Î 1
1 relation P(x, y) and a Î£1
1 relation Q(x, y) such
that for every y âˆˆA and all x,
(25.28)
x âˆˆA and Ï•(x) â‰¤Ï•(y) â†”P(x, y) â†”Q(x, y).
A norm Ï• with the above property is called a Î 1
1-norm and the statement
â€œevery Î 1
1 set has a Î 1
1-normâ€ is called the prewellordering property of Î 1

A relativization of Theorem 25.32 shows that every Î 1

property of Î£1

A major application of scales is the uniformization property.
Deï¬nition 25.35. A set A âŠ‚N Ã— N is uniformized by a function F if

Theorem 25.36 can be used to improve the result in Corollary 25.29:
Corollary 25.37. If V = L then there exists an uncountable Î 1
1 set without
a perfect subset.
Proof. Let A be a Î£1
2 set without a perfect subset (by 25.29). Now A is the
projection of some Î 1
1 set B âŠ‚N 2. By the Uniformization Theorem, B has
a Î 1
1 subset f that is a function and has the same projection A. The set f
is uncountable; we claim that f does not have a perfect subset. Assume that
P âŠ‚f is perfect. The projection of P is an analytic subset of A. Since P âŠ‚f,
P is itself a function and because P is uncountable, the projection dom(P) is
also uncountable. This is a contradiction since we proved that every analytic
subset of A is countable.

Lemma 25.41. Every Î£1

Borel Codes
Every Borel set of reals is obtained, in fewer than Ï‰1 steps, from open inter-
vals by taking complements and countable unions. We shall show how this
procedure can be coded by a function c âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰. We shall deï¬ne the set BC of
Borel codes and assign to each c âˆˆBC a unique Borel set Ac. The code c not
only describes the Borel set Ac but also describes the procedure by which the
set Ac is constructed from basic open sets.
Let I1, I2, . . . , Ik, . . . be a recursive enumeration of open intervals with
rational endpoints (i.e., the sequence of the pairs of endpoints is rercursive).
For each c âˆˆN, let

and
vi(c)
(i âˆˆN)

all n; if d = vi(c), then d(n) = c(Î“(i, n)+1) for all n (where Î“ is the canonical
one-to-one correspondence between N Ã— N and N).
For 0 < Î± < Ï‰1, we deï¬ne sets Î£Î± and Î Î± âŠ‚N as follows:

Lemma 25.44. The set BC of all Borel codes is Î 1
1.
Proof. Let us consider the following relation E on N:
(25.45)

âˆ…) and vice versa; if y âˆˆÎ Î± and x E y, then x âˆˆÎ£Î±, and if y âˆˆÎ£Î± (Î± > 1)
and x E y, then x âˆˆ

descending sequence z0 = y, z1 E z0, z2 E z1, etc. Conversely, if E is well-

that y is itself a Borel code.
Now (25.46) gives a Î 1

Historical Notes
For classical descriptive set theory, see the books of Luzin [1930] and Kuratow-
ski [1966]; the terminology is that of modern descriptive set theory based on the
analogy with Kleeneâ€™s hierarchies ([1955]).
The basic facts on Î£1
1 and Î 1
1 sets are all in Luzinâ€™s book [1930] and some
are of earlier origin: Lemma 25.10 was in eï¬€ect proved by Lebesgue in [1905], and
Corollary 25.13 and Lemma 25.17 were proved by Luzin and SierpiÂ´nski in [1923].
Theorem 25.19 appeared in SierpiÂ´nski [1925]. Theorem 25.36 is due to KondË†o
[1939].
Theorem 25.20 is due to Shoenï¬eld [1961]. Previously, Mostowski had es-
tablished absoluteness of Î£1
1 and Î 1
1 predicates (Theorem 25.4). Lemma 25.25:
LÂ´evy [1965b].
The tree representation of Î£1
2 sets is implicit in Shoenï¬eldâ€™s proof in [1961].
Lemma 25.22 is due to Kechris and Moschovakis [1972].
Theorem 25.23 is due to Mansï¬eld [1970] and Solovay [1969]. Lemma 25.24 was
formulated and ï¬rst proved by Mansï¬eld.
Theorem 25.26 and corollaries: In his announcement [1938] GÂ¨odel stated that
the Axiom of Constructibility implies that there exists a nonmeasurable âˆ†1
2 set
and an uncountable Î 1
1 set without a perfect subset. GÂ¨odel did not publish the
proof but gave an outline in the second printing (in 1951) of his monograph [1940].

25. Descriptive Set Theory
509
Novikov in [1951] gave a proof of the corollaries (Kuratowskiâ€™s paper [1948] contains
somewhat weaker results) and Addison in [1959] worked out the details of GÂ¨odel
outline of the proof of the theorem.
Lemma 25.30: Solovay [1967].
For scales and uniformization, see Moschovakisâ€™ book [1980]. Moschovakis in-
troduced scales in [1971].
Theorem 25.38: Solovay [1969].
Theorem 25.39: Mansï¬eld [1975].
Theorem 25.42 (as well as the present proof) is due to Martin; and Theo-
rem 25.43 is due to Kunen and Martin, the present proof is Kunenâ€™s.
Borel codes are as in Solovay [1970].
The reduction and separation principles were introduced by Kuratowski; they
are discussed in detail in Kuratowskiâ€™s book [1966] and in Addison [1959].
Exercise 25.7: Kuratowski [1936].

26. The Real Line
This chapter deals with some properties of the real line, primarily with ques-
tions concerning measure and category. Among others we present the theorem
of Solovay establishing the consistency of the statement â€œevery set of reals is
Lebesgue measurable.â€
Random and Cohen reals
Let us consider generic extensions using either the algebra of Borel sets mod-
ulo the ideal of null sets or the algebra of Borel sets modulo the ideal of
meager sets.
Let B be the Ïƒ-algebra of Borel sets of reals, let Im and Ic (m for measure,
c for category) be the Ïƒ-ideals
Im = {B âˆˆB : Âµ(B) = 0},
Ic = {B âˆˆB : B is meager}
and let
(26.1)
Bm = B/Im = {[B]m : B âˆˆB},
Bc = B/Ic = {[B]c : B âˆˆB}
where [B]m and [B]c denote equivalence classes mod Im and mod Ic, respec-
tively. Bm and Bc are complete Boolean algebras and if Bn, n âˆˆÏ‰, are Borel
sets then (in either Bm or Bc),
âˆ

n=0
[Bn] =
 âˆ

n=0

The following lemma provides a characterization of random and Cohen
reals.
Lemma 26.4. A real number is random over M if and only if it does not
belong to any null Borel set coded in M, and is Cohen over M if and only if
it does not belong to any meager Borel set coded in M.

Solovay Sets of Reals
Let M be a transitive model of ZFC. Let S be a set of reals. We say that the
set S is Solovay over M if there is a formula Ï•(x), with parameters in M,
such that for all reals x,
(26.13)
x âˆˆS â†”M[x] âŠ¨Ï•(x).
Lemma 26.5. Let S be a Solovay set of reals over M. There exist Borel sets
A and B such that
S âˆ©R(M) = A âˆ©R(M)
and
S âˆ©C(M) = B âˆ©C(M).
Proof. Let us prove the lemma for random reals. Let us consider the forcing

ultraï¬lter on Bm, and let Ë™a be the canonical name for a random real; i.e., let
Ë™a be the Bm-valued name deï¬ned in M Bm from Ë™G, by (26.6): âˆ¥Ë™a = xGâˆ¥= 1.
Let Ï•(x) be a formula with parameters in M such that (26.13) holds for
all x. Let Ac âˆˆB be such that [Ac] = âˆ¥Ï•(Ë™a)âˆ¥and let A = Aâˆ—
c. The set A is
a Borel set (in the universe); we claim that for all x âˆˆR(M), x belongs to S
if and only if x belongs to A. But if x is random over M, let G be M-generic
on Bm such that x = xG; then Ë™a is a name for x and we have

âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 26.6. Let S be a Solovay set of reals over M.
(i) If the set of all reals that are not random over M is null, then S is
Lebesgue measurable.
(ii) If the set of all reals that are not Cohen over M is meager, then S has
the property of Baire.
Proof. Under the assumptions of the corollary, S â–³A is null and S â–³B is
meager.

The LÂ´evy Collapse
We review properties of the forcing that collapses uncountable cardinals to â„µ0,
and establish the homogeneity of the LÂ´evy collapse.
If Î» is an inï¬nite cardinal, let PÎ» denote the set of all ï¬nite sequences
(26.14)
p = âŸ¨p(0), . . . , p(n âˆ’1)âŸ©
(n âˆˆÏ‰)
of ordinals less than Î» and let Col(â„µ0, Î») = B(PÎ»).
The following lemma provides a characterization of the collapsing algebra:
Lemma 26.7. Let (Q, <) be a notion of forcing such that |Q| = Î» > â„µ0 and
such that Q collapses Î» onto â„µ0, i.e.,
âˆ¥Ë‡Î» is countableâˆ¥B(Q) = 1.
Then B(Q) = Col(â„µ0, Î»).
Proof. Without loss of generality we may assume that (Q, <) is a separative
partial ordering. We shall ï¬nd a dense subset of Q isomorphic to PÎ».
Let B = B(Q), and let Ë™G be the canonical name for the generic ï¬lter
on Q. Let Ë™f âˆˆV B be such that
âˆ¥Ë™f maps Ë‡Ï‰ onto Ë™Gâˆ¥B = 1.
For each p âˆˆPÎ», we shall construct q(p) âˆˆQ such that D = {q(p) : p âˆˆPÎ»}
is dense in Q and that p â†’q(p) is an isomorphism of PÎ» onto D. We con-
struct q(p) by induction on the length of p.
If p = âŸ¨p(0)âŸ©, we construct q(p) as follows: Since Q collapses Î», there
exists an antichain W âŠ‚Q of size Î». Moreover, we may ï¬nd such W of size Î»
with the additional property that each w âˆˆW decides

qw âˆˆQ such that w âŠ©Ë™f(0) = Ë‡qw. Thus let Wâˆ…be a maximal antichain with
these properties, Wâˆ…= {wÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î»}, and for each p = âŸ¨p(0)âŸ©âˆˆPÎ» we let

q(pâŒ¢Î¾), Î¾ < Î», as follows: We let Wp = {wÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î»} be a maximal antichain
below q(p) such that |Wp| = Î» and that each w âˆˆWp decides Ë™f(n). Then we
let q(pâŒ¢Î¾) = wÎ¾, for all wÎ¾ âˆˆWp.
The set D = {q(p) : p âˆˆPÎ»} is clearly isomorphic to PÎ». Let us show that
D is dense in Q. Let q âˆˆQ be arbitrary. Since q âŠ©Ë‡q âˆˆË™G, and q âŠ©Ë‡q âˆˆran( Ë™f),
there is r â‰¤q and n < Ï‰ such that r âŠ©q = Ë™f(n). Now there is p âˆˆPÎ»

separative, it follows that q(p) â‰¤q. This proves that D is dense in Q.

Corollary 26.8 (Kripke). If B is a complete Boolean algebra and |B| â‰¤Î»
then B embeds as a complete subalgebra of Col(â„µ0, Î»).

B is isomorphic to a complete subalgebra of Col(â„µ0, Î»).

Lemma 26.9. Let B be a complete Boolean algebra, |B| = Î». Let C be a com-

Corollary 26.10. Let G be a generic ï¬lter on PÎ» and let X be a set of

to PÎ». If Î» is countable in V [X] and V [X] Ì¸= V [G], then V [G] is a generic

LÂ´evy collapse P, and let X be a countable set of ordinals in V [G]. Then there

Solovayâ€™s Theorem
Theorem 26.14 (Solovay). Assume that there exits an inaccessible cardi-
nal.
(i) There is a model of ZF + DC in which all sets of real numbers are
Lebesgue measurable and have the property of Baire, and every un-
countable set of reals has a perfect subset.
(ii) There is a model of ZFC in which every projective set of reals is
Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property, and if uncountable, then
it contains a perfect subset.
Let M be a transitive model of ZFC and let Îº be an inaccessible cardinal
in M. Let B be the LÂ´evy collapse for Îº, i.e., B = B(P) where P is the notion
of forcing that collapses each Î± < Îº onto â„µ0: The conditions are functions p
on subsets of ÎºÃ—Ï‰ such that each dom(p) is ï¬nite, and p(Î±, n) < Î± whenever
(Î±, n) âˆˆdom(p).
Let G be an M-generic ultraï¬lter on B. We shall show that in M[G] every
projective set of reals is Lebesgue measurable, has the property of Baire, and
if uncountable, then it contains a perfect subset.
In M[G], let S be the class of all inï¬nite sequences of ordinal numbers,
S = OrdÏ‰, and let N = HOD(S) be the class of all sets hereditarily ordinal
deï¬nable over S. The class N is a model of ZF; in fact, N is a model of
ZF + DC (see Lemma 26.15 below), and we shall show that in N every set
of reals is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property, and if uncountable,
then it contains a perfect subset.
Let s be an inï¬nite sequence of ordinals in M[G], let Ï• be a formula, and
let X âˆˆM[G] be a set such that
(26.15)
X = {x : M[G] âŠ¨Ï•(x, s)}.
X is (in M[G]) ordinal deï¬nable over S = OrdÏ‰. Conversely, if X âˆˆOD(S),
then for some formula Ïˆ and a ï¬nite sequence âŸ¨s1, . . . , skâŸ©of elements of S,
X = {x âˆˆM[G] : Ïˆ(x, âŸ¨s1, . . . , skâŸ©)}. Then clearly there exist Ï• and s âˆˆS
such that (26.15) holds. Hence the class OD(S) consists of all sets X of the
form (26.15)â€”sets deï¬nable in M[G] from a sequence of ordinals.
Note that every projective set of reals is deï¬nable from a sequence of
ordinals: If A is Î£1
n(a) for some a âˆˆN, then A is deï¬nable in HC from a,
and therefore A âˆˆOD(S).
Lemma 26.15.
(i) If f âˆˆM[G] is a function on Ï‰ with values in N, then f âˆˆN.
(ii) The model N satisï¬es the Principle of Dependent Choices.
Proof. (i) We show that if f is a function from Ï‰ into OD(S) then f âˆˆOD(S).
By (26.15), OD(S) = {OD(s) : s âˆˆS}; therefore there is a deï¬nable

function F on Ord Ã—S such that for each s âˆˆS, the function Fs(Î±) = F(Î±, s)
maps Ord onto OD(s). Let f : Ï‰ â†’OD(S). For each n, we choose Î±n and sn
such that f(n) = F(Î±n, sn). Clearly, f is deï¬nable from âŸ¨Î±n : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©and
âŸ¨sn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©. It is easy to ï¬nd a single sequence u of ordinals such that both
âŸ¨Î±n : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©and âŸ¨sn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©are deï¬nable from u. Hence f is deï¬nable
from u, and so f âˆˆOD(S).
(ii) In N, let Ï be a relation over a nonempty set A such that for every
x âˆˆA there is a y such that y Ï x. Since M[G] satisï¬es the Axiom of Choice,
there exists in M[G] a sequence a0, a1, . . . , an, . . . such that an+1 Ï an
for all n. However, by part (i) of this lemma, the sequence âŸ¨an : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©is
in N.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall now prove the part of Theorem 26.14 dealing with Lebesgue
measure and the Baire property, using Lemma 26.5.
Lemma 26.16. Let s âˆˆM[G] be an inï¬nite sequence of ordinals. The set of
all reals (in M[G]) that are not random over M[s] is null; the set of all reals
that are not Cohen over M[s] is meager.
Proof. Since the algebra B is Îº-saturated, there exists a subalgebra D âŠ‚B
such that |D| < Îº and M[s] = M[D âˆ©G]. It follows that Îº is inaccessible
in M[s]; and since Îº = â„µM[G]
1
, M[s] has only countably many subsets of Ï‰.
Thus there are only countably many Borel codes in M[s]; and by (26.11), the
complement of the set R(M[s]) is the union of countably many null sets and
hence null. Similarly, the complement of C(M[s]) is meager.

from a sequence s of ordinals. Then X is (in M[G]) Solovay over M[s].

a formula Ï•, there is a formula ËœÏ• such that for every sequence of ordinals
x âˆˆM[G],

if and only if
M[x] âŠ¨ËœÏ•(x).

an M[x]-generic ï¬lter H on P such that M[G] = M[x][H]. Arguing in M[x],

Corollary 26.18. In M[G] every set of reals deï¬nable from a sequence of
ordinals (and in particular, every projective set of reals) is Lebesgue measur-
able and has the property of Baire.
Proof. This follows from Lemmas 26.5 26.16, and 26.17.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 26.19. In N, every set of reals is Lebesgue measurable and has
the property of Baire.
Proof. Clearly, the model N has the same reals as the model M[G]. In partic-
ular, N and M[G] have the same Borel codes, and since AM
c
= AM[G]
c
âˆ©N =
AM[G]
c
for every c âˆˆBCM[G], the two models have the same Borel sets.
If X âˆˆN is a set of reals, then X is deï¬nable in M[G] from a sequence
of ordinals and hence M[G] âŠ¨(X is Lebesgue measurable and has the Baire
property). Thus there are (in M[G]) Borel sets A, B, H, K such that Xâ–³A âŠ‚
H, X â–³B âŠ‚K, and H is null and K is meager (in M[G]). By Lemma 26.1,
N satisï¬es that H is null and K is meager, and hence N satisï¬es that X is
Lebesgue measurable and has the Baire property.

We shall now ï¬nish the proof of Theorem 26.14 by showing that in M[G]
every uncountable set of reals deï¬nable from a countable sequence of ordinals
contains a perfect subset. Then it follows that in N, every uncountable set A
of reals has a perfect subset: If A is uncountable in N, then A is uncountable
in M[G] (by Lemma 26.15); and since A is deï¬nable from a sequence of
ordinals, A has a perfect subset F (in M[G]); but then N âŠ¨F is a perfect
set.

By Lemma 26.17, every set of reals deï¬nable in M[G] from s is Solovay
over M[s]; thus it suï¬ƒces to prove that in M[G] every uncountable set of

case (Solovay over M[s]) follows from the special case by the Factor Lemma:
M[G] = M[s][H] is a generic extension of M[s] by the LÂ´evy collapse. And

is a perfect subset of A.

Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Ramsey Sets of Reals and Mathias Forcing
For an inï¬nite set A âŠ‚Ï‰, let [A]Ï‰ denote the set of all inï¬nite subsets of A.
Let us consider the following partition property for [Ï‰]Ï‰: If S âŠ‚[Ï‰]Ï‰, we call
an inï¬nite set H âŠ‚Ï‰ homogeneous for S if either [H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S or [H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ….
A set S âŠ‚[Ï‰]Ï‰ is a Ramsey set if there exists an inï¬nite homogeneous set H
for S.
A consequence of the Axiom of Choice is that not every set S âŠ‚[Ï‰]Ï‰ is
Ramsey (Exercise 26.3). We prove that the Axiom of Choice is necessary, and
that all analytic sets are Ramsey.
Identifying subsets of Ï‰ with their characteristic functions, we con-
sider [Ï‰]Ï‰ as a GÎ´ subspace of the Cantor space. We prove the following
theorems:
Theorem 26.22 (Galvin-Prikry, Silver). Every analytic subset of [Ï‰]Ï‰
is Ramsey.
Theorem 26.23 (Mathias). Let M[G] and N be the models from Theo-
rem 26.14.
(i) In N, every subset of [Ï‰]Ï‰ is Ramsey.
(ii) In M[G], every projective subset of [Ï‰]Ï‰ is Ramsey.
The method of proof of both theorems uses a notion of forcing introduced
by Mathias, and a topology based on the Mathias forcing.
Deï¬nition 26.24 (Mathias Forcing). A forcing condition is a pair (s, A)
where s is a ï¬nite subset of Ï‰ and A is an inï¬nite subset of Ï‰ such that
max s < min A. A condition (s, A) is stronger than a condition (t, B) if
(i) t is an initial segment of s;
(ii) A âŠ‚B;
(iii) s âˆ’t âŠ‚B.
(26.19)
(Compare this with the Prikry forcing (21.15).) For the rest of this section,
(s, A) will denote a Mathias forcing condition.
For s âˆˆ[Ï‰]<Ï‰ and A âˆˆ[Ï‰]Ï‰, let Aâˆ–s = Aâˆ’(max(s)+1) = {n âˆˆA : n > k
for all k âˆˆs}, and
(26.20)
[s, A]Ï‰ = {X âˆˆ[Ï‰]Ï‰ : s âŠ‚X and X âˆ–s âŠ‚A}.
Note that [âˆ…, A]Ï‰ = [A]Ï‰, and [s, A]Ï‰ âŠ‚[t, B]Ï‰ if and only if (s, A) is
stronger than (t, B).
Deï¬nition 26.25. The Ellentuck topology on [Ï‰]Ï‰ has as basic open sets the
sets of the form [s, A]Ï‰ where s âˆˆ[Ï‰]<Ï‰ and A âˆˆ[Ï‰]Ï‰.
Note that every open set in the usual topology is open in the Ellentuck
topology.

26. The Real Line
525
Deï¬nition 26.26 (Galvin-Prikry).
(i) A set S âŠ‚[Ï‰]Ï‰ is completely Ramsey if for every (s, A) there exists an
inï¬nite H âŠ‚A such that either [s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S or [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ….
(ii) A set N âŠ‚[Ï‰]Ï‰ is Ramsey null if for every (s, A) there exists an inï¬nite
H âŠ‚A such that [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ….
We ï¬rst observe that every Ramsey null set is nowhere dense in the El-
lentuck topology: S is nowhere dense if and only if for every basic open set
there exists a basic open subset disjoint from S, i.e.,
âˆ€(s, A) âˆƒ(t, B) < (s, A) [t, B]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ….
Let S be completely Ramsey, let int(S) denote the interior of S (in the
Ellentuck topology), and let N = S âˆ’int(S). For every (s, A) there exists
an H âŠ‚A such that either [s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S, and since [s, H]Ï‰ is open, we have
[s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚int(S); or [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ…, and in either case [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©N = âˆ…. Hence
N is Ramsey null, and therefore nowhere dense. It follows that S = int(S)âˆªN
has the Baire property.
We shall prove the following (for the Ellentuck topology):
Lemma 26.27.
(i) A set S is completely Ramsey if and only if it has the Baire property.
(ii) A set N is Ramsey null if and only if it is nowhere dense if and only
if it is meager.
Toward the proof of Lemma 26.27, let S be a given subset of [Ï‰]Ï‰. Given
(s, A) we say that A accepts s if [s, A]Ï‰ âŠ‚S; we say that A rejects s if no
X âŠ‚A accepts s.
Lemma 26.28. There is an X that accepts or rejects each of its ï¬nite subset.
Proof. Let X0 be such that X0 either accepts or rejects âˆ…(if no X accepts âˆ…
then X0 = Ï‰ rejects âˆ…). Let a0 be the least element of X0. Let X1 âŠ‚X
be such that X1 either accepts or rejects each subset of {a0}. Let a1 be the
least element of X1 âˆ–{a0}, and let X2 âŠ‚X1 be such that X2 accepts or
rejects each subset of {a0, a1}. We continue in this fashion and construct
a set X = {a0, a1, a2, . . .}. This X accepts or rejects each of its ï¬nite subsets.

subsets.

s âŠ‚{a0, . . . , anâˆ’1} there are only ï¬nitely many z âˆˆX such that X accepts

Lemma 26.30. Every open set is Ramsey.

such that [s, Y âˆ–s]Ï‰ âŠ‚S. Hence Y accepts s, contrary to the assumption
that X rejects s.

Lemma 26.31. Every open set is completely Ramsey.

then H = fâ€œK satisï¬es either [s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S or [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ….

[s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S or [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ…. But [s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S is impossible since S is
nowhere dense.

Proof of Lemma 26.27. By Lemmas 26.32 and 26.33, every meager set is

By (ii) there is some X âŠ‚A such that [s, X]Ï‰ âˆ©M = âˆ…. By Lemma 26.31
there is some H âŠ‚X such that either [s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚G or [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©G = âˆ…. It
follows that either [s, H]Ï‰ âŠ‚S or [s, H]Ï‰ âˆ©S = âˆ….
âŠ“âŠ”

26. The Real Line
527
Proof of Theorem 26.22. Every analytic set (in the usual topology) is the
result of the Suslin operation A applied to closed sets. Every closed set is
closed in the Ellentuck topology and therefore has the Baire property (in the
Ellentuck topology). It can be proved (as in Theorem 11.18) that the Baire
property in the Ellentuck topology is preserved under the operation A. Hence
every analytic set is completely Ramsey, by Lemma 26.27(i).
âŠ“âŠ”
The combinatorial content of Lemma 26.27 is this property of Mathias
forcing (compare with Lemma 21.12):
Lemma 26.34. Let Ïƒ be a sentence of the forcing language and let (s, A)
be a condition. Then there exists an inï¬nite set B âŠ‚A such that (s, B)
decides Ïƒ.
Proof. Let Q+ = {p : p âŠ©Ïƒ}, Qâˆ’= {p : p âŠ©Â¬Ïƒ}, S+ = {[t, X]Ï‰ : (t, X) âˆˆ
Q+} and Sâˆ’= {[t, X]Ï‰ : (t, X) âˆˆQâˆ’}. Since the complement of S+ âˆªSâˆ’
is nowhere dense, there exists, by Lemma 26.27, an inï¬nite B âŠ‚A such that
[s, B]Ï‰ âŠ‚S+ or [s, B]Ï‰ âŠ‚Sâˆ’. We claim that in the former case (s, B) âŠ©Ïƒ
and in the latter case (s, B) âŠ©Â¬Ïƒ. This is because for every (t, X) < (s, B)
there exists some (u, Y ) < (t, X) which is in Q+ (or Qâˆ’).

Mathias reals admit the following characterization, analogous to Theo-
rem 21.14:
Theorem 26.35 (Mathias). Let M be a transitive model of ZFC. An in-
ï¬nite set x âŠ‚Ï‰ is a Mathias real over M if and only if for every maximal
almost disjoint family A âˆˆM of subsets of Ï‰, there exists an X âˆˆA such
that x âˆ’X is ï¬nite.
Proof. The condition is necessary: If A is a maximal almost disjoint family
then D = {(s, A âˆ–s) : s âˆˆ[Ï‰]<Ï‰, A âˆˆA} is a predense set of forcing
conditions, and it follows that if x is a Mathias real then Gx âˆ©D Ì¸= âˆ….
For the proof of suï¬ƒciency, let D be an open dense set of Mathias forc-

Mathias forcing. If X âŠ‚Ï‰ is inï¬nite and max s < min X we say that X cap-
tures (s, D) if for every inï¬nite Y âŠ‚X there exists an initial segment t of Y
such that (s âˆªt, X) âˆˆD.

Lemma 26.36. For every inï¬nite set A âŠ‚Ï‰ and for every ï¬nite s âŠ‚Ï‰ there

of conditions).

Measure and Category
Lebesgue measure and Baire property have been the most thoroughly inves-
tigated properties of sets of reals, both in the classical descriptive set theory,
and in the modern era of independence results. We shall touch brieï¬‚y on
the subject, with emphasis on the role of Martinâ€™s Axiom and combinato-
rial â€œcardinal invariants.â€ We start with the following application of Martinâ€™s
Axiom:
Theorem 26.39 (Martin-Solovay). If Martinâ€™s Axiom holds, then the
union of fewer than 2â„µ0 null sets is null, and the union of fewer than 2â„µ0
meager sets is meager.
Proof. First we prove that the union of fewer than 2â„µ0 null sets is mull. Let
Îº < 2â„µ0 and let AÎ±, Î± < Îº, be null sets of reals. Let A = 
Î±<Îº AÎ±. In order
to prove that A is null, it suï¬ƒces to ï¬nd, for each Îµ > 0, an open set U âŠƒA
such that Âµ(U) â‰¤Îµ. Let Îµ > 0.
We apply Martinâ€™s Axiom as follows. Let P be the set of all open sets of
measure < Îµ, and let p âˆˆP be stronger than q âˆˆP if p âŠƒq. We claim that
the notion of forcing (P, âŠƒ) satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
It suï¬ƒces to show that if W is an uncountable subset of P, then there
are p, q âˆˆW, p Ì¸= q, such that Âµ(p âˆªq) < Îµ. Let S be the countable set of

The proof of Theorem 26.39 yields a slightly better result: It shows that
for every Îº â‰¤2â„µ0, MAÎº implies the Îº-additivity of the ideals of null and
meager sets. The study of additivity of measure and category initiated by

532
Part II. Advanced Set Theory
Theorem 26.39 developed into an extensive theory that established a detailed
relationship between various properties of measure and category. We refer the
reader to BartoszyÂ´nskiâ€™s article [âˆ] in the Handbook of Set Theory.
Deï¬nition 26.43. (i) Additivity:
add(LM) = the least cardinal Îº such that the union of some family of Îº null
sets is not null,
add(BP) = the least cardinal Îº such that the union of some family of Îº mea-
ger sets is not meager.
(ii) Covering:
cov(LM) = the least cardinal Îº for which R is the union of Îº null sets,
cov(BP) = the least cardinal Îº for which R is the union of Îº meager sets.
(iii) Uniformity:
unif(LM) = the least cardinal Îº such that there exists a set of cardinality Îº
that is not null,
unif(BP) = the least cardinal Îº such that there exists a set of cardinality Îº
that is not meager.
(iv) Coï¬nality:
cof(LM) = the least cardinality of a family F of null sets such that every
null set is included in a set from F,
cof(BP) = the least cardinality of a family F of meager sets such that every
meager set is included in a set from F.
The proof of Theorem 26.39 shows that MAÎº implies add(LM) â‰¥Îº and
add(BP) â‰¥Îº. In a series of results a complete picture of inequalities emerged
between these properties. First, it is obvious that add â‰¤cov â‰¤cof and
add â‰¤unif â‰¤cof, both for measure and category (Exercise 26.5). Secondly,
two of the inequalities have been known classically; see Exercise 26.7.
Before we proceed we introduce two cardinal invariants that are not only
relevant in this context but appear frequently in results in set-theoretic topol-
ogy. First some notation:
âˆ€âˆ
means
for all but ï¬nitely many n âˆˆÏ‰,
âˆƒâˆ
means
for inï¬nitely many n âˆˆÏ‰.
A family F âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰ is a dominating family if
(26.28)
âˆ€g âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰ âˆƒf âˆˆF âˆ€âˆn g(n) < f(n);
F us an unbounded family if
(26.29)
âˆ€g âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰ âˆƒf âˆˆF âˆƒâˆn g(n) â‰¤f(n).

26. The Real Line
533
Deï¬nition 26.44. The dominating number
d = the least cardinality of a dominating family;
the bounding number
b = the least cardinality of an unbounded family.
It is clear that b â‰¤d, and â„µ1 â‰¤b â‰¤d â‰¤c. Martinâ€™s Axiom implies that
b = d = c; see Exercise 26.8.
To see the signiï¬cance of b and d for Baire category, notice that for each
f âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰ and each k, the set {g âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰ : âˆ€n â‰¥k g(n) < f(n)} is nowhere
dense (in the space N). Hence if g < f means âˆ€âˆn g(n) < f(n), each set
{g : g < f} is meager, and it follows that b â‰¤unif(BP) and cov(BP) â‰¤d; see
Exercise 26.10.
The relationship between the invariants deï¬ned in 26.43 and 26.44 can be
illustrated by the following diagram:
add(LM)

The cardinals become larger as one moves right and up. Exercises 26.5, 26.7,
and 26.10 give proofs of the easy inequalities. The remaining inequalities are
given by these theorems (that we state without proofs):
Theorem 26.45 ((i) Truss, Miller; (ii) Fremlin).
(i) add(BP) = min{b, cov(BP)}.
(ii) cof(BP) = max{d, unif(BP)}.
Theorem 26.46 (BartoszyÂ´nski, Raisonnier-Stern).
(i) add(LM) â‰¤add(BP).
(ii) cof(BP) â‰¤cof(LM).
It is no accident that each result is accompanied by a dual version: There
is a general theory that explains this duality. (For details, see BartoszyÂ´nskiâ€™s
Handbook article.) For instance, consider Theorem 26.46. Both (i) and (ii)
can be proved from this general result (see Exercise 26.11):

Part II. Advanced Set Theory

the property that for every family F âŠ‚Im, if  F is null then  Ï•âˆ’1(F) is
meager.

A signiï¬cant part of the theory of invariants of measure and category

Theorem 26.49. add(LM) is the least cardinality of a family F âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰ such

The diagram, along with Theorem 26.45, gives a complete relationship
among these invariants. Nothing else can be proved in ZFC, and models have
been constructed verifying all independence results based on the diagram.
We conclude this chapter with two of the earliest independence results
concerning measure and category. We give an example of a model where
2â„µ0 is large and the set R âˆ©L is not Lebesgue measurable, and another
example where 2â„µ0 is large and R âˆ©L does not have the Baire property.
Lemma 26.50. If there exists a nonconstructible real, then:
(i) R âˆ©L is either null or not Lebesgue measurable.
(ii) R âˆ©L is either meager or does not have the Baire property.
Proof. (i) Let S be the set of all constructible reals in the unit interval [0, 1].
Let a be a nonconstructible real. For each n > 0, let Sn = {x+(a/n) : x âˆˆS}.
The sets Sn are pairwise disjoint, Âµ(Sn) = Âµ(S) for all n and âˆ
n=0 Sn is
a bounded set. Therefore if S is measurable, then Âµ(S) > 0 is impossible.

26. The Real Line
535
(ii) Let S be the set of all constructible reals. First we prove that R âˆ’S
is not meager. Let a be a nonconstructible real and let Sa = {x + a : x âˆˆS};
clearly, Sâˆ©Sa = âˆ…. Thus R = (Râˆ’S)âˆª(Râˆ’Sa)âˆª(Sâˆ©Sa) = (Râˆ’S)âˆª(Râˆ’Sa),
and if Râˆ’S were meager, then Râˆ’Sa would also be meager, a contradiction.
It follows that for any nonempty interval I, I âˆ’S is not meager: For each
rational r, let Ar = {x + r : x âˆˆI âˆ’S}; if I âˆ’S is meager, then each Ar is
meager, and R âˆ’S = {Ar : r is rational}.
If S has the Baire property, then because U âˆ’S is not meager for any
nonempty open set U, S is meager.

Historical Notes
The model in which all sets of reals are Lebesgue measurable is due to Solo-
vay [1970], as is the concept of random reals, as well as Lemmas 26.1, 26.2, 26.4, 26.5,
the Factor Lemma (Corollary 26.11), 26.16, and Theorem 26.20. Corollary 26.8 is
due to Kripke [1967], and Theorem 26.12 is due to Jensen.
Galvin and Prikry proved in [1973] that every Borel set is Ramsey; this was
extended by Silver in [1970b] to analytic sets, and Ellentuck [1974] gave the proof
of Theorem 26.22 that we reproduce here. Theorem 26.23 is due to Mathias [1977].
Theorem 26.39 is due to Martin and Solovay [1970]. A systematic study of the
properties of measure and category from Deï¬nition 26.43 was started by Miller
in [1981], although the two results in Exercise 26.7 were proved by Rothberger
in [1938]. Similarly, there had been various scattered results on what is now known
as cardinal invariants (such as b, d, etc.) but the ï¬rst comprehensive account ap-
peared in van Douwenâ€™s [1984]. A most recent survey of the results stated here is
BartoszyÂ´nskiâ€™s chapter [âˆ] in the Handbook of Set Theory. Theorem 26.45(i) is
due to Truss [1977] and Miller [1981]. Theorem 26.46 was proved independently by
BartoszyÂ´nski [1984] and Raisonnier and Stern [1985]; Pawlikowskiâ€™s Theorem 26.47
followed in [1985]. Theorems 26.48 and 26.49 BartoszyÂ´nski [1987] and [1984].
Example 26.51 is due to Solovay, and Example 26.52 is due to VopË‡enka and
HrbÂ´aË‡cek [1967].
Exercise 26.2: Judah and Shelah [1989].
Exercise 26.3: ErdËos and Rado [1952].
Exercise 26.10: Rothberger [1941].
Exercise 26.13: BartoszyÂ´nski [1984].
Strong measure zero sets were introduced by Borel [1919].
Exercise 26.15: Marczewski [1930b].
Exercise 26.16: Kunen.
Exercise 26.17: Luzin [1914].
Exercise 26.18: SierpiÂ´nski [1928].

26. The Real Line
541
Exercise 26.19: Rothberger [1941].
Exercise 26.20: the argument is due to ErdËos.
Exercise 26.22: Rothberger.

Part III
Selected Topics

27. Combinatorial Principles in L
The Fine Structure Theory
In his paper [1972], Ronald Jensen embarked on a detailed analysis of the
levels of the constructible hierarchy. The resulting theory, the ï¬ne structure
theory, describes precisely how new sets arise in the construction of L, and has
signiï¬cant applications. Historically, the ï¬rst application of the ï¬ne structure
theory was Jensenâ€™s proof of â–¡Îº in L, and we shall use that as a motivation
for the introduction of ï¬ne-structural concepts. We have already described
another, later, application of Jensenâ€™s theory, the Covering Theorem 18.30.
While Magidorâ€™s proof presented in Chapter 18 does not use the full force of
the ï¬ne structure theory, it can serve as a starting point toward the study of
ï¬ne structure.
We have seen that the constructible hierarchy is Î£1, in a uniform way,
and we have also seen the role played by the condensation arguments. In
particular we mention Lemma 18.38, the Condensation Lemma, stating that
every Î£1-elementary submodel of LÎ± is isomorphic to some LÎ³, for every
inï¬nite ordinal Î±.
Every LÎ± (for Î± â‰¥Ï‰) has a Î£1 Skolem function, with a Î£1 deï¬nition
independent of Î±. Precisely, there is a Î£0 formula Î¦ such that for every
Î± â‰¥Ï‰, the (partial) function hÎ± : Ï‰ Ã— LÎ± â†’LÎ± deï¬ned by
(27.1)
y = hÎ±(n, x) â†”(LÎ±, âˆˆ) âŠ¨âˆƒz Î¦(n, x, y, z)
is a Î£1 Skolem function for LÎ± in the sense that for every X âŠ‚LÎ±,
(27.2)
hÎ±â€œ(Ï‰ Ã— X) = HÎ±
1 (X)
is the Î£1 Skolem hull of X in LÎ±. This can be deduced by using the
Î£1 well-ordering <L, as in (18.5). (For details, we refer the reader to De-
vlinâ€™s book [1984], in particular Lemma II.6.5.)
In Chapter 18 we introduced Î£n Skolem functions for n > 1 as well,
but mentioned (following Deï¬nition 18.40) that a Î£n Skolem function is not
necessarily a Î£n function. In fact, for n > 1 there is no uniform Î£2 Skolem
function (in the sense of (27.1)â€“(27.2)); for details, see Exercises on pages

To overcome this obstacle, Jensen introduced an elaborate machinery by
which arguments about Î£n predicates on LÎ± can be reduced to arguments
about Î£1 predicates on a structure (LÏ, A) which in some sense describes the
Î£n properties on LÎ±.
The Principle â–¡Îº
We recall (cf. (23.4)) that for an uncountable cardinal Îº, a square-sequence is
a sequence âŸ¨CÎ± : Î± âˆˆLim(Îº+)âŸ©such that every CÎ± is closed unbounded in Î±,

In [1972], Jensen proved that in L, every uncountable cardinal Îº has a square-
sequence.
Theorem 27.1 (Jensen). If V = L then â–¡Îº holds for every uncountable
cardinal Îº.
To illustrate how the proof of â–¡Îº uses condensation principles, and to

The Jensen Hierarchy
One of the technical obstacles in the analysis how constructible sets arise in
the hierarchy LÎ± is that the sets LÎ± are not closed under the formation of
ordered pairs. This can be overcome by modifying the constructible hierarchy
in an inessential way. The resulting hierarchy JÎ± has become the preferred
tool for studying the ï¬ne structure of L and of more general inner models.
Deï¬nition 27.2 (Rudimentary Functions).
(i) F(x1, . . . , xn) = xi
(i = 1, . . . , n),
F(x1, . . . , xn) = {xi, xj}
(i, j = 1, . . . , n),
F(x1, . . . , xn) = xi âˆ’xj
(i, j = 1, . . . , n)
are rudimentary.
(ii) If G is rudimentary, then so is
F(y, x1, . . . , xnâˆ’1) = 
zâˆˆy
g(z, x1, . . . , xnâˆ’1).
(iii) A composition of rudimentary functions is rudimentary.
The rudimentary closure of a set X is the smallest Y âŠƒX closed under all
rudimentary functions. If X is transitive then so is its rudimentary closure,
and for every transitive set M, let
(27.8)
rud(M) = the rudimentary closure of M âˆª{M}.
It can be shown that for every transitive set M,
(27.9)
rud(M) âˆ©P(M) = def(M)
(compare with Corollary 13.8).

Diamond Principles
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal and let E be a stationary subset of Îº.
â™¦(E), or (more precisely) â™¦Îº(E), is the following principle (23.1):
(27.16)

Trees in L
Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal. Generalizing Deï¬nition 9.12, we have:
Deï¬nition 27.6. A Îº+-Suslin tree is a tree of height Îº+ such that every
branch and every antichain have cardinality at most Îº.
The following result generalizes Theorem 15.26:
Theorem 27.7 (Jensen). If V = L then for every inï¬nite cardinal Îº there
exists a Îº+-Suslin tree.
When Îº is regular, the proof is a straightforward generalization of the
construction of a Suslin tree using â™¦: instead we use â™¦(EÎº+
Îº ). We construct
a tree by induction on levels. At limit levels Î± of coï¬nality < Îº we extend
all branches in TÎ±; since Îº<Îº = Îº, the Î±th level has size Îº. If cf Î± = Îº then
we use Diamond to destroy potential antichains of size Îº+. Note that since
all branches have been extended at lower coï¬nalities, every x âˆˆTÎ± has an Î±-
branch in TÎ± going through x. The proof that the resulting tree is a Îº+-Suslin
tree is exactly as in Theorem 15.26.
When Îº is singular, this approach does not work as there are Îº+-branches
in TÎ± when cf Î± = cf Îº. By not extending all of them we cannot guarantee
that at a later stage Î², TÎ² has Î²-branches at all. Jensenâ€™s proof succeeds by
involving not only â™¦, but the â–¡Îº principle as well. The proof shows that if
â–¡Îº holds and if â™¦Îº+(E) for all E, then a Îº+-Suslin tree exists. For a proof,
see Devlin [1984], Theorem IV.2.4.
Let us recall (Deï¬nition 9.24) that a tree of height Ï‰1 is a Kurepa tree if
it has countable levels and at least â„µ2 uncountable branches.
Theorem 27.8 (Solovay). If V = L then there exists a Kurepa tree.
Proof. Assume V = L. We shall construct a family of subsets of Ï‰1 that
satisfy (9.12).

Lemma 27.10. If P is an â„µ0-closed notion of forcing and T is an Ï‰1-tree
in the ground model such that every level of T is countable, then T has no

pfâ†¾n, n âˆˆÏ‰. Since p0 âŠ©Ë™b is uncountable, there exist q < pf and xf at the
Î±th level of T such that q âŠ©xf âˆˆË™b. Now it is clear that xf Ì¸= xg whenever f
and g are distinct 0â€“1 functions on Ï‰. Thus the Î±th level of T has at least 2â„µ0
elements, contrary to our assumption.
âŠ“âŠ”
It follows immediately from the lemma that in V [G], no tree T âˆˆV whose
levels are countable can be a Kurepa tree: Since every branch of T in V [G] is
in V , T has at most (2â„µ1)V branches, but (2â„µ1)V < Î» = â„µV [G]
2
, and so T has
(in V [G]) fewer than â„µ2 branches.
A similar argument can be used for any tree in V [G], with a slight modiï¬-
cation. For each Î± < Î», let PÎ± denote the set of all conditions whose domain
is a subset of Î± Ã— Ï‰1; similarly, let P Î± = {p âˆˆP : dom(p) âŠ‚(Îº âˆ’Î±) Ã— Ï‰1}.
Clearly, P is (isomorphic to) the product PÎ± Ã—P Î±. Let X âˆˆV [G] be a subset
of Ï‰1, and let Ë™X be a name of X; since P satisï¬es the Î»-chain condition, there

that âˆ¥Î¾ âˆˆË™Xâˆ¥= {p : p âˆˆWÎ¾}. There exists an Î± < Î» such that WÎ¾ âŠ‚PÎ±,
for all Î¾ < Ï‰1. It follows that X âˆˆV [G âˆ©PÎ±].
Now let T âˆˆV [G] be an Ï‰1-tree with countable levels. There exists an
Î± < Î» such that T âˆˆV [Gâˆ©PÎ±]. By the Product Lemma, Gâˆ©P Î± is P Î±-generic

Canonical Functions on Ï‰1
For ordinal functions on Ï‰1, let f < g if {Î¾ < Ï‰1 : f(Î¾) < g(Î¾)} contains
a closed unbounded set. The rank of f in < is the Galvin-Hajnal norm âˆ¥fâˆ¥;
cf. Deï¬nition 24.4. By induction on Î±, the Î±th canonical function fÎ± is deï¬ned
(if it exists) as the <-least ordinal function greater than each fÎ², Î² < Î±. If fÎ±
exists then it is unique up to the equivalence =INS. Lemma 24.5 shows that
for every Î± < Ï‰2 the Î±th canonical function exists; see also Exercise 27.6.
It is possible that the constant function Ï‰1 is the Ï‰2nd canonical function
(see Exercise 27.7) but this is known to have large cardinal consequences;
in particular, in L there is a function f : Ï‰1 â†’Ï‰1 such that âˆ¥fâˆ¥= Ï‰2
(Exercise 27.8).
If canonical functions fÎ± exist for all Î±, then the ideal INS is precipitous
(Exercise 27.10) and hence there is an inner model with a measurable cardi-
nal. Conversely, a combination of the method from Jech and Mitchell [1983]
with the proof of Theorem 23.10 yields the consistency, relative to a measur-
able cardinal, of canonical functions for all Î±.
The following result shows that in L, the Ï‰2nd canonical function does
not exist.
Theorem 27.11 (Hajnal). If V = L then there is no Ï‰2nd canonical func-
tion on Ï‰1.
Proof. Assume V = L, and assume that there is an Ï‰2nd canonical function.

The existence of an Ï‰2nd canonical function is not a large cardinal prop-
erty, as this consistency result shows:
Theorem 27.12 (Jech-Shelah). There is a generic extension of L in which
the Ï‰2nd canonical function exists.
The model is obtained by ï¬rst adding (by forcing with countable condi-
tions) an increasing sequence âŸ¨fÎ± : Î± â‰¤Ï‰2âŸ©of ordinal functions from Ï‰1
into Ï‰1. Then one uses an iterated forcing, with countable support of
length Ï‰2, that successively destroys all stationary subsets of Ï‰1 that wit-
ness that the sequence âŸ¨fÎ± : Î± â‰¤Ï‰2âŸ©is not canonical. For details, consult
Jech and Shelah [1989].

Historical Notes
The ï¬ne structure theory was introduced by Jensen in [1972]. The paper gives,
among others, proofs of â–¡Îº and of the existence of Îº+-Suslin trees in L. It also
formulates a combinatorial principle â™¦+ that implies the existence of a Kurepa
tree (abstracting Solovayâ€™s proof given here). Silverâ€™s model with no Kurepa trees
appears in [1971c]. Theorem 27.11 is an unpublished result of AndrÂ´as Hajnal
from 1976; the model in Theorem 27.11 is from Jech and Shelah [1989].
Exercises 27.2, 27.3: Solovay.
Exercise 27.4: Jensen.

28. More Applications of Forcing
In this chapter we present a selection of forcing constructions related to topics
discussed earlier in the book.
A Nonconstructible âˆ†1
3 Real
By Shoenï¬eldâ€™s Absoluteness Theorem, every Î 1
2 or Î£1
2 real is constructible;
on the other hand 0â™¯is a âˆ†1
3 real. We now present a model due to Jensen
that produces a nonconstructible âˆ†1
3 real by forcing over L.
Theorem 28.1 (Jensen). There is a generic extension L[a] of L such that
a is a âˆ†1
3 real.
The construction is a combination of perfect set forcing and arguments
using the â™¦-principle. Let us consider perfect trees p âŠ‚Seq({0, 1}), cf. (15.24).
The stem of a perfect tree p is the maximal s âˆˆSeq({0, 1}) such that for every
t âˆˆp, either t âŠ‚s or s âŠ‚t. If p is a perfect tree and if s âˆˆp, we denote by pâ†¾s
the perfect tree {t âˆˆp : t âŠ‚s or t âŠƒs}.
Assume that P is a set of perfect trees, partially ordered by âŠ‚, such that
if p âˆˆP and s âˆˆp, then pâ†¾s âˆˆP, and let G be an L-generic ï¬lter on P.
Then there is a unique f âˆˆ{0, 1}Ï‰ which is a branch in every p âˆˆG; and
conversely, G = {p âˆˆP : f is a branch in p}. Therefore L[G] = L[f], and we
call f P-generic over L. Note that f âˆˆ{0, 1}Ï‰ is P-generic over L if and only
if for every constructible predense set X âŠ‚P, f is a branch in some p âˆˆX.
Similarly, a generic ï¬lter G on P Ã— P corresponds to a unique pair (a, b)
such that for each (p, q) âˆˆG, a is a branch in p and b is a branch in q. A pair
(a, b) is (P Ã— P)-generic over L if and only if for every constructible predense
set X âŠ‚P Ã— P, there exists a pair (p, q) âˆˆX such that a is a branch in p
and b is a branch in q.
In Chapter 15 we used the Fusion Lemma for perfect trees. Let T =
{T (s) : s âˆˆSeq({0, 1})} be a collection of perfect trees such that for every s,
(i) T (s) is a perfect tree whose stem has length â‰¥length(s).
(ii) T (sâŒ¢0) âŠ‚T (s) and T (sâŒ¢1) âŠ‚T (s).
(iii) T (sâŒ¢0) and T (sâŒ¢1) have incompatible stems.

Namba Forcing
By Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem if Î» is a regular cardinal in L and V is a generic
extension of L, then either cf Î» = |Î»| or Î» < â„µ2. In other words, the only
nontrivial change of coï¬nality is to make |Î»| = â„µ1 and cf Î» = Ï‰. The following
model, due to Namba, does exactly that:
Theorem 28.10 (Namba). Assume CH. There is a generic extension V [G]
such that â„µV [G]
1
= â„µ1 and cfV [G](Ï‰V
2 ) = Ï‰.
Proof. Let S be the set of all ï¬nite sequences of ordinals less than Ï‰2, S =
Ï‰<Ï‰
2
. A tree is a set T âŠ‚S such that if t âˆˆT and s = tâ†¾n for some n, then
s âˆˆT . A nonempty tree T âŠ‚S is perfect if every t âˆˆT has â„µ2 extensions
s âŠƒt in T . (Note that then every t âˆˆT has â„µ2 incompatible extensions in T .)
In analogy with perfect sets in the Baire space, we have a Cantor-Bendixson
analysis of trees T âŠ‚S: Let

A Cohen Real Adds a Suslin Tree
We proved earlier that Suslin trees exist in L, and that adding generically
a subset of Ï‰1 with countable conditions adds a Suslin tree. It turns out that
adding a Cohen real also adds a Suslin tree. This result is due to Shelah; the
following proof is due to TodorË‡ceviÂ´c.
Theorem 28.12 (Shelah). If r is a Cohen real over V then in V [r] there
exists a Suslin tree.
Proof. We start with an alternative construction of an Aronszajn tree, a mod-
iï¬cation of the construction in Theorem 9.16.
Lemma 28.13. There exists an Ï‰1-sequence of functions âŸ¨eÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©such

(ii) for all Î± < Î² < Ï‰1, eÎ±(Î¾) = eÎ²(Î¾) for all but ï¬nitely many
Î¾ < Î±.
(28.12)
Proof. Exercise 28.1 (or see Kunen [1980], Theorem II.5.9).
âŠ“âŠ”
The set {eÎ±â†¾Î² : Î±, Î² âˆˆÏ‰1} ordered by inclusion is a tree. Since every
node at level Î± is a ï¬nite change of eÎ±, all levels are countable; there are no
uncountable branches and so the tree is an Aronszajn tree (Exercise 28.2).
For any function r : Ï‰ â†’Ï‰, consider the tree

Consistency of Borelâ€™s Conjecture
A set X of real numbers has strong measure zero if for every sequence âŸ¨Îµn :
n < Ï‰âŸ©of positive real numbers there is a sequence âŸ¨In : n < Ï‰âŸ©of intervals
with length(In) â‰¤Îµn such that X âŠ‚âˆ
n=0 In.
Borelâ€™s Conjecture. All strong measure zero sets are countable.
Borelâ€™s Conjecture fails under CHâ€”see Exercise 26.18. The following the-
orem shows that it is consistent with ZFC:
Theorem 28.14 (Laver). Assuming GCH there is a generic extension V [G]
in which 2â„µ0 = â„µ2 and Borelâ€™s Conjecture holds.
Laverâ€™s proof uses the countable support iteration (of length Ï‰2) of a forc-
ing notion that adds a Laver real. We shall now describe this forcing. (Subse-
quently, Laver proved that an iteration of Mathias forcing also yields Borelâ€™s
Conjecture).

âŠ“âŠ”

568
Part III. Selected Topics
Laverâ€™s model for the consistency of Borelâ€™s Conjecture is obtained by
iteration with countable support of length Ï‰2. At each stage of the itera-
tion, one adds a Laver real by forcing with Laver trees. If the ground model
satisï¬es GCH, then the iteration preserves cardinals and coï¬nalities, makes
2â„µ0 = â„µ2, and the resulting model satisï¬es Borelâ€™s Conjecture.
We state the relevant properties of Laverâ€™s model without proof:
Firstly, for every countable set X of ordinals in V [G] there is a set Y âˆˆV ,
countable in V , such that X âŠ‚Y . This is the analog of Lemma 28.17 (see
Lemma 6(iii) of Laver [1976]) and implies that â„µ1 is preserved by the iteration.
In Chapter 31 we prove a more general result, showing that this property is
preserved by countable support iteration of proper forcing.
Secondly, the iteration satisï¬es the â„µ2-chain condition (Lemma 10(ii) of
Laver [1976]). This can be proved as in Exercise 16.20, or Lemma 23.11,
by ï¬rst showing that for every Î± < Ï‰2, the Laver iteration of length Î± has
a dense subset of cardinality â„µ1. Again, this is a general property of countable
support iteration of proper forcing, when at each stage, the Î²th iterate Ë™QÎ²
has cardinality â„µ1.
The key property of Laverâ€™s iteration is that there are no uncountable
strong measure zero sets in V [G]. If X is a set of reals of size â„µ1 in V [G],
then because of the â„µ2-chain condition, X appears at some stage V [GÎ±],
and by forcing a Laver real, one makes X not to have strong measure zero
in V [GÎ±+1]. However, one has to show that X fails to have strong mea-
sure zero in V [G], not just in V [GÎ±+1]. The main technical lemma (Laverâ€™s
Lemma 15) proves that, and is analogous to Lemma 28.20, working with
iteration of Laver forcing rather than with Laver trees only.
In his paper [1983] Baumgartner gives the consistency proof of Borelâ€™s
Conjecture using the countable support iteration of Mathias forcing. His
Theorem 7.1 shows that the iteration of either Laver or Mathias forcing pre-
serves â„µ1, and if CH holds in the ground model then iteration of length Ï‰2
satisï¬es the â„µ2-chain condition. He also gives a detailed proof of Borelâ€™s Con-
jecture in the iteration of Mathias forcing.
Îº+-Aronszajn Trees
Theorem 9.16 states that there exists an Aronszajn tree, i.e., a tree of
length Ï‰1 with countable levels and no branch of length Ï‰1. In Chapter 9 we
also deï¬ned what it means for an inï¬nite cardinal Îº to have the tree property:
Every tree of height Îº and levels of size < Îº has a branch of length Îº. When
Îº is inaccessible then the tree property is equivalent to weak compactness.
Let Îº+ be a successor cardinal. A tree of height Îº+ is a Îº+-Aronszajn
tree if its levels have size at most Îº and it has no branch of length Îº+. When
Îº is singular, the tree property of Îº+ is related to large cardinals; we shall

now address the case when Îº is regular. We discuss the case of â„µ2 as it easily

a weakly compact cardinal in L.

The following theorem shows that it is consistent (relative to a weakly

Theorem 28.24 (Mitchell). If Îº is a weakly compact cardinal then there
is a generic extension in which Îº = â„µ2, 2â„µ0 = â„µ2, and there exists no â„µ2-

A related result is the following theorem that we state without proof:

Historical Notes
The construction of a nonconstructible âˆ†1
3 real in Theorem 28.1 is as in Jensen
[1970]. Nambaâ€™s forcing appeared in Namba [1971]; in [1976] BukovskÂ´y obtains the
same result by a somewhat diï¬€erent forcing construction. The result that adding
a Cohen real adds a Suslin tree is due to Shelah [1984]; the present proof is due to
TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1987] (for details see Bagaria [1994]).
The consistency of Borelâ€™s Conjecture is due to Laver [1976].
For the construction of a Îº+-Aronszajn tree if 2<Îº = Îº, see Specker [1949]. The
consistency proof of the tree property for â„µ2, as well as the proof of Silverâ€™s Theo-
rem 28.23 appeared in Mitchell [1972/73]. Theorem 28.25 is in Laver-Shelah [1981].

29. More Combinatorial Set Theory
Ramsey Theory
Ramseyâ€™s Theorem 9.1 has been generalized in many ways, giving rise to an
area of combinatorial mathematics known as Ramsey theory. In this section
we present three results involving combinatorics of inï¬nite sets. For a com-
plete account of Ramsey theory we refer the reader to the book [1980] of
Graham, Rothschild and Spencer.
Theorem 29.1 (Hindman). If N is partitioned into ï¬nitely many pieces
then one of the pieces A contains an inï¬nite set H such that a1+. . .+an âˆˆA
whenever a1, . . ., an are distinct members of H.
For the proof, we introduce the concept of an idempotent ultraï¬lter. If U
and V are ultraï¬lters on N, let
(29.1)
U + V = {X âŠ‚N : {m âˆˆN : X âˆ’m âˆˆV } âˆˆU}
where Xâˆ’m = {n : m+n âˆˆX}. See Exercises 29.1 and 29.2 for an alternative
characterization. In the proof we use the following lemma due to S. Glazer:
Lemma 29.2. There exists a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter U on N such that U +
U = U.
An ultraï¬lter U such that U + U = U is idempotent. While Glazerâ€™s
Lemma can be proved directly, it can be deduced from a more general result
on topological semigroups. Let Î²N be the space of all ultraï¬lters on N, the
Stone-Ë‡Cech compactiï¬cation on N. The operation U + V on Î²N is a contin-
uous function of U for any ï¬xed V , thus making (Î²N, +) a left-topological
semigroup. It can be shown that every compact left-topological semigroup
has an idempotent element (Exercises 29.3 and 29.4).
Proof of Theorem 29.1. Given a partition of N into ï¬nitely many pieces, let
U be an idempotent ultraï¬lter, and let A be a piece of the partition such
that A âˆˆU. We construct a sequence A = A0 âŠƒA1 âŠƒA2 âŠƒ. . . with
Ak âˆˆU and a0 < a1 < a2 < . . . as follows: Let a0 âˆˆA0. Given Ak âˆˆU and
akâˆ’1, we ï¬nd ak > akâˆ’1 such that ak âˆˆAk and that Ak âˆ’ak âˆˆU (since
{n : Ak âˆ’n âˆˆU} âˆˆU). Let Ak+1 = Ak âˆ©(Ak âˆ’ak).

574
Part III. Selected Topics
Now let H = {ak : k < Ï‰}. To verify that all ï¬nite sums from H are in A,
one shows, by induction on n, that if k1 > . . . > kn then ak1 +. . .+akn âˆˆAkn.
âŠ“âŠ”
A similar technique can be used to give a proof of the following classical
theorem in Ramsey Theory. An arithmetic progression (of length k) is a ï¬nite
set of the form
(29.2)
{n, n + d, n + 2d, . . . , n + (k âˆ’1)d}
where d is a positive integer.
Theorem 29.3 (van der Waerden). If N is partitioned into ï¬nitely many
pieces then one of the pieces contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions.
For the proof of Theorem 29.3, we ï¬x an integer k â‰¥1 and consider the
space (Î²N)k. Let I be the set of all arithmetic progressions of length k, and
let Â¯I be its closure in (Î²N)k. Arguments similar to those in Exercise 29.3
can be used to show that if R âŠ‚Î²N is any minimal right ideal and U âˆˆR,
then âŸ¨U, . . . , UâŸ©âˆˆÂ¯I. For details, we refer reader to TodorË‡ceviÂ´câ€™s book [1997].
Now to prove the theorem, let U be a nonprincipal ultraï¬lter on N that
belongs to some minimal right ideal on Î²N. Let A be the piece of the given
partition such that A âˆˆU, and let Aâˆ—= {V âˆˆÎ²N : A âˆˆV }. If k â‰¥1 is
any integer, let I and Â¯I be as above. Since âŸ¨U, . . . , UâŸ©âˆˆÂ¯I, it follows that
(Aâˆ—Ã— . . . Ã— Aâˆ—) âˆ©Â¯I is nonempty, and hence I âˆ©(A Ã— . . . Ã— A) Ì¸= âˆ…. Therefore
A contains an arithmetic progression of length k.
The third result, which we state without a proof, is the Hales-Jewett
Theorem. Let Î£ be a ï¬nite set, called alphabet, and let W be the set of
all words on Î£, the set of all ï¬nite sequences in Î£. Let v be a variable, an
object not in Î£. The set V of all variable words over Î£ is the set of all words
on Î£ âˆª{v} in which v occurs. An instance of a variable word x âˆˆV is the
result of substituting some a âˆˆÎ£ for v in x.
Theorem 29.4 (Hales-Jewett). If W is partitioned into ï¬nitely many
pieces then there is a variable word x âˆˆV whose all instances lie in the
same piece of the partition.
We refer the reader to TodorË‡ceviÂ´câ€™s book for a proof using topological
semigroups.
Gaps in Ï‰Ï‰
Consider the partial order on Ï‰Ï‰ by eventual domination: f < g if and only
if f(n) < g(n) for all but ï¬nitely many n.

29. More Combinatorial Set Theory
575
Deï¬nition 29.5. Let Îº and Î» be regular cardinals. A (Îº, Î»)-gap in Ï‰Ï‰ is
a pair of transï¬nite sequences âŸ¨fÎ± : Î± < ÎºâŸ©and âŸ¨gÎ² : Î² < Î»âŸ©in Ï‰Ï‰ such that
(i) fÎ±1 < fÎ±2 if Î±1 < Î±2,
(ii) gÎ²1 > gÎ²2 if Î²1 < Î²2,
(iii) fÎ± < gÎ² for all Î± < Îº and Î² < Î»,
(iv) there is no h between {fÎ±}Î± and {gÎ²}Î², i.e., no h such that
fÎ± < h < gÎ² for all Î± and Î².
(29.3)
We shall prove a classical theorem of Hausdorï¬€stating that (Ï‰1, Ï‰1)-gaps
exist.
First we prove that (Ï‰, Ï‰)-gaps do not exist:
Lemma 29.6. If f0 < f1 < . . . < fn < . . . < gm < . . . < g1 < g0, then there
exists an h between {fn}n and {gm}m.
Proof. For each k there exists an nk such that for all n â‰¥nk, mk(n) =
max{f0(n), . . . , fk(n)} â‰¤min{g0(n), . . . , gk(n)} = Mk(n). Choose such nkâ€™s
so that n0 < n1 < . . . < nk < . . ., and let h be a function such that mk(n) â‰¤
h(n) â‰¤Mk(n) when nk â‰¤n < nk+1.
âŠ“âŠ”
Another easily seen fact is that a (Îº, Î»)-gap exists if and only if a (Î», Îº)-gap
exists (Exercise 29.5). That some gaps exists follows from Zornâ€™s Lemma. In
fact, there exists an (Ï‰, b)-gap, see Exercise 29.6 (and there are no (Ï‰, Î»)-gaps
for Î» < b, see Exercise 29.7).
Apart from Hausdorï¬€â€™s Theorem 29.7, the existence of speciï¬c (Îº, Î»)-gaps
is unprovable: For instance, (c, c)-gaps may or may not exist, depending on
the model. A detailed account of known consistency results on gaps can be
found in Scheepers [1993].
Theorem 29.7 (Hausdorï¬€). There exists an (Ï‰1, Ï‰1)-gap in Ï‰Ï‰.
Proof. We construct an increasing âŸ¨fÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©and a decreasing âŸ¨gÎ² : Î² <
Ï‰1âŸ©such that
(i) for all Î± and Î², limnâ†’âˆgÎ²(n) âˆ’fÎ±(n) = âˆ,
(ii) for every Î± < Ï‰1 and every n âˆˆÏ‰, there are only ï¬nitely many
Î² < Î± such that âˆ€k â‰¥n fÎ±(k) < gÎ²(k).
(29.4)
Let us show ï¬rst that (29.4) guarantees that {fÎ±}Î±, {gÎ²}Î² is a gap. As-
sume that h âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰ is between {fÎ±}Î±, {gÎ²}Î². Then there exist an uncountable
Z âŠ‚Ï‰1 and some n âˆˆÏ‰ such that for all k â‰¥n and h(k) < gÎ±(k) for
all k â‰¥n. Thus fÎ±(k) < gÎ²(k) for all Î±, Î² âˆˆZ and all k â‰¥n. Now if Î± is
the Ï‰th element of Z, the set {Î² < Î± : âˆ€k â‰¥n fÎ±(k) < gÎ²(k)} is inï¬nite,

We construct fÎ± and gÎ± by induction on Î±. Let f0(n) = 0 and g0(n) = n
for all n. Let Î³ < Ï‰1. If fÎ± and gÎ² satisfy (29.4) for all Î±, Î² â‰¤Î³, then it is
easy to ï¬nd fÎ³+1 and gÎ³+1 such that (29.4) remains true.

The Open Coloring Axiom
We shall now discuss the axiom OCA (Open Coloring Axiom) that has a num-
ber of applications in combinatorial set theory. Let X be a set of reals (or
X âŠ‚N, or X âŠ‚P(Ï‰), etc.) and let K âŠ‚[X]2. We say that K is open if
the set {(x, y) : {x, y} âˆˆK} is an open set in the space X Ã— X. The Open
Coloring Axiom (OCA) states:
(29.6)
Let X be a subset of R. For any partition [X]2 = K0 âˆªK1 with
K0 open, either there is an uncountable Y âŠ‚X such that [Y ]2 âŠ‚K0,
or there exist sets Hn, n âˆˆÏ‰, such that X = âˆ
n=0 Hn and [Hn]2 âŠ‚
K1 for all n.

29. More Combinatorial Set Theory
577
The axiom OCA is consistent with ZFC; we discuss this in Chapter 31. It
should be noted that its dual version is false; Exercise 29.9. OCA has a num-
ber of consequences; see TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1989]. (One example is Exercise 29.10.)
The most notable is the following result:
Theorem 29.8 (TodorË‡ceviÂ´c). If OCA holds then b = â„µ2.
First we show that under OCA, b > Ï‰1.
Lemma 29.9. Assume OCA. Then every subset of Ï‰Ï‰ of size â„µ1 is bounded.
Proof. In order to show that every subset X âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰ of size â„µ1 is bounded, it is
clearly enough to show this for every increasing X = {fÎ±}Î±<Ï‰1 (i.e., fÎ± < fÎ²
if Î± < Î²), and assume that each fÎ± is an increasing function from Ï‰ to Ï‰. Let
X = {fÎ±}Î± be such and let [X]2 = K0 âˆªK1 where K0 consists of all {fÎ±, fÎ²}
with Î± < Î² such that fÎ±(k) > fÎ²(k) for some k.
First assume that X = âˆ
n=0 Hn and [Hn]2 âŠ‚K1 for all n. Then for
some n, Hn is uncountable, and if Î± < Î² are such that fÎ±, fÎ² âˆˆHn then
fÎ±(k) â‰¤fÎ²(k) for all k, and fÎ±(k) < fÎ²(k) for some k. Then if we let SÎ± =
{(m, k) : m â‰¤fÎ±(k)}, we have an Ï‰1-chain of subsets of Ï‰Ã—Ï‰, a contradiction.
Thus, assuming OCA, there is an uncountable Y âŠ‚X such that [Y 2] âŠ‚
K0. We claim that Y is bounded (and it follows that X is bounded). To
prove the claim, assume that Y is not bounded and let {gÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} be the
increasing enumeration of Y . For each t âˆˆÏ‰<Ï‰ that is an initial segment of
some g âˆˆY , choose Î±t such that t âŠ‚gÎ±t. Then let Î³ > supt Î±t, and let k0 be
such that for uncountably many Î², gÎ³(k) < gÎ²(k) for all k â‰¥k0. Thus there
is an uncountable Z âŠ‚Ï‰1 âˆ’Î³ such that gÎ³(k) < gÎ²(k) for all Î² âˆˆZ and all
k â‰¥k0 and that gÎ²1â†¾k0 = gÎ²2â†¾k0 whenever Î²1, Î²2 âˆˆZ.
Now let m â‰¥k0 be the least m such that the set {gÎ²(m) : Î² âˆˆZ} is

and some W âŠ‚Z such that gÎ²â†¾m = t for all all Î² âˆˆW and {gÎ²(m) : Î² âˆˆW}
is inï¬nite.
Let Î± = Î±t; since Î± < Î³, there exists a k1 â‰¥m such that gÎ±(k) < gÎ³(k) for
all k â‰¥k1. Let Î² âˆˆW be such that gÎ²(m) â‰¥gÎ±(k1). Since gÎ²â†¾m = t = gÎ±â†¾m,
and since gÎ± and gÎ² are increasing, we have gÎ±(k) â‰¤gÎ²(k) for all k â‰¤k1. But
for k â‰¥k1 we have gÎ±(k) â‰¤gÎ³(k) < gÎ²(k); hence gÎ±(k) â‰¤gÎ²(k) for all k.
This contradicts the assumption that {gÎ±, gÎ²} âˆˆK0. Hence Y is bounded,
and so X is bounded.

Almost Disjoint Subsets of Ï‰1
Let Îº be a regular uncountable cardinal, and let X and Y be unbounded
subsets of Îº. The sets X and Y are almost disjoint if |X âˆ©Y | < Îº (cf. Deï¬-
nition 9.20). Similarly, two functions f and g on Îº are almost disjoint if for

29. More Combinatorial Set Theory
579
some Î³ < Îº, f(Î±) Ì¸= g(Î±) for all Î± > Î³ (cf. Deï¬nition 9.22). Unlike in the
case Îº = Ï‰, it is a nontrivial question how large a set of almost disjoint sets
of functions can be; clearly, the maximal size of an almost disjoint family
of subsets of Îº is equal to the maximal size of an almost disjoint family of
functions from Îº to Îº.
For simplicity, we consider the case Îº = Ï‰1. This can be generalized to
any regular uncountable Îº.
First, there exists an almost disjoint family of size â„µ2 (Lemma 9.23), and
if 2â„µ0 = â„µ1 then there exists one of size 2â„µ1. We shall prove the following:
Theorem 29.11. If 2â„µ0 < 2â„µ1 and 2â„µ0 < â„µÏ‰1 then there exists an almost
disjoint family of 2â„µ1 uncountable subsets of Ï‰1.
Compare this with Theorem 22.16: If I is the ideal of bounded subsets
of Ï‰1, then Theorem 29.11 states that sat(I) = (2â„µ1)+; by Theorem 22.16,
sat(I) â‰¥2â„µ1. As sat(I) is regular (by Theorem 7.15), the following lemma
implies the theorem:
Lemma 29.12. Assume 2â„µ0 < â„µÏ‰1. If Îº is a regular cardinal such that 2â„µ0 <
Îº â‰¤2â„µ1, then there exists a family of Îº almost disjoint functions from Ï‰1
into Ï‰1.
Proof. Let F be a family of almost disjoint functions on Ï‰1; we call F
a branching family if whenever f, g âˆˆF and Î± is such that f(Î±) = g(Î±),
then f(Î¾) = g(Î¾) for all Î¾ â‰¤Î±.
For each X âŠ‚Ï‰1, let fX = âŸ¨X âˆ©Î± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©. The family F = {fX :
X âˆˆP(Ï‰1)} is a branching family of functions on Ï‰1, |F| = 2â„µ1; and for each
Î± < Ï‰1, the functions in F take values in P(Î±). Thus there exists a branching
family of 2â„µ1 functions from Ï‰1 into 2â„µ0.
Let Îº be a regular cardinal such that 2â„µ0 < Îº â‰¤2â„µ1. We shall show that
for every â„µÎ³ such that â„µ1 < â„µÎ³ â‰¤2â„µ0, if there is a branching family of Îº
functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰Î³, then there is a branching family of Îº functions
from Ï‰1 into some Ï‰Î´ < Ï‰Î³. Then the lemma clearly follows.
First let â„µÎ³ = â„µÎ´+1 where â„µ1 â‰¤â„µÎ´, and let F be a branching family of Îº
functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰Î´+1. Each f âˆˆF is bounded below Ï‰Î´+1 (because
Ï‰Î´+1 > Ï‰1), and because Îº is regular and Îº > Ï‰Î´+1, there exists Î± < Ï‰Î´+1
such that ran(f) âŠ‚Î± for Îº functions in F. Thus there exists a branching fam-
ily of Îº functions from Ï‰1 into Î±; and since |Î±| â‰¤â„µÎ´, there is also a branching
family of Îº functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰Î´.
If â„µÎ³ is a limit cardinal, then cf(Ï‰Î³) = Ï‰ because â„µÎ³ < â„µÏ‰1. Let F be
a branching family of Îº functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰Î³. For each f âˆˆF there exists
an ordinal Î·f < Ï‰Î³ such that f(Î±) < Î·f for uncountably many Î±â€™s. Since Îº is
a regular cardinal and Îº > â„µÎ³, there exists â„µÎ´ such that â„µ1 â‰¤â„µÎ´ < â„µÎ³, and
a family G âŠ‚F of size Îº such that for every f âˆˆG, f(Î±) < Ï‰Î´ for uncountably
many Î±â€™s.

For each Î± < Ï‰1, let SÎ± = {f(Î±) : f âˆˆG}. Since G is a branching family
and G âŠ‚
Î±<Ï‰1 SÎ±, it suï¬ƒces to show that |SÎ±| â‰¤â„µÎ´ for all Î± < Ï‰1. Thus let
Î± < Ï‰1. We deï¬ne a function t : SÎ± â†’Ï‰1 Ã— Ï‰Î´ as follows: For each x âˆˆSÎ±,

such f(Î¾) < Ï‰Î´, and we let
t(x) = (Î¾, f(Î¾)).
We shall now complete the proof by showing that the function t is one-
to-one, and hence |SÎ±| â‰¤â„µÎ´. Let x, y âˆˆSÎ± be such t(x) = t(y). Let Î¾ > Î±
and f, g âˆˆG be such that x = f(Î±), y = g(Î±), and t(x) = t(y) = (Î¾, f(Î¾)) =

and hence x = y.

Theorem 29.13.
(i) If cof(Ï‰Ï‰1) < 2â„µ1 then 2â„µ0 â‰¥â„µ3.
(ii) If 2â„µ0 < 2â„µ1 and 2â„µ0 < â„µÏ‰1 then cof(Ï‰Ï‰1) = 2â„µ1.
The theorem is a consequence of this lemma:
Lemma 29.14. If there exist 2â„µ1 almost disjoint functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰2
then cof(Ï‰Ï‰1) = 2â„µ1.
Then Theorem 29.13 follows: If 2â„µ0 â‰¤â„µ2 then use Exercise 29.12(ii);
for (ii), use Theorem 29.11.

and J are ideals on S and T , then I Ã— J is the ideal on S Ã— T

Lemma 29.16. If there exist 2â„µ1 almost disjoint functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰2

Proof of Lemma 29.14. By Lemma 29.16 there exist a Ïƒ-ideal J on Ï‰1 and
a family H = {hÎ± : Î± < 2â„µ1} of J-disjoint functions from Ï‰1 into Ï‰. Let F
be a coï¬nal family in Ï‰Ï‰1 such that |F| < 2â„µ1. There exists an f âˆˆF that
eventually dominates inï¬nitely many hÎ±; then let A âŠ‚2â„µ1 be a countable
inï¬nite set such that hÎ± < f for all Î± âˆˆA. The set {Î¾ < Ï‰1 : hÎ±(Î¾) = hÎ²(Î¾)
for some distinct Î±, Î² âˆˆA} is the union of countably many sets in J, hence
belongs to J, and hence its complement is uncountable. Thus for uncountably
many Î¾ < Ï‰1, the set {hÎ±(Î¾) : Î± âˆˆA} is an inï¬nite subset of Ï‰. This
contradicts the fact that there exists a Î³ < Ï‰1 such that for all Î¾ â‰¥Î³,
hÎ±(Î¾) < f(Î¾) for all Î± âˆˆA.

Historical Notes
Hindmanâ€™s Theorem appeared in [1974]. The present proof is due to Glazer and
can be found e.g. in the book [1980] by Graham et al. The book also contains van
der Waerdenâ€™s Theorem and its generalizations. The topological proof presented
here is as in TodorË‡ceviÂ´câ€™s book [1997]. For the Hales-Jewett Theorem, see Hales
and Jewett [1963].
Hausdorï¬€â€™s Theorem appeared in Hausdorï¬€[1909]. We follow the construction
presented in Scheepers [1993], which gives a comprehensive account of the subject of
gaps. The Open Coloring Axiom was isolated by TodorË‡ceviÂ´c in [1989]; related par-
tition axioms were previously introduced by Abraham, Rubin and Shelah in [1985].
Theorem 29.8 is due to TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1989].
Theorem 29.11 as well as Exercise 29.11 are results of Baumgartner [1976]; for
almost disjoint functions see Jech and Prikry [1979]. Part (i) of Theorem 29.13 is
due to Galvin. For part (ii) and Lemma 29.14, see Jech and Prikry [1984].
Exercise 29.3 is attributed to R. Ellis; see TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1997].
Exercises 29.6 and 29.7: Rothberger [1941].
Exercise 29.8: Hausdorï¬€[1936a].

30. Complete Boolean Algebras
Measure Algebras
A complete Boolean algebra B is a measure algebra if it carries a (strictly
positive probabilistic) measure, i.e., a real-valued function m on B that satis-
ï¬es (22.1) (or cf. Deï¬nition 30.2 below). In Chapters 26 and 22 we looked at
two examples of measure algebras: The algebra Bm of (26.1), and the more
general product measure algebra deï¬ned in (22.3). We present below a the-
orem that states that this measure algebra is essentially the only measure
algebra that exists.
Throughout this section, we consider measure algebras, and for simplic-
ity assume that all the measure algebras under consideration are atomless.
Note that every measure algebra satisï¬es the countable chain condition, and
consequently, all questions of completeness can be reduced to Ïƒ-completeness.
If G is a subset of a measure algebra B, we say that G Ïƒ-generates B if
B is the smallest Ïƒ-subalgebra containing G. The weight of B is the least size
of G âŠ‚B that Ïƒ-generates B. B is homogeneous if each Bâ†¾u (with u Ì¸= 0)
has the same weight. Note that every measure algebra is the direct sum of Ï‰
many homogeneous measure algebras.
The result that we shall prove in this section is the following:
Theorem 30.1 (Maharam). Every inï¬nite homogeneous measure algebra
is the unique measure algebra of its weight.
If A and B are inï¬nite homogeneous measure algebras of the same weight
and if Âµ and Î½ are strictly positive probabilistic measures on A and B, then
there exists an isomorphism f between A and B such that Î½(f(a)) = Âµ(a) for
all a âˆˆA.
We begin by introducing some terminology and presenting two lemmas
that are standard techniques of measure theory.
Deï¬nition 30.2. Let B be a complete Boolean algebra. A measure on B is
a real-valued function Âµ on B that satisï¬es
(i) Âµ(0) = 0,
(ii) Âµ(a) â‰¥0 for all a âˆˆA,

(iii) for all pairwise disjoint an, n = 0, 1, . . . ,
Âµ(

an) =

n=0
(an).
A measure Âµ is strictly positive if
(iv) Âµ(a) > 0 for all a Ì¸= 0,
and probabilistic, if also
(v) Âµ(1) = 1.
Finally, a function Âµ that satisï¬es (i) and (iii) is called a signed measure.
Lemma 30.3. If Î½ is a signed measure on B that satisï¬es c.c.c. then there
exists an a âˆˆB such that Î½(x) â‰¥0 for all x â‰¤a and Î½(x) â‰¤0 for all x â‰¤âˆ’a.

Lemma 30.5 allows one to extend partial measure-preserving isomor-
phisms between homogeneous measure algebras. If Âµ and Î½ are probabilistic
measures on measure algebras A and B, then an isomorphism f of A onto B
is measure-preserving if Î½(f(a)) = Âµ(a) for all a âˆˆA.
Lemma 30.6. Let A1 and A2 be homogeneous measure algebras, both of the
same weight Îº, and let Âµ1 and Âµ2 be probabilistic measures on A1 and A2.

Cohen Algebras
Let Îº be an inï¬nite cardinal. We consider the notion of forcing PÎº that adds
Îº Cohen reals: conditions in PÎº are ï¬nite 0â€“1 functions with domain âŠ‚Îº. Let
(30.5)
CÎº = B(PÎº)
denote the complete Boolean algebra corresponding to PÎº. Throughout this
section, B denotes the completion of a Boolean algebra B.
Deï¬nition 30.7. A Boolean algebra B is a Cohen algebra if B = CÎº for
some inï¬nite cardinal Îº.
In Theorem 30.10 below we give a combinatorial characterization of Cohen
algebras.
Deï¬nition 30.8. A subalgebra A of a Boolean algebra B is a regular subal-
gebra,
A â‰¤reg B,
if for any X âŠ‚A, if A X exists then A X = B X.

The following is easily established:
Lemma 30.9. The following are equivalent:
(i) A â‰¤reg B.
(ii) Every maximal antichain in A is maximal in B.
(iii) For every b âˆˆB+ there exists an a âˆˆA+ such that for every x âˆˆA+,
if x â‰¤a then x Â· b Ì¸= 0.
âŠ“âŠ”
See Exercises 30.3â€“30.9 for further properties of â‰¤reg.
If A is a subalgebra of B and b âˆˆB, then the projection of b to A, prA(b),
is the smallest element a âˆˆA, if it exists, such that b â‰¤a. (Similarly, prA(b)
is the greatest a âˆˆA such that a â‰¤b.)
The density of a Boolean algebra B is the least size of a dense subset
of B. B has uniform density if for every a âˆˆB+, Bâ†¾a has the same density.
If X is a subset of a Boolean algebra B, we denote

Theorem 30.10. Let B be an inï¬nite Boolean algebra of uniform density.
B is a Cohen algebra if and only if the set {A âˆˆ[B]Ï‰ : A â‰¤reg B} contains
a closed unbounded set C with the property

If B is countable, the condition is trivially satisï¬ed as C = {B} is a closed
unbounded subset of [B]Ï‰.
First we prove the forward direction of the theorem: If B is a dense subal-
gebra of CÎº, then B has the property stated in Theorem 30.10. (In particular,
CÎº itself has the property.) Let B be a dense subalgebra of CÎº. For every

every A âˆˆC is a regular subalgebra of B.

The following property is a natural weakening of the characterization of
Cohen algebras in Theorem 30.10:
Deï¬nition 30.13. An inï¬nite Boolean algebra B of uniform density is semi-
Cohen if [B]Ï‰ has a closed unbounded set of countable regular subalgebras.
An immediate consequence of the deï¬nition is that if B is semi-Cohen
and |B| â‰¤â„µ1 then B is a Cohen algebra. This is because [B]Ï‰ has a closed
unbounded subset that is a chain, and therefore satisï¬es (30.8).
The important feature of semi-Cohen algebras is that the property is
hereditary:
Theorem 30.14. If B is a semi-Cohen algebra and if A is a regular subal-
gebra of B of uniform density then A is semi-Cohen.

592
Part III. Selected Topics
Proof. [B]Ï‰ has a closed unbounded subset of regular subalgebras of B. Since
A â‰¤reg B, there exists for every b âˆˆB+ some a âˆˆA+ such that there is no
x âˆˆA+ with x â‰¤a âˆ’b. Let F : B+ â†’A+ be a function that to each b âˆˆB+
assigns such an a âˆˆA+. Let C âŠ‚[B]Ï‰ be a closed unbounded set of regular
subalgebras closed under F.
If X âˆˆC then Aâˆ©X â‰¤reg X because X is closed under F. Every maximal
antichain in A âˆ©X is maximal in X, hence in B (because X â‰¤reg B), hence
in A. Therefore A âˆ©X â‰¤reg A.
There is a closed unbounded set D âŠ‚[A]Ï‰ such that D âŠ‚{Xâˆ©A : X âˆˆC};
D witnesses that A is semi-Cohen.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 30.15. If B is semi-Cohen and has density â„µ1 then B is a Cohen
algebra.
Proof. B has a dense subalgebra A of size â„µ1. By Theorem 30.14, A is also
semi-Cohen, and hence Cohen. But A = B, and hence B is Cohen.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 30.16. Every complete subalgebra of CÎº of uniform density â„µ1
is isomorphic to CÏ‰1.
âŠ“âŠ”
The property of being semi-Cohen is also preserved by completion. This
can be proved using the following lemma:
Lemma 30.17. A Boolean algebra B of uniform density is semi-Cohen if
and only if B is Cohen in V P , where P is the collapse of |B| onto â„µ1 with
countable conditions.
Proof. As |B| = â„µ1 in V P , it suï¬ƒces to show that B is semi-Cohen if and
only if it is semi-Cohen in V P .
As P does not add new countable sets, [B]Ï‰ remains the same in V P .
By property (iii) of Lemma 30.9, the relation â‰¤reg is absolute. Let S be the
set of all regular subalgebras of B. If S contains a closed unbounded set C
then C is closed unbounded in V P . Conversely, if S does not contain a closed
unbounded set, then it does not contain one in V P .
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 30.18. B is semi-Cohen if and only if its completion is semi-
Cohen.
Proof. Let B be semi-Cohen and let A = B. Let P be the Ï‰-closed collapse
of |A| to â„µ1. In V P , A has a dense subalgebra B that is a Cohen algebra,
hence A itself is Cohen. Therefore A is semi-Cohen.
The converse follows from Theorem 30.14.
âŠ“âŠ”
Not every semi-Cohen algebra is a Cohen algebra, and Corollary 30.16
does not extend to density â„µ2. Koppelberg and Shelah gave an example of
a complete subalgebra of CÏ‰2 of (uniform density â„µ2) that is not isomorphic

30. Complete Boolean Algebras
593
to CÏ‰2. Another example, due to Zapletal, is the forcing that adds â„µ2 even-
tually diï¬€erent reals: Let
P = {z : z is a ï¬nite function with dom(z) âŠ‚Ï‰2 and ran(z) âŠ‚Ï‰<Ï‰},
and let z â‰¤w if z is a coordinate-wise extension of w and for Î± Ì¸= Î² in dom(w),
if n âˆˆdom(z(Î±) âˆ’w(Î±)) and n âˆˆdom(z(Î²)), then z(Î±)(n) Ì¸= z(Î²)(n).
If B = B(P) then B can be embedded in CÏ‰2 but is not isomorphic
to CÏ‰2. We omit the proof.
Suslin Algebras
Deï¬nition 30.19. A Suslin algebra is a complete atomless Boolean algebra
that is Ï‰-distributive and satisï¬es the countable chain condition.
If T is a normal Suslin tree, and PT is the forcing with T upside down, then
B(PT ) is a Suslin algebra. Conversely, if B is a Suslin algebra of density â„µ1
then B = B(PT ) for some Suslin tree T ; in general, if B is a Suslin algebra
then B has a complete subalgebra BT such that BT = B(PT ) for some Suslin
tree T .
Theorem 30.20. If B is a Suslin algebra then |B| â‰¤2â„µ1.
Proof. Let Îº = 2â„µ1. Assume that there is a Suslin algebra B such that
