âŠ“âŠ”
Suslin algebras of size 2â„µ1 can be constructed by forcing (cf. Jech [1973b]),
or in L (an unpublished result of Laver).

30. Complete Boolean Algebras
595
Simple Algebras
Deï¬nition 30.21. A complete Boolean algebra B is simple if it is atomless
and if it has no proper atomless complete subalgebra.
The problem of existence of simple algebras originated in forcing and
was ï¬rst discussed by McAloon in [1971]. It is clear that a simple algebra is
minimal, i.e., when forcing with it, there is no intermediate model between
the ground model and the generic extension. Minimality, when formulated in
Boolean-algebraic terms, is the following property:
(30.14)
If A is a complete atomless subalgebra of B then there exists a par-
tition W such that Aâ†¾w = Bâ†¾w for all w âˆˆW.
(An example of a minimal algebra is B(P) where P is the Sacks forcing.)
Simple algebras, in addition to being minimal, are rigid, i.e., have no
nontrivial automorphisms (Exercise 30.13). It turns out that the conjunction
of these two properties also implies that the algebra is simple (Exercise 30.14).
Thus we have:
Theorem 30.22. An atomless complete Boolean algebra is simple if and
only if it is rigid and minimal.
âŠ“âŠ”
An example of a rigid and minimal algebra is BP where P is Jensenâ€™s
forcing from Theorem 28.1 that produces a minimal âˆ†1
3 real. BP is minimal
because the generic real has minimal degree of constructibility, and rigid
because it is deï¬nable. It follows that if V = L then a simple complete
Boolean algebra exists.
In L, one can also construct Suslin algebras that are simple (see Exercises
30.15 and 30.16 for the construction of a rigid Suslin algebra).
Simple complete Boolean algebras have been constructed in ZFC; we refer
the reader to Jech-Shelahâ€™s papers [1996] and [2001]. The former constructs
a countably generated simple algebra and uses a modiï¬cation of the Sacks
forcing to produce a minimal deï¬nable real. The latter construction is some-
what less complicated and yields forcing that produces a minimal deï¬nable
uncountable set.
Inï¬nite Games on Boolean Algebras
Inï¬nite games have many applications in set theory, particularly in descrip-
tive set theory, and we shall investigate these methods in some detail in the
chapter on Axiom of Determinacy. In the present section we look into some
properties of complete Boolean algebras, and of forcing, that are formulated
in terms of inï¬nite games.

596
Part III. Selected Topics
Let B be a Boolean algebra, and let G be the following inï¬nite game
between two players I and II: I chooses a nonzero element a0 âˆˆB and then
II chooses some b0 âˆˆB+ such that b0 â‰¤a0. Then I plays (chooses) a1 â‰¤b0
and II plays b1 â‰¤a1 (both Ì¸= 0). The game continues, with Iâ€™s moves an âˆˆB+,
n < Ï‰, and IIâ€™s moves bn âˆˆB+, n < Ï‰, such that
(30.15)
a0 â‰¥b0 â‰¥a1 â‰¥b1 â‰¥. . . â‰¥an â‰¥bn â‰¥. . . .
Player I wins the game if âˆ
n=0 an = 0; player II wins otherwise: if the
chain (30.15) has a nonzero lower bound. A strategy for player I is a function
Ïƒ : B<Ï‰ â†’B; it is a winning strategy if I wins every play (30.15) in which
I follows Ïƒ, i.e., for each n, an = Ïƒ(âŸ¨b0, . . . , bnâˆ’1âŸ©). A (winning) strategy for II
is deï¬ned similarly. If player I has a winning strategy then II does not, and
vice versa, and in general, neither player need have a winning strategy.
Lemma 30.23. Player I has a winning strategy in G if and only if B is not
Ï‰-distributive.
Proof. Let Ïƒ be a winning strategy for I. Let a0 = Ïƒ(âŸ¨âŸ©); we shall ï¬nd parti-
tions Wn of a0 without a common reï¬nement. Let W0 = {a0}. Having con-
structed W0, . . . , Wn, consider all ï¬nite sequences a0 â‰¥b0 â‰¥. . . â‰¥an â‰¥bn
where the anâ€™s are chosen by Ïƒ and ak âˆˆWk for all k â‰¤n. Let Wn be a max-
imal antichain whose members are elements an+1 = Ïƒ(âŸ¨b0, . . . , bnâŸ©) where
a0 â‰¥b0 â‰¥. . . â‰¥an â‰¥bn is as described. The Wnâ€™s are partitions of a0 and
do not have a common reï¬nement.
Conversely, if B is not Ï‰-distributive, there exist some a0 and open dense
sets Dn below a0 such that âˆ
n=0 Dn = âˆ…. We deï¬ne Ïƒ(âŸ¨âŸ©) = a0, and if a0 â‰¥
b0 â‰¥. . . â‰¥an â‰¥bn is such that the anâ€™s are chosen by Ïƒ, let Ïƒ(âŸ¨b0, . . . , bnâŸ©) be
some element of Dn below bn. The function Ïƒ is a winning strategy for I.
âŠ“âŠ”
Let P be a separative notion of forcing, and consider the inï¬nite game G
in which players I and II take turns to play a descending chain a0 â‰¥b0 â‰¥
. . . â‰¥an â‰¥bn â‰¥. . . in P. I wins if and only if the chain does not have a lower
bound. It is easy to see that either player has a winning strategy in this game
if and only if the same player has a winning strategy in G played on B(P)
(Exercise 30.17).
Deï¬nition 30.24. A separative notion of forcing P (a Boolean algebra B)
is strategically Ï‰-closed if player II has a winning strategy in the game G.
Being strategically Ï‰-closed is a hereditary property. If B is strategically
Ï‰-closed and if A is a regular subalgebra of B then also A is strategically
Ï‰-closed (Exercise 30.18).
It is obvious that if P is Ï‰-closed then player II has a winning strategy
in G. Hence if B has a dense Ï‰-closed subset, then B is strategically Ï‰-closed.
The converse is true for small algebras:

30. Complete Boolean Algebras
597

closed, then it has a dense Ï‰-closed subset.
Proof. Let {dÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} be a dense set in B. By induction on Î±, we ï¬nd

on T . We shall ï¬nd a dense subset P of T that is Ï‰-closed.

As a corollary, we get the following characterization of strategically Ï‰-

Corollary 30.26. B is strategically Ï‰-closed if and only if B is a regular
subalgebra of some algebra that has an Ï‰-closed dense subset.
Proof. Suï¬ƒciency follows from Exercise 30.18. Thus assume that B is strate-

in A. D is Ï‰-closed: Let {(pn, bn)}n be descending and let p = 

and b â‰¤bn for all n). Hence (p, b) is a lower bound of {(pn, bn)}n.

of forcing and Boolean algebras, see Jech [1984]. Weâ€™ll show in Chapter 31
that proper forcing admits such characterization. See also Exercise 30.19.

Historical Notes
Maharamâ€™s Theorem 30.1 appeared in [1942]; the present proof is based on Fremlinâ€™s
article [1989]. Theorem 30.10 appeared in Balcar, Jech and Zapletal [1997] improv-
ing a similar earlier result of Koppelberg [1993]. The [1997] investigates semi-Cohen
algebra, the concept introduced by Fuchino and Jech. Corollary 30.16: Koppelberg.
Theorem 30.20 is due to Solovay.
Rigid minimal algebras were studied by McAloon in [1971]. Constructions of
a simple complete Boolean algebra in ZFC appeared in Jech and Shelah [1996]
and [2001].
The game G on a Boolean algebra was introduced in Jech [1978]; this and similar
games were studied in Jech [1984]. Foremanâ€™s Theorem 30.25 appeared in [1983].
Exercises 30.11 and 30.12: Vladimirov [1969].
Exercises 30.13 and 30.14: McAloon [1971].

31. Proper Forcing
Deï¬nition and Examples
Proper forcing was introduced by S. Shelah who isolated properness as the
property of forcing that is common to many standard examples of forcing
notions and that is preserved under countable support iteration.
Deï¬nition 31.1. A notion of forcing (P, <) is proper if for every uncount-
able cardinal Î», every stationary subset of [Î»]Ï‰ remains stationary in the
generic extension.
Properness is a generalization of both the countable chain condition and
of being Ï‰-closed. The following two lemmas are the analogs of Lemma 22.25
and Lemma 23.7 (for Îº = â„µ1):
Lemma 31.2. If P satisï¬es the countable chain condition then for every
uncountable Î», every closed unbounded set C âŠ‚[Î»]Ï‰ in V [G] has a subset
D âˆˆV that is closed unbounded in V . Hence every stationary set S âŠ‚[Î»]Ï‰
remains stationary in V [G].
Proof. Let p âŠ©
Ë™C is closed unbounded; let
Ë™F be a name for a function
from Î»<Ï‰ into Î» such that p âŠ©C Ë™F âŠ‚
Ë™C (where C Ë™F is the set of all clo-
sure points of Ë™Fâ€”see Theorem 8.28). Let f : Î»<Ï‰ â†’[Î»]Ï‰ be the function
f(e) = {Î± âˆˆÎ» : âˆ¥Ë™F(e) = Î±âˆ¥Ì¸= 0}.
f(e) is countable because P satisï¬es the countable chain condition. Let
D = Cf.
Since p âŠ©Ë™F(e) âˆˆf(e), if x is closed under f then p âŠ©Ë™F(e) âˆˆx, and so
p âŠ©D âŠ‚Ë™C.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 31.3. If P is Ï‰-closed then every stationary set S âŠ‚[Î»]Ï‰ remains
stationary in V [G].
Proof. Let p âŠ©Ë™F : Î»<Ï‰ â†’Î». We shall ï¬nd a condition q â‰¤p and some x âˆˆS
such that q âŠ©Ë™F(x<Ï‰) âŠ‚x.
Consider the model (HÎº, âˆˆ, (P, <), p, Ë™F, âŠ©) where Îº â‰¥Î» is suï¬ƒciently
large. Let C be the closed unbounded set in [HÎ»]Ï‰ of all countable elementary

Proper forcing does not collapse â„µ1. In fact, an easy argument shows that
a stronger property is true:
Lemma 31.4. If P is proper then every countable set of ordinals in V [G] is
included in a set in V that is countable in V .
Proof. Let X be a countable set of ordinals in V [G] and let Î» be uncountable
in V such that X âŠ‚Î». The set ([Î»]Ï‰)V remains stationary in V [G] and

in V [G]. Thus X âŠ‚A for some A âˆˆ([Î»]Ï‰)V .
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall now formulate a technical condition that is equivalent to proper-
ness of a forcing notion, and that will be used to prove that properness is
preserved under countable support iteration. We refer the reader to the ex-
ercises for other equivalents of properness.
Let (P, <) be a ï¬xed notion of forcing. We say that Î» is suï¬ƒciently large
if Î» is a cardinal and Î» > 2|P |. A model M is an elementary submodel of
(HÎ», âˆˆ, <, . . .) where HÎ» is the collection of all sets hereditarily of cardinality
less than Î», < is some unspeciï¬ed well-ordering of HÎ» (to allow for inductive
constructions), and the structure of HÎ» contains all the relevant parameters;
in particular, M contains (P, <).
Deï¬nition 31.5. A condition q is (M, P)-generic if for every maximal an-
tichain A âˆˆM, the set A âˆ©M is predense below q.
The following lemma (the proof is a routine exercise) illuminates the con-
cept of (M, P)-genericity:
Lemma 31.6. Let Î» be suï¬ƒciently large, let M â‰ºHÎ» be such that P âˆˆM,
and let q âˆˆP. The following are equivalent:
(i) q is (M, P)-generic.
(ii) If Ë™Î± âˆˆM is an ordinal name then q âŠ©Ë™Î± âˆˆM, i.e.,
âˆ€r â‰¤q âˆƒs â‰¤r âˆƒÎ² âˆˆM s âŠ©Ë™Î± = Î².
(iii) q âŠ©Ë™G âˆ©M is a ï¬lter on P generic over M.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 31.7. A forcing notion P is proper if and only if for all suï¬ƒciently
large Î» there is a closed unbounded set C of elementary submodels M â‰º
(HÎ», . . .) such that

Another characterization of properness is formulated in terms of inï¬nite
games.
Deï¬nition 31.8. Let P be a forcing notion and let p âˆˆP. The proper game
(for P, below p) is played as follows: I plays P-names Ë™Î±n for ordinal numbers,
and II plays ordinal numbers Î²n. Player II wins if there exists a q â‰¤p such
that
(31.2)
q âŠ©âˆ€n âˆƒk Ë™Î±n = Î²k.
Theorem 31.9. A forcing notion P is proper if and only if for every p âˆˆP,
II has a winning strategy for the proper game.
Proof. Exercise 31.3.

We shall now present some examples of proper forcing. The following
concept is due to J. Baumgartner:

Deï¬nition 31.10. A notion of forcing (P, <) satisï¬es Axiom A if there is
a collection {â‰¤n}âˆ
n=0 of partial orderings of P such that p â‰¤0 q implies p â‰¤q
and for every n, p â‰¤n+1 q implies p â‰¤n q, and

a q â‰¤n p and a countable set B such that q âŠ©Ë™Î± âˆˆB.
Lemma 31.11. If P satisï¬es Axiom A then P is proper.
Proof. Let P satisfy Axiom A and let p âˆˆP. The following is a winning
strategy for II in the game from Exercise 31.2: When I plays Ë™Î±n, let II ï¬nd

âŠ“âŠ”
Example 31.12. Every Ï‰-closed forcing satisï¬es Axiom A.
Let p â‰¤n q if and only if p â‰¤q, for all n.
âŠ“âŠ”
Example 31.13. Every c.c.c. forcing satisï¬es Axiom A.
Let p â‰¤n q if and only if p = q, for all n > 0.
âŠ“âŠ”
Example 31.14. The notions of forcing that add a Sacks real, a Mathias
real or a Laver real satisfy Axiom A.
For Sacks reals, see (15.26). For Laver forcing, see (28.17); Mathias forcing
is similar.

In Exercises 31.5 and 31.6 we give Baumgartnerâ€™s example of proper forc-
ing that does not satisfy Axiom A.
Iteration of Proper Forcing
It is obvious that a two-step iteration of proper forcing is proper: If P pre-
serves stationary sets and in V P , Ë™Q preserves stationary sets then P âˆ—Ë™Q
preserves stationary sets. What is more important however is that proper-
ness is preserved under countable support iteration. The present section is
devoted to the proof of this.
Theorem 31.15 (Shelah). If PÎ± is a countable support iteration of { Ë™QÎ² :
Î² < Î±} such that every Ë™QÎ² is a proper forcing notion in V PÎ±â†¾Î², then PÎ± is
proper.
Toward the proof of Theorem 31.15 we ï¬rst observe that the properness
condition in Theorem 31.7 can be somewhat simpliï¬ed:

Lemma 31.16. P is proper if and only if for every p âˆˆP, every suï¬ƒciently
large Î» and every countable M â‰º(HÎ», âˆˆ, <) containing P and p, there exists
a q â‰¤p that is (M, P)-generic.

â†’HÂµ. If F is the least such

satisï¬es (31.1). Hence every such M with P, p âˆˆM satisï¬es the condition of
the lemma.

In order to prove that an iteration PÎ± is proper, we wish to show that if

A signiï¬cant consequence of Theorem 31.15 is that countable support it-
eration of proper forcing preserves â„µ1. As for cardinals above â„µ1, one often
needs additional assumptions on the iterates Ë™QÎ² to calculate the chain condi-
tion. The easiest case was already stated in Exercise 16.20: If P is a countable
support iteration of length Îº â‰¥â„µ2 such that each Pâ†¾Î², Î² < Îº, has a dense
subset of size < Îº, then P satisï¬es the Îº-chain condition. In particular, iter-
ation of length Ï‰2 with each Pâ†¾Î² having a dense set of size â„µ1, satisï¬es the
â„µ2-chain condition, and all cardinals are preserved.

A somewhat better result is the following which we state without a proof.
For a proof, see Abrahamâ€™s paper [âˆ] in the Handbook of Set Theory. [She-
lahâ€™s book [1998] contains more general chain condition theorems.]
Theorem 31.19. Assume CH. If P is a countable support iteration of length
Îº â‰¤Ï‰2 of proper forcings Ë™QÎ² of size â„µ1, then P satisï¬es the â„µ2-chain condi-
tion.

The Proper Forcing Axiom
When we replace the countable chain condition in Martinâ€™s Axiom MAâ„µ1
by properness we obtain a more powerful statement, the Proper Forcing Ax-
iom (PFA):
Deï¬nition 31.20 (Proper Forcing Axiom (PFA)). If (P, <) is a proper
notion of forcing and if D is a collection of â„µ1 dense subsets of P, then there
exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
It turns out that PFA implies that 2â„µ0 = â„µ2, and therefore PFA is a gen-
eralization of Martinâ€™s Axiom MA. Unlike MA, consistency of PFA requires
large cardinals: It follows from the results stated later in this chapter that at
least a Woodin cardinal is necessary. The consistency proof given below uses
a supercompact cardinal.
Theorem 31.21. If there exists a supercompact cardinal then there is a
generic model that satisï¬es PFA.
Proof. The proof follows loosely the proof of the consistency of MA. Let Îº
be a supercompact cardinal. The model is obtained by countable support
iteration of length Îº. Each notion of forcing used in the iteration is proper
and has size < Îº, thus both â„µ1 and all cardinals â‰¥Îº are preserved. Cardinals
between â„µ1 and Îº are collapsed and so Îº becomes â„µ2, and the model satisï¬es
2â„µ0 = â„µ2.
In order to show that the resulting model satisï¬es PFA, we use a Laver
function (see Theorem 20.21); this makes it possible to handle all potential
proper forcing notions in Îº steps.
Let f : Îº â†’VÎº be a Laver function. We construct a countable support
iteration PÎº of { Ë™QÎ± : Î± < Îº} as follows: At stage Î±, if f(Î±) is a pair ( Ë™P , Ë™D)
of PÎ±-names such that Ë™P is a proper forcing notion and D is a Î³-sequence
of dense subsets of Ë™P for some Î³ < Îº, we let Ë™QÎ± = Ë™P; otherwise, Ë™QÎ± is the
trivial forcing.
Let G be a generic ï¬lter on PÎº, the countable support iteration of { Ë™QÎ± :
Î± < Îº}. Since each Ë™QÎ± is proper, PÎº is proper and therefore â„µ1 is preserved.
Each PÎ± (the iteration of { Ë™QÎ² : Î² < Î±}) has size less than Îº (because
f(Î±) âˆˆVÎ±) and so PÎº has the Îº-chain condition; hence all cardinals â‰¥Îº
are preserved.

608
Part III. Selected Topics
Lemma 31.22. In V [G], if P is proper and D = {DÎ± : Î± < Î³}, with Î³ < Îº,
is a family of dense subsets of P, then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
This lemma will complete the proof of the theorem: For every Î³ < Îº,
let P be the forcing that collapses Î³ onto Ï‰1 with countable conditions, and
for Î± < Î³ let DÎ± = {p âˆˆP : Î± âˆˆran(p)}. By Lemma 31.22, there exists
a collapsing map of Î³ onto Ï‰1. Thus Îº = â„µ2 in V [G]. Now Lemma 31.22
implies that V [G] satisï¬es PFA. Moreover, 2â„µ0 = â„µ2 in V [G]: On the one
hand, PFA implies MAâ„µ1 and so 2â„µ0 > â„µ1, and on the other hand, 2â„µ0 â‰¤Îº
because |PÎº| = Îº.
Proof of Lemma 31.22. Let Ë™P and Ë™D be PÎº-names for P and D. Let Î» > 22|P |
be suï¬ƒciently large; we may also assume that P âŠ‚Î». Since f is a Laver
function, there exists an elementary embedding j : V â†’M with critical
point Îº such that j(Îº) > Î», M Î» âŠ‚M, and (jf)(Îº) = ( Ë™P, Ë™D).

set C âŠ‚[HÎ·]Ï‰ of countable models for some Î· with 2|P | < Î· < Î». Since M Î» âŠ‚
M and PÎº has the Îº-chain condition, V [G] satisï¬es that M[G]Î» âŠ‚M[G],
and therefore C is closed unbounded in M[G]. Therefore P is proper in the
model M[G].
Now consider the forcing notion j(PÎº) in M. It is a countable support
iteration of length j(Îº) using the Laver function j(f). Since jâ†¾VÎº is the iden-
tity, we have j(PÎº)â†¾Îº = PÎº. As (jf)(Îº) = ( Ë™P , Ë™D) and P is proper in M[G],
it follows that (j Ë™Q)Îº = Ë™P. Hence
j(PÎº) = PÎº âˆ—Ë™P âˆ—Ë™R
for some Ë™R.
Let H âˆ—K be a V [G]-generic ultraï¬lter on Ë™P âˆ—Ë™R. In V [G âˆ—H âˆ—K] we
extend the elementary embedding j : V â†’M to an elementary embedding
jâˆ—: V [G] â†’M[G âˆ—H âˆ—K] as follows: For every PÎº-name Ë™x, let

âˆ¥Ë™x = Ë™yâˆ¥âˆˆG implies âˆ¥j( Ë™x) = j( Ë™y)âˆ¥âˆˆG âˆ—H âˆ—K (because j(p) = p for every

The ï¬lter H on P is V [G]-generic and thus meets every DÎ±, Î± < Î³. Let

and since jâˆ—: V [G] â†’M[G âˆ—H âˆ—K] is elementary, there exists in V [G] a D-

Applications of PFA
Our ï¬rst goal is to outline the proof of the following theorem:
Theorem 31.23 (TodorË‡ceviÂ´c). PFA implies 2â„µ0 = â„µ2.
As the ï¬rst step we show that the Open Coloring Axiom (29.6) is a con-
sequence of PFA. If [X]2 = K0 âˆªK1 with K0 open, let us call Z âŠ‚X
0-homogeneous if [Z]2 âŠ‚K0 and 1-homogeneous if [Z]2 âŠ‚K1. It is clear that
the closure of a 1-homogeneous set is also 1-homogeneous, and so in (29.6)
we can further assume that the sets Hn are closed.
The proof of OCA from PFA uses the following technical lemma that we
state without proof:
Lemma 31.24 (TodorË‡ceviÂ´c). Assume 2â„µ0 = â„µ1. Let X âŠ‚R and [X]2 =
K0 âˆªK1 with K0 open, and assume that X is not the union of countably
many closed 1-homogeneous sets. Then there exists an uncountable Y âŠ‚X
such that in any uncountable set W âŠ‚{p âˆˆ[Y ]<Ï‰ : p is 0-homogeneous}
there exist p Ì¸= q such that p âˆªq is 0-homogeneous.
Proof. See Theorem 4.4 of TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1989]. (To apply the theorem, let F(x)
be the closure of {y âˆˆX : x < y and {x, y} âˆˆK1}.)
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 31.25. PFA implies OCA.
Proof. Let X âŠ‚R and let [X]2 = K0 âˆªK1 with K0 open, and assume that
X is not the union of countably many closed 1-homogeneous sets. We shall
use PFA to ï¬nd an uncountable 0-homogeneous set.
Let P be the forcing (15.2) that adds a subset of Ï‰1 with countable con-
ditions. By Exercise 15.14, V P satisï¬es 2â„µ0 = â„µ1. Since P does not add new
reals, it does not add new closed sets of reals and so in V P , X is not the
union of countably many closed 1-homogeneous sets.
By Lemma 31.24 there exists an uncountable Ë™Y âˆˆV P such that if we let
Ë™Q = {p âˆˆ[ Ë™Y ]<Ï‰ : p is 0-homogeneous} (and p is stronger than q if p âŠƒq)
then the forcing notion Ë™Q satisï¬es the countable chain condition. Hence P âˆ—Ë™Q
is proper.
Let âŸ¨yÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©be an enumeration of Ë™Y in V P . For each Î± < Ï‰1,
the set DÎ± = {(p, q) âˆˆP Ã— Ë™Q : p âŠ©yÎ± âˆˆq} is a dense set in P âˆ—Ë™Q. Let
D = {DÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1}. By PFA there exists a D-generic ï¬lter G on P âˆ—Ë™Q, and
then the set Y = {q : (p, q) âˆˆG} is an uncountable 0-homogeneous set.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 31.25 appears in TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1989]. Its proof does not require
the full force of PFA. What we used is a weaker statement that is obtained
by replacing â€œproper notion of forcingâ€ in Deï¬nition 31.20 by â€œAxiom A
forcing of cardinality â‰¤2â„µ0.â€ This axiom is weaker than PFA (and stronger
than MAâ„µ1) and is consistent relative to ZFC+â€œthere exists a weakly compact
cardinalâ€ (see Baumgartner [1984]).

The consistency of related partition axioms was ï¬rst established in Abra-
ham, Rubin and Shelah [1985].

The next theorem establishes the consistency strength of PFA (see the

(31.6)

Lemma 31.29. P is proper.

those principles imply an inner model for a Woodin cardinal. Thus we have:
Theorem 31.30 (Schimmerling). If PFA holds then there exists an inner
model of â€œthere exists a Woodin cardinal.â€

Part III. Selected Topics
Martinâ€™s Axiom MAâ„µ1 implies that there are no Suslin trees, and more-
over, that every Aronszajn tree is special. PFA implies a stronger result. If
T is a normal Ï‰1-tree and C âŠ‚Ï‰1 a closed unbounded set, then T â†¾C is the
tree {t âˆˆT : o(t) âˆˆC}. Two trees T1 and T2 are club-isomorphic if there
exists a closed unbounded C such that T1â†¾C and T2â†¾C are isomorphic.
Theorem 31.31. If PFA holds then any two normal Aronszajn trees are
club-isomorphic.
Proof. Let T1 and T2 be two normal Aronszajn trees. Consider the forcing
with ï¬nite conditions (E, f) such that
(i) E is a ï¬nite subset of Ï‰1,
(ii) dom(f) is a subtree of T1â†¾E in which every branch has size |E|;
similarly for ran(f) âŠ‚T2â†¾E,
(iii) f us an isomorphism.
(31.7)
We omit the proof that P is proper and refer the reader to TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1984],
Theorem 5.10.
A suï¬ƒciently generic ï¬lter on P yields an uncountable set A and an
isomorphism between T1â†¾A and T2â†¾A, which easily extends to T1â†¾C where
C is the closure of A.
âŠ“âŠ”
We present one more consequence of PFA, due to J. Baumgartner (com-
pare with Theorem 28.24):
Theorem 31.32. If PFA holds then there are no â„µ2-Aronszajn trees.
Proof. Assume that T is an â„µ2-Aronszajn tree. Let P be the forcing that adds
a subset of Ï‰1 with countable conditions. Since 2â„µ0 = â„µ2, P collapses Ï‰2 and
so there is in V P a closed unbounded subset Ë™C of Ï‰2, of order-type Ï‰1. The
tree T has no new branches (this is proved as in Lemma 27.10, because the
levels of T have size â„µ1 < 2â„µ0). Thus Ë™U = T â†¾Ë™C is in V P an Ï‰1-tree with no
Ï‰1-branches.
Now let Ë™Q âˆˆV P be the specializing forcing for Ë™U, as in Theorem 16.17.
Ë™Q satisï¬es the countable chain condition, and so P âˆ—Ë™Q is proper.
Let G be a suï¬ƒciently generic ï¬lter on P âˆ—Ë™Q. It yields a closed unbounded
subset C of some Î³ < Ï‰2, a tree U = T â†¾C, and a specializing function f :
U â†’Ï‰. This is a contradiction, since a special tree has no Ï‰1-branches, while
every t âˆˆT at level Î³ produces an Ï‰1-branch in U.

Historical Notes
Proper forcing was introduced by Shelah, cf. [1982] and [1998]. The iteration The-
orem 31.15 is due to Shelah; our treatment follows Abrahamâ€™s article [âˆ]. The
proper game was formulated independently by Shelah and C. Gray.
Proper Forcing Axiom was introduced by Baumgartner [1984]; earlier (Baum-
gartner [1983]) he introduced Axiom A. Theorem 31.21 is due to Baumgartner.
Theorem 31.23: TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1989], see also Bekkali [1991]. (The claim in
VeliË‡ckoviÂ´c [1992] to this result cannot be substantiated.)
Theorem 31.25: TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1989]; Abraham, Rubin and Shelah [1985].
Theorem 31.28: TodorË‡ceviÂ´c [1984].
Theorem 31.31: Abraham and Shelah [1985].
Theorem 31.32: Baumgartner [1984].
The forcing for adding a closed unbounded set with ï¬nite conditions is due to
Baumgartner [1983].
Exercises 31.8, 31.9: Baumgartner [1984].
Exercise 31.10: Abraham and Shelah [1985].

32. More Descriptive Set Theory
Î 1
1 Equivalence Relations
Theorem 32.1 (Silver). If E is a Î 1
1 equivalence relation on N then either
E has at most â„µ0 equivalence classes or there exits a perfect set of mutually
inequivalent reals.
Thus every Î 1
1 (and in particular) Borel equivalence relation has either at
most countably many or 2â„µ0 equivalence classes. This can be viewed as a gen-
eralization of the perfect set property for analytic sets (Theorem 11.18); cf.
Exercise 32.1. The theorem does not extend to Î£1
1, as there exists a Î£1
1 equiv-
alence relation with exactly â„µ1 equivalence classes (Exercise 32.2).
We present a proof of Theorem 32.1 that is due to Leo Harrington. We
start with an easy lemma.
Lemma 32.2. Let E be a meager equivalence relation on N. Then there
exist a perfect set of inequivalent reals.
Proof. Let {Dn}n be dense open sets in N Ã—N such that N 2âˆ’E âŠƒâˆ
n=0 Dn.
We construct a binary tree of ï¬nite sequences {us : s âˆˆSeq({0, 1})} âŠ‚Seq
such that for every n, if |s| = |t| = n and s Ì¸= t, then O(us) Ã— O(ut) âŠ‚Dn.
This is done by induction on the length of s. If the us have been deï¬ned
for all s âˆˆ{0, 1}n, we consider successively all possible pairs (sâŒ¢i, tâŒ¢j), and
using the density of Dn+1, successively extend each usâŒ¢i until O(usâŒ¢i) Ã—
O(utâŒ¢j) âŠ‚Dn+1 for all s, t âˆˆ{0, 1}n and i, j = 0, 1.
For each f âˆˆ{0, 1}Ï‰ let af be the unique member of âˆ
n=0 O(ufâ†¾n). The
set {af : f âˆˆ{0, 1}Ï‰} is perfect, and if f Ì¸= g then (af, ag) /âˆˆE.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall use a version of Lemma 32.2 for a diï¬€erent topology on N Ã— N.
Toward the proof let us recall some basic facts about the property of Baire.
In particular, Lemmas 11.16 and 11.17 as well as the fact that the Ïƒ-algebra
of sets with the Baire property is closed under the Suslin operation A, remain
true in every second countable space (i.e., space that has a countable basis).
We shall prove Silverâ€™s Theorem for (lightface) Î 1
1 equivalence relations;
the proof relativizes to Î 1
1(a) for every real parameter a.
Deï¬nition 32.3. The Î£1
1-topology on N is the topology with basic open sets
being all the Î£1 subsets of N.

1.

Proof. Exercise 32.3.

Constructible Reals and Perfect Sets
We recall (Lemma 26.50) that if there exists a nonconstructible real then the
set R âˆ©L is Lebesgue measurable only if it is null, and has the property of
Baire only if it is meager. The following theorem proves a similar result for
perfect sets.
Theorem 32.11. If there exists a nonconstructible real then the set R âˆ©L
does not have a perfect subset.
Proof. As a ï¬rst step we show that Râˆ©L does not have a superperfect subset.
A tree T âŠ‚Seq is superperfect if for every t âˆˆT there exists an s âŠƒt in T
such that sâŒ¢k âˆˆT for inï¬nitely many k âˆˆÏ‰. (We call s an Ï‰-splitting node
of T .) A nonempty set P âŠ‚N is superperfect if P = [T ] for some superperfect
tree T .

The space X is homeomorphic to the irrationals which in turn is homeo-

of [Ï‰]Ï‰ âˆ©L, contradicting Lemma 32.12.

Projective Sets and Large Cardinals
One of the successes of modern set theory has been the discovery of the close
relationship between the hierarchy of deï¬nable sets of reals and the hierar-
chy of large cardinals. We shall elaborate on this relationship in subsequent
chapters. In the present section we apply the large cardinal theory to Î£1
3 sets.
By Theorem 25.38, the perfect set property for Î£1
2 sets is equivalent to
the large cardinal assumption
(32.8)
â„µ1 is inaccessible in L[a], for every a âˆˆR
(see Exercise 32.4). The statement (32.8) also implies that every Î£1
2 set is
Lebesgue measurable and has the Baire property.
By Solovayâ€™s Theorem 26.14, inaccessibility is suï¬ƒcient for the consis-
tency of Lebesgue measurability and the Baire property of all projective sets.
The following theorem shows that the assumption is necessary for Lebesgue
measurability, while by another result of Shelah, the Baire property for all
projective sets is consistent relative to ZFC only:
Theorem 32.13 (Shelah [1984]). If every Î£1
3 set of reals is Lebesgue mea-
surable then â„µ1 is an inaccessible cardinal in L.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall outline a result that shows that under a suitable strengthening
of (32.8), every Î£1
3 set is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property, and
has the perfect set property. The key is a tree representation of Î£1
3 sets in
the presence of a measurable cardinal.
Theorem 32.14 (Martin and Solovay [1969], Mansï¬eld [1971]). If
there exists a measurable cardinal then for every Î£1
3 set A there exists a tree T
on Ï‰ Ã— Î» (for some Î») such that A = p[T ].
Proof. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal and let U be a normal measure on Îº.
For each n, let Un be the ultraï¬lter {X âŠ‚Îºn : X âŠƒ[Z]n for some Z âˆˆU}, and
let jn = in,n+1 be the canonical elementary embedding in,n+1 : UltUn(V ) â†’
UltUn+1(V ).

Universally Baire sets
Deï¬nition 32.21. A set A âŠ‚R is universally Baire if for any compact
Hausdorï¬€space X and any continuous function f : X â†’R, the set
fâˆ’1(A) has the property of Baire in X.
The set of all universally Baire sets is a Ïƒ-algebra and is closed under
operation A. Thus every Î£1
1 set is universally Baire. We show below that
every universally Baire set is Lebesgue measurable and that the statement
that every âˆ†1
2 set is universally Baire has consistency strength between inac-
cessible and Mahlo cardinals. The assumption that every projective (or even
every Î£1
2 set) is universally Baire is considerably stronger; we refer to Feng,
Magidor and Woodin [1992] for details.
Theorem 32.22. A set A âŠ‚R is universally Baire if and only if for every
notion of forcing P there exist trees T and S on Ï‰ Ã— Î» (where Î» = 2|P |) such
that
(32.15)
A = p[T ],
R âˆ’A = p[S]
and for every generic ï¬lter G on P,
V [G] âŠ¨p[T ] âˆªp[S] = R and p[T ] âˆ©p[S] = âˆ….
âŠ“âŠ”
(32.16)
We omit the proof of this equivalence. We remark that in the deï¬nition the
space X can be replaced by the generalized Cantor space Î»Ï‰ (for all Î»), and
in the theorem, the forcing notion P can be replaced by Col(Î») = Col(Ï‰, Î»),
the collapse of Î» with ï¬nite conditions.

624
Part III. Selected Topics
Corollary 32.23. Every universally Baire set is Lebesgue measurable.
Proof. Let A âŠ‚R be universally Baire. Let B be the measure algebra, and
let T and S be trees on Ï‰ Ã— Î» such that A = p[T ], R âˆ’A = p[S], and
(32.16) holds for every generic ultraï¬lter G on B.
Let Ë™a be the canonical name for a random real and let B be a Borel set
such that âˆ¥Ë™a âˆˆp[T ]âˆ¥= [B]. We will show that A â–³B has measure 0, and
thus A is measurable.
Let M be a countable elementary submodel of HÎº where HÎº is suï¬ƒciently
large. We claim that for every random real x over M,
(32.17)
x âˆˆp[T ] â†”x âˆˆB.
If x âˆˆB then B âŠ©Ë™a âˆˆp[T ] and hence M âŠ¨(B âŠ©Ë™a âˆˆp[T ]). Thus
M[x] âŠ¨x âˆˆp[T ], and so x âˆˆp[T ]. If x /âˆˆB then âˆ’B âŠ©Ë™a âˆˆp[S] and
M[x] âŠ¨x âˆˆp[S], and hence x /âˆˆp[T ], proving (32.17).
Since M is countable, almost all reals are random over M, and therefore
A â–³B is null.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 32.24. The following are equivalent:
(i) Every âˆ†1
2 set is universally Baire.

3-absolute with respect to every generic extension.

xn) a Î 1
3 formula then for all reals a1, . . . , an,
Ï•(a1, . . . , an)
if and only if
âŠ©P Ï•(a1, . . . , an).
Its consistency strength is between inaccessible and Mahlo: It is the exis-

Historical Notes
Theorem 32.1 on Î 1
1 equivalence relations is due to Silver [1980]. The present proof
is Harringtonâ€™s as presented in Kechris and Martin [1980]. Lemma 32.5 is due to
Louveau. Silverâ€™s Theorem was extended to Theorem 32.9 by J. Burgess in [1978].
Theorem 32.11 is due to Groszek and Slaman [1998]. The proof presented here
is from VeliË‡ckoviÂ´c and Woodin [1998].
Theorem 32.13: Shelah [1984]. The tree representation of Î£1
3 sets is implicit in
Martin and Solovay [1969] and described in Mansï¬eld [1971]. Theorem 32.16 is due
to Magidor [1980].
Universally Baire sets are investigated in Feng, Magidor, and Woodin [1992].

33. Determinacy
With each subset A of Ï‰Ï‰ we associate the following game GA, played by
two players I and II. First I chooses a natural number a0, then II chooses
a natural number b0, then I chooses a1, then II chooses b1, and so on. The
game ends after Ï‰ steps; if the resulting sequence âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©is in A,
then I wins, otherwise II wins.
A strategy (for I or II) is a rule that tells the player what move to make
depending on the previous moves of both players. A strategy is a winning
strategy if the player who follows it always wins. The game GA is determined
if one of the players has a winning strategy.
The Axiom of Determinacy (AD) states that for every A âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰, the
game GA is determined.
Determinacy and Choice
First some deï¬nitions: Let A âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰ be given and let GA denote the corre-
sponding game. A play is a sequence âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©âˆˆÏ‰Ï‰; for each n, an is
the nth move of player I and bn is the nth move of player II. A strategy for I
is a function Ïƒ with values in Ï‰ whose domain consists of ï¬nite sequences
s âˆˆSeq of even length. Player I plays âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©by the strategy Ïƒ
if a0 = Ïƒ(âˆ…), a1 = Ïƒ(âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©), a2 = Ïƒ(âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1âŸ©), and so on; it is clear
that if I plays by Ïƒ, then the play is determined by Ïƒ and the sequence
b = âŸ¨bn : n âˆˆÏ‰âŸ©. We denote the play by Ïƒ âˆ—b. A strategy Ïƒ is a winning
strategy for I if
{Ïƒ âˆ—b : b âˆˆN} âŠ‚A,
in other words, if all plays that I plays by Ïƒ are in A. Similarly, a strategy
for II is a function Ï„ with values in Ï‰, deï¬ned on ï¬nite sequences s âˆˆSeq of
odd length. If a âˆˆN and if Ï„ is a strategy for II, then a âˆ—Ï„ denotes the play
in which I plays a and II plays by Ï„. A strategy Ï„ for II is a winning strategy
if
{a âˆ—Ï„ : a âˆˆN} âŠ‚N âˆ’A.
We sometimes consider games GA whose moves are not natural numbers
but elements of an arbitrary set S. A play is then a sequence p âˆˆSÏ‰, and the

628
Part III. Selected Topics
result of the game depends on whether p âˆˆA or p /âˆˆA (here A is a subset
of SÏ‰). The other relevant notions are deï¬ned accordingly.
Since the number of strategies is 2â„µ0, an easy diagonal argument shows
that the Axiom of Choice is incompatible with the Axiom of Determinacy:
Lemma 33.1. Assuming the Axiom of Choice, there exists A âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰ such
that the game GA is not determined.
Proof. Let {ÏƒÎ± : Î± < 2â„µ0} and {Ï„Î± : Î± < 2â„µ0} enumerate all strategies
for I and all strategies for II. We construct sets X = {xÎ± : Î± < 2â„µ0} and
Y = {yÎ± : Î± < 2â„µ0}, subsets of N, as follows: Given {xÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±} and
{yÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±}, let us choose some yÎ± such that yÎ± = ÏƒÎ± âˆ—b for some b and
yÎ± /âˆˆ{xÎ¾ : Î¾ < Î±} (such yÎ± exist because the set {ÏƒÎ± âˆ—b : b âˆˆN} has
size 2â„µ0); similarly, let us choose xÎ± such that xÎ± = a âˆ—Ï„Î± for some a and
xÎ± /âˆˆ{yÎ¾ : Î¾ â‰¤Î±}. It is clear that the sets X and Y are disjoint, that for
each Î± there is b such that ÏƒÎ± âˆ—b /âˆˆX, and there is a such that a âˆ—Ï„Î± âˆˆX.
Thus neither I nor II has a winning strategy in the game GX, and hence
GX is not determined.
âŠ“âŠ”
In contrast with this lemma, the Axiom of Determinacy implies a weak
form of the Axiom of Choice:
Lemma 33.2. The Axiom of Determinacy implies that every countable fam-
ily of nonempty sets of real numbers has a choice function.
Proof. We prove that if X = {Xn : n âˆˆÏ‰} is a family of nonempty sub-
sets of N, then there exists f on X such that f(Xn) âˆˆXn for all n. Let
us consider the following game: If I plays âŸ¨a0, a1, a2, . . .âŸ©and and II plays
âŸ¨b0, b1, b2, . . .âŸ©, then II wins if and only if b âˆˆXa0. It is clear that I does not
have a winning strategy: Once I plays a0, the player II ï¬nds some b âˆˆXa0,
plays b = âŸ¨b0, b1, b2, . . .âŸ©and wins. Hence II has a winning strategy Ï„, and we
can deï¬ne f on X as follows: f(Xn) = Ï„ âˆ—âŸ¨n, 0, 0, 0, . . .âŸ©.
âŠ“âŠ”
As we show below, Determinacy has desirable consequences for sets of
reals: AD implies that every set of reals is Lebesgue measurable, has the
Baire property and the perfect set property. Thus it is natural to postulate
that Determinacy holds to the extent it does not contradict the Axiom of
Choice. The appropriate postulate turns out to be that AD holds in the
model L(R), and therefore all sets of reals deï¬nable from a real parameter are
determined. This implies, in particular, that the game GA is determined for
every projective setâ€”Projective Determinacy (PD). It has been established
that both ADL(R) and PD are large cardinal axioms; we shall elaborate on
this later in this chapter.
Throughout the rest of the present chapter we work in ZF+the Principle
of Dependent Choices.

33. Determinacy
629
Some Consequences of AD
We shall now prove that under the assumption of Determinacy, sets of real
numbers are well behaved.
Theorem 33.3. Assume the Axiom of Determinacy. Then:
(i) Every set of reals is Lebesgue measurable.
(ii) Every set of reals has the property of Baire.
(iii) Every uncountable set of reals contains a perfect subset.
Proof. (i) It suï¬ƒces to prove the following lemma:
Lemma 33.4. Assuming AD, let S be a set of reals such that every measur-
able Z âŠ‚S is null. Then S is null.
It is easy to see that Lemma 33.4 implies that every set X is Lebesgue
measurable: Let A âŠƒX be a measurable set with the property that every
measurable Z âŠ‚Aâˆ’X is null. Then Aâˆ’X is null and hence X is measurable.
Proof. Thus let S be a set of reals with the property
(33.1)
if Z âŠ‚S is Lebesgue measurable, then Z is null;
we shall use AD to show that S is null. It is clear that we can restrict ourselves
to subsets of the unit interval; thus assume that S âŠ‚[0, 1]. In order to show
that S is null, it suï¬ƒces to show that the outer measure Âµâˆ—(S) is less than
any Îµ > 0. Thus let Îµ be a ï¬xed positive real number.

(ii) Next we consider the property of Baire:

Lemma 33.7. Player II has a winning strategy in the Banach-Mazur game
if and only if X is meager.
Proof. Let Y be the complement of X in N. For each s âˆˆSeq, O(s) denotes
the basic open set {x âˆˆN : s âŠ‚x}.
(a) If X is a meager set, then there exist open dense sets Gn, n âˆˆN,
such that Y âŠƒâˆ
n=0 Gn. It is easy to ï¬nd a winning strategy Ï„ for II: If

n=0 Gn, and hence Ï„ is a winning
strategy for II.
(b) Conversely, assume that II has a winning strategy Ï„. A correct position
is a ï¬nite sequence âŸ¨s0, t0, . . . , sn, tnâŸ©such that s0 âŠ‚t0 âŠ‚. . . âŠ‚tn and
t0 = Ï„(âŸ¨s0âŸ©), t1 = Ï„(âŸ¨s0, t0, s1âŸ©), etc. We shall ï¬rst prove the following claim:

tn âŠ‚x there exists s âŠƒtn such that Ï„(pâŒ¢s) âŠ‚x. Then x âˆˆY .
To prove the claim, let x satisfy the condition. To begin, there exists s0
such that Ï„(âŸ¨s0âŸ©) âŠ‚x; let t0 = Ï„(âŸ¨s0âŸ©). Then there exists s1 âŠƒt0 such that

For every correct position p = âŸ¨s0, . . . , tnâŸ©, let

in other words,

It is easy to see that for each p, O(tn) âˆ’Fp is on open dense set in O(tn);
hence Fp is a closed nowhere dense set. The number of correct positions is
countable and hence X is meager.
âŠ“âŠ”
Corollary 33.8. Let X âŠ‚N. Player I has a winning strategy in the Banach-
Mazur game if and only if for some s âˆˆSeq, O(s) âˆ’X is meager.
Proof. Note that I has a winning strategy if and only if there exists s âˆˆSeq
(the ï¬rst move of I) such that player II has a winning strategy in the following
game: I plays t0 âŠƒs, II plays s0 âŠƒt0, I plays t1 âŠƒs0, etc.; and I wins if
t0 âŠ‚s0 âŠ‚t1 âŠ‚. . . converges to x âˆˆUs âˆ’X. By Lemma 33.7, II has a winning
strategy in this game if and only if O(s) âˆ’X is meager.
âŠ“âŠ”
Now part (ii) of Theorem 33.3 follows. If X âŠ‚N, then since the Banach-
Mazur game is determined, either X is meager or for some s âˆˆSeq, O(s)âˆ’X
is meager. Thus let X âŠ‚N be arbitrary. If X is meager, then X has the
Baire property. If X is nonmeager, then let G = {O(s) : O(s) âˆ’X is

Part III. Selected Topics
meager}. Clearly, G âˆ’X is meager, and X âˆ’G must be meager too because
otherwise there would exist some s such that O(s)âˆ’(X âˆ’G) is meager, which
contradicts the deï¬nition of G. It follows that X has the Baire property.
(iii) We will use AD to prove that every uncountable set in the Cantor
space C = {0, 1}Ï‰ has a perfect subset. We consider the following game:
33.9. The Perfect Set Game. Let X be a subset of {0, 1}Ï‰. The game is
deï¬ned as follows: Player I plays a sequence s0 âˆˆSeq({0, 1}) of 0â€™s and 1â€™s
(possibly the empty sequence), then player II plays n0 âˆˆ{0, 1}, then I plays
s1 âˆˆSeq({0, 1}), and so on. Let x = s âŒ¢
0 n âŒ¢
0 s âŒ¢
1 n âŒ¢
1 . . .. Player I wins if x âˆˆX,
and II wins if x /âˆˆX.
The game can be reformulated as a game GA, for some A âŠ‚Ï‰Ï‰.
Lemma 33.10. Let X âŠ‚C. If II has a winning strategy in the perfect set
game, then X is countable.
Proof. Let Ï„ be a winning strategy for II. A correct position is a ï¬nite se-
quence âŸ¨s0, n0, . . . , sk, nkâŸ©such that n0 = Ï„(âŸ¨s0âŸ©), n1 = Ï„(âŸ¨s0, n0, s1âŸ©), etc.

AD and Large Cardinals
To illustrate the relationship between the Axiom of Determinacy and the
theory of large cardinals, we show that AD implies that â„µ1 and â„µ2 are mea-
surable cardinals.
Theorem 33.12 (Solovay). The Axiom of Determinacy implies that:
(i) â„µ1 is a measurable cardinal, and moreover, the closed unbounded ï¬lter
on â„µ1 is an ultraï¬lter.
(ii) â„µ2 is a measurable cardinal.
Proof. (i) We ï¬rst show that AD implies that Ï‰1 is measurable. We already
know that Ï‰1 is inaccessible in every L[a], a âŠ‚Ï‰.
Let us consider the following partial ordering of the Baire space:
(33.7)
x â‰¼y
if and only if
x âˆˆL[y]
and the corresponding equivalence relation
(33.8)

if and only if
x â‰¼y and y â‰¼x.
We say that A âŠ‚N is â‰¡-closed if (x âˆˆA and y â‰¡x) implies y âˆˆA. Note
that the collection B of all â‰¡-closed sets in N is a complete Boolean algebra.
If x0 âˆˆN, then we let
(33.9)

Lemma 33.13. AD implies that for every â‰¡-closed A âŠ‚N, either A or its

Proof. We show that if I has a winning strategy in the game GA, then A con-

then Î˜ is a Woodin cardinal in the model HOD.)
Projective Determinacy
In this section we address the question how strong is the determinacy as-
sumption when restricted to games that have a simple enough deï¬nition. In
particular, we turn our attention to the game GA where A âŠ‚N is a projective
set.
When A is open (or closed) then GA is determined:
Lemma 33.17. If A âŠ‚N is an open set, then GA is determined.
Proof. Player I plays âŸ¨a0, a1, . . .âŸ©, player II plays âŸ¨b0, b1, . . .âŸ©, and I wins if
âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©âˆˆA. Let us assume that player I does not have a winning
strategy, and let us show that II has a winning strategy. The strategy for II is
as follows: When I plays a0, then because I does not have a winning strategy,

33. Determinacy
637
there exists b0 such the position âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©is not yet lost for II. That is, I does
not have a winning strategy in the game GâŸ¨a0,b0âŸ©
A
that starts at âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©, in
which I plays âŸ¨a1, a2, . . .âŸ©and II plays âŸ¨b1, b2, . . .âŸ©, and in which I wins when
âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©âˆˆA.
Let II plays such b0. When I plays a1, then again, because II is not yet
lost at âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©, there exists b1 such that II is not yet lost at âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1âŸ©.
Let II play such b1. And so on. We claim that this strategy for II is a winning
strategy.
Let x = âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©be a play which II plays by the above strategy;
We want to show that x /âˆˆA. If x âˆˆA, then because A is open, there is
s = âŸ¨a0, b0, . . . , an, bnâŸ©âŠ‚x such that O(s) âŠ‚A. But then it is clear that II is
lost at s; a contradiction.
âŠ“âŠ”
The same argument (interchanging the players) would show that every
closed game is determined. Or, we can show that every closed game is deter-
mined as follows: If A is closed, then I has a winning strategy in GA if and
only if there is a0 âˆˆN such that II does not have a winning strategy in the
open game Ga0
A in which II make a ï¬rst move b0, then I plays a1, etc., and
II wins if âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©is in the open set N âˆ’A. Since Ga0
A is determined
for all a0 âˆˆN, GA is determined.
One of the major results in descriptive set theory is Martinâ€™s proof that
for every Borel set A the game GA is determined:
Theorem 33.18 (Martin [1975]). All Borel games are determined.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall not give a proof. It can be found either in Martinâ€™s paper [1975],
or in the survey article [1980] by Kechris and Martin; furthermore, Martin
gives a simpliï¬cation of his proof in [1985].
Analytic Determinacy, i.e., determinacy of all analytic games, is already
a large cardinal assumption:
Theorem 33.19. Let a âˆˆN. Every Î£1
1(a) game is determined if and only
if aâ™¯exists.
Thus Analytic Determinacy is equivalent to the statement
(33.11)
aâ™¯exists for all a âˆˆN.
The proof of Analytic Determinacy from (33.11) is due to Martin [1969/70].
The necessity of (33.11) is a result of Harrington [1978]. We omit Harringtonâ€™s
proof and prove a corollary of Martinâ€™s result. We note however that the proof
of the corollary can be converted into a proof of the â€œifâ€ part of Theorem 33.19
without much diï¬ƒculty.
Corollary 33.20. If there exists a measurable cardinal, then all analytic
games are determined.

638
Part III. Selected Topics
Proof. Let Îº be a measurable cardinal and let A âŠ‚N be an analytic set. We
want to show that the game GA is determined.
Let us use the tree representation of analytic sets. There is a tree T âŠ‚Seq2
such that for all x âˆˆN,
x âˆˆA â†”T (x) is ill-founded.
Let â‰¼be the linear ordering of the set Seq that extends the partial ordering âŠƒ:
If s, t âˆˆSeq, then s â‰¼t either if s âŠƒt, or if s and t are incompatible, and
s(n) < t(n) where n is the least n such that s(n) Ì¸= t(n). Thus
x âˆˆA â†”T (x) is not well-ordered by â‰¼.
We also recall that T (x) = {t : (xâ†¾n, t) âˆˆT for some n} and that the ï¬rst
n levels of T (x) depend only on xâ†¾n. For s âˆˆSeq, we let Ts = {t : (u, t) âˆˆT
for some u âŠ‚s}; then Txâ†¾n is exactly the ï¬rst n levels of the tree T (x).
We need some further notation. Let t0, t1, . . . , tn, . . . be an enumeration of
the set Seq. If s âˆˆSeq is a sequence of length 2n, let Ks be the ï¬nite set
{t0, . . . , tnâˆ’1} âˆ©Ts and let ks = |Ks|.
We shall now deï¬ne an auxiliary game Gâˆ—: Player I plays natural numbers
a0, a1, a2, . . . , and player II plays pairs (b0, h0), (b1, h1), (b2, h2), . . . where
b0, b1, b2, . . . are natural numbers, and for each n, hn is an order-preserving
mapping from (Ks, â‰¼) into Îº where s = âŸ¨a0, b0, . . . , an, bnâŸ©such that h0 âŠ‚
h1 âŠ‚h2 âŠ‚. . . âŠ‚hn âŠ‚. . .. If player II is able to follow these rules throughout
the game, then he wins. Otherwise, I wins.
It is clear that the game Gâˆ—is determined: If I does not have a winning
strategy, then he cannot prevent II from following the rules and thus II has
a winning strategy, namely his each move is to reach a position in which
I does not have a winning strategy. (The argument is the same as in the
proof of determinacy of open games; in fact, Gâˆ—is an open game in a suitable
topology.)
If II wins a play in the game Gâˆ—, then he has constructed an order-
preserving mapping h = âˆ
n=0 hn of (T (x), â‰¼) into Îº, where x = âŸ¨a0, b0,
a1, b1, . . .âŸ©; hence â‰¼well-orders T (x) and so x /âˆˆA. Thus we can view the
game Gâˆ—as a variant of GA, but more diï¬ƒcult for player II: II tries to make
sure that x /âˆˆA, and in addition, he tries to construct an embedding of
(T (x), â‰¼) in Îº. Hence it is fairly obvious that if II has a winning strategy
in the game Gâˆ—, then II has a winning strategy in GA: If Ï„ âˆ—is a winning
strategy for II in Gâˆ—, let Ï„ be as follows. When I plays a0, let Ï„(âŸ¨a0âŸ©) = b0
where (b0, h0) = Ï„ âˆ—(âŸ¨a0âŸ©); then when I plays a1, let Ï„(âŸ¨a0, b0, a1âŸ©) = b1 where
(b1, h1) = Ï„ âˆ—(âŸ¨a0, (b0, h0), a1âŸ©); etc.
Since Gâˆ—is determined, it suï¬ƒces to prove the following lemma in order
to show that GA is determined:
Lemma 33.21. If I has a winning strategy in Gâˆ—, then I has a winning
strategy in GA.

33. Determinacy
639
Proof. Let Ïƒâˆ—be a winning strategy for I in Gâˆ—. After 2n+2 moves, the players
have produced a sequence s = âŸ¨a0, b0, . . . , an, bnâŸ©, and II has constructed
order-preserving functions h0 âŠ‚. . . âŠ‚hn; the strategy Ïƒâˆ—then tells player I
what to play next. Let E be the range of hn; E is a ï¬nite subset of Îº, and
in fact its size is ks. We observe that there is one and only one way II could
have constructed h0, . . . , hn so that ran(hn) = E; the reason is that hn is
the unique order-preserving one-to-one function between (Ks, â‰¼) and E. Thus
Ïƒâˆ—depends (as long as II plays correctly) only on s âˆˆSeq and the ï¬nite set
E âŠ‚Îº.
For each s âˆˆSeq of even length, let Fs be the following function from [Îº]ks
into Ï‰:
(33.12)
Fs(E) = Ïƒâˆ—(s, E).
Each Fs is a partition of [Îº]ks into Ï‰ pieces; and because Îº is measurable,
there exists a set H âŠ‚Îº of size Îº homogeneous for each Fs. Let us denote
by Ïƒ(s) the unique value of Fs(E) for E âˆˆ[H]ks.
We shall complete the proof by showing that Ïƒ is a winning strategy for I
in the game GA. Let x = âŸ¨a0, b0, a1, b1, . . .âŸ©be a play in which I plays by Ïƒ.
We shall show that x âˆˆA.
Assume that on the contrary, x /âˆˆA. Then (T (x), â‰¼) is well-ordered and
has order-type < Ï‰1. Since H is uncountable, there exists an embedding h of
(T (x), â‰¼) into H. Let us consider the following play of the game Gâˆ—: I plays a0.
Then II plays (b0, h0) where h0 is the restriction of h to KâŸ¨a0,b0âŸ©. Then
I plays a1 and II plays (b1, h1) where h1 is the restriction of h to KâŸ¨a0,b0,a1,b1âŸ©.
And so on.
We show that in this play, player I plays by the strategy Ïƒâˆ—. Clearly,
a0 = Ïƒ(âˆ…) = Ïƒâˆ—(âˆ…, âˆ…). Then a1 = Ïƒ(âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©), and by the deï¬nition of Ïƒ it
is clear that Ïƒ(âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©) = Ïƒâˆ—(âŸ¨a0, b0âŸ©, h(KâŸ¨a0,b0âŸ©)) and therefore a1 is a move
according to Ïƒâˆ—. And so on: All the moves a0, a1, . . . , an, . . . are by Ïƒâˆ—.
This is a contradiction because Ïƒâˆ—is a winning strategy for I in Gâˆ—, but
the play we described is won by player II. It follows that x âˆˆA and hence
Ïƒ is a winning strategy for I in the game GA.
âŠ“âŠ”
This completes the proof of Î£1

dinal. This assumption can be weakened to the assumption that aâ™¯exists for

Determinacy of all projective games is considerably stronger than Ana-
lytic Determinacy: âˆ†1

The proof of Theorem 33.3 shows that Projective Determinacy implies
that every projective set of reals is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire prop-
erty, and if uncountable, contains a perfect subset. The most important con-
sequence of PD for the structure of projective sets of reals is the existence of
scales. The following is a generalization of (25.28) and (25.34):
Deï¬nition 33.22. A Î 1
n-norm on a Î 1
n set A is a norm Ï• on A with the
property that there exist a Î 1
n relation P(x, y) and a Î£1
n relation Q(x, y) such
that for every y âˆˆA and all x,
x âˆˆA and Ï•(x) â‰¤Ï•(y) â†”P(x, y) â†”Q(x, y).
A Î£1
n-norm on a Î£1
n set A is deï¬ned similarly, as is a Î 1
n-scale on a Î 1
n set
(or a Î£1
n-scale on a Î£1
n set).
We say that the class Î 1
n has the prewellordering property (the scale prop-
erty) if every Î 1
n set has a Î 1
n-norm (a Î 1
n-scale). Î 1
n has the uniformization
property if every Î 1
n relation on N Ã— N is uniformized by a Î 1
n function.
Similarly for Î£1
n.
Theorem 33.23 (Moschovakis [1971]). Assume Projective Determinacy.
Then the following classes have the scale property (for every a âˆˆN):
Î 1
1(a), Î£1

2n+2(a), . . . .
Corollary 33.24. Assume PD. The classes Î 1
2n+1(a) and Î£1
2n+2(a) have
the prewellordering property and the uniformization property and satisfy the
reduction principle; the classes Î£1
2n+1(a) and Î 1
2n+2(a) satisfy the separation
principle.
The scale property generalizes the prewellordering property, and implies
uniformization (using the proof of KondË†oâ€™s Theorem 25.26; cf. Exercise 33.4).
The prewellordering property implies the reduction principle (as in Exer-
cise 25.7; see Exercise 33.5), which in turn implies the separation principle
for the dual class (cf. Exercise 25.9).
Moreover, since reduction holds for Î 1
2n+1 and Î£1
2n+2, separation fails
for these classes (see Exercise 25.11 and Exercise 33.6). Hence reduction,
prewellordering and scale properties fail for the dual classes Î£1
1, Î 1
2, Î£1
3, . . . .
Instead of proving Theorem 33.23 we shall prove the weaker statement:
Assuming PD, every Î 1
2n+1 and every Î£1

method.
In Chapter 25 we proved that every Î 1

Î£1

following:

For x, y âˆˆB, deï¬ne

We will show that â‰¼is a prewellordering of B and the corresponding norm

Clearly, x â‰¼x for every x âˆˆB (II wins by copying Iâ€™s moves).
To check that â‰¼is transitive, let x â‰¼y and y â‰¼z. Thus II has winning

to be the kth move of I in G(y, z) and apply the strategy in G(y, z) to
respond c(k). This c(k) is then the kth move of II in G(x, z). It is clear that
II wins.

and so II wins.

Consistency of AD
The following theorem conï¬rms what has been expected since the early
1970â€™s: Determinacy is a large cardinal axiom:
Theorem 33.26 (Martin-Steel-Woodin). If there exist inï¬nitely many
Woodin cardinals and a measurable cardinal above them, then the Axiom of
Determinacy holds in L(R).
âŠ“âŠ”
In the rest of this chapter we shall outline some ideas on which this result
is based. But ï¬rst we state two related results:
Theorem 33.27 (Woodin). The following are equiconsistent:
(i) ZFC + â€œThere exist inï¬nitely many Woodin cardinals.â€
(ii) ZF + AD.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 33.28 (Martin-Steel). Let n âˆˆN. If there exist n Woodin car-
dinals with a measurable cardinal above them then every Î 1
n+1 game is de-
termined.
âŠ“âŠ”
The crucial concept in these proofs is that of a homogeneous tree.
Following the terminology and notation of Chapter 25, and speciï¬cally
Deï¬nition 25.8, let K be a set and let T be a tree on Ï‰ Ã— K (or more
generally, on Ï‰r Ã— K). For s âˆˆSeq let
(33.13)
Ts = {t : (s, t) âˆˆT }.
In the present context, a measure is a Ïƒ-complete ultraï¬lter, not necessarily
nonprincipal.
Deï¬nition 33.29. A tree T on Ï‰ Ã— K is homogeneous if there are measures
Âµs, s âˆˆSeq, such that Âµs is a measure on Ts and:
(i) If t extends s then Ï€s,t(Âµt) = Âµs where Ï€s,t is the natural projection
map from Tt to Ts.
(ii) If x âˆˆp[T ] then the direct limit of the ultrapowers by {Âµxâ†¾n : n âˆˆÏ‰}
is well-founded.
(See Exercise 33.8 for an explicit formulation of (ii).)
A tree T is Îº-homogeneous (where Îº is a regular uncountable cardinal) if
the measures Âµs are all Îº-complete. A set A âŠ‚N is (Îº-)homogeneously Suslin
if A = p[T ] for some (Îº-)homogeneous tree T .
Homogeneous trees are an abstraction of Martinâ€™s proof of Î 1
1 Determi-

the following:

Îº-homogeneously Suslin.

cardinals with a measurable cardinal above, then every subset of N in L(R)
is Î´+-weakly homogeneously Suslin, for some Woodin cardinal Î´.

Historical Notes
Inï¬nite games were ï¬rst considered in the 1930. Mazur described an inï¬nite game
and conjectured its connection to Baire category, which was then proved by Banach.
In [1953] Gale and Stewart investigated inï¬nite games in general and proved
that the Axiom of Choice implies that there exist undetermined games and that
open games are determined.
In [1962] Mycielski and Steinhaus proposed an axiom and called it the Axiom of
Determinateness (AD). In [1963/64, 1966] Mycielski gave a comprehensive account
of consequences of AD and related open problems.
Theorem 33.3(i) is due to Mycielski and Â´Swierczkowski [1964]; the present proof
(and the covering game) is due to Harrington. Theorem 33.3(iii) is due to Morton
Davis [1964].

33. Determinacy
645
Following Solovayâ€™s discovery that AD implies that â„µ1 is a measurable cardinal,
attention has been turned to the relation between Determinacy and large cardinals.
There have been numerous results in this direction, and a vast of literature exists
on the subject. The reader can ï¬nd an excellent account of current research on AD
in Kanamoriâ€™s book [1994]; a comprehensive treatment of the subject is expected
to appear in the near future (Woodin et al. [âˆ]).
Theorem 33.12 is due to Solovay; the present proof of measurability of â„µ1
(Lemma 33.13) is due to Martin [1968].
Projective ordinals Î´1
n as well as the cardinal Î˜ were introduced by Moschovakis
[1970] and studied extensively by Kechris [1974, 1978]. The calculation of the size
of the Î´1
5 was accomplished by Steve Jackson, cf. [1988, 1999]. For the results on Î˜,
see e.g. Kechris [1985].
Theorem 33.18 (Borel Determinacy) is due to Martin [1975]; see also Mar-
tin [1985] and Kechris and Martin [1980].
Theorem 33.19: In [1969/70], Martin proved that analytic games are determined
if aâ™¯exists for all a âˆˆN; the converse was proved by Harrington in [1978].
Moschovakisâ€™ Theorem 33.23, cf. [1971], is the culmination of applications of
Projective Determinacy to classical descriptive set theory: among others, see Black-
well [1967], Addison and Moschovakis [1968] and Martin [1968]. For a comprehensive
survey, see Kechris and Moschovakis [1978].
Consistency of AD follows from the results of Martin, Steel and Woodin, cf. Mar-
tin and Steel [1988, 1989] and Woodin [1988].
Homogeneous trees are implicit in Martin and Solovay [1969] and in Mar-
tin [1969/70]. They were explicitly isolated by Kechris [1981]. Weakly homogeneous
trees ï¬gured prominently in Woodin [1988].

34. Supercompact Cardinals and the Real Line
In this chapter we present results showing the eï¬€ect of very large cardinals
(such as supercompact) on the structure of sets of real numbers. In earlier
chapters we showed that if â„µ1 is inaccessible in every L[x] (where x âˆˆR)
then all Î£1
2 sets of reals are Lebesgue measurable, have the Baire property,
and the perfect set property. If xâ™¯exists for all x âˆˆR then every Î 1
1 game is
determined. Thus already the existence of moderately large cardinals (such as
measurable) has an eï¬€ect on regularity of projective sets (but recall thatâ€”by
Silverâ€™s Theorem 32.20â€”measurability is still weak to inï¬‚uence Î£1
3 sets, as
measurable cardinals are consistent with a Î£1
3 well-ordering of R). It follows
from the results presented below that if a supercompact cardinal exists, then
all sets of reals in L(R) have the regularity properties mentioned above.
Woodin Cardinals
As we mentioned in the last chapter (Theorem 33.27), the consistency
strength of Determinacy is below a supercompact cardinal; the appropri-
ate large cardinal concept (a Woodin cardinal) was isolated in the course of
investigations leading to the proof of AD. Let us elaborate on the deï¬nition
(Deï¬nition 20.31) of Woodin cardinals: Let Îº and Î» â‰¥Îº be cardinals, and
let A be an arbitrary set. We say that Îº is Î»-strong for A if there exists an
elementary embedding j : V â†’M with critical point Îº such that
(i) j(Îº) > Î»,
(ii) VÎ» âŠ‚M,
(iii) A âˆ©VÎ» = j(A) âˆ©VÎ».
(34.1)
Hence Îº is Î»-strong if it is Î»-strong for âˆ…, and by deï¬nition, Î´ is a Woodin
cardinal if for every A âŠ‚VÎ´ there are arbitrarily large Îº < Î´ that are Î»-strong
for A for all Î» < Î´. We now present a diï¬€erent deï¬nition of Woodin cardinals
and show that it is equivalent to Deï¬nition 20.31.
Deï¬nition 34.1. A cardinal Î´ is a Woodin cardinal if for every function
f : Î´ â†’Î´ there exists a Îº < Î´ with fâ€œÎº âŠ‚Îº, and an elementary embedding
j : V â†’M with critical point Îº such that Vj(f)(Î±) âŠ‚M.

648
Part III. Selected Topics
Every supercompact cardinal is Woodin, and is a limit of Woodin car-
dinals (Exercise 34.1). An immediate consequence of Deï¬nition 34.1 is that
every Woodin cardinal is a Mahlo cardinal, and in fact has a stationary set
of measurable cardinals. The following lemma proves the equivalence of Def-
initions 20.31 and 34.1:
Lemma 34.2. The following are equivalent:
(i) For every A âŠ‚VÎ´ there exists a Îº < Î´ that is Î»-strong for A for all
Î» < Î´.
(ii) For every A âŠ‚VÎ´ the set of all Îº < Î´ that are Î»-strong for A for all
Î» < Î´ is stationary.
(iii) For every f : Î´ â†’Î´ there exists a Îº < Î´ with fâ€œÎº âŠ‚Îº, and an
elementary embedding j : V â†’M with critical point Îº such that
Vj(f)(Î±) âŠ‚M.
(iv) For every f : Î´ â†’Î´ there exists a Îº < Î´ with fâ€œÎº âŠ‚Îº, and an
extender E âˆˆVÎº with critical point Îº such that jE(f)(Îº) = f(Îº) and
Vf(Îº) âŠ‚UltE.
Proof. It suï¬ƒces to show that (i) implies (iv) and that (iii) implies (ii).
Assume that (i) holds, and let f : Î´ â†’Î´. By (i) there exists a Îº < Î´ that
is Î»-strong for A for all Î» < Î´. Let Î» < Î´ be suï¬ƒciently large, and let E be an
extender with critical point Îº such that Vf(Îº) âŠ‚UltE and f âˆ©VÎ» = jE(f)âˆ©VÎ»;
such an extender exists in VÎ´. Clearly, fâ€œÎº âŠ‚Îº, and since Î» is suï¬ƒciently
large, we have jE(f)(Îº) = f(Îº). Therefore (iv) holds.
Now assume that (iii) holds; let A âŠ‚VÎ´ and let C âŠ‚Î´ be a closed
unbounded set. To prove (ii) we need a Îº âˆˆC that is Î»-strong for A for all
Î» < Î´. For each Î± < Î´ let f(Î±) be a limit ordinal Î² âˆˆC such that if there
exists a Î» < Î´ such that Î± is not Î»-strong for A, then such a Î» exists below Î².
By (iii) there exists some Îº < Î´ with fâ€œÎº âŠ‚Îº, and an elementary j : V â†’M
with critical point Îº such that Vj(f)(Îº) âŠ‚M. Since fâ€œÎº âŠ‚Îº, C âˆ©Îº is closed
unbounded in Îº and hence Îº âˆˆj(C). By elementarity it suï¬ƒces to show that
(34.2)
M âŠ¨Îº is Î»-strong for j(A) for all Î» < j(Î´).
Assume that (34.2) fails, and let Î» be the least Î» such that in M, Îº is not
Î»-strong for j(A). By deï¬nition of f we have Î» < j(f)(Îº). Let E be the
(Îº, Î»)-extender derived from j. It is routine to verify that VÎ» âŠ‚UltE and

Semiproper Forcing
A property of forcing somewhat weaker than properness, called semiproper-
ness, have been of considerable use in the theory of large cardinals. We shall
investigate it in some detail in Chapter 37; at this point we introduce semi-
proper forcing, prove basic properties and use it in an application involv-
ing L(R) and supercompact cardinals.
Modifying condition (ii) in Lemma 31.6 and the characterization of
properness in Theorem 31.7 we obtain the following: Let P be a notion of
forcing and let Î» be suï¬ƒciently large. Let M be a countable elementary sub-
model of (HÎ», âˆˆ, <). A condition q is (M, P)-semigeneric if for every name
Ë™Î± âˆˆM such that âŠ©Ë™Î± is a countable ordinal,
(34.4)
q âŠ©âˆƒÎ² âˆˆM Ë™Î± = Î².
Deï¬nition 34.3. A notion of forcing P is semiproper if for every suï¬ƒciently
large Î» there is a closed unbounded set in [HÎ»]Ï‰ of countable elementary
submodels such that
âˆ€p âˆˆM âˆƒq â‰¤p q is (M, P)-semigeneric.
Thus semiproperness is a weaker property than properness: Deï¬nition 34.3
is obtained by replacing arbitrary ordinal names in Lemma 31.6 by names
for countable ordinals. While the condition in Theorem 31.7 is equivalent to
preservation of stationary sets in [Î»]Ï‰, only the second part of the proof of
Theorem 31.7 remains valid for semiproper forcing, and we get:
Theorem 34.4. If P is semiproper then every stationary set S âŠ‚Ï‰1 remains
stationary in V P .
âŠ“âŠ”
If P is semiproper and Ë™Q is semiproper in V P , then P âˆ—Ë™Q is semiproper.
Semiproperness is generally not preserved under countable support iteration;
the proof of Theorem 31.15 does not generalize to iterations of semiproper
forcing. (The reason is that a semiproper forcing may change the coï¬nality
of a regular uncountable cardinal to Ï‰: It is not necessarily the case that
a countable set of ordinals in V [G] is included in a set that is countable
in V .) When the iteration adds no new countable sets, however, the proof of
Theorem 31.15 does go through for semiproper forcing, and we have:
Lemma 34.5. If P is a countable support iteration of semiproper forcing
notions and if P is Ï‰-distributive, then P is semiproper.
âŠ“âŠ”
In Chapter 37 we shall deal with iterations of semiproper forcings.

650
Part III. Selected Topics
The Model L(R)
We shall now show that if there exists a supercompact cardinal then every
set of reals in L(R) is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property and
the perfect set property. In fact, the reals in L(R) behave exactly as the
reals in Solovayâ€™s model in Theorem 26.14(i). The regularity of sets of reals
in L(R) follows of course from Theorem 33.26, and we shall outline later in
this chapter the methods that lead to the proof of that theorem. We shall
prove the following:
Theorem 34.6 (Woodin). Let Îº be a superstrong cardinal and let V [G]
be the generic extension of V by the LÂ´evy collapse Col(â„µ0, <Îº). Then there
exists an elementary embedding
j : L(R) â†’(L(R))V [G].
(For superstrong cardinals, see Exercise 34.2.)
Corollary 34.7. If there exists a superstrong cardinal then every set of reals
in L(R) is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property, and has the perfect
set property. In particular, there is no projective well-ordering of R.
âŠ“âŠ”
The main result used in the proof of Theorem 34.6 is the following result
on saturated ideals:
Theorem 34.8. If Îº is a superstrong cardinal then there exists an Ï‰-dis-
tributive Îº-c.c. notion of forcing P such that in V P , Îº = â„µ2 and there exists
a normal â„µ2-saturated ideal on Ï‰1.
Let us show how Theorem 34.8 implies Theorem 34.6:

Stationary Tower Forcing
We shall describe a forcing notion, due to Hugh Woodin, that is used, among
other applications, to generalize Theorem 34.6 and prove Theorem 33.33.
Deï¬nition 34.10 (Stationary Tower Forcing). Let Îº be an inaccessible
cardinal. The forcing notion Q = Q<Îº consists of conditions (VÎ±, S) where
Î± < Îº and S is a stationary subset of [VÎ±]Ï‰. A condition (VÎ², T ) is stronger
than (VÎ±, S) if Î± â‰¤Î² and T â†¾VÎ± âŠ‚S.
Equivalently, (VÎ², T ) â‰¤(VÎ±, S) if Î± â‰¤Î² and T âŠ‚SVÎ² where SVÎ² is the
lifting of S to [VÎ²]Ï‰; see Theorem 8.27. The forcing Q<Îº is not separative:
Two conditions (VÎ±, S) and (VÎ², T ) are equivalent if and only if for some (all)
Î³ â‰¥Î±, Î², SVÎ³ â‰ƒT VÎ³ mod the nonstationary ideal on [VÎ³]Ï‰.
If (VÎ±, S) is a condition, VÎ± is determined by S (VÎ± =  S), so we can
abuse the notation by calling S a condition in Q<Îº; we say that VÎ± is the
support of S.
If G is a generic ï¬lter then for each Î± < Îº, Gâˆ©[VÎ±]Ï‰ is a normal ultraï¬lter
extending the closed unbounded ï¬lter. In V [G], we deï¬ne a generic ultrapower
UltG(V ) as follows: Consider formulas f âˆˆV deï¬ned on some VÎ±, Î± < Îº, and
let, for f on VÎ± and g on VÎ²,
(34.10)
f =G g if for some S âˆˆG with support â‰¥Î±, Î², f(xâˆ©VÎ±) = g(xâˆ©VÎ²)
for all x âˆˆS;
f âˆˆG g is deï¬ned similarly. Below we prove that if Îº is a Woodin cardinal
then UltG(V ) is well-founded.

The following deï¬nition was inspired by the earlier sections of this chapter,
in particular Exercise 34.9: Let M âŠ‚N be countable models; we say that
N end-extends M if for all u âˆˆM, u âˆ©N = u âˆ©M.
Deï¬nition 34.11. Let A be a dense set of conditions in Q<Îº. A is semiproper
if for all suï¬ƒciently large Î» there is a closed unbounded set in [HÎ»]Ï‰ of
countable elementary submodels M such that for some countable N â‰ºHÎ»,
(i) M âŠ‚N and N end-extends M âˆ©VÎº,
(ii) âˆƒS âˆˆA âˆ©N with support VÎ± such that N âˆ©VÎ± âˆˆS.
(34.11)
The deï¬nition has equivalent variants:
Lemma 34.12. Each of the following two properties is equivalent to semi-
properness of A:
(i) There is a closed unbounded set of countable M â‰ºVÎº+1 such that
some countable N â‰ºVÎº+1 satisï¬es (34.11).
(ii) For all suï¬ƒciently large Î», for every countable M â‰ºHÎ» such that
A âˆˆM there is a countable N â‰ºHÎ» that satisï¬es (34.11).
Proof. For the nontrivial implication (i) â‡’(ii) see Exercise 34.10.
âŠ“âŠ”
The following is the key lemma. If Î´ is a Woodin cardinal and A is a dense
subset of Q<Î´ then for a closed unbounded set of Îº < Î´, A âˆ©Q<Îº is dense
in Q<Îº, and for a stationary set of Îº, Îº is Î»-strong for A for all Î» < Î´.
Lemma 34.13. Let Îº < Î´ be such that A âˆ©Q<Îº is dense in Q<Îº and that
Îº is Î»-strong for A for all Î» < Î´. Then A âˆ©Q<Îº is semiproper in Q<Îº.
Proof. Toward a contradiction, assume that the set

Lemma 34.13 is used to prove the following theorem on the stationary
tower forcing:
Theorem 34.14 (Woodin, [1988]). Let Î´ be a Woodin cardinal and let
Q<Î´ be the stationary tower forcing. Let G be a generic ï¬lter on Q<Î´, and
let j : V â†’UltG be the canonical elementary embedding into the generic
ultrapower. Then
(i) UltG is well-founded.
(ii) j(Ï‰1) = Î´.
(iii) In V [G], the model UltG is closed under <Î´-sequences.
We sketch the proof of (i) and refer the reader to Woodin [1988] for the
details of the complete proof. (Woodinâ€™s paper states the theorem for a super-
compact cardinal but the proof can be easily adapted. See also Woodin [1999],
Theorem 2.36.)
Proof. (i) If A is a dense set and N is a countable model, we say that N cap-
tures A if (34.11)(ii) holds. First we claim that if A âŠ‚Q<Îº is semiproper
then for every condition p âˆˆQ<Îº there is a stronger condition q such that
every N âˆˆq captures A. This is proved by showing that the set
q = {N â‰ºVÎº+1 : N âˆ©VÎ± âˆˆp and N captures A}
(where VÎ± is the support of p) is stationary. To show this, let F : V <Ï‰
Îº+1 â†’VÎº+1
and let M â‰ºHÎ» for some Î» be such that A âˆˆM, F âˆˆM, and M âˆ©VÎ± âˆˆp.
Let N âŠƒM be such that N end-extends M âˆ©VÎº and captures A. Then
N âˆ©VÎº+1 âˆˆq and is closed under F.
One proves similarly that if An, n < Ï‰, are semiproper then for every p
there exists a q < p such that every N âˆˆq captures every An.
Now let âŸ¨Ë™fn : n < Ï‰âŸ©be a sequence of names of functions in the generic
ultrapower, names for a descending sequence of ordinals. For each n there is
a dense set An such that for each S âˆˆAn there is an ordinal function f S
n on S
such that S âŠ©Ë™fn = f S
n . Let Îº < Î´ be such that each An âˆ©Q<Îº is semiproper,
and let p âˆˆG be such that every N âˆˆp captures each An.
Now we deï¬ne, for each n < Ï‰, a function fn on p as follows: If N âˆˆp, let
fn(N) = f S
n (N) where S âˆˆAn (with support VÎ±) is such that N âˆ©VÎ± âˆˆS.
The functions fn are deï¬ned for almost all (mod INS) N âˆˆp, and fn+1(N) <
fn(N) for all n, producing a descending sequence of ordinals.
(iii) is proved similarly; one can show that if AÎ±, Î± < Î³, with Î³ < Î´
are semiproper then for every p there exists a q < p such that every N âˆˆq
captures AÎ± for all Î± âˆˆN.
(ii) follows by showing that Î´ remains a regular cardinal in V [G] and that
every Î± < Î´ is collapsed to Ï‰. While the proof of regularity of Î´ is similar to
the proof of (iii), the proof that Î± becomes countable is a consequence of the
following fact that is easy to verify: If S âˆˆQ<Î´ has support VÎ± then
S âŠ©jâ€œVÎ± âˆˆj(S).

Part III. Selected Topics
Weakly Homogeneous Trees
Let Î´ be a Woodin cardinal. By Theorem 34.14 there exists a generic ele-
mentary embedding j : V â†’M such that RM = RV [G] and j(Ï‰1) = Î´; G is
a generic ï¬lter on Q = Q<Î´. Consider the following forcing notion P in V [G]:
A forcing condition p is a V -generic ï¬lter on the LÂ´evy collapse Col(Ï‰, <Î»)
for some Î» < Î´; p is stronger than q if p âŠƒq. The forcing P does not add
reals and if H âŠ‚P is V [G]-generic then H is a V -generic ï¬lter on Col(Ï‰, <Î´).
Under additional assumptions on Î´, such as that Î´ is also a limit of Woodin
cardinals, every countably generated subalgebra of Q<Î´ has cardinality less
than Î´, and RV [G] = RV [H]. Hence there exists an elementary embedding
j : L(R) â†’L(R)Col(Ï‰,<Î´) and consequently, the sets of reals in L(R) have
the regularity properties stated in Corollary 34.7.
The above argument yields a stronger result:
Corollary 34.15. If Î´ is a Woodin cardinal and a limit of Woodin cardinals,
if P is a forcing notion such that |P| < Î´, and if G is a generic ï¬lter on P,
then the model L(R)V [G] is elementarily equivalent to L(R).
Proof. As Î´ remains a Woodin cardinal in V [G], we can ï¬nd a V -generic
ï¬lter H on Col(Ï‰, <Î´) such that V [G] âŠ‚V [H] and V [H] is a Col(Ï‰, <Î´)-
generic extension of V [G], and elementary embeddings j : L(R) â†’L(R)V [H]
and k : L(R)V [G] â†’L(R)V [H].
âŠ“âŠ”
This property of Woodin cardinals (that the theory of L(R) is unchanged
by small forcing) has been exploited by Woodin to prove the following theo-
rem. In [1988] these results are stated under the assumption that a supercom-
pact cardinal exists, but Woodin subsequently proved the theorem under the
assumption stated below. The assumption is close to optimal as Ï‰ Woodin
cardinals do not suï¬ƒce; compare also with Theorem 35.20. The proof of (ii)
uses the result in (i), and is a restatement of Theorem 33.33, establishing
Determinacy in L(R).
Theorem 34.16 (Woodin, [1988]). Assume that there exist inï¬nitely many
Woodin cardinals with a measurable cardinal above them. Let Î» be the supre-
mum of the ï¬rst Ï‰ Woodin cardinals.
(i) For every set A âŠ‚R in L(R) there exist trees T and S such that

658
Part III. Selected Topics
Historical Notes
Woodin cardinals were introduced by Woodin (both Deï¬nitions 20.31 and 34.1).
Strong and superstrong cardinals were considered by Mitchell [1979a], Dodd and
Jensen (Dodd [1982]) and Baldwin [1986], in their study of inner models.
Semiproper forcing was introduced by Shelah and was investigated extensively
by Foreman, Magidor, and Shelah in [1988]. For Theorem 34.6, see Shelah and
Woodin [1990]. The proof of Theorem 34.8 was inspired by the work of Foreman,
Magidor, and Shelah on Martinâ€™s Maximum.
Stationary tower forcing and its applications (Theorem 34.14, Corollary 34.15,
and Theorem 34.16) are due to Woodin.

35. Inner Models for Large Cardinals
This chapter is an introduction to the highly technical theory of inner models
for large cardinals. We present the fundamental concepts and ideas of the
theory and state, mostly without a proof (or giving an outline of a proof)
some signiï¬cant results.
There are two major themes in the theory of inner models. One is that
with a given large cardinal property one can associate a minimal inner model
of ZFC for that property. An example is the model L[U] for a measurable
cardinal. The other is the construction of core models for large cardinals.
These generalize the Dodd-Jensen core model K that we describe in some
detail. K is an inner model of ZFC that satisï¬es GCH and either the Covering
Theorem holds for K (see below) or L[U] exists.
Deï¬nition 35.1. Let M be an inner model of ZFC. We say that the Cov-
ering Theorem holds for M if for every uncountable set X of ordinals there
exists some Y âˆˆM such that |Y | = |X|.
If the Covering Theorem holds for some inner model M that satisï¬es GCH
then (exactly as in Corollaries 18.31â€“18.33) the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis
holds, every singular cardinal is singular in M, and (Îº+)M = Îº+ for every
singular cardinal Îº.
A theory of core models has been developed for large cardinals up to
a Woodin cardinal. While the Covering Theorem does not hold beyond K,
a generalized core model possesses the following feature: If there exists no
inner model for a large cardinal with a given property then the core model M
for such a property is â€œclose toâ€ the universe V ; typically, (Îº+)M = Îº+ for
every singular strong limit cardinal. This feature makes core models a tool
for gauging the consistency strength of set-theoretical conjectures.
As an example, Dodd-Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem for K gives a lower
bound for the consistency of the failure of SCH: If SCH fails then the Cover-
ing Theorem for K fails and therefore there exists an inner model for a mea-
surable cardinal.

660
Part III. Selected Topics
The Core Model
The origin of the core model theory was the construction, by Dodd and
Jensen, of the core model K. The Dodd-Jensen core model (â€œthe core model
up to a measurable cardinalâ€) is an inner model K that contains much of
the large cardinal structure without the existence of measurable cardinals.
Its main features are:
(1) K has a deï¬nable well-ordering, satisï¬es GCH and combinatorial prin-
ciples such as â–¡.
(2) There exists a nontrivial elementary embedding j : K â†’K if and
only if L[U] exists.
(3) If L[U] does not exist then the Covering Theorem holds for K.
If L[U] exists then K has a simple deï¬nition:
Deï¬nition 35.2. Assume that L[U] exists. The core model is the inner
model

U (L[U]).
It is easy to verify that K is an inner model. Only the lower parts of the
iterated ultrapowers matter; see Exercise 35.1.
Central to the theory of inner models is the â€œinternalâ€ deï¬nition of K.
The main idea underlying the theory, including the generalizations of K, is
that the core model is approximated by transitive models (sets), so called
mice. Mice are the building blocks of K, as much as the models LÎ± are for L.
The preferred hierarchy for the ï¬ne structure of L is the Jensen hierar-
chy JÎ±. For K, we use its relativization JA

suï¬ƒcient that the Ï‰1st iterate is well-founded.
Deï¬nition 35.5. K = L{M : M is a mouse}.
Below we outline a proof of the following theorem:
Theorem 35.6 (Dodd-Jensen).
(i) K is an inner model of ZFC and has a Î£2 well-ordering.
(ii) K satisï¬es GCH.
(iii) RK has a Î£1

(iv) KK = K, and KV [G] = K for every generic extension.
(v) If L[U] exists then K = 

U L[U].
(vi) In K, L[U] does not exist.
(vii) If 0â™¯does not exist then K = L. If 0â™¯exists then 0â™¯âˆˆK. More
generally, for every x âˆˆK, if xâ™¯exists then xâ™¯âˆˆK.
âŠ“âŠ”
We now outline the basic theory of mice and techniques used in the core

Lemma 35.7. A mouse exists if and only if 0â™¯exists.
Proof. If a mouse exists at Îº, then the iterates Îº(Î±) are indiscernibles for L.

Being a mouse is absolute for transitive models of ZF, and so is the well-
ordering of mice. Thus if M is an inner model then KM = L{N : N is
a mouse and N âˆˆM}, and KK = K. Since the well-ordering of mice is
deï¬nable in K, K is a model of ZFC.

One important feature of K is the following, which we state without
a proof:
Lemma 35.10. If mice exist then K = {M : M is a mouse}.
