35. Inner Models for Large Cardinals
663
Proofs in the core model theory such as the proof of Lemma 35.10 involve
iterations of mice. One of the diï¬ƒculties is that since mice do not satisfy ZFâˆ’,
the resulting embeddings are not fully elementary. It is easy to verify that
i0,1 : M â†’UltU M is Î£0-elementary, and an additional argument shows that
i0,1 is Î£1-elementary; similarly for iÎ±,Î². While the ï¬nite iterates of a mouse
are mice, arbitrary iterates are not. See Exercises 35.5â€“35.7.
The proof of GCH in K resembles somewhat Silverâ€™s proof of GCH
in L[U]. Instrumental in the proof (and proofs of combinatorial principles
in K) are condensation arguments, similar to Lemmas 18.38 and 27.5. These
proofs use heavily the ï¬ne structure of K (including projecta, standard codes
and parameters), reducing arguments about Î£n to Î£1.
The ï¬ne structure of K makes it possible to generalize combinatorial
properties such as â™¦and â–¡from L to K.
There is an alternative way of developing the theory of K and proving
the main theorems. This method, due to Magidor, uses the closed unbounded
ï¬lter directly. Instead of using mice, K can be deï¬ned using Deï¬nition 35.12
below (this deï¬nition is equivalent to the Dodd-Jensen deï¬nition).
Deï¬nition 35.11. The closed unbounded ï¬lter CÎº on Îº survives at Î² if for
every n and f : [Îº]n â†’{0, 1} with f âˆˆLÎ²+1[CÎº] there is a set C âˆˆCÎº
homogeneous for f.
Deï¬nition 35.12. A set x belongs to K if and only if for some Îº > rank(x)
and some Î², x âˆˆLÎ²[CÎº] and CÎº survives at Î².
If CÎº survives at Î² then it survives at all Î²â€² < Î². If it survives at all Î² then
L[CÎº] is the inner model for one measurable cardinal. CÎº survives vacuously
at every Î² < Îº, and survives at Îº if and only if 0â™¯exists (Exercise 35.8).
If L[U] exists then for every suï¬ƒciently large regular Îº, L[CÎº] = L[U (Îº)],
and so {LÎ²[CÎº] âˆ©VÎº : CÎº survives at Î²} = {L[U (Îº)] âˆ©VÎº : Îº > Ï‰ regu-
lar} = K.
The Covering Theorem for K
The two main results on the core model are that unless L[U] exists, K is
rigid and the Covering Theorem holds for K:
Theorem 35.13 (Dodd-Jensen). The following are equivalent:
(i) L[U] exists.
(ii) There exists a nontrivial elementary embedding j : K â†’K.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 35.14 (Dodd-Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem for K). If L[U]
does not exist, then for every uncountable set X of ordinals there exists a set
Y âŠƒX in K such that |Y | = |X|.
âŠ“âŠ”

664
Part III. Selected Topics
If L[U] exists then the ultrapower by U yields an elementary embedding
j : K â†’K. The proof of the converse shows somewhat more: If j : K â†’M
is elementary, then necessarily M = K (and L[U] exists). The proofs of both
theorems use the ï¬ne structure of K, but a great deal of the ï¬ne structure
can be eliminated when using Magidorâ€™s approach.
Since K is a model of ZFC, Corollaries 18.31, 18.32 and 18.33 all remain
true when L is replaced by K:
Corollary 35.15. If L[U] does not exist then every singular cardinal is sin-
gular in K, (Îº+)K = Îº+ for every singular Îº, and the Singular Cardinal
Hypothesis holds.
âŠ“âŠ”
The Covering Theorem for L[U]
By Prikryâ€™s Theorem 21.10 there is a generic extension of L[U] in which the
measurable cardinal Îº of L[U] remains a cardinal while cf Îº = Ï‰. It follows
that the Covering Theorem for L[U] fails. However, it turns out that the
existence of a Prikry sequence is the only obstacle to the Covering Theorem:
Theorem 35.16 (Dodd-Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem for L[U]). As-
sume that there is an inner model with a measurable cardinal, let Îº be the
least such cardinal and let U be a measure on Îº in L[U]. Then
(i) either 0â€  exists, or
(ii) the Covering Theorem holds for L[U], or
(iii) there exists an Ï‰-sequence S âŠ‚Îº Prikry generic over L[U], such that
the Covering Theorem holds for L[U][S].
âŠ“âŠ”
Note that by Theorem 21.14, L[U][S] = L[S].
The Core Model for Sequences of Measures
The theory of K has been generalized by W. Mitchell who constructed a core
model Km for sequences of measures (the â€œcore model up to o(Îº) = Îº++â€).
In analogy with K,
(i) Km has a deï¬nable well-ordering, satisï¬es GCH and â–¡.
(ii) There exists a nontrivial j : Km â†’Km if and only if there is an inner
model for a measurable cardinal Îº with o(Îº) = Îº++.
(iii) If there is no model for o(Îº) = Îº++ then a â€œweakâ€ covering theorem
holds for Km.
Mitchellâ€™s core model is the union of mice where a mouse is an appropri-
ate generalization of the Dodd-Jensen mouse. The main result on Km is as
follows:

35. Inner Models for Large Cardinals
665
Theorem 35.17 (Mitchell).
(i) Km is a model of ZFC + GCH.
(ii) Km has a Î£2 well-ordering and â–¡holds; R âˆ©Km has a Î£1
3 well-
ordering.
If there exists no inner model for o(Îº) = Îº++, then:
(iii) If U is a normal iterable Km-ultraï¬lter with UltU(Km) well-founded
then U âˆˆKm.
(iv) If j : Km â†’M is a nontrivial elementary embedding then j is an iter-
ated ultrapower using measures in Km. (Hence there is no nontrivial
j : Km â†’Km.)
(v) If Îº is a singular strong limit cardinal then (Îº+)Km = Îº+.
âŠ“âŠ”
Clause (v) is often called â€œthe Weak Covering Theorem.â€
Theorem 35.17 is a useful tool for obtaining lower bounds for the consis-
tency strength. As an example, we present the following application:
Corollary 35.18 (Mitchell). Assume that Îº is a measurable cardinal and
2Îº > Îº+. Then there is an inner model with a measurable Î» of order Î»++.
Proof. If there is no such model then (iii) and (iv) hold. Let D be a normal
measure on Îº and jD : V â†’M = UltD(V ); let j = jDâ†¾Km : Km â†’N.
By (iv), j is an iterated ultrapower, j = i0,Ï‘ : Km â†’Ult(Ï‘) = N, by
measures in Km. Let NÎ½, Î½ â‰¤Ï‘, be the iterates; N0 = Km and NÏ‘ = N.
If Î½ < Ï‘ is a limit ordinal then there exist Î¾Î½ < Î½ and UÎ½ âˆˆNÎ¾Î½ such that
NÎ½+1 = UltiÎ¾Î½ ,Î½(UÎ½)(NÎ½). Since o(Îº) < Îº++ â‰¤2Îº â‰¤Ï‘, there is a stationary
set S âŠ‚Îº++ of ordinals of coï¬nality Ï‰ such that Î¾Î½ = Î¾ and UÎ½ = U are
constant for Î½ âˆˆS. Let Î½ âˆˆS be a limit point of S, let âŸ¨Î½n : n < Ï‰âŸ©be
coï¬nal in S âˆ©Î½, and let Îºn be the critical point of iÎ½n,Î½, for each n. The
sequence âŸ¨Îºn : n < Ï‰âŸ©generates the measure iÎ¾,Î½(U) and belongs to M,
hence iÎ¾,Î½(U) âˆˆM. By (iii), iÎ¾,Î½(U) âˆˆ(Km)M = NÏ‘ but this is impossible
since iÎ¾,Î½(U) /âˆˆNÎ½+1.
âŠ“âŠ”
This, combined with a theorem of Gitik [1989] shows that the existence
of a measurable cardinal Îº such that 2Îº > Îº+ is equiconsistent with the
existence of a measurable cardinal Îº of Mitchell order Îº++.
Another result of Gitik (cf. [1989] and [1991]) shows that the consis-
tency strength of the failure of SCH is exactly a measurable cardinal Îº with
o(Îº) = Îº++.
Up to a Strong Cardinal
The current core model theory employs sequences of extenders rather than
sequences of measures. This not only enables one to generalize the theory to

666
Part III. Selected Topics
large cardinals beyond measurable but also has some technical advantages
even in the case of Km.
Strong cardinals (see Chapter 20) were introduced by Dodd and Jensen
who also provided their characterization in terms of extenders. They also con-
structed an inner model of the form L[E] where E is a (transï¬nite) sequence
of extenders such that
(i) L[E] is a model of ZFC,
(ii) in L[E], E witnesses that there exists a strong cardinal,
(iii) L[E] satisï¬es GCH, â–¡, and has a Î£1
3 well-ordering of the reals.
They also introduced a real, the sharp for a strong cardinal, that exists if and
only if there exists a nontrivial elementary embedding j : L[E] â†’L[E].
The theory of core models up to a strong cardinal uses mice of the form JE
Î±
where E is a sequence of JE
Î±-extenders. The crucial fact that makes the gen-
eralization of the Dodd-Jensen theory possible is that one uses sequences of
non-overlapping extenders. (Two extenders overlap if one is a (Îº, Î»)-extender,
the other a (Îºâ€², Î»â€²)-extender and Îº â‰¤Îºâ€² < Î».) This fact allows the compari-
son of mice by iteration, and while the generalization is far from routine, one
obtains a result similar to those for K and Km.
Theorem 35.19. There exists an inner model Kstrong such that:
(i) Kstrong is a model of ZFC + GCH.
(ii) Kstrong has a Î£2 well-ordering and â–¡holds; Râˆ©Kstrong has a Î£1
3 well-
ordering.
If there exists no inner model for a strong cardinal then:
(iii) If j : Kstrong â†’M is a nontrivial elementary embedding then j is an
iterated ultrapower by extenders in Kstrong. (Hence there is no non-
trivial j : Kstrong â†’Kstrong.)
(iv) If Îº is a singular strong limit cardinal then (Îº+)Kstrong = Îº+.
âŠ“âŠ”
Inner Models for Woodin Cardinals
Inner models for very large cardinals employ a new method of comparison
of mice. Due to the presence of overlapping extenders, a â€œlinearâ€ iteration
of mice does not work and a new technique has been developedâ€”the theory
of iteration trees. Iteration trees were introduced by Martin and Steel, who
used the technique to construct inner models for Woodin cardinals
Theorem 35.20 (Martin-Steel). If there are n Woodin cardinals then
there is an inner model that has n Woodin cardinals, and its reals have
a Î£1
n+2 well-ordering.
âŠ“âŠ”

35. Inner Models for Large Cardinals
667
The Î£1
n+2 result is best possible: If there are n Woodin cardinals with
a measurable cardinal above them then Î 1
n+1 determinacy holds (Theo-
rem 33.26) and so R does not have a Î£1
n+2 well-ordering.
The ï¬ne structure for iteration trees was developed further by Mitchell
and Steel who constructed an inner model for a Woodin cardinal that sat-
isï¬es GCH. Then Steel constructed a core model up to a Woodin cardinal,
under an additional assumption of a measurable cardinal above.
Let â„¦be a measurable cardinal. Steelâ€™s core model Ksteel is an inner model
of Vâ„¦and if Vâ„¦has no inner model with a Woodin cardinal then Ksteel is
both rigid and satisï¬es the Weak Covering Theorem:
Theorem 35.21. Let â„¦be a measurable cardinal.
(i) (Ksteel)Vâ„¦[G] = Ksteel, for every generic extension of V â„¦(by forcing
in Vâ„¦).
If Vâ„¦has no inner model with a Woodin cardinal then:
(ii) There is no nontrivial elementary embedding j : Ksteel â†’Ksteel.
(iii) For every singular cardinal Î» < â„¦, (Î»+)Ksteel = Î»+.
âŠ“âŠ”
The following is an application of Steelâ€™s core model:
Theorem 35.22 (Steel). If â„µ1 carries an â„µ2-saturated ideal, and if there
exists a measurable cardinal, then there exists an inner model with a Woodin
cardinal.
âŠ“âŠ”
This is (almost) best possible, as Shelah proved that if Îº is a Woodin
cardinal then there is a generic extension in which Îº = Ï‰2 and NSÏ‰1 is Ï‰2-
saturated.

Historical Notes
The core model K was introduced by Dodd and Jensen in [1981, 1982a, 1982b];
see also Dodd [1982]. Theorem 35.6 is proved in [1981], Theorem 35.13 and 35.14
in [1982a], and the proof of â™¦and â–¡in K is due to Welch. An overview of K, with
some proofs, can be found in Mitchell [1979b] and Dodd [1983]. Magidorâ€™s approach
is described in Magidor [1990] and in Kanamoriâ€™s forthcoming book [âˆ].
The core model Km for sequences of measures was introduced by Mitchell.
Theorem 35.17 was stated in Mitchell [1984]. Its proof has never been published
but a detailed sketch will appear in Mitchell [âˆb] (in the forthcoming Handbook
of Set Theory). Mitchellâ€™s article [âˆb] and its companion [âˆa] give an excellent
introduction to the inner model theory, as does the more expository Mitchell [1994].
The inner model L[E] for a strong cardinal appeared in Dodd [1982]. The deï¬-
nition of Kstrong is given explicitly in Koepke [1989] where Theorem 35.19 is stated
(a proof has not been published).
Iteration trees are introduced in Martin and Steel [1994] where Theorem 35.20 is
proved. Fine structure for iteration trees is developed in Mitchell and Steel [1994]
obtaining an inner model with a Woodin cardinal and GCH. Steelâ€™s core model
is constructed in Steel [1996], proving Theorem 35.21(i), (ii) and Theorem 35.22.
Theorem 35.21(iii) is proved in Mitchell et al. [1997].
An overview of these (and of more recent results) is given in LÂ¨owe and
Steel [1999].

36. Forcing and Large Cardinals
In this chapter we continue to develop the techniques introduced in Chap-
ter 21. We shall describe several applications of forcing that use various large
cardinal assumptions.
Violating GCH at a Measurable Cardinal
By Silverâ€™s Theorem 21.4 it is consistent, relative to a supercompact cardinal,
that GCH can fail at a measurable cardinal. This, combined with Prikry
forcing, shows further that the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis is unprovable.
The consistency strength of both statements has been proved to be exactly
o(Îº) = Îº++:
Theorem 36.1 (Gitik). The following are equiconsistent:
(i) There exists a measurable cardinal Îº such that 2Îº > Îº+.
(ii) There exists a strong limit singular cardinal Îº such that 2Îº > Îº+.
(iii) There exists a measurable cardinal Îº of Mitchell order Îº++.
As proved in Chapter 21 (Corollary 21.13), the consistency of (ii) follows
from the consistency of (i) by Prikry forcing. The necessity of (iii) for the
consistency of â€œnot SCHâ€ was proved by Gitik, by a combination of the pcf
theory and Mitchellâ€™s inner model for sequences of measures. We omit the
proof.
As for the consistency of (i) using o(Îº) = Îº++, this improvement of Silverâ€™s
Theorem 21.4 is a combination of an intermediate forcing result of Woodin
which we outline below, and an additional forcing argument of Gitik that we
also omit.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 36.2 (Woodin). Assume GCH and assume that there exists an
elementary embedding j : V â†’M with critical point Îº such that M Îº âŠ‚M
and that there exists a function f : Îº â†’Îº with j(f)(Îº) = Îº++. Then there is
a generic extension in which Îº is a measurable cardinal and 2Îº > Îº+.
The assumption of Theorem 36.2 is easily seen to follow from Îº being
(Îº + 2)-strong (Exercise 36.1). By Gitik, the statement holds in some generic
extension of the canonical inner model for o(Îº) = Îº++.

Details can be found in Gitikâ€™s paper [1989].
As this ï¬nal step is performed inside V [G][K], it follows that in V [G][K],
Îº is measurable.

The Singular Cardinal Problem
By Corollary 21.13, the negation of the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis is con-
sistent relative to large cardinals, and its consistency strength is determined
by Theorem 36.1. These results belong to a wide area of theorems and con-
jectures known collectively as the Singular Cardinal Problem. Unlike the be-
haviour of the continuum function on regular cardinals, which by Eastonâ€™s
Theorem can be quite arbitrary, the values of the continuum function at
singular cardinals are subject to three kinds of constraint:
(1) By Silverâ€™s Theorems 8.12 and 8.13, the value of 2Îº for a singular car-
dinal Îº of uncountable coï¬nality depends on the continuum function
below Îº.
(2) The Galvin-Hajnal Theorem 24.1 and Shelahâ€™s results in the pcf theory
give upper bounds for the value of 2Îº when Îº is a strong limit singular
cardinal such that Îº < â„µÎº.
(3) Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem 18.30 and the subsequent theory of core
models shows that the consistency of the failure of SCH requires large
cardinal assumptions.
There is a large body of forcing constructions that, using large cardinals,
yield models with various behaviour of the continuum function subject to the
above mentioned constraints. There is, however, no comprehensive solution
of the Singular Cardinal Problem analogous to Eastonâ€™s Theorem.
Below we list some of the advances in this area:
Theorem 36.3 (Magidor [1977a], [1977b]).
(i) If there exists a supercompact cardinal then there is a generic extension
in which 2â„µn < â„µÏ‰ for all n < Ï‰ and 2â„µÏ‰ = â„µÏ‰+2.

36. Forcing and Large Cardinals
673
(ii) If there exist Îº < Î» with Îº supercompact and Î» huge then there exists
a generic extension in which 2â„µn = â„µn+1 for all n < Ï‰ and 2â„µÏ‰ =
â„µÏ‰+2.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 36.4 (Woodin, Gitik [1989]). If there exists a measurable car-
dinal Îº of Mitchell order Îº++, then there exists a generic extension in which
GCH holds below â„µÏ‰ and 2â„µÏ‰ = â„µÏ‰+2.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 36.5 (Magidor [1977a], Shelah [1983], Gitik [âˆ]). Assume
that there exists a supercompact cardinal.
(i) There is a generic extension in which GCH holds below â„µÏ‰, and 2â„µÏ‰ =
â„µÏ‰+Î±+1, where Î± is any prescribed countable ordinal.
(ii) There is a generic extension in which â„µÏ‰1 is strong limit and 2â„µÏ‰1 =
â„µÏ‰1+Î±+1 for any prescribed ordinal Î± < Ï‰2.
(iii) There is a generic extension in which GCH holds below the least ï¬xed
point of the aleph function Îº = â„µÎº while 2Îº is any arbitrarily large
prescribed successor cardinal.
âŠ“âŠ”
Theorem 36.6 (Woodin, Cummings [1992]).
(i) If there exists a supercompact cardinal, then there is a generic exten-
sion in which 2Îº = Îº++ for each cardinal Îº.
(ii) If there exists a strong cardinal, then there is a generic extension in
which 2Îº = Îº+ for each successor cardinal and 2Îº = Îº++ for each
limit cardinal.
âŠ“âŠ”
There are additional results on the failure of SCH by Gitik, Shelah and
others. The main open problem in this area is the following:
Problem 36.7. Is it consistent that â„µÏ‰ is strong limit and 2â„µÏ‰ > â„µÏ‰1?
Compare this with Shelahâ€™s Theorem 24.33.
Violating SCH at â„µÏ‰
We shall now outline the Woodin-Gitik modiï¬cation of Magidorâ€™s technique
for getting a model in which â„µÏ‰ is strong limit and 2â„µÏ‰ = â„µÏ‰+2. First we
describe the preparation forcing (which replaces Magidorâ€™s use of a super-
compact cardinal):
Lemma 36.8. Assume that there exists a measurable cardinal Îº with o(Îº) =
Îº++.
(i) There is a model V that satisï¬es GCH and
(36.9)
âˆƒj : V â†’M, crit(j) = Îº, M Îº âŠ‚M and (Îº++)M = Îº++.

Part III. Selected Topics
(ii) There exists a model V with a measurable cardinal Îº such that 2Îº =
Îº++ and a normal measure U on Îº with N = UltU(V ), and there exists
a set G âˆˆV which is an N-generic ï¬lter on ColN((Îº+++)N, <jU(Îº))
(a LÂ´evy collapse in N).
Proof. (i) We outline how to get a model that satisï¬es (36.9). First one
uses Gitikâ€™s forcing from [1989] to get a model of GCH that has a (Îº, Îº++)-
extender E and a function f : Îº â†’Îº such that j(f)(Îº) = Îº++ (the as-

an inaccessible cardinal. To obtain (36.9), one uses the iteration of length Îº,
with Easton support, of LÂ´evy collapses Col(Î±+, <f(Î±)), followed by the LÂ´evy
collapse Col(Îº+, <Îº++). In this generic extension, the embedding j : V â†’M
can be extended to an embedding that satisï¬es (36.9). (For details, see Gi-
tik [1989].)
(ii) Starting with j : V â†’M that satisï¬es (36.9), we do Woodinâ€™s con-
struction described in the proof of Theorem 36.2, except that by (36.9), we
may assume that f(Î±) = Î±++ for all Î±. In the resulting model, Îº is mea-
surable, 2Îº = Îº++, and if U is the measure {X : Îº âˆˆj(X)} given by the
extended embedding j, then U has the required property. (Again, details are
in Gitikâ€™s [1989].)
âŠ“âŠ”

2Îº = Îº++, U is a normal measure on Îº, N = UltU(V ) and j = jU : V â†’N,

in N. Magidorâ€™s forcing conditions are as follows:

The crucial property of this forcing is that the cardinals Îºn are preserved,

675
and 2Îºn < Îºn+1. Since all but ï¬nitely many cardinals between Îºn and Îºn+1

can follow this generic extension by a LÂ´evy collapse Col(â„µ0, <Îº0) and in the
resulting model we have Îº = â„µÏ‰ and 2â„µÏ‰ = â„µÏ‰+2 with â„µÏ‰ strong limit.
The key to preservation of the cardinals Îºn is an analog of Prikryâ€™s
Lemma 21.12:
Lemma 36.9. Let Ïƒ be a sentence of the forcing language and let p = (Îº0, f0,
. . . , Îºnâˆ’1, fnâˆ’1, A, F) be a condition. Then there exists a stronger condition

We omit the proof of Lemma 36.9 as well as its application and refer the
reader to Magidor [1977a] and Gitik [1989] for the details.
Radin Forcing
As a consequence of Jensenâ€™s Covering Theorem, and more generally of the
inner model theory, large cardinals are necessary for any nontrivial change
of coï¬nality (with the exception of Namba forcing, Theorem 28.10). Prikry
forcing is the prime example of forcing that changes coï¬nality. In this section
we describe its generalizations.
The ï¬rst example, due to Magidor, generalizes Prikry forcing to change
the coï¬nality of a large cardinal Îº to a given regular cardinal Î» < Îº while
preserving Îº as a cardinal:
Let Î» be a regular cardinal and let Îº > Î» be a measurable cardinal such
that o(Îº) = Î». Using an inner model for o(Îº) = Î», we may assume that there
exists a sequence
(36.12)
U0 < U1 < . . . < UÎ± < . . .
(Î± < Î»)
of normal measures on Îº, ordered by the Mitchell order. For every Î± < Î² < Î»,
let f Î²
Î± : Îº â†’VÎº be the function that represents UÎ± in UltUÎ², i.e., [f Î²
Î±]UÎ² = UÎ±.
A forcing condition is a pair (g, G) such that
(i) g is an increasing function from a ï¬nite subset of Î» into Îº,
(ii) G is a function on Î» such that G(Î±) âŠ‚Îº for all Î± < Î»,
(iii) if Î± > max(dom g) then G(Î±) âˆˆUÎ±,
(iv) if Î± < max(dom g) and Î² is the least Î² âˆˆdom(g) above Î±,
then G(Î±) âˆˆf Î²
Î±(g(Î²)).
(36.13)
The ï¬nite function g plays the role of the ï¬nite sequence in the Prikry
forcing. The function G plays the role of the measure one set: Clause (iii) is
an obvious generalization while (iv) states that G(Î±) has measure one with

Î±(g(Î²)) on g(Î²), which reï¬‚ects the properties of the
measure UÎ± in the ultrapower by UÎ².
A condition (h, H) is stronger than (g, G) if
(i) h âŠƒg,
(ii) for every Î±, H(Î±) âŠ‚G(Î±),
(iii) for every Î± âˆˆdom(h) âˆ’dom(g), h(Î±) âˆˆG(Î±).
(36.14)
Magidorâ€™s forcing (36.13) is a generalization of Prikry forcing. A generic
ï¬lter yields a coï¬nal Î»-sequence in Îº (Exercise 36.10). Similarly to the Prikry
forcing, (36.13) has a Îº+-chain condition (Exercise 36.11). The crucial prop-
erty of Magidorâ€™s forcing is that it preserves cardinals. The proof is a gen-
eralization of the proof for the Prikry forcing and the following is the key
lemma:
Lemma 36.10. Let Ïƒ be a sentence of the forcing language and let (g, G) be
a condition. Then there exists a stronger condition (g, H) (with the same g)
that decides Ïƒ.
âŠ“âŠ”
Magidorâ€™s forcing changes the coï¬nality of Îº to cf Îº = Î», under the as-
sumption that o(Îº) = Î». If Î» is uncountable then by Mitchell [1984] this
assumption is necessary.
Radin forcing generalizes Prikry forcing further and uses objects called
measure sequences. Let j : V â†’M be an elementary embedding with critical
point Îº. Let us deï¬ne a sequence âŸ¨u(Î±) : Î± < Ï‘âŸ©as follows:
(36.15)

(Î± > 0).

on Î±-sequences.
We deï¬ne measure sequences as sequences obtained by (36.15) from ele-

Stationary Tower Forcing
We now describe the general version of the stationary tower forcing (Deï¬ni-
tion 34.10) which can be used, among others, to change coï¬nalities in a way
that is not possible without very large cardinals.
Let A be an uncountable set. A set S âŠ‚P(A) is stationary in P(A) if for
every F : [A]<Ï‰ â†’A, S contains a closure point of F, i.e., a set X âŠ‚A such
that F(e) âˆˆX for all e âˆˆ[X]<Ï‰. As in Theorem 8.27, projections and liftings
of stationary sets are stationary. Also, the analog of Theorem 8.24 holds. For
the relation to stationary sets in PÎº(Î») see Exercise 36.17.
Deï¬nition 36.17 (Stationary Tower Forcing). Let Î´ be a Woodin car-
dinal. The forcing notion P = P<Î´ consists of conditions (A, S) where A âˆˆVÎ´
is uncountable and S is stationary in P(A). (B, T) is stronger than (A, S) if
B âŠƒA and T â†¾A âŠ‚S.
If G is a generic ï¬lter on P<Î´ then we form the generic ultrapower UltG(V )
as in (34.10). The general form of Theorem 34.14 is as follows:
Theorem 36.18 (Woodin [1988]). Let Î´ be a Woodin cardinal. If G is
generic on P<Î´ then the generic ultrapower UltG(V ) is well-founded and the
model UltG(V ) is closed under < Î´-sequences.
âŠ“âŠ”

Forcing with P<Î´ gives more ï¬‚exibility than forcing with Q<Î´ (from Def-

gular cardinal and give it any prescribed coï¬nality, see Example 36.19 below.
In fact, the consistency strength of this is exactly that of a Woodin cardinal.

Historical Notes
Following the (unpublished) Theorem 36.2 of Woodin, Gitik proved in [1989] that
o(Îº) = Îº++ suï¬ƒces for the consistency of a measurable cardinal Îº with 2Îº = Îº++,
as well as for a model of â€œâ„µÏ‰ is strong limit and 2â„µÏ‰ = â„µÏ‰+2.â€ In [1991], Gitik
showed that the assumption o(Îº) = Îº++ is necessary for the negation of SCH.
Methods for violating GCH at â„µÏ‰ were originated by Magidor in [1977a, 1977b].
Woodin (unpublished) improved the method by using a (Îº+2)-strong cardinal, and
Gitik [1989] obtained the result from o(Îº) = Îº++.
In [1983], Shelah improved Magidorâ€™s method in the direction of getting an ar-
bitrary countable gap between â„µÏ‰ and 2â„µÏ‰. In [1992], Gitik and Magidor introduced
a novel method for blowing up the power of 2Îº for singular cardinals, leading to re-
sults that give the precise consistency strength (e.g., the large cardinal assumptions
for Theorem 36.5 are considerably weaker than supercompactness).
In [1991], Foreman and Woodin constructed a model in which GCH fails ev-
erywhere; this was then improved by Woodin to Theorem 36.6(i), and Cummings
followed with 36.6(ii).
Magidorâ€™s forcing for changing coï¬nality appeared in [1978]. For Radinâ€™s forcing,
see Radin [1982]. Our presentation is based on improvements by Mitchell [1982],
Woodin (unpublished) and Cummings [1992]. Theorem 36.16 is due to Mitchell
[1982].
Stationary tower forcing is due to Woodin.

37. Martinâ€™s Maximum
This chapter is devoted to a generalization of the Proper Forcing Axiom.
The stronger axiom is obtained by replacing â€œproper notion of forcingâ€ in
Deï¬nition 31.20 by â€œstationary set preserving notion of forcing.â€ A notion of
forcing P is stationary set preserving if every stationary set S âŠ‚Ï‰1 remains
stationary in V P .
Deï¬nition 37.1 (Martinâ€™s Maximum (MM)). If (P, <) is a stationary
set preserving notion of forcing and if D is a collection of â„µ1 dense subsets
of P, then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.
As every proper notion of forcing is stationary set preserving, MM is
a strengthening of PFA which in turn is a strengthening of MA. The ax-
iom MM has been dubbed â€œMartinâ€™s Maximumâ€ as it is ostensibly the
strongest possible generalization of Martinâ€™s Axiom: If P is not stationary
set preserving then the corresponding axiom for P is false (Exercise 37.1).
Below we establish the consistency of Martinâ€™s Maximum, and present
some applications.
RCS iteration of semiproper forcing
The proof of the consistency of MM is modeled after the consistency proof
of either MA or PFA: By iterated forcing one obtains a generic extension in
which every stationary set preserving P satisï¬es the statement of MM.
The straightforward approach, iterating stationary set preserving forc-
ings, does not work: If g : Ï‰1 â†’Ï‰1 dominates the canonical functions fÎ·,
Î· < Ï‰2, (mod INS) then there is a stationary preserving forcing notion Pg that
produces a function f < g mod INS (and still above the fÎ·) (Exercise 37.2).
An Ï‰-iteration of such forcing collapses Ï‰1.
It turns out that semiproper forcing can be iterated, yielding the consis-
tency of the following principle:
Deï¬nition 37.2 (Semiproper Forcing Axiom (SPFA)). If (P, <) is
a semiproper notion of forcing and if D is a collection of â„µ1 dense subsets
of P then there exists a D-generic ï¬lter on P.

682
Part III. Selected Topics
Clearly, MM implies SPFA and SPFA implies PFA. In the next section
we show that SPFA is in fact equivalent to MM and so for the consistency
of MM it is enough to construct a model of SPFA.
While under special circumstances semiproperness may by preserved un-
der countable support iteration (see Lemma 34.5), in general this is not the
case. The reason is that a semiproper forcing notion may change the coï¬nal-
ity of ordinals from uncountable to countable. (An example of such forcing
is the Prikry forcing, see Exercise 37.7.)
The iteration applicable to semiproper forcings is the revised countable
support (RCS) iteration. Informally, a support of a condition is not just
a countable set, but even a name for a countable set.
Deï¬nition 37.3. Let Î± â‰¥1. A forcing notion PÎ± is an RCS (revised count-
able support) iteration of { Ë™QÎ² : Î² < Î±} if it is an iteration (cf. Deï¬ni-
tion 16.29) consisting of all Î±-sequences p that satisfy
(37.1)
for every q â‰¤p there exist a Î³ < Î± and an r â‰¤Î³ qâ†¾Î³ such that
r âŠ©Î³ cf Î± = Ï‰ or âˆ€Î² â‰¥Î³ pâ†¾[Î³, Î²) âŠ©PÎ³,Î² p(Î²) = 1.
In (37.1), q ranges over elements of the inverse limit of the Ë™QÎ², cf. (16.12),
and PÎ³,Î² is the restriction of the inverse limit to the interval [Î³, Î²) = {Î¾ : Î³ â‰¤
Î¾ < Î²}.
The main result on RCS iterations is that they preserve semiproperness:
Theorem 37.4 (Shelah). If PÎ± is an RCS iteration of { Ë™QÎ² : Î² < Î±} such
that every Ë™QÎ² is a semiproper forcing notion in V PÎ±â†¾Î² then PÎ± is semiproper.
Theorem 37.4 can be proved along the lines of the proof of Theorem 31.15.
We shall outline the proof of a special case of Theorem 37.4 (Proposition 37.8
below) which suï¬ƒces for the consistency proof of SPFA. (To be precise, Shelah
proved Theorem 37.4 for a more complicated deï¬nition of RCS iteration;
the current Deï¬nition 37.3 is based on simpliï¬cations by Schlindwein and
Donder).
A two-step iteration of semiproper forcings is semiproper, cf. Exer-
cise 37.8. The proof of Theorem 37.4 proceeds by induction, showing
(37.2)
for all Î³ < Î² â‰¤Î±, âŠ©Î³ BÎ² : BÎ³ is semiproper;
here BÎ² = B(PÎ²), and BÎ² : BÎ³ is the complete Boolean algebra in V PÎ³ such
that BÎ³ âˆ—(BÎ² : BÎ³) = BÎ² (see Exercise 16.4). One property of RCS that is
used in the proof is that BÎ² :BÎ³ is (in V PÎ³) an RCS iteration (Exercise 37.9).
The following three lemmas, special cases of Theorem 37.4, can be proved
in a similar way as Theorem 31.15:
Lemma 37.5. Let PÏ‰ be the inverse limit iteration of semiproper forcings
{ Ë™Qn : n < Ï‰}. Then PÏ‰ is semiproper.
âŠ“âŠ”

37. Martinâ€™s Maximum
683
Lemma 37.6. Let PÏ‰1 be a countable support iteration such that for all Î³ <
Î² < Î±, âŠ©Î³ BÎ² : BÎ³ is semiproper. Then PÏ‰1 is semiproper.
âŠ“âŠ”
Lemma 37.7. Let Î» be a regular uncountable cardinal. Assume that
(i) PÎ» is a direct limit,
(ii) for every Î± < Î» of coï¬nality Ï‰, PÎ± is the inverse limit,
(iii) for all Î³ < Î² < Î», âŠ©Î³ BÎ² : BÎ³ is semiproper,
(iv) PÎ» satisï¬es the Î»-chain condition.
Then PÎ» is semiproper.
âŠ“âŠ”
We shall now prove a version of Theorem 37.4 that will be used in the
consistency proof of MM:
Proposition 37.8. If PÎ± is an RCS iteration of semiproper forcings { Ë™QÎ² :
Î² < Î±} such that for every Î² < Î±, âŠ©Î²+1 |PÎ²| â‰¤â„µ1, then PÎ± is semiproper.
Proof. We proceed by induction, proving (37.2). As successor stages present
no problem, let Î± be a limit ordinal. By the induction hypothesis, for every
Î³ < Î² < Î±, âŠ©Î³ BÎ² : BÎ³ is semiproper; we shall prove that PÎ± is semiproper,
and (37.2) for Î± then follows by Exercise 37.8.
Case I. Let p âˆˆP and Î³ < Î± be such that pâ†¾Î³ âŠ©cf Î± = Ï‰. We will show
that Pâ†¾p is semiproper. In this case, pâ†¾Î³ forces that BÎ± : BÎ³ is the inverse
limit, and in fact, an inverse limit iteration of length Ï‰ of semiproper forcings,
hence semiproper by Lemma 37.5. It follows that Pâ†¾p is semiproper.
Case II. Let p âˆˆP be such that âˆ€Î³ < Î± pâ†¾Î³ âŠ©cf Î± > Ï‰, and let Î³ < Î± be
such that pâ†¾Î³ âŠ©cf Î± = Ï‰1. Again, we will show that Pâ†¾p is semiproper. In
this case, pâ†¾Î³ forces that BÎ± : BÎ³ is a direct limit iteration of length Ï‰1 of
semiproper forcings, and hence semiproper by Lemma 37.6. Therefore Pâ†¾p is
semiproper.
Case III. Let p âˆˆP be such that âˆ€Î³ < Î± pâ†¾Î³ âŠ©cf Î± > â„µ1; we will show that
in this case too, Pâ†¾p is semiproper. This will complete the proof that P is
semiproper.
Without loss of generality, assume that p = 1, and since PÎ± is in this case
a direct limit of the PÎ², it is a direct limit of the PÎ²i, i < cf Î± (where Î± =
limi<cf Î± Î²i), so we can assume that Î± is a regular cardinal. For every Î³ < Î±,
since âŠ©Î³+1 |PÎ³| â‰¤â„µ1 < cf Î±, we have |PÎ³| < Î±. Also since âŠ©Î³+1 cf Î± > â„µ1,
there is a stationary set of Î² < Î± (those for which âˆ€Î³ âŠ©Î³ cf Î² â‰¥â„µ1) at which
PÎ² is a direct limit. By Theorem 16.30, PÎ± satisï¬es the Î±-chain condition.
Therefore P is semiproper by Lemma 37.7.
âŠ“âŠ”

Part III. Selected Topics
Consistency of MM
Theorem 37.9 (Foreman, Magidor and Shelah). If there exists a su-
percompact cardinal then there is a generic model that satisï¬es MM.
Following the proof of Theorem 31.21, we construct a model that satis-
ï¬es SPFA. Instead of proper forcings, we iterated semiproper forcings, and
use the RCS iteration. At each stage Î± of the iteration, in addition to us-
ing the notion of forcing presented by the Laver function, we also collapse
(with countable conditions) the cardinal |PÎ±| to â„µ1. By Proposition 37.8,
such iteration is semiproper. An argument similar to the one in the proof of
Theorem 31.21 shows that the iteration up to a supercompact cardinal yields
a model in which SPFA holds.
The consistency of MM then follows from this result:
Theorem 37.10 (Shelah). SPFA implies that every stationary set preserv-
ing notion of forcing is semiproper. Therefore SPFA implies MM.
Proof. Let X be a set of countable elementary submodels of HÎ» = (HÎ», âˆˆ, <).

Applications of MM

it follows (by Theorem 31.23) that 2â„µ0 = 2â„µ1 = â„µ2. It turns out that from MM
one can prove much more, including the Singular Cardinal Hypothesis:

Reï¬‚ection Principles
An important consequence of MM are reï¬‚ection principles. These combina-
torial principles imply some major consequences of MM.

688
Part III. Selected Topics
Deï¬nition 37.17 (Reï¬‚ection Principle (RP)). For every regular Î» â‰¥â„µ2
the following holds:
RP(Î») If S is a stationary set in [Î»]Ï‰ then for every X âŠ‚Î» of cardinality â„µ1
there exists a Y âŠ‚Î» of cardinality â„µ1 such that X âŠ‚Y and that
S âˆ©[Y ]Ï‰ is stationary in [Y ]Ï‰.
RP follows from Martinâ€™s Maximum, see Theorems 37.21 and 37.23 below.
One consequence of RP is that every stationary set preserving notion of
forcing is semiproper (Exercise 37.13). This in turn implies that INS on Ï‰1
is precipitous (Foreman, Magidor and Shelah [1988], Theorem 26) and is
therefore a large cardinal property.
Theorem 37.18 (TodorË‡ceviÂ´c). RP(Ï‰2) implies that 2â„µ0 â‰¤â„µ2.
Proof. One can show that RP(Î») implies a stronger version of RP(Î»), namely
that S âˆ©[Y ]Ï‰ is stationary for stationary many Y âˆˆ[Î»]â„µ1 (Exercise 37.14).
If Ï‰1 â‰¤Î± < Ï‰2, let CÎ± be a closed unbounded subset of [Î±]Ï‰ of order-
type Ï‰1, and let D = 
Ï‰1â‰¤Î±<Ï‰2 CÎ±. Since |CÎ±| = â„µ1 for each Î±, we have
|D| = â„µ2. By RP(Ï‰2), D contains a closed unbounded set: Otherwise, if
S = [Ï‰2]Ï‰ âˆ’D is stationary, there exists an Î± â‰¥Ï‰1 such that S âˆ©[Î±]Ï‰ is
stationary, a contradiction.
By a theorem of Baumgartner and Taylor ([1982], Theorem 3.2(a)), every
closed unbounded subset of [Ï‰2]Ï‰ has size at least 2â„µ0. Therefore 2â„µ0 â‰¤â„µ2.
âŠ“âŠ”
RP(Ï‰2) is not very strong; its consistency follows from a weakly compact
cardinal (a modiï¬cation of Theorem 23.23).
Deï¬nition 37.19. A set S âŠ‚[Î»]Ï‰ is projective stationary if for every sta-
tionary set T âŠ‚Ï‰1, the set {X âˆˆS : X âˆ©Ï‰1 âˆˆT } is stationary.
(Equivalently, for every closed unbounded C âŠ‚[Î»]Ï‰, the projection
(S âˆ©C)â†¾Ï‰1 contains a closed unbounded set.)
Deï¬nition 37.20 (Strong Reï¬‚ection Principle SRP). For every regular
Î» â‰¥â„µ2, the following holds:
SRP(Î») If S is projective stationary in [HÎ»]Ï‰ then there exists an elementary
chain âŸ¨MÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©of countable models such that MÎ± âˆˆS for all Î±.

Theorem 37.23. For every regular Î» â‰¥Ï‰2, SRP(Î») implies RP(Î»).

(37.6)

contains an elementary chain âŸ¨MÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1âŸ©. It follows that MÎ± âˆˆS for

Part III. Selected Topics
Forcing Axioms
Martinâ€™s Maximum (as well as MA and PFA) are principles that postulate
the existence of suï¬ƒciently generic ï¬lter on every forcing notion of a given
kind. In general, let P be a class of forcing notions.
Deï¬nition 37.24 (MA(P)). If P is a forcing notion in P and if {DÎ± :
Î± < Ï‰1} are dense (or predense) subsets of P, then there exists a ï¬lter G
on P that meets all the DÎ±.
Thus MA(c.c.c.) is MAâ„µ1, MA(proper) is PFA and MA(semiproper) =
MA(stationary set preserving) is SPFA = MM. A useful strengthening of
a given forcing axiom is the following:
Deï¬nition 37.25 (MA+(P)). If P is a forcing notion in P, if {DÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1}
are dense (or predense) subsets of P and if Ë™S is a name of a subset of Ï‰1 such
that âŠ©Ë™S is stationary, then there exists a ï¬lter G on P that meets all the DÎ±,
and Ë™SG = {Î± : âˆƒp âˆˆG p âŠ©Î± âˆˆË™S} is stationary.
MM+ is stronger than MM; its consistency follows by a modiï¬cation
of the proof of Theorem 37.9. While MA+
â„µ1 is equivalent to MAâ„µ1 (Exer-
cise 37.22), MA+(P) is generally stronger than MA(P). A useful special case
is MA+(Ï‰-closed). Among others, it implies the Reï¬‚ection Principle RP and is
therefore a large cardinal axiom. Moreover, it implies (37.6) (Exercise 37.23)
and hence SCH. The following theorem shows that MA+(Ï‰-closed) follows
from MM:
Theorem 37.26 (Shelah). MM implies MA+(Ï‰-closed).
Proof. Assume MM and let P be Ï‰-closed, D a family of â„µ1 dense subsets
of P and Ë™S a P-name for a stationary set. Let {Ai : i âˆˆW} be a maximal
antichain of those stationary sets for which âŠ©P Ai âˆ©Ë™S is nonstationary.
By MM, |W| â‰¤â„µ1. Let A = 
iâˆˆW Ai be the diagonal union and let T =
Ï‰1 âˆ’A. We have âŠ©P Ë™S âˆ’T is nonstationary (hence T is stationary) and for
every stationary X âŠ‚T there exists some p âˆˆP such that p âŠ©Ë™S âˆ©X is
stationary.
Let Q be the countable support product of Ï‰1 copies of P; let QÎ± = P
and Ë™SÎ± = Ë™S. For every stationary X âŠ‚T and every q âˆˆQ there exist some

37. Martinâ€™s Maximum
691
While PFA is a large cardinal axiom and implies that 2â„µ0 = â„µ2 there
are weaker versions that do not need large cardinals, and are consistent with
c > â„µ2: For instance, there is a class P of proper forcings that includes,
among others, the forcings for adding Cohen reals, Sacks reals, Mathias reals
and Laver reals and MA(P) is consistent (relative to ZFC) with 2â„µ0 > â„µ2
(Groszek and Jech [1991]).
Finally, forcing axioms can be further modiï¬ed by restricting the size of
predense sets that the ï¬lter should meet. If only DÎ± of size â‰¤â„µ1 are involved,
these are known as bounded forcing axioms:
Deï¬nition 37.27 (Bounded MA(P)). If P is a forcing notion in P and if
{DÎ± : Î± < Ï‰1} are predense subsets of P such that |DÎ±| â‰¤â„µ1 for all Î±, then
there exists a ï¬lter G on P that meets all the DÎ±.
The consistency strength of Bounded PFA is below a Mahlo cardinal
(Goldstern and Shelah [1995]). An interesting equivalence for Bounded MM
was proved by Bagaria:
Theorem 37.28 (Bagaria [2000]). Bounded MM holds if and only if for
every stationary set preserving forcing notion P,
(HÏ‰2, âˆˆ) â‰ºÎ£1 (HÏ‰2, âˆˆ)V P .

Historical Notes
Martinâ€™s Maximum was formulated by Foreman, Magidor and Shelah [1988]. The
consistency proof (Theorem 37.9) as well as the major applications (Theorem 37.13,
Theorem 37.16 and Deï¬nition 37.17) are in that paper. The method of RCS iteration

694
Part III. Selected Topics
and Theorem 37.4 are due to Shelah and appear in [1982]. The (simpliï¬ed) deï¬nition
presented here follows Fuchs [1992] and Schlindwein [1993].
Theorem 37.10 was proved by Shelah in [1987].
TodorË‡ceviÂ´c proved (in unpublished notes) that RP implies 2â„µ0 â‰¤â„µ2; he also
formulated a strong reï¬‚ection principle (see Exercise 37.21) and used it to prove
Theorems 37.21, 37.22 and 37.23, as well as SCH. The present version of SRP (Def-
inition 37.20) is due to Feng and Jech [1998]; so is the equivalence in Exercise 37.21.
MA+(Ï‰-closed) and MM+ are discussed in Foreman, Magidor and Shelah [1988].
Theorem 37.26 was proved by Shelah in [1987].
Exercises 37.1, 37.12 and 37.23: Foreman, Magidor and Shelah [1988].
Exercise 37.3: Feng and Jech [1989].
Exercises 37.10 and 37.19: Feng and Jech [1998].
Exercises 37.18 and 37.20: TodorË‡ceviÂ´c.
Exercises 37.22: Baumgartner.

38. More on Stationary Sets
Stationary sets play a central role in several areas of set theory. In this ï¬nal
chapter we address some of the issues dealing with stationary sets.
The Nonstationary Ideal on â„µ1
The question of considerable interest is whether the ideal INS on â„µ1 can be
â„µ2-saturated. By Theorem 37.16, the saturation of INS follows from MM, and
thus is consistent relative to a supercompact cardinal. This can be improved:
Theorem 38.1 (Shelah). If there exists a Woodin cardinal then there is
a generic model in which the nonstationary ideal on â„µ1 is â„µ2-saturated.
Proof (sketch). The model is constructed by an RCS iteration (up to a
Woodin cardinal), as in the proof of Theorem 37.9, iterating the forcings
described in (37.5), for those maximal antichains for which the forcing (37.5)
is semiproper. An argument similar to the one used in the proof of Theo-
rem 34.8 shows that in the resulting model, INS is saturated.
âŠ“âŠ”
Combining this result with Steelâ€™s Theorem 35.21, it follows that the
consistency strength of the saturation of INS is approximately that of the
existence of a Woodin cardinal.
In contrast to that, the consistency strength of the precipitousness of INS
is only that of the existence of a measurable cardinal (Theorems 22.33
and 23.10).
A Ïƒ-complete ideal I on Ï‰1 is Ï‰1-dense if the Boolean algebra P(Ï‰1)/I
has a dense subset of size â„µ1. Clearly, every (nontrivial) Ï‰1-dense ideal is â„µ2-
saturated. The following result (that we state without proof) shows that the
consistency strength of â€œINS is Ï‰1-denseâ€ is exactly the existence of inï¬nitely
many Woodin cardinals.
Theorem 38.2 (Woodin). The following are equiconsistent:
(i) INS is Ï‰1-dense.
(ii) AD holds in L(R).
âŠ“âŠ”

696
Part III. Selected Topics
The saturation of the nonstationary ideal implies (almost) that the Con-
tinuum Hypothesis fails:
Theorem 38.3 (Woodin). If INS is â„µ2-saturated and if there exists a mea-
surable cardinal, then Î´1
2 = â„µ2 (and hence 2â„µ0 â‰¥â„µ2).
âŠ“âŠ”
Note that the construction in the proof of Theorem 34.8 yields a model
in which for some stationary set A, the ideal INSâ†¾A is â„µ2-saturated and the
Continuum Hypothesis holds.
Saturation and Precipitousness
By Theorem 23.17, the nonstationary ideal on Îº is not Îº+-saturated, for
any Îº â‰¥â„µ2. The proof of Theorem 23.17 yields a somewhat stronger result:
If Îº and Î» are regular cardinals such that Î»+ < Îº, then INSâ†¾EÎº
Î» is not
Îº+-saturated. Theorem 38.4 below shows that the saturation of INSâ†¾Reg is
consistent (and not particularly strong). It remains open whether for a regular
uncountable cardinal Îº, INSâ†¾EÎº+
Îº
can be Îº++-saturated.
Let Îº be a regular cardinal and let Î± < Îº+. The cardinal Îº is Î±-Mahlo
if the order of Îº (as deï¬ned in Chapter 8) is at least Îº + Î±. (Thus 0-Mahlo
means weakly inaccessible, 1-Mahlo means weakly Mahlo, etc.)
Theorem 38.4.
(i) Let Îº be an Î±-Mahlo cardinal, with 0 < Î± < Îº+. If INSâ†¾Reg is Îº+-
saturated then Îº is a measurable cardinal of Mitchell order at least Î±
in the model Km.
(ii) Let Îº be a measurable cardinal of Mitchell order Î±, with 0 < Î± < Îº+.
There is a generic model in which Îº is Î±-Mahlo and INSâ†¾Reg is Îº+-
saturated.
Proof. Cf. Jech and Woodin [1985]. For (i), see Exercise 38.1.
âŠ“âŠ”
By Theorem 23.10, the existence of a measurable cardinal is suï¬ƒcient for
the construction of a generic model in which the ideal INS on Ï‰1 is precipitous.
The construction generalizes to obtain the precipitousness of INSâ†¾EÎº+
Îº , for
every regular cardinal Îº. For the precipitousness of the entire ideal INS on
Îº â‰¥â„µ2, more than measurability is needed. For instance:
Theorem 38.5. The following are equiconsistent:
(i) INS on â„µ2 is precipitous.
(ii) There exists a measurable cardinal of Mitchell order 2.
Proof. Cf. Gitik [1984]. For the lower bound, see Exercise 38.2.
âŠ“âŠ”
The consistency strength of the precipitousness of INS on Îº â‰¥â„µ3 is more
than o(Îº) = Îº+. In [1997], Gitik calculated the exact strength for successors
or regulars, and nearly optimal lower and upper bounds for inaccessible Îº (in
both cases, it is the Mitchell order between Îº+ and Îº++). For successors of
singulars the consistency strength is in the region of Woodin cardinals.

38. More on Stationary Sets
697
Reï¬‚ection
Let Îº â‰¥â„µ2 be a regular cardinal. A stationary set S âŠ‚Îº reï¬‚ects at Î± < Îº if
S âˆ©Î± is stationary in Î± (see Deï¬nition 23.5). We shall now discuss brieï¬‚y to
what extent can stationary sets reï¬‚ect.
First we consider the property â€œevery stationary set S âŠ‚Îº reï¬‚ects (at
some Î± < Îº).â€ This implies that Îº is either (weakly) inaccessible or the
successor of a singular cardinal, because if Îº = Î»+ with Î» regular, the set EÎ»+
Î»
does not reï¬‚ect (see Exercise 23.4). Let Îº be an inaccessible cardinal. If Îº is
weakly compact then every stationary S âŠ‚Îº reï¬‚ects (Corollary 17.20). If
V = L then the converse is true as well: If every stationary set reï¬‚ects then
Îº is weakly compact (Jensen [1972], Theorem 6.1).
Following Mekler and Shelah [1989], let us call Îº a reï¬‚ecting cardinal if
there exists a normal ideal I on Îº such that for every X âˆˆI+, {Î± âˆˆÎº :
X reï¬‚ects at Î±} âˆˆI+. Every weakly compact cardinal is reï¬‚ecting, and since
being a reï¬‚ecting cardinal is a Î 1
1 property (see Exercise 38.3), every weakly
compact cardinal is a limit of reï¬‚ecting cardinals.
Theorem 38.6. The following are equiconsistent:
(i) There exists a cardinal Îº such that every stationary S âŠ‚Îº reï¬‚ects.
(ii) There exists a reï¬‚ecting cardinal.
Proof. Mekler and Shelah [1989].
âŠ“âŠ”
A cardinal Îº is greatly Mahlo if Îº is Î±-Mahlo for every Î± < Îº+. If V = L
then every reï¬‚ecting cardinal is greatly Mahlo and a limit of greatly Mahlo
cardinals (Mekler and Shelah [1989]). Thus the consistency strength of â€œevery
stationary set reï¬‚ectsâ€ is strictly between â€œgreatly Mahloâ€ and â€œweakly com-
pact.â€
Now let Îº be a successor of a singular cardinal Î». The property â€œevery
stationary set S âŠ‚Î»+ reï¬‚ectsâ€ is a very large cardinal property. On the one
hand there is this consistency result:
Theorem 38.7. If there exist inï¬nitely many supercompact cardinals, then
there is a generic model in which every stationary set S âŠ‚â„µÏ‰+1 reï¬‚ects.
Proof. Magidor [1982].
âŠ“âŠ”
On the other hand, â–¡Î» implies that there exists a stationary subset of Î»+
that does not reï¬‚ect (Exercise 38.5). As â–¡Î» holds in the core model Kstrong
then if (Î»+)Kstrong = Î»+, â–¡Î» holds in V as well (with the same square se-
quence) and one concludes (by Theorem 35.19) that if Î» is a strong limit
singular cardinal and every S âŠ‚Î» reï¬‚ects then there exists an inner model
for a strong cardinal. This has been extended by Schimmerling and others to
show that the consistency strength of this reï¬‚ection property is more than
the existence of a Woodin cardinal.

698
Part III. Selected Topics
Now consider the question of what is the largest possible extent of re-
ï¬‚ection. Let us recall (Deï¬nition 8.18) that S < T means that S reï¬‚ects at
almost all Î± âˆˆT . If S < T then o(S) < o(T ) and one may ask whether it is
possible that S < T holds whenever o(S) < o(T ). This is possible for Îº = â„µ2:
By Magidorâ€™s Theorem 23.23 it is consistent that every stationary S âŠ‚EÏ‰2
Ï‰
reï¬‚ects at almost all Î± of coï¬nality Ï‰1.
For Îº > â„µ2 it is impossible that S < T whenever o(S) < o(T ). If Âµ < Î» are
regular cardinals such that Î»+ < Îº then there exist stationary sets S âŠ‚EÎº
Âµ
and A âŠ‚EÎº
Î» such that S does not reï¬‚ect at any Î± âˆˆA (Exercise 38.7). Thus
let us restrict ourselves to reï¬‚ection at regular cardinals.
Deï¬nition 38.8. A weakly inaccessible cardinal Îº satisï¬es full reï¬‚ection if
for every stationary set S âŠ‚Îº and every stationary set T âŠ‚Îº of regular
cardinals, o(S) < o(T ) implies S < T .
Obviously, the property is meaningful only if Îº is at least a (weakly)
Mahlo cardinal. The consistency strength of full reï¬‚ection for cardinals in
the Mahlo hierarchy has been established by Jech and Shelah. For instance:
Theorem 38.9. The following are equiconsistent, for every n â‰¥1:
(i) There exists an n-Mahlo cardinal that satisï¬es full reï¬‚ection.
(ii) There exists a Î 1
n-indescribable cardinal.
Proof. Jech and Shelah [1993]. See also Exercises 38.8 and 38.9.
âŠ“âŠ”
If Îº is a large cardinal such as measurable, strong, or supercompact then
there is a generic extension in which Îº remains measurable (strong, super-
compact) and in addition satisï¬es full reï¬‚ection (Gitik and Witzany [1996]).
Stationary Sets in PÎº(Î»)
By Theorem 8.28, the closed unbounded ï¬lter on [Î»]Ï‰ is generated by the
sets CF = {x âˆˆ[Î»]Ï‰ : x is closed under F} where F : [Î»]<Ï‰ â†’Î». Thus
in many applications one considers the space [HÎ»]Ï‰ and stationary sets are
those S âŠ‚[HÎ»]Ï‰ such that for every model (HÎ», âˆˆ, . . .) there exists an M âˆˆS
with M â‰º(HÎ», âˆˆ, . . .).
When Îº > â„µ1, the sets CF do not generate the closed unbounded ï¬lter
on PÎº(Î») as the set {x âˆˆPÎº(Î») : |x| â‰¥â„µ1} is closed unbounded and does
not include any CF (which contains a countable set). A generalization of
Theorem 8.28 yields the following description of the closed unbounded ï¬lter:
it is the ï¬lter generated by the sets CF and the set {x âˆˆPÎº(Î») : x âˆ©Îº âˆˆÎº}
(Exercise 38.10; see also Exercises 8.18, 8.19 and 36.17). For more on this
subject, see Exercises 38.11 and 38.12.
By Lemma 31.3, Ï‰-closed forcing preserves stationary sets in [Î»]Ï‰. This
does not generalize to PÎº(Î») for Îº > â„µ1, as <Îº-closed forcing may destroy

38. More on Stationary Sets
699
stationary sets in PÎº(Î»). The following concept is relevant to this problem
and has other applications:
A model M â‰ºHÎ» is internally approachable if there exists an elemen-
tary chain âŸ¨MÎ± : Î± < Î³âŸ©with M = 
Î±<Î³ MÎ± such that for every Î² < Î³,
âŸ¨MÎ± : Î± < Î²âŸ©âˆˆM. In PÎº(HÎ»), let IA denote the set of all internally ap-
proachable M. The set IA is stationary, and if Îº = â„µ1 then IA contains
a closed unbounded set (since every countable M is internally approachable).
A stationary set S is preserved by <Îº-closed forcing if and only if S âˆ©IA is
stationary (Exercises 38.13 and 38.14).
By Theorem 8.10, every stationary subset of Îº can be partitioned into
Îº disjoint stationary sets. The situation is more complicated for PÎº(Î»). Since
|PÎº(Î»)| = Î»<Îº we may ask whether stationary sets in PÎº(Î») can be parti-
tioned into Î»<Îº disjoint stationary sets. This is generally not provable, for
two reasons. One is cardinal arithmetic and the other are large cardinals.
The cardinal arithmetic reason is that there may exist stationary, or even
closed unbounded, sets of size Î» while Î»<Îº > Î». For instance, there exists
a stationary set S âŠ‚[Ï‰2]Ï‰ of size â„µ2 (Exercise 38.15), or a closed unbounded
set C âŠ‚[Ï‰4]Ï‰2 of cardinality â„µâ„µ1
4
(Exercise 38.16).
A generalization of Solovayâ€™s proof of Theorem 8.10 gives that every sta-
tionary set in PÎº(Î») can be partitioned into Îº disjoint stationary sets (Ex-
ercise 38.18). This is best possible as Gitik [1985] constructs a model, using
a supercompact cardinal, in which there is a stationary set S âŠ‚PÎº(Îº+) that
cannot be partitioned into Îº+ disjoint stationary sets.
In view of this discussion, the following is best possible:
Theorem 38.10. Let Îº be regular uncountable and Î» â‰¥Îº.
(i) PÎº(Î») can be partitioned into Î» disjoint stationary sets.
(ii) If Îº is a successor cardinal then every stationary subset of PÎº(Î») can
be partitioned into Î» disjoint stationary sets.
(iii) If 0â™¯does not exist then every stationary subset of PÎº(Î») can be par-
titioned into Î» disjoint stationary sets.
(iv) If GCH holds then PÎº(Î») can be partitioned into Î»<Îº stationary sets,
and if moreover 0â™¯does not exist then every stationary subset of PÎº(Î»)
can be partitioned into Î»<Îº disjoint stationary sets.
Proof. Let us consider the following set
(38.1)

large cardinals; cf. the following lemma and Exercise 38.20.

Mutually Stationary Sets
The following deï¬nition, due to Foreman and Magidor, exploits the fact that
if Îº is a regular cardinal and Î» > Îº then a set S âŠ‚Îº is stationary if and
only if for every model A = âŸ¨HÎ», âˆˆ, . . .âŸ©there exists some M â‰ºA such that
sup(M âˆ©Îº) âˆˆS; i.e., if and only if the set {M âˆˆP(HÎ») : sup(M âˆ©Îº) âˆˆS}
is stationary in P(HÎ»).
Deï¬nition 38.15. Let A be a set of regular cardinals and let Î» = sup A.
The sets SÎº, Îº âˆˆA, where SÎº âŠ‚Îº for each Îº âˆˆA, are mutually stationary if
the set {M : sup(M âˆ©Îº) âˆˆSÎº for every Îº âˆˆM} is stationary in P(HÎ»).
Not much is known about mutual stationarity beyond the following the-
orem:
Theorem 38.16 (Foreman-Magidor). Let A be a set of regular cardi-
nals with Î» = sup A. If for each Îº, SÎº is a stationary subset of Îº such that
cf Î± = Ï‰ for every Î± âˆˆSÎº, then the SÎº are mutually stationary. For every
A = âŸ¨HÎ», âˆˆ, . . .âŸ©there exists a countable M â‰ºA such that sup(M âˆ©x) âˆˆSÎº
for every Îº âˆˆM.
Proof. Foreman and Magidor [2001].
âŠ“âŠ”
One consequence of this result is that the nonstationary ideal on [Î»]Ï‰ is
not Î»+-saturated when Î» is singular:

ary sets SÎ¾, Î¾ < Î»cf Î», in [Î»]Ï‰ such that SÎ¾ âˆ©SÎ· is nonstationary whenever
Î¾ Ì¸= Î·.

Weak Squares
The theory of inner models shows that in the absence of very large cardinals,
Jensenâ€™s principle â–¡Îº holds whenever Îº is a singular cardinal. In this last
section we take a look at some weaker versions of Square.
Deï¬nition 38.18. Let Îº be an uncountable cardinal, and let Î½ be a cardinal,
1 â‰¤Î½ â‰¤Îº; â–¡Îº,Î½ is as follows:
(â–¡Îº,Î½) There exists a sequence âŸ¨CÎ± : Î± âˆˆLim(Îº+)âŸ©such that
(i) CÎ± is nonempty and |CÎ±| â‰¤Î½, and each C âˆˆCÎ± is a closed
unbounded subset of Î±;
(ii) if C âˆˆCÎ± and Î² âˆˆLim(C) then C âˆ©Î² âˆˆCÎ²;
(iii) if cf Î± < Îº then |C| < Îº for every C âˆˆCÎ±.
(38.2)
The principle â–¡Îº,<Î½ is deï¬ned similarly, replacing |CÎ±| â‰¤Î½ by |CÎ±| < Î½.
The weakest principle of these, â–¡Îº,Îº, is also denoted by â–¡âˆ—
Îº and is called
Weak Square. By Jensen [1972], â–¡âˆ—
Îº is equivalent to the existence of a special
Aronszajn Îº+-tree, and therefore, if Îº is regular, â–¡âˆ—
Îº follows from 2Îº = Îº+.
The main interest in the principles â–¡Îº,Î½ and â–¡Îº,<Î½ is in the case when Îº is
a singular cardinal. The failure of â–¡âˆ—
Îº for Îº singular (which, as mentioned
below, entails a Woodin cardinal) is consistent: In [1979] Shelah proved the
consistency, relative to a supercompact cardinal, of the negation of â–¡âˆ—
â„µÏ‰.
The failure of Weak Square for singular Îº has the consistency strength
of (roughly) at least one Woodin cardinal: If there is a measurable cardinal
and there is no inner model for the Woodin cardinal, then â–¡Îº,cf Îº holds for
every strong limit singular cardinal. This follows from results of Mitchell,
Schimmerling and Steel; cf. Schimmerling [1995].
Exercise 38.5 shows that if â–¡Îº holds then Îº+ has a nonreï¬‚ecting sta-
tionary set. The proof is easily modiï¬ed to show that â–¡Îº,<Ï‰ suï¬ƒces, see
Exercise 38.23. (In contrast, â–¡â„µÏ‰,Ï‰ is consistent with â€œevery stationary sub-
set of â„µÏ‰+1 reï¬‚ects;â€ cf. Cummings, Foreman and Magidor [2001].)
The proof of Theorem 31.28 can be modiï¬ed to show that PFA implies
the negation of â–¡Îº,Ï‰1 for every Îº â‰¥Ï‰1; see Exercise 38.24. This, and the
afore mentioned results on â–¡Îº,cf Îº and Woodin cardinals yields Schimmer-
lingâ€™s Theorem 31.30.
As a ï¬nal application of weak squares we mention the following; for sim-
plicity, let Îº = â„µÏ‰. By the pcf theory there exists a scale âŸ¨fÎ± : Î± < â„µÏ‰+1âŸ©
in 
nâˆˆA â„µn (mod ï¬nite) for some A âŠ‚Ï‰. If â–¡â„µÏ‰,â„µm holds for some m, then
there exists a scale âŸ¨gÎ± : Î± < â„µÏ‰+1âŸ©with this property:
(38.3)
For every Î± < â„µÏ‰+1 such that cf Î± > Ï‰ there exists a closed un-

n â‰¥k in A, gÎ²(n) < gÎ³(n).
(See Exercise 38.25.) Such scales were used in Cummings, Foreman and Magi-

Historical Notes
The ï¬rst consistency proof for the saturation of INS was obtained by Steel and
van Wesep [1982], forcing over a model of ZF + ADR + â€œÎ˜ is regularâ€ (ADR is
the determinacy of games where moves are real numbers). Following the proof of
Theorem 37.16 (by Foreman, Magidor and Shelah), Shelah obtained the consistency
from the existence of a Woodin cardinal (Theorem 38.1).
Theorem 38.2 will appear in the forthcoming book on AD, cf. Woodin et al. [âˆ].
Theorem 38.3 is proved in Woodin [1999].
Theorem 38.4: Jech and Woodin [1985].
Theorem 38.5: Gitik [1984].
Theorem 38.6: Mekler and Shelah [1989].
Theorem 38.9: Jech and Shelah [1993].
Theorem 38.10 is a combination of several results, including Jech [1972/73],
Matsubara [1987], [1988] and [1990], Di Prisco and Baumgartner.
Lemma 38.11: Baumgartner.
Lemma 38.12: Di Prisco.
Lemma 38.13: Matsubara.
Theorem 38.14 is a combination of several results, including Gitik and She-
lah [1997], Baumgartner and Taylor [1982], Donder and Matet [1993], Burke and
Matsubara [1999] and Foreman and Magidor [2001].
Mutually stationary sets are investigated in Foreman and Magidor [2001].
For weak squares, see Schimmerling [1995] and Cummings, Foreman and Magi-
dor [2001].
Exercises 38.3 and 38.4: Mekler and Shelah [1989].
Exercises 38.5: Jensen.
Exercises 38.6 and 38.22: Solovay.
Exercises 38.7: Shelah.
Exercises 38.8 and 38.9: Jech and Shelah [1993].
Exercises 38.10: Kueker.
Exercises 38.11, 38.12, 38.13 and 38.14: Foreman, Magidor and Shelah [1988].
Exercises 38.15, 38.16, 38.19 and 38.20: Baumgartner.
Exercises 38.24: Magidor.
Exercises 38.25: Cummings, Foreman and Magidor [2001].

SpringerMonographs inMathematics
This series publishes advanced monographs giving well-written presentations of the â€œstate-of-the-artâ€
in ï¬elds of mathematical research that have acquired the maturity needed for such a treatment. They
are sufï¬ciently self-contained to be accessible to more than just the intimate specialists of the subject,
and sufï¬ciently comprehensive to remain valuable references for many years. Besides the current state
of knowledge in its ï¬eld, an SMM volume should also describe its relevance to and interaction with
neighbouring ï¬elds of mathematics, and give pointers to future directions of research.
